It was after 2 a.m. when I decided to take a break from my work and walk to the corner to clear my head and smoke a cigarette. I mentioned Edmond Dantes, asking if she'd read the novel, and she gave me a look so long and so silent that I feared our conversation would end right there. title: Style; Macho Mann
description: Although he strenuously resists the notion, Michael Mann, the creative force behind ''Miami Vice'' and the director of, among other films, ''Thief,'' ''Heat'' and now ''Collateral,'' has, through his work, through his sense of style melded with character, created the dominant male aesthetic of the last 20 years. From the glowing pastels, sockless loafers and stubble of ''Miami Vice'' to Tom Cruise's gray hair in ''Collateral,'' Mann has evoked a revolutionary kind of cool. He has a precise instinct for how his men want to dress and live, and that sensibility, that particular code of tough guys who know how to wear a suit, pick a perfect bottle of wine and shoot a gun, has shaped a generation. Mann is prickly about this idea -- he doesn't want his work reduced to shoes and architecture. ''What it looks like is important to me,'' he says, barely eating his lunch of Japanese soup at his office in West L.A. ''But I've worked too hard to just be known as an arbiter of taste.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAGE, PER
description: HAGE--Per. 1935--2004. Born October 9, 1935; his brilliant mind closed in the morning hours of July 25, 2004 after a valiant fight with a long illness which he endured with characteristic stoicism and grace. Per joined the faculty of the Department of Anthropology at the University of Utah in 1971 and remained there, with brief interruptions as Visiting Scholar at the University of Copenhagen and Cambridge University (Robinson College). Per was a social anthropologist initially interested in cognition, but whose restless mind soon wandered to the classic topics of social structure and kinship. He pioneered the use of graph theoretical models in anthropology to greatly enhance our knowledge of the human mind, human society and human history, especially in his beloved Polynesia. The three books he wrote (co-authored with Frank Harary), Island Networks, Exchange in Oceania, and Structural Models in Anthropology, have been the cornerstones of a new appreciation of kinship in all of social science. Always generous with his time for students and colleagues alike, he was most often found in his office quietly reading in one of a number of languages in which he was fluent or writing another article or book. He received accolades from the most prestigious scholars from around the world and was treasured by his colleagues as a man of high integrity who demanded high standards of all, but first and foremost of himself. Of the old school, he was a true gentleman and a scholar.

But in Italy, Ducasse is not a household word, and no particular fanfare greeted the partial opening last May of L'Andana, his first Italian operation, with two Italian partners. Consumed by curiosity, my companion, Franco, and I spent a weekend (anonymously) at the hotel-resort in Tuscany, a few miles from the Tyrrhenian Sea, in its fifth week of life.

A gaggle of onlookers, gathered behind a barrier on a nearby cliff, hooted and whistled, although at least one of them seemed more impressed by Ms. Jensen's outfit than by her spectacular ride. ''There's something about a girl in a wet suit,'' said Stephen Marks, a dentistry student from Sacramento. ''I may have to take up surfing.''

The regular price is $19,500 to $21,000 for the entire barge. title: 'The Irresponsible Self'
description: The famous windmills Don Quixote mistakes for giants have something in common with the madeleine that makes Marcel's memory-buds salivate: they both occur conveniently early in very long books that are, in English at least, more praised than read. And Cervantes may resemble Proust in one further dimension. Both are comic writers, properly snagged in the mundane, whose fiction has too often been etherealized out of existence. Miguel de Unamuno, the relentlessly idealizing Spanish philosopher, considered Don Quixote a "profoundly Christian epic" and the true Spanish bible, and correspondingly managed to write about the novel as if not a single comic episode occurs in it. W. H. Auden thought that Don Quixote was a portrait of a Christian saint; and Unamuno's unlikely American supporter, Harold Bloom, reminds us that although " Don Quixote may not be a scripture," it nonetheless contains us all as Shakespeare does-which sounds more like religious lament than secular caution.

title: Correction

title: Can This Man Save the Sitcom?

Just a few nights later, the show took top honors from the Television Critics Association for best new program and best comedy. ''It's been a crazy period of approbation,'' said Mitchell Hurwitz, the show's creator and one of its executive producers, last week in his office on the Fox lot. ''Before you know it, I'll be caught smuggling mushrooms through security at Burbank Airport,'' he joked, referring to the infamous drug bust that befell the Emmy-winning writer Aaron Sorkin, creator of ''The West Wing,'' several years ago.

title: 'Eating Crow'
description: Iam sorry you bought this book. If it was given to you as a gift, then technically I am not required - or even entitled - to apologize to you. My apology should go to the original purchaser and they, in turn, should say sorry. To be honest, though, I can't be bothered with any of those rigid laws and rules anymore. I can see they are needed for diplomatic exchanges, and as a onetime exponent of the art of the international apology - the leading exponent, I suppose - I was constantly grateful that the Professor had gone to the bother of formulating all the laws in the first place. But they have their time and their place and this isn't one of them.

In the days before Calvin Klein came along to seduce men into becoming unwitting consumers of personal lingerie, there was little reason to think about stuff like microfibers or combed pima cotton, forget skivvies engineered along the lines of the push-up bra.

title: Feathers, Fur and Jungle Waters
description: PARAKEETS flew at us in the blind like a hail of emerald bullets, and we ducked. When the barrage of birds stopped, Rodrigo rushed outside, scanned the forest and pointed up at a large, white hawk that had just settled on a branch above us. It had scared off 70 or more parakeets that had been feasting on minerals at the clay lick opposite the blind. The hawk swiveled its head calmly from side to side deciding which of three stragglers rustling in the bushes would be its next meal. Rodrigo broke into a boyish smile. A bodyguard for an Ecuadorean oil company executive, he was trained to spot more serious problems, and this rare raptor was a nice change.

That makes this an awkward time for the International Olympic Committee to decide, as it did in May, that transsexuals may compete openly in the Games. None are expected to participate this time, but the decision raises difficult questions about the nature of sports achievement.

Or of Ed Hutchins's ''Words for the World,'' whose pages are colored pencils bearing messages in different languages and whose cover is the metal tin in which they lie?

title: STATE BUDGET TROUBLE
description: The State Supreme Court ruled on Monday that beginning next year, the state cannot borrow money to balance the budget as it did this year. By allowing Governor McGreevey to proceed with $1.9 billion in borrowing for operating expenses in the current fiscal year, which began July 1, the court averted a scramble for revenue to replace it. The borrowed money accounts for nearly 7 percent of the $28 billion budget. Within days of the ruling, three credit-rating agencies, Fitch Ratings, Standard & Poor's and Moody's, lowered their ratings of New Jersey bonds. Standard & Poor's and Fitch said that this year's budget reflected a continuing failure of fiscal discipline and that the budget would be even harder to balance next year, when the state cannot resort to borrowing.

title: Mr. Maxwell and Me

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Rilke on Rodin
description: In 1902, an obscure young poet named Rainer Maria Rilke arrived on the Paris doorstep of Auguste Rodin, armed with an assignment to write a monograph on the French sculptor. At the time, Rilke, fastidious and recently married, was equipped with only halting French; Rodin, unable to read Rilke's lyrical German, was an imperious 62, his creative drive matched only by his skill at seducing the women who posed nude for him. Combining Daniel Slager's elegant translation from the German of Rilke's writings on Rodin with Michael Eastman's photographs of Rodin's sculptures, AUGUSTE RODIN (Archipelago, $30) offers a fresh look at an unlikely mentorship. Adopting the rapturous tone of a new disciple, Rilke finds in Rodin's sculpture much of his own ideal of the solitary genius -- ''sheltered behind the efforts that sustained him'' and ''filled with the animating burden of his vast knowledge.'' But he may be closer to the mark, as the evocative photographs suggest, in portraying Rodin as a keen student of the flesh. In such works as ''The Caryatid'' and ''The Kiss,'' Rilke observes, ''faces were extinguished and bodies came into their own,'' an achievement that transformed the movement of limbs into ''strange documents of the momentary.'' Hugh Eakin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINMAN, BORIS
description: FEINMAN--Boris. Longtime New Rochellean and civil activist, died peacefully at home in Lantana, FL on July 22, 2004. Born 1916 in Riga, Latvia. Emigrated 1920. Graduated NYU 1937, Electrical Engineering. Worked for General Electric, on the team responsible for the railroad engine featured in ''Union Pacific''. September 1941 volunteered for the Signal Corps. As Captain with the elite ETG, developed radar alongside the RAF. Boris dedicated his life to teaching youth to take pride in this country and to participate in their government. He developed educational programs focused on civics and the freedoms that the Constitution affords us. During the 60's in New Rochelle, he mounted the first ''Builders of America'' exhibit, displayed in City Hall celebrating African American contributions to America. He created innovative programs to keep troubled kids off the streets by giving them the responsiblity to run their own businesses. In the 70's, to celebrate the Constitution, he founded Convention II, a national program for high school students to debate proposed amendments on the floor of the House. His ''Builders of America'' exhibit of Jewish contributions to America from Columbus to Ellis Island is on permanent exhibit at West Point, and tours nationally including the Cannon Rotunda, House of Representatives. Boris had a unique ability to impact people of all ages and circumstances. Unselfish, and generous, the goodness he shared with his family, friends and the nation will be sorely missed. This country has lost a true leader. Survived by his wife Grace, children Peter, Patti and Debi; brother Alfred, nephews Robert, Martin and Andrew and their children Zarina, Joel, Sacha, Nicholas, and Reuben; niece Ellen and nephew Marc. Donations to IHARE (memo: Boris Feinman Civics Education Fund) POBox 41 Purchase,NY 10577.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EHRSAM, THEODORE GEORGE, PH.D.
description: EHRSAM--Theodore George, Ph.D. An accomplished author and Professor Emeritus of English at New York University, died of natural causes on July 30, 2004 at Hackensack Medical Center in Hackensack, NJ at the age of 94. Theodore George Ehrsam was born December 7, 1909 in New York, NY. He received his bachelor's degree from Lehigh University in 1931 and his master's degree in 1932. Prior to receiving his Ph.D. from New York University in 1948, Theodore taught as an instructor of English at Lehigh University, Hofstra College, and New York University. His tenure at NYU as Professor of English spanned 31 years. Dr. Ehrsam was the author of ''Major Byron,'' 1951, co-author of ''The Shelley Legend,'' 1945, and compiled the Bibliography of Joseph Conrad, 1969. In addition, Dr. Ehrsam was the Editor of the Handbook of Alpha Kappa Psi, 1993. Dr. Ehrsam was the President of the Board of Trustees for the River Vale Public Library from 1991-2003. He served as an honorary Commodore of the Lake Hopatcong Yacht Club since 1991. Dr. Ehrsam was a member of the Modern Language Association (MLA), the Thoreau Society, and the Lake Hopatcong Historical Society. He received the Distinguished Service Award from Alpha Kappa Psi in 1993. Dr. Ehrsam is survived by Marcia, his wife of 28 years, his daughter, Jean Sammons, from his first marriage to Wanda Budd (deceased 1975), and his daughters, Jaye Meyers and Susan Kaplan. His infectious love of life will live on through his family, particularly his six grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Service at Becker Funeral Home, 219 Kinderkamack Road, Westwood, NJ on Monday at 11:30 am. The family will receive their friends on Monday from 9-11 am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial contributions be made to the River Vale Public Library at 412 Rivervale Road, River Vale, NJ 07675.

title: TUITION CLIMBS
description: Tuition for the coming school year will climb 4.8 percent to 10.8 percent at New Jersey's four-year colleges and universities, according to a survey by The Star-Ledger. The rates are less steep than those of recent years, the newspaper said in a report on Monday, because of an improving economy and an 8 percent cap on tuition increases at public colleges imposed by the new state budget. In the state, this year's annual tuition costs will range from $4,665 at some public colleges to nearly $30,000 at private institutions. Jessica Bruder

The accountant who calculated my 2001 taxes confirmed that the I.R.S. was correct; he had overlooked some income on which taxes were due. While I know there is no legal recourse when an accountant fails to complete a tax return accurately, should he have offered to pay any of the accrued interest? Bruce Benson, Morris Plains, N.J.

title: PRISON DIARY, PART I: HELL
description: WHEN the London tabloid The Daily Star claimed that Jeffrey Archer, the Tory politician and best-selling novelist, had slept with a prostitute and paid her to keep quiet about it, he made what turned out to be a big mistake: he decided to fight back. He sued the paper for libel and was awarded $800,000 in 1987; but he had fabricated an alibi to win the case, partly by concocting false diaries, and that would come back to haunt him. In 2001, he was convicted of perjury and perverting the course of justice in the earlier trial, and sent to jail for four years.

description: OUTSIDE the State Hermitage Museum on June 22, the paparazzi were waiting in the wet summer chill, along with black-windowed limousines, bodyguards bearing visible weapons and several hundred spectators elbowing for umbrella room. Inside, 12 camera crews ignored officials from the Russian government and the Guggenheim and Hermitage museums to focus on the prodigal art couple at the center of the spectacle, Ilya and Emilia Kabakov. ''It's an affair of state,'' said Robert Storr, a professor at New York University's Institute of Fine Arts. ''I've never seen anything like this.''

title: COUNCIL SETS RECORD ON GRANTS
description: Just a year after being scheduled for extinction, the State Council on the Arts announced a record $22.7 million in grants last week for more than 700 groups and individuals. The big winners were the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, which will receive $1.76 million; the Performing Arts Center, $1.65 million; the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, $1.14 million; and McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, $825,000. Fourteen folk artist apprentice grants were awarded to people whose talents range from decoy carving to Chinese knotting. Last year, financing was eliminated for the arts council until a lobbying effort managed to restore $16 million. This year, part of a new state fee on overnight hotel and motel rooms is going toward arts spending. Jill P. Capuzzo

title: Poor Countries, Rich Resources
description: The World Bank has helped finance exploitation of oil, gas, coal and other minerals in the developing world, mainly through its private sector lending arm, even though this has rarely advanced the institution's mission of reducing poverty. Indeed, it often makes poverty worse.

title: Blackboard: Campus Politics; How to Separate a Boy From His Beer Change
description: COLLEGE students are more likely to spend extra change on pizza and beer than on a political cause. That's what Ben Brandzel figured when he started looking for ways to motivate students to contribute to a liberal-minded voter fund earlier this year. Mr. Brandzel, a recent Brandeis graduate, skipped the traditional cup-rattling approach and set up ClickbackAmerica.org. The Web site asks students to register voters, sign petitions or take other action on hot-button issues, like e-mailing Rush Limbaugh to protest his comparing abuses at Abu Ghraib prison to a fraternity prank.

title: A Strong Quarter For Westchester
description: The median sale price of a single-family house in Westchester County soared to an all-time high of $660,000 in the second quarter -- the first time it ever exceeded $600,000 -- according to the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service. The price represents an increase of nearly 16 percent over the county's median for the second quarter last year.

title: College Prep: Ask the Expert; Early Decision II
description: CAN college admissions procedures get any more complicated? A relatively new program, early decision II, is gaining ground. Vanderbilt University, for one, uses an early decision II plan in addition to early decision I and regular admissions. William Shain, dean of undergraduate admissions, explains how it works. VICTORIA GOLDMAN

title: Jimmy Buffett Allows Himself to Be Upstaged
description: 'POR VIDA' -- The songs of the Texas songwriter Alejandro Escovedo stare down death and loss with a handful of chords, stoic despair and barely a glimmer of self-pity. ''Por Vida'' (''Or Music'') is a two-CD tribute album and a fund-raiser for Mr. Escovedo, who has hepatitis C and is unable to tour. It gathers luminaries of alt-country and roots-rock, among them Lucinda Williams, Steve Earle, Calexico, Howe Gelb, the Cowboy Junkies, Charlie Sexton, Son Volt and Jon Langford and Sally Timms of the Mekons; Mr. Escovedo himself has the finale, singing ''I just might break this time'' over a swaggering two-chord vamp. And nearly everyone involved does justice to his rock-ribbed songs, with their mixture of dark revelation and down-home twang.

title: The Art of Resilience
description: THE positive psychology curriculum developed for Strath Haven High School in Pennsylvania seeks to teach adolescents how to overcome negative events. While part of the program involves academics, much of it deals with cognitive behavioral techniques modified for the classroom. The ''ABC model'' (for the interplay between adversity, beliefs and consequences) aims to help students assess a problem and their role in it, and gain control of their environment and emotions -- keys to preventing depression. The model is detailed in ''The Resilience Factor'' by two psychologists at the University of Pennsylvania, Karen Reivich and Andrew Shatt.

Although the shop offers plenty of rhinestone-studded collars, plaid dog beds and requisite groaner puns (the pawtisserie features an array of gour-mutt treats), it is the events at Scout that really get tails wagging.

description: LYLES--James B., Jr. Died Saturday, July 25, 2004 from a heart attack in St. Vincent Hospital in Manhattan at the age of 81. James was a loving husband to his wife of 40 years, the late Enid G. Lyles and a caring father whose attention and endless gift of his previous, little, free time will never be forgotten. He was a compassionate and caring man evident by his choice of service during WWII as a Field Medic who landed on Normandy on D Day, and later during his 25 year career, as a social worker for the city of New York. James is survived by his son Philip who will miss him terribly.

Today, access to music means finding a path through the maze of digital music options while dodging lawsuits for illegal file sharing. The Recording Industry Association of America has so far sued more than 3,000 people, many of them students, for stealing music from unauthorized networks like Kazaa.

title: LIVING IN/Ringwood, N.J.; An Oasis Within Commuting Distance
description: THE borough of Ringwood stands out in densely populated northern New Jersey as an oasis of water, rocky outcrops and hardwood-forested ridges, laced with hiking and biking trails and winding, undulating roads. Situated in the foothills of the Ramapo Mountains, just south of the New York border, the borough has no streetlamps, sidewalks or traffic lights, and is 70 percent open space -- public parkland, lakes and reservoirs.

title: Food; Cold Fusion
description: A few years back, I spent a couple of weeks in Oaxaca, Mexico. It was, of course, an eating holiday, but to ease the languors between breakfast on the zcalo and lunch at wherever, I arranged French conversation lessons with a likable chap named Herv. His existence in the town was pure Magic Realism, predicated on the notion that eating Oaxacan chapulines -- fried grasshoppers -- has the same mystical someday-you-will-return effect as a coin tossed over the shoulder into the Trevi Fountain. On a youthful dare, a visiting Herv had downed a cricket or two a couple of blocks from the zcalo in Benito Jurez Market; when I met him years later, he was living in Oaxaca, still blinking with surprise, giving French classes to pass the time.

At Kapps Bar & Grill, a dim, smoky tavern seemingly yanked off a sitcom and deposited among the dollar stores lining Broadway, the food was never meant to be the draw -- fraternizing among the original owners' New Jersey Institute of Technology Pi Kappa Phi brothers was. Try telling that to regulars, though -- like the new mother who says that Kapps' hot wings ($6.75) got her through her pregnancy -- and you are apt to be met with blank stares.

title: Things You Do Only in College

Today's traditions are more likely to involve nudity, fire and intoxicants and be closely monitored by publicity-wary administrators. Some rituals have been abolished because of safety concerns or underage drinking. Recent casualties include spring couch burning at the University of Vermont and Princeton's Nude Winter Olympics. In one of the higher-profile incidents, the death of 12 people by collapsing logs in 1999 brought to an end the tradition of Texas A&M's bonfire on the eve of the annual football game against the University of Texas (the bonfire has since been revived off campus). But other traditions are going strong, sanctioned or not. Like their zanier predecessors, they are a long-remembered part of the college experience -- if occasionally rowdy, childish, illegal or all three.

Educated at Smith College, she completed her doctoral studies with distinction at the University of Pennsylvania. She devoted her life to the betterment of children's lives, first as a commited educator, then as founder of Chris' Corner, a bookstore for kids and teens, and recipient of the ''Best of Philly'' Award. She helped thousands of children to love to read as she did. She taught integrity, courage and strength by example, and her kindness and generosity will be remembered by countless friends, family members and children of her community. Friends will be received at Logan Funeral Home, 2410 Lombard St, Philadelphia, Monday, 6-8 pm, and Tuesday, 9-11 am, and in New York at Fairchild, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, Wednesday, 3-5 and 7-9 pm. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEE, AMY FREEMAN
description: LEE--Amy Freeman. Beloved artist, teacher and humanitarian, passed away peacefully in the company of loving friends in San Antonio, Texas on July 20, 2004. She was 89. Dr. Lee's profound reverence for life was the guiding principle in her distinguished career as artist, educator and humanitarian. It was also the primary theme of literally thousands of lectures she delivered to audiences nationwide throughout her life. She served as President of the Board of Incarnate Word College (now University) in San Antonio from 1973-1990, and was Chairman of the Board of the Houstonbased Wilhelm Schole International from 1976-2004. An internationally acclaimed artist, she had more than 1,250 exhibitions of her work. She was a founder of the San Antonio Symphony, San Antonio Art League and the Texas Watercolor Society, and a charter member of the University of Texas Fine Arts Council. Dr. Lee was a champion of literacy and libraries, serving as chairman of the Young Pegasus Poetry competition for 60 years. She was a lifelong leader of the Humane Society of the United States, and received its Joseph Wood Krutch Medal. She was also honored with the Wilhelm Schole International Imperishable Star Award and the American Civil Liberties Union Maury Maverick Award, in addition to many other awards and acknowledgements. In 1985, Lee was the subject of ''Reality is Becoming,'' an inspirational CBS documentary on her life and accomplishments. She is survived by her foster daughter Marilyn Wilhelm, her goddaughter Carol Karotkin and many loving friends. A memorial service in celebration of Dr. Lee's remarkable life and gifts will be held at 4 p.m. on Thursday, August 5, at the Marguerite B. Parker Chapel at Trinity University, San Antonio, Texas. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Wilhelm Schole International, 3711 San Felipe Road, #

title: Mutiny in the House
description: After a stretch of bad news for the millions of Americans trying to find decent affordable housing, there are finally signs of progress. First, lawmakers rejected the Bush administration's attempt to shortchange Section 8, the housing subsidy program for the poor. Now, there is a procedural mutiny against Republican leaders in the House who have kept a bill that addresses the housing crisis bottled up in committee -- even though it has more than 200 co-sponsors. That could conceivably force the measure to the floor for a debate and vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANE, CAROL FEIT, PH.D.
description: LANE--Carol Feit, Ph.D. 70, died on August 1, of breast cancer at the NYU Medical Center. We depely mourn her loss. She is the beloved daughter of Belle Harmon, sister of James A. Harmon, wife of Frederick M. Lane, mother of Wendy and Laurie, loving Nana of Rachel and Brad, Grandma Carol to Joshua, Jacob and Eleanor, beloved stepmother to Elliot, Roberta and Carol. Always a champion of women's causes, she devoted her efforts to promote the development of women at midlife. She founded and was President of The Career Development Specialists' Network (CDSN), a professional group of over 100 members. She had worked at Barnard College, at the Women's Wellness Center at NYU Medical Center, and served on Women's O.W.N., promoting women's health. She was a revered teacher of memoir writing at the senior center at the 92nd Street Y. A sculptor, dancer, essayist, and poet, she loved life and imparted her love and vitality to all who knew her. Funeral services at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave and 81st St, on Tuesday, August 3, 1:30 pm. Interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. She was a sunbeam, lighting all our lives. Any memorial donations to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CORBETTA, LOUIS J. (JERRY)
description: CORBETTA--Louis J. (Jerry). Of Norwalk, CT (formerly of Scarsdale, NY), died on July 30, 2004, at the age of 80. Mr. Corbetta was President of Corbetta Construction Company, a firm founded by his father and uncle in 1922. During his career, he was involved as the concrete constructor and general contractor of many projects in 20 states, Spain and Puerto Rico. Some of the projects included the Dulles Airport Terminal Building, Tappan Zee Bridge, the Union Carbide Headquarters in Danbury, CT, and both the New York State Theater and Fordham University in Lincoln Center. Before his retirement, he was active in many building organizations in the New York Metropolitan area. He attended Cornell University and Louisiana State University before serving in the US Army Corps of Engineers in WWII. He was a member of the Westchester Country Club for over 50 years and enjoyed golf, the seashore and spending time with his family. He is survived by his wife Evelyn Danks Corbetta and his five children, Robert Corbetta, Jane Yezzi, Maryann Cousins, Richard Corbetta and Allison Radin. He is also survived by eight grandchildren and two sisters, Vee Landolfe and Caryl Schiess. Calling hours are Tuesday, August 3, from 2-4 pm and 7-9 pm, at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Pius X Church, 91 Secor Road, Scarsdale, NY, on Wednesday, August 4, at 11 am. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to Person-to-Person Campership Program, 1864 Post Road, Darien, CT 06820.

title: Last Chance for Inclusion in Iraq
description: Steering Iraq away from civil war and toward a workable new constitution is far more important than holding to an arbitrarily chosen date on the transition calendar. That is why it was right for Iraqi authorities to delay, for at least a couple of weeks, a potentially crucial national conference originally scheduled for this past weekend. The specific function of the conference is to choose a national council to oversee the current, narrowly based interim government. But its real importance is the opportunity it offers to attract dangerously alienated Sunni and Shiite factions into peaceful political bargaining.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVER, JOSEPH W., M.D.
description: SILVER--Joseph W., M.D. The board of trustees, medical staff, administration and employees of New York Methodist Hospital deeply mourn the passing of our respected friend and colleague, Joseph W. Silver, M.D. Dr. Silver was affiliated with New York Methodist Hospital for 40 years and had served as chief of orthopedic surgery at the Hospital for the past 20 years. His dedication and service to New York Methodist were honored when he received the 2004 Physician Service Award at the Hospital's annual dinner dance last May. Known as an outstanding technical and clinical surgeon, Dr. Silver was much loved and greatly esteemed by his patients as well as his colleagues. He was also an excellent teacher. He was associate clinical professor of orthopedic surgery at the SUNY/Downstate College of Medicine and professor of surgery at Saint George's University School of Medicine. He authored or co-authored articles in numerous peer-reviewed journals and was active in many professional societies. At various times, he served as president, vice president, secretary and treasurer of the Brooklyn Orthopaedic Society. We will greatly miss this outstanding and compassionate gentleman and we send our deepest sympathies to Dr. Silver's family, especially his wife, Madeline, his children, Lauren and Marc, and his three grandchildren.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Synopsys Income Is Below Forecasts
description: Synopsys Inc., a maker of computer software, said yesterday that third-quarter net income and sales were below its forecasts because of lower-than-expected bookings. In a preliminary release of results for the three months ended July 31, the company said net income was 15 cents to 19 cents a share, below its forecast of 20 cents to 25 cents. Sales fell to $279 million to $283 million, below a forecast of $300 million to $320 million. Synopsys said its book-to-bill ratio was 0.7 to 1, compared with an expected 1-to-1 ratio. A ratio of 1 or more implies that orders are expanding. Synopsys, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., scrapped a plan in April to acquire Monolithic System Technology Inc. and paid Monolithic a $10 million breakup fee after the developer of semiconductor technology sued. Third-quarter profit excluding some items was 31 cents to 34 cents a share, the company said. Shares of Synopsys fell $4.20, or 16.7 percent, to $21.05.

Another attempt by airlines to impose small fare increases to offset high fuel costs collapsed yesterday after AMR's American Airlines retreated from a $10 price increase on round-trip fares that it announced on Thursday. Competitors also dropped their fare increases. title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo To Start New Business Directory
description: Yahoo is taking its war with Google and Microsoft house to house, or more precisely shop to shop. The big Internet portal will start a public test today of a new service to help users find stores and other resources in a specific neighborhood. The new service is meant to replace Yahoo's existing online Yellow Pages listings with a broader directory that combines information from traditional Yellow Pages directories with the results of searches of the Web and other databases. The site can be seen at beta.local.yahoo.com. In addition, Yahoo will allow users to post ratings and reviews of businesses. For now, Yahoo is giving up some advertising revenue it had earned from its previous Yellow Pages service, on which some businesses paid to appear first on a list of results. The new local service ranks results based on how well they fit a user's query. There will be advertising, however, in which businesses can bid to associate their ad with a certain topic and location. title: The Review of Reviews
description: The beginning of the end came last February, when anonymous book reviews on Amazon.com's Canadian site were posted with reviewers' real names. For some, it was an embarrassing unmasking. Several authors had raved about their own books. A number of reviewers had tried to skew the Amazon system, supporting friends or attacking enemies with anonymous or pseudonymous reviews. What kept this from being merely laughable is the scale of Amazon's business and the role customers' reviews play in its social and financial economy. Like eBay, Amazon.com is a community, and trust is one of its most important commodities. Just visit Amazon's discussion boards if you don't believe it.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trade Surplus Grows
description: Helped by rising agricultural exports, Brazil posted a trade surplus in July of $3.48 billion, up 69 percent from the period a year earlier, the government said. That brought the accumulated surplus this year to $18.53 billion, up from a surplus of $12.45 billion in the first seven months of 2003. Exports totaled $8.99 billion in July, while imports continued to bounce back from a slump last year, reaching $5.51 billion last month. Most economists expect Brazil, South America's largest economy, to finish the year with a trade surplus of about $29 billion, up from a record $24.8 billion in 2003. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANE, CAROL FEIT, PH.D.
description: LANE--Carol Feit, Ph.D. 70, died on August 1, of breast cancer at the NYU Medical Center. We depely mourn her loss. She is the beloved daughter of Belle Harmon, sister of James A. Harmon, wife of Frederick M. Lane, mother of Wendy and Laurie, loving Nana of Rachel and Brad, Grandma Carol to Joshua, Jacob and Eleanor, beloved stepmother to Elliot, Roberta and Carol. Always a champion of women's causes, she devoted her efforts to promote the development of women at midlife. She founded and was President of The Career Development Specialists' Network (CDSN), a professional group of over 100 members. She had worked at Barnard College, at the Women's Wellness Center at NYU Medical Center, and served on Women's O.W.N., promoting women's health. She was a revered teacher of memoir writing at the senior center at the 92nd Street Y. A sculptor, dancer, essayist, and poet, she loved life and imparted her love and vitality to all who knew her. Funeral services at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave and 81st St, on Tuesday, August 3, 1:30 pm. Interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. She was a sunbeam, lighting all our lives. Any memorial donations to the American Cancer Society.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: More Illegal Migrants

Italy has tried to stem illegal immigrations by signing agreements with the countries from where the migrants depart, but the spike this summer has shown no signs of letting up. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: SAFECO EARNS $1.51 BILLION IN SALE OF LIFE INSURANCE UNITS
description: The Safeco Corporation said yesterday that it had received $1.51 billion from selling its life insurance unit and related businesses and would buy back debt and stock with the proceeds. The company, a home and life insurer, also said the sales would result in a third-quarter loss of $260 million, or $390 million before taxes, because the buyers paid less than book value for the units. Safeco had estimated a $330 million pretax loss when it announced the transactions in March. An investor group led by Berkshire Hathaway Inc. and White Mountains Insurance Group paid $1.41 billion for the life insurance unit. The company, based in Seattle, said it would use $710 million of the proceeds to repay $620 million of debt, recording a $90 million pretax loss in the third quarter. Another $620 million will finance a buyback of 13.2 million share of stock.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Napping Mother Smothers Infant
description: A 2-month-old boy was smothered on Sunday when his mother inadvertently rolled on top of him while she was asleep, the police said yesterday. The baby, Neheimah Nixon, was asleep with his mother on the same bed at their home on Emmons Avenue in Sheepshead Bay when his mother awoke around 6:15 P.M. to find the boy unconscious and called 911, the police said. No charges were expected to be filed against the mother, the police said. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: EARNINGS FOR CORINTHIAN COLLEGES LAG FORECAST

Net income in the period ended June 30 was 19 cents to 20 cents a share, said Corinthian, which is based in Santa Ana, Calif. The forecast was lowered from the 27 cents a share the company said it expected in April. Earnings are expected to drop to 17 cents to 19 cents a share in the first quarter, which ends Sept. 30, from 21 cents a share a year earlier. Corinthian, which will operate 88 colleges in the United States and 35 in Canada after it closes campuses in the next year, blamed higher expenses for services, marketing and advertising for the lower-than-expected earnings.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Another Yukos Inquiry
description: The tax ministry said it would begin another audit of the oil company Yukos, this time for 2002. The agency requested that Yukos provide documents for the inspection, the Prime-Tass news agency reported. Yukos already owes $3.4 billion in taxes for the year 2000 and is expected to pay a similar amount for 2001. Earlier yesterday, a Russian court ruled that Yukos, the country's largest oil producer, did not have to pay a late fee of 6.7 billion rubles ($223 million) to court bailiffs for a delay in paying its original tax bill. Yukos failed earlier this summer to meet a deadline to pay 99.4 billion rubles ($3.4 billion) as part of a battle with the government over its tax bill. Analysts have said the final tax bill for Yukos could approach $10 billion. The government's pursuit of Yukos is continuing as its founder, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, is on trial for fraud and tax evasion; both are considered to be politically motivated investigations. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

description: LAHORE, Pakistan: A team of Italian mountaineers sent a radio message today reporting they have conquered Mt. Godwin Austen, a 28,250-foot Himalayan peak which had never before been climbed. K2, as the mountain is known to climbers, ranks second only to Mt. Everest, which was scaled for the first time by a British expedition in May, 1953. But it has always been considered the more difficult ascent due to the precipitous character of its final approaches. A message from the expedition's leader, Prof. Ardito Desio, heard by the Pakistan radio, said the group fought its way to the summit last Saturday [July 30] after several months of battling up jagged slopes which claimed the life of one member of the party. Dr. Desio did not give the names of the men who actually reached the summit. He was apparently acting in accordance with the precedent set by the ill-fated American expedition which tried to conquer the peak last year. The American leader had announced that if it were successful the names of the actual men to reach the summit would be withheld.

title: Olerud Gets A Chance At First

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Profit Rises
description: Royal Bank of Scotland said first-half net profit rose 18 percent, helped by income from acquisitions in the United States and Britain and a strong performance in its insurance business. Net profit was 2.33 billion ($4.25 billion), up from 1.97 billion in the period a year earlier. Revenue rose 20 percent, to 10.94 billion. Profit in general insurance more than doubled, to 1.72 billion in the first half. Pretax profit was up 17 percent, to 3.38 billion, short of analysts' forecast of 3.47 billion, and the company's share price fell 3 percent. The bank said integration of the American bank Charter One Financial, which it bought in May for $10.5 billion, was going well and should be completed by the end of 2004. The chief executive, Fred Goodwin, said recent acquisitions and an improved economic outlook provided an optimistic outlook for the second half.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Internet Bank Sale Abandoned
description: The British insurer Prudential P.L.C. abandoned plans to sell control of the Internet bank Egg P.L.C. after a seven-month search failed to produce a buyer. Egg shares lost more than a quarter of their value. The insurer has been trying to sell Egg since January to concentrate on expanding in Asia and the United States. ''The board of Prudential has concluded that retention of its 79 percent stake offers better value to its shareholders than the sale of Prudential's interest,'' the company said. Shares of Egg, which is based in London, fell 28 percent yesterday. Prudential has sufficient cash flow for the dividend, which will also be supported by a ''cash flow positive'' Asian business in 2006, the finance director, Philip Broadley, said. The insurer's expansion in Asia and the United States has been and will remain largely organic, said Jonathan Bloomer, the chief executive of Prudential.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Ciena Misses Sales Forecast
description: The Ciena Corporation, which makes fiber optic equipment, said it had fiscal third-quarter sales of $75 million, missing its forecast because of slowing sales of Internet equipment. The shares fell as much as 14 percent. Ciena had forecast sales of as much as $97.1 million, a company statement said. It was expected to report sales of $95.4 million, the average of 19 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. An ''ongoing environment of uncertainty resulting in cautious spending'' by its customers led to the lower sales, said Ciena, which is based in Linthicum, Md. The company cut spending on research and development, sales and marketing in the period. Shares of Ciena fell 44 cents, or 16 percent, to $2.32 in extended trading after the announcement. They were unchanged at $2.76 as of the end of regular trading. The company said it had a preliminary net loss of 24 cents to 26 cents a share in the period ended July 31.

title: Halliburton Settles S.E.C. Accusations

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Sales Fall At Ad Concern
description: The advertising and marketing company Havas said second-quarter revenue fell 9.4 percent, hurt by the decline in the dollar. Revenue dropped to 393 million euros ($472 million) from 433.6 million euros a year earlier, the chief executive, Alain de Pouzilhac, said. Excluding the effects of exchange rates, acquisitions and assets sold, sales rose 0.5 percent in the second quarter, less than analysts had forecast. The company said revenue was higher in France and Britain, but lower in the United States. Havas, based in the Paris suburb of Suresnes, also said it had lined up more financial backers for a possible bid for the Grey Global Group of New York.

description: A 13-year-old boy floating unconscious in Jamaica Bay in the Rockaways yesterday was rescued by a firefighter who revived the boy, according to the fire department. Firefighter Craig Mosia of Ladder Truck 121, which had responded to a 911 call in the Arverne section at about 12:30 P.M., went into the water off Beach 67th Street after stripping to his underwear and socks. He then swam about 50 feet to the boy who was found floating face down. Firefighter Mosia said he pulled the boy, whose name was not released, to a nearby dock and performed CPR for several minutes until an ambulance arrived and took the boy to a local hospital. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Breakaway Communists Lose
description: The leader of Russia's Communists has retained control of his party, according to decision by the Justice Ministry. Last month, the remnants of the Communist Party held two simultaneous congresses. Both claimed to be official. At one, a breakaway faction claimed to have seized the party's helm by electing a leadership slate opposed to the longstanding party boss, Gennadi A. Zyuganov. Mr. Zyuganov refused to recognize the ouster attempt. The Justice Ministry ruled that the breakaway faction's congress was illegitimate, leaving Mr. Zyuganov in command of a party that, dogged by infighting and ideological drift, is declining in size and influence. Please view and sign family guest book at www.pumphreyfuneralhome.com.

title: A 19th-Century G.O.P. Bastion Holds Firm
description: It has been a rough year for the Bush administration by some measures, with criticism from the Sept. 11 commission, prison scandals in Iraq and a flat economy at home. But here in the remote hills of northeastern West Virginia, most people have a hard time imagining a candidate better than the incumbent, who they say shares their values in a way no Democrat ever could.

title: Our Security Is His Mandate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   URBAN, PAULINE
description: URBAN -- Pauline. Beloved wife of Marvin. Loving and cherished mother of Michael (Sherry) and Randi (Yakov). Devoted grandmother of Ryan, Nicole and Matthew. Loving sister of Doris. Cherished Aunt. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 11:00 AM, Thursday.

title: Tom Ridge Is Favorite in the Hambletonian
description: A week ago, there were questions about whether Tom Ridge could secure a berth in the Hambletonian, the most prestigious event in harness racing. In the post position draw Tuesday, Tom Ridge was installed as the early favorite for the race, which is Saturday at the Meadowlands.

title: U.S. Finds Severe Flaws at L.I. Nursing Home
description: A 77-year-old nursing home patient was taking two antipsychotic medications, despite having no history of psychiatric problems. When another patient shed 12 pounds in a week, the staff did not try to find out why. Still another patient who was confined to his bed had been improperly restrained and was at risk of suffocating himself.

title: Separatist Tensions Flare Again in Georgia
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 4  Separatist tensions flared in Georgia today, with new violence reported in South Ossetia a day after President Mikhail Saakashvili threatened to sink ships approaching the country's other separatist region, Abkhazia.

title: 6 Are Charged With Murder After Paraguay Store Fire
description: Prosecutors in Paraguay filed murder charges on Tuesday against the owners and security guards of a megastore in Asuncin where as many as 460 people were killed and hundreds more were injured in a fire over the weekend.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about tensions in the town of Nauvoo, Ill., as more Mormons move there referred incorrectly to Wayne S. Marting, who said real estate sales had risen since a Mormon temple was restored. He is an agent for one of the town's three real estate agencies, not the town's only agent.

title: Hindu Temple to Challenge State Judge on Religious Grounds
description: A prominent Hindu temple in Queens plans to file a motion in federal court today accusing a state judge of violating the separation of church and state by intervening in the temple's affairs.

title: Berry Sales to U.S. Offer Security to Amazon Farmers
description: For more than 30 years, Raimundo Julio da Costa has eked out a living by selling a dazzling array of wild tropical fruits that grow naturally on his land in the lush floodplains of the Amazon rainforest.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about efforts to preserve the Gould Memorial Library and other buildings designed by Stanford White at Bronx Community College, formerly a campus of New York University, referred incorrectly to the academic background of Helen Gould, who donated the library in memory of her father, the railroad tycoon Jay Gould. (The error also occurred in an article in March 1996.) While Helen Gould completed a law program for women at N.Y.U., she did not graduate from its law school.

title: Mets Show Signs of Life Against the Brewers
description: The Mets, at least for one night, decided they would not go quietly for the rest of the season. They pitched, they hit, they darted around the bases. The team that struggled for traction throughout a miserable three-game weekend series in Atlanta regained its grip Tuesday night.

title: In Age of Terror, How Long Should Security Stay Tight?
description: In New Jersey, which has suddenly found itself on a list of potential terrorism targets, police chiefs bemoaned the costs of its heightened security procedures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOORE, KNEELAND SAVERY
description: MOORE--Kneeland Savery. On July 29, at home in South Carver, Massachusetts after short illness. Husband of late Mary Kane Moore of Ossining, NY. Survived by son and daughter-in-law, K. Savery and Janice H. Moore of Sunnyside, NY, daughter Mary Lee Moore & granddaughter Lea Savery Moore of Boston, and his companion of many years, Marian W. Newton. Born Brooklyn, New York, June 5, 1913. Served in United States Air Force as captain during World War II. 30 year resident of North Tarrytown, NY. Advertising Account Director at BBD&O, New York, for 21 years. Marketing Director for Interbank Card Association, which became MasterCard, for 16 years. Nine - time men's tennis champion at Sleepy Hollow Country Club, Scarborough, NY. Memorial service noon Saturday, September 18, 2004, Union Church, South Carver, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Union Church Society, PO Box 37, South Carver, MA 02366.

title: Op-Chart; A Record of Recovery
description: Over the course of last week, we heard a lot from the Democrats about their record of economic achievement. So let's take the advice of a Democrat of yesteryear, Al Smith, the former governor of New York. His trademark phrase was, ''Let's look at the record.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, WILLIAM FARRELL III (BILLY)
description: SMITH--William Farrell III (Billy) suddenly on August 2, 2004 of Manhasset, NY. Loving husband of Peggy. Dear son of Eleanor and the late William F. Smith, Jr. Devoted uncle of Michael Monahan. Loved by all that met him. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset Thursday and Friday 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Saturday 10AM, St. Mary's RC Church, Manhasset with interment to follow in Nassau Knolls Cemetery. Donations may be made to: The Royal Irish Artillery of N.Y. POB 116, Manhasset, New York 11030.

title: Glimmerglass Finds Adventure in the Country
description: Opera buffs can't go wrong with any of the four new productions the adventurous Glimmerglass Opera is offering this summer, its 30th anniversary season. There is an impassioned performance of Puccini's inexplicably neglected tale of homesick miners during the California Gold Rush, ''La Fanciulla del West''; a boldly updated and splendidly sung production of Handel's ''Imeneo''; and a wildly costumed and zany staging of Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Patience.''

title: Brought to Earth, Vick Is Looking For Another Liftoff
description: The limp is long gone, but oddly, the swagger has not fully returned to Michael Vick's step.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALDMAN, MARCELLA
description: WALDMAN--Marcella. Artist. She died July 29 in Miami Beach, age 90. Wife of the late Seymour. Survived by son Mark and daughter Jane. Beloved by all who knew her.

title: Ryanair Reports Slight Recovery in Quarter
description: Ryanair, the discount Irish airline, announced on Tuesday that its after-tax profit rose 30 percent in the first quarter, to 52.6 million euros ($63.4 million) including exceptional items, as the number of passengers rose 28 percent from a year earlier, to 6.6 million. The earnings beat analysts' expectations and marked a slight recovery from three months ago, when the company reported its first quarterly loss.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Designer Arraigned On Child Pornography Charge
description: An Upper East Side jewelry designer was arraigned yesterday on charges of possessing child pornography and drugs and tampering with physical evidence. The designer, Clive Kandel, 53, who pleaded not guilty, could face up to seven years in prison if convicted, officials with the Manhattan district attorney's office said. After executing a search warrant at Mr. Kandel's East 87th Street apartment, police officers recovered cocaine, marijuana and a badly scratched CD-ROM with video clips of children engaging in sexual activity, officials said. Mr. Kandel remains free without bail. His lawyer did not return a call for comment. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: New Warnings, Old Intelligence (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. Plans Tamer Halftime Show
description: Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League commissioner, said yesterday that planning for the halftime show at next year's Super Bowl was being ''more effectively managed and controlled'' to avoid the type of embarrassment that occurred when Justin Timberlake exposed Janet Jackson's breast during this year's show.

title: No More Social Promotion? Studying Instead of Criticizing
description: FOR the last six months, one of the louder and most persistent noises emanating from education circles in New York was the condemnation of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to attack social promotion. He called for holding back third graders who failed basic-skills tests in math or reading and requiring them to attend summer school before trying the exams again.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: With Them, However, It's Always 'Hold the Bread'

title: Cartier-Bresson, Who Photographed the 'Decisive Moment,' Dies
description: Henri Cartier-Bresson, one of the major artists of the 20th century, who used his tiny hand-held 35-millimeter Leica camera to bear humane witness to many of the century's signal events, from the Spanish Civil War to the German occupation of France to the partition of India to the Chinese revolution to the student uprisings of 1968, has died in France, the Ministry of Culture announced today. He was 95.

title: Bargains Help Auto Industry Recover in July
description: Auto sales rebounded in July after a disappointing June, driven by hot products like the Toyota Sienna minivan and the Chrysler 300C sedan and by big incentives on sport utility vehicles, figures released on Tuesday showed.

description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq Is Soliciting Bids To Help Determine How Much Oil It Has
description: Iraq has an immense amount of oil, but no one knows in detail just how much is there, not even the country's oil ministry.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on July 20 about ''Night Watch,'' a popular Russian movie, overstated the share of technical work on it that was completed in Russia. Not only sound but some other postproduction aspects of the film were completed in Los Angeles.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRIS, BURT I.
description: HARRIS--Burt I. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of their warm and steadfast friend Burt I. Harris of Los Angeles, Calif. A pioneering cable television executive, Mr. Harris served the ATS as president of the Southern California Chapter, a national board member and life trustee of the ATS Board of Regents. Devoted philanthropists, Mr. Harris and his wife Shirley established the Shirley and Burt Harris Chair in Communications and the Burt and Shirley Harris Scholarship Fund, and supported a variety of Southern California Chapter projects. An honorary life member of the Technion International Board of Governors, Mr. Harris was recognized with an honorary fellowship from the Technion in 1987. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Shirley, children Janie, Buzz, Melissa and Natalie, and the entire Harris family. The American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Stephen A. Laser, President Evelyn Berger, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President David Polak, Chairman of the Board, Western Region Edith Fischer, President, Western Region William Litvak, Chairman of the Board, Southern California Chapter Joan Seidel, President, Southern California Chapter Diane Siegel, Director, Western Region

title: Safety Precautions Transform Appearance of Capitol Hill
description: Members of Congress often call the Capitol the People's House. But the house is looking more and more like a fortress.

title: Birds Flew Earlier Than Previously Thought, Scientists Say
description: Scientists have determined that the ancient avian fossil Archaeopteryx was definitely bird-brained, meaning no disrespect. Indeed, they consider it decisive evidence that this earliest known bird had what it took to fly.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Francis H. C. Crick, co-discoverer of the structure of DNA, misstated the cause of death for Dr. Rosalind Franklin, another DNA researcher whose data provided a key clue. It was ovarian cancer, not leukemia.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Republicans Narrow Senate Possibilities
description: The state Republican Party said it had narrowed its search for a United States Senate candidate to two people: Alan Keyes, a former presidential candidate, and Andrea Grubb Barthwell, former deputy director in the Office of National Drug Control Policy. Republican leaders will meet with both on Wednesday and decide after that. The candidate will face Barack Obama, who was a relatively unknown state senator before gaining national recognition by delivering the keynote address at the Democratic National Convention in Boston. The slot became open after Jack Ryan dropped out following the release of embarrassing court records. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Drop That Umbrella; G.O.P. Delegates Get List of Banned Items
description: A warning to delegates planning to attend the Republican National Convention: No guns, knives or explosives will be allowed inside Madison Square Garden. And if you are thinking about bringing strollers, spray cans or umbrellas, think again.
By Bloomberg News

title: Issue of Politics and Terror Complicates Strategy for Kerry and His Party
description: For Howard Dean, there is now no question about why the White House raised the terror alert on Sunday.

title: The Woman With the Leash Appears in Court on Abu Ghraib Abuse Charges
description: She is the last but best known of seven accused soldiers to enter a military courtroom on charges of prisoner abuse that have disgraced the armed services.

title: Fight Over Same-Sex Marriage Tough on Specter
description: Republicans had hoped to score political points by forcing a Senate vote on a proposed Constitutional amendment to ban same-sex marriage, but the fight has proven costly to at least one member of their party.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Report Warns Of Job Losses
description: New Jersey could lose nearly 500,000 jobs to employers overseas unless the state changes some of its labor practices, according to a study released yesterday by a nonprofit organization that conducts research on state issues. The New Jersey Policy Perspective said jobs in the state were susceptible to being transferred to countries where workers are paid less for the same tasks. The study, which did not list the number of jobs already lost, recommends that the state fight the outsourcing trend by promoting better paying jobs to replace lost jobs, supporting unionization, and increasing the minimum wage John Holl (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on July 15 about the licensing of three experimental cancer drugs from Cuba by a California biotechnology company, CancerVax, included an erroneous reference from the U.S.-Cuba Trade and Economic Council about the status of another Cuban drug, PPG, which is used to lower cholesterol. The federal government has not given permission for an American company to license it.

title: SMITH & WESSON SUES INSURER FOR DEFENSE COSTS
description: The Smith & Wesson Corporation, the handgun maker, sued a unit of the American International Group for failing to pay Smith & Wesson's defense costs in three dozen lawsuits filed by cities in the 1990's. Smith & Wesson, based in Springfield, Mass., claimed the National Union Fire Insurance Company of Pittsburgh violated an agreement to defend it in court under seven policies sold to its former parent company, Tomkins P.L.C. of London. The suit, filed July 26 in United States District Court in Springfield, Mass., said Smith & Wesson had been forced to pay millions of dollars defending itself in the firearms litigation.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- New Jersey; Making Room for Technology Start-Ups
description: After a long search for lab and office space for their fledgling life-science company late in 2002, Christian Kopfli and his business partner found a home at the Commercialization Center for Innovative Technologies in North Brunswick, N.J., a new, nonprofit complex providing ''incubator'' space for emerging technology companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEARLMAN, HERBERT M.
description: PEARLMAN--Herbert M. Beloved husband, father and grandfather, entrepreneur, corporate founder and builder, sponsor of medical and educational charities. The very best of men.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about the Hollywood agent Ari Emanuel gave an outdated title for Michael D. Eisner, the Walt Disney executive with whom he dueled over the distribution of ''Fahrenheit: 9/11'' while representing its director. (The error also appeared in an article in the section on May 25 about efforts to find a distributor.) Mr. Eisner is chief executive, no longer chairman.
