title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITMAN, ALEXANDER HARVEY
description: WHITMAN--Alexander Harvey, 85, on July 30, at home. Beloved husband of Sylvia Choate Whitman, of Chester, CT. He lived most of his life in Cedarhurst, NY, where he was born. Graduate of St. Paul's School and Harvard College '41. Served on and then commanded U.S. Navy patrol craft in the Atlantic and Pacific in World War II. He worked as a chartering broker for W.R. Grace and Co., James E. Ward, and MidOcean Brokers, Inc. Longtime member of the Rockaway Hunting Club, the Lawrence Beach Club, the Cedarhurst Yacht Club, the Harvard Club of New York, and the Brook Club. Avid supporter of the Seamen's Church Institute. He was a gentleman known for his charm and wit. Survivors include his wife; sons Alexander H. Whitman, of Seattle, WA, and Stephen V.R. Whitman, of Simsbury, CT; daughters Angelica Schuyler Whitman and Jennifer Whitman Foster, of Northampton, MA, and Sylvia Whitman, of Arlington, VA; and ten grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Seamen's Church Institute, 241 Water St, New York 10038. Memorial service 11:30AM, September 11, Trinity-St. John's Episcopal Church, Hewlett, NY.

title: Giants Cornerback Inflicts Pain While He Is Trying to Forget It
description: Midway through a drill Tuesday morning, Giants cornerback Terry Cousin saw the ball and a receiver coming at him. He drove his shoulder pads into them, the hit echoing across a suddenly quiet field. The receiver, Tim Carter, lay on the ground for a minute before he could hop up and shake it off.

title: CALENDAR
description: Tomatoes by the Ton

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Myra Waldo, an author of travel guides and cookbooks, gave an incomplete title for a book she wrote with the actress Gertrude Berg. It was ''The Molly Goldberg Jewish Cookbook,'' not ''The Molly Goldberg Cookbook.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about the Hollywood agent Ari Emanuel gave an outdated title for Michael D. Eisner, the Walt Disney executive with whom he dueled over the distribution of ''Fahrenheit: 9/11'' while representing its director. (The error also appeared in an article in the section on May 25 about efforts to find a distributor.) Mr. Eisner is chief executive, no longer chairman.

title: Bank to Go On Financing Coal And Oil Projects
description: The World Bank's governing board yesterday rejected the recommendations of an independent adviser that the bank stop financing new coal-mining ventures and end support for oil projects by 2008, and instead use those resources to encourage poor countries to develop renewable energy sources.

title: Market Place; Stewart's Woes Hurt Company; Losses Expected Through 2004
description: Martha Stewart's legal problems continue to batter the company that bears her name, with worse-than-expected losses across the entire business after her federal criminal conviction. In a conference call with investors yesterday, the chief financial officer said Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, under pressure from the continuing negative publicity around what Ms. Stewart has called ''a small personal matter,'' would continue to lose money through the end of the year.

title: Issue of Politics and Terror Complicates Strategy for Kerry and His Party
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 - For Howard Dean, there is now no question about why the White House raised the terror alert on Sunday.

title: AT&T Plans to Raise Its Rates For Residential Calling Plans
description: AT&T Communications plans to reach out and put the touch on its customers.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Settles New Mexico Lawsuit
description: Microsoft will give $31.5 million in software vouchers to settle a lawsuit by New Mexico consumers who assert they were overcharged for the Windows operating system. The lawsuit claimed that consumers paid higher prices for personal computer software because of Microsoft's Windows monopoly. Consumers will receive vouchers that can be used to purchase any manufacturer's software or computers. Half of any unclaimed vouchers will go to public schools. More than 100 consumer lawsuits were filed after a federal appeals court ruled in 2001 against Microsoft in an antitrust suit brought by the government. Microsoft has agreed to pay at least $1.8 billion to settle consumer antitrust suits in more than a dozen states and the District of Columbia.

title: Police Corruption Plagues Argentines and President
description: He was a 23-year-old engineering student from a middle-class family, kidnapped one night early this year on his way to see his fiance. Days later, while held for ransom, he managed to escape, but when neighbors alerted the police to a man running down the street calling for help, they say they were ordered back into their houses and told to mind their own business.

title: Scholar in Smuggling Trial Switches to a Guilty Plea
description: A noted Middle East scholar pleaded guilty yesterday to smuggling stolen Mesopotamian relics from Iraq last year and lying to federal customs officials when he said he had never traveled to the country.

title: National Briefings
description: SOUTHWEST

title: State Accused Of Failure To Integrate In Hartford
description: The plaintiffs whose school desegregation lawsuit against Connecticut 15 years ago resulted in a $245 million plan to shift white, suburban students to Hartford's overwhelmingly minority schools and minority students in the opposite direction filed court papers on Tuesday charging the state is woefully behind schedule and has served only a fraction of the students it agreed to help.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, TRISTAM B.
description: JOHNSON--Tristam B. A lifelong Princeton resident and retired investment advisor, died July 31, 2004. Husband of the late Eileen Douglas and Helen Harris Johnson. Survived by two daughters, Kate E. Hill and Elizabeth H. Johnson, four sons, Tristam B. Johnson, Jr., Thomas H. Johnson, Jeffrey D. Johnson and Kevin P. Johnson, two stepsons, Christopher Reeve and Benjamin Reeve, nineteen grandchildren, five stepgrandchildren and a greatgrandson. A memorial service will be held at Nassau Presbyterian Church, 61 Nassau St., Princeton, Friday, August 6th, 4PM. A reception will follow at the Nassau Club, 6 Mercer St., Princeton. Memorial contributions may be made to The Swan Foundation, at the National Museum of the America Revolution, Washington Crossing State Park, 355 Washington Crossing-Pennington Road, Titusville, N.J. 08560.

title: Red? White? With Stuffed Tomatoes, Anything Goes
description: MORE than 30 years ago, a friend returned from Greece with a gift, an autographed copy of a paperback, ''The Best Book of Greek Cookery'' by Chrissa Paradissis. This unassuming little volume has 200 or so recipes that I treasure for their straightforward simplicity and authenticity.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Messenger Spacecraft Begins Journey To Mercury
description: After a 24-hour weather delay, NASA's Messenger spacecraft began a five-billion-mile journey to Mercury. Once Messenger arrives in orbit around the planet in 2011, its battery of seven instruments will study Mercury's heavily cratered surface, the composition of its core, its thin atmosphere and its magnetic field. ''We know as much about Mercury as we knew about the Moon before the space age,'' said Mark S. Robinson, of Northwestern University, an investigator for the Mercury program. Stefano S. Coledan (NYT)

title: The Dead and Dostoyevsky, in a War With Bush
description: It might not have swayed many swing voters: a playlet in which a man portrays Laura Bush, talking passionately about Dostoyevsky and moral relativity to the ghosts of Iraqi children, cursing occasionally and revealing at one point that she sometimes calls her husband ''the Chimp.'' (''You know, those ears,'' the character of the first lady says, smiling impishly.)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Chip Maker Selects Executive
description: The largest maker of semiconductor equipment in Europe, ASML Holding, has named Eric Meurice president and chief executive. Mr. Meurice, 48, an executive vice president at Thomson Television Worldwide, a unit of the electronics maker Thomson, will take charge on Oct. 1, ASML said. He will succeed Doug Dunn, whose retirement was announced in January and who will stay at ASML until the end of the year. ASML is based in Vedlhoven, the Netherlands.

title: Iran's Nuclear Challenge
description: The invasion of Iraq, which President Bush has often said would help stabilize the Middle East, is now hindering efforts to deal with a real nuclear threat: Iran. Despite its ritualistic denials, Iran gives every indication of building all the essential elements of a nuclear weapons program. And while the United States has hoped to pressure Iran into halting that program, the government in Tehran has clearly concluded that it has little to fear for now from an American government whose diplomatic credibility has been damaged and whose military capacities have been stretched by the war in Iraq.

title: Chinese Exports, Marinated in India
description: ''DRY or gravy?''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Tax Form Check-Off For Cancer Research
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed into law yesterday a measure to create a voluntary check-off box on state income tax forms that will allow New York residents and businesses to donate money for prostate cancer research. The idea grew out of a meeting of cancer experts this year that was held by State Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, and Michael R. Milken, left, the financier whose name was once synonymous with junk bonds and who served 22 months in prison for securities law violations. Mr. Milken is also a survivor of prostate cancer, a condition he learned he had on release from custody in 1993. He is also the founder and chairman of the Prostate Cancer Foundation, a nonprofit foundation that will provide matching funds for those raised by the tax return check-off.

title: Art? Smut? Commerce? Billboard Gets Attention
description: Drivers cruising down Sunset Boulevard have been rubbernecking even more than usual these hot Hollywood nights at the sight of a looming image that shows a woman performing oral sex for a man.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Iraqis Denied Entry To City Hall
description: A group of community leaders in the new Iraqi government who are visiting American cities to learn about local government and civil rights were denied entry to the Memphis city hall after the City Council chairman said he was concerned for the safety of workers there, said Elisabeth Silverman, executive director of the Memphis Council for International Visitors. The meeting the Iraqis were to attend, a discussion of democracy with Councilwoman Carol Chumney, took place at the Memphis Convention and Visitors Bureau instead. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Piazza Pays Tribute to Murphy
description: Mike Piazza said his Saturdays as a child included watching cartoons in the morning, then listening to the veteran announcers of the Phillies and the Mets in the afternoons. Piazza said he frequently picked up the calls of Bob Murphy, the Mets' Hall of Fame broadcaster, who died of lung cancer at age 79 on Tuesday.

title: ADELPHIA TO PAY $8 MILLION TO SETTLE LAWSUITS
description: The Adelphia Communications Corporation agreed to pay $8.1 million to settle more than $1 billion in claims by entertainment companies that alleged their material was used without permission. The companies, including Viacom Inc.'s Paramount Pictures Corporation, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc., the Sony Corporation's Sony Pictures Entertainment Inc., and Time Warner Inc., will withdraw their damage claims and related lawsuits, according to documents filed with United States Bankruptcy Court in New York. The settlement requires court approval. Adelphia is based in Greenwood Village, Colo.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday with an article about I.B.M.'s decision to make some software code more widely available to programmers referred imprecisely to its plans. While the code will be contributed to an ''open source'' software group, it will not be in the public domain. The group, the Apache Software Foundation, will hold the licensing and intellectual-property rights.

title: For Greeks, a Respectable Finish
description: GREEK winemakers must feel as if they are at the center of the world. Not since the times of Homer have Greek wines received as much attention as they have in the last few months. The reason, of course, is that the Olympics, which begin in Athens on Aug. 13, serve as the classic news peg, the event that allows feature writers to tie their essentially unmoored subjects to real-life goings-on. For Greek wines, luckily, the time is right for discovery.

title: Carbon Dioxide Lawsuits
description: To the Editor:

title: Moviemaking: Luck, Timing And More Luck
description: Getting a movie made in Hollywood is about perception, luck and timing. Ask Larry Gross, a veteran screenwriter whose script for a film based on three novellas by Andr Dubus gathered dust for 23 years.

title: A Small World in Iowa
description: Presidential contenders often careen around Iowa almost bumping into one another, but that is generally during the primary season, not the general election campaign.

title: A Bag Full of Bubbles
description: A sleek little metallic gauze tote trimmed in summery white, green, pink or yellow and fitted with three splits of Mot & Chandon White Star Champagne and small plastic flutes is a stylish new accessory for picnics and concerts in the park. The reusable bag will show off the wine but not keep it cold.

title: Driver Is Fined for Nascar Ad Cover-Up
description: A Nascar driver, Jimmie Johnson, who is sponsored by PepsiCo Inc., was fined $10,000 for covering a bottle of the Coca-Cola Company's Powerade sports drink with a sign after he won the Pennsylvania 500 on Sunday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Exports Rise
description: Malaysia's exports rose 22.2 percent in the first half of the year, to 39.75 billion ringgit ($10.46 billion), as demand from the United States and Hong Kong for the country's electronics surged more than expected. Malaysia's trade surplus fell to 5.09 billion ringgit, however, as factories imported more raw materials. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Inquiry Names 2nd Hospital In Deaths Of 4 Babies
description: Officials revealed Tuesday that a state investigation into the deaths of four premature babies amid an uncommon bacterial outbreak at Westchester Medical Center includes a Bronx hospital where one of the babies was born and where another baby was found to have been infected by the bacteria.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial last Thursday about the Democratic National Convention incorrectly described the United Nations Charter. Article 51 acknowledges the ''inherent right'' of self-defense against an attack. That article has been interpreted by American governments as permitting pre-emptive attacks against an imminent danger to the United States. But it does not convey that right specifically.

title: Sidney Morgenbesser, 82, Kibitzing Philosopher, Dies
description: Sidney Morgenbesser, whose servings of logic, wit and insight as a Columbia University philosopher for a half-century prompted comparisons to Socrates -- minus the Yiddish accent -- died on Sunday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: INSIDE
description: Abu Ghraib Guard Appears in Court

title: National Briefing | Washington: Program Tracking Foreign Visitors To Be Expanded
description: Officials at the Department of Homeland Security said the agency would expand a program that tracks the departure of foreign visitors to 11 of the nation's airports -- Chicago O'Hare, Newark, Atlanta, Dallas-Fort Worth, Denver, Detroit, Philadelphia, San Francisco, San Juan, Seattle and Phoenix -- and to two seaports in Los Angeles. Starting in August and September, officials will capture digital fingerprints and photographs at those locations from travelers required to apply for visas to visit the United States. Rachel Swarns (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, RICHARD L. (DICK)
description: LEVY--Richard L. (Dick) of Sarasota, FL and Somers, NY (formerly of New York City) died on August 2, 2004 at the age of 83 of melanoma. Beloved husband of Barbara Ershler Levy, cherished father of Adam (Natalie) and Carol (Andrew) Garfinkle, adored grandfather of Madeline and Grace Levy, Julia and Alexa Garfinkle. Brother of Laurence and the late Janice Goldstein. He worked in the women's shoe manufacturing industry for 43 years, retiring in 1990. He represented Encore Shoes for 25 years. He was a Shakespeare buff and organized and led weekly reading and discussion groups in Heritage Hills in Somers and at the Selby Public Library in Sarasota. He was a gifted craftsman who made unique gold and silver jewelry, as well as varied woodworking pieces during his retirement. He was born in Boston, graduated from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. He joined the army as an enlisted man and was discharged in 1946 as a first lieutenant, having served in the Signal Intelligence Corp in Europe and Asia. We will remember him as a true renaissance man. His integrity, strength of character, and above all, love for his family will be an inspiration to us always. Funeral services will be held at the Levine Chapel, 1 PM, August 4. In lieu of flowers, donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, Melanoma Research, 1275 York Avenue, New York City 10021.

title: Pilot Is Expected to Plead Guilty In S.I. Ferry Crash That Killed 11
description: The pilot of the Staten Island ferry that plowed into a maintenance pier last October is expected to plead guilty today to criminal negligence for his role in the deaths of all 11 people killed as a result of the crash, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOTCHMAN, JAY L.
description: BOTCHMAN--Jay L., a resident of Las Vegas died on Saturday, July 31, 2004. He was 72 years old. Mr. Botchman was born on June 6, 1932 in Boston, Massachusetts, to the late Louis and Ruth. Mr. Botchman was a graduate of White Plains High School and resided in the area for 30 years. He served in the Navy on the USS Salem in the 50's and was a self-made business man in the Metropolitan area for 50 years. He is survived by his wife Shirley (Gibbons), his brother Allan & his nephews Bruce, Keith & Gary. Funeral services will be private in Las Vegas. Remembrances in Jay's name may be made to the Salvation Army.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LA FONTAINE, WILFRED
description: LA FONTAINE--Wilfred. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Wilfred La Fontaine, associated with The Times from November 17, 1984 until retiring in March 31, 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILBERZWEIG, SOL
description: SILBERZWEIG -- Sol. The American Society for Yad Vashem mourns the passing of Sol Silberzweig, Board member and benefactor of Yad Vashem. A Holocaust survivor who survived the Warsaw Ghetto uprising and seven concentration camps, lost his whole family except one brother who was living in the United States. He went on to become a highly successful businessman in the fur trade. A book about Mr. Silberzweig's life will be published shortly by Yad Vashem. He is survived by daughters Rochelle Cherry and Leslie Rueda, son Moe Silberzweig, eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Eli Zborowski, Chairman American Society for Yad Vashem

title: OFF THE MENU
description: CRU opens at 24 Fifth Avenue (Ninth Street) on Saturday, featuring the 65,000-bottle wine cellar of its owner, ROY WELLAND, and the cooking of SHEA GALLANTE, left, formerly the chef de cuisine at Bouley. He tilts subtly to Italy with raw fish dishes, or crudo, white polenta and olive oil soup, and quail risotto.

title: Fight Over Same-Sex Marriage Tough on Specter
description: Republicans had hoped to score political points by forcing a Senate vote on a proposed Constitutional amendment to ban same-sex marriage, but the fight has proven costly to at least one member of their party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVER, JOSEPH W., M.D.
description: SILVER--Joseph W., M.D. The Board of Governors, staff, and membership of the greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) mourn the passing of an esteemed and beloved physician and friend, Joseph W. Silver, M.D., who served with distinction as chief of orthopedic surgery at New York Methodist Hospital for the past two decades. We send our deepest sympathies to Dr. Silver's family, including his wife Madeline, his children Lauren and Marc, and his brother Shelly. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President & CEO, NYPH & Healthcare System Chairman, GNYHA Kenneth E. Raske President, GNYHA

description: Members of the Sept. 11 commission joined with Congressional Democrats on Tuesday in criticizing President Bush's proposal for creating the job of national intelligence director, saying the plan would not grant nearly enough power to the position.

title: 3 Iraqi Guardsmen and 6 Americans Killed
description: A car bomb exploded Tuesday in the restive city of Baquba, killing at least three Iraqi national guardsmen, as the United States military reported the deaths of six American troops over the last day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PINCHIAROLI, DINO
description: PINCHIAROLI--Dino. Of Old Westbury, New York on August 3, 2004. Active member of Herricks Community Players, passionate published writer, and avid fisherman. Beloved husband of Adelaide, loving father of six, adored companion of Roxy and Murphy. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday 7-9 P.M. at The Roslyn Heights Funeral Home, Inc., 75 Mineola Avenue, Roslyn Hts, NY. Funeral Mass Friday 10 A.M. Saint Mary's R.C. Church, Roslyn Harbor, New York. Cremation private.

Marting, who said real estate sales had risen since a Mormon temple was restored. He is an agent for one of the town's three real estate agencies, not the town's only agent. ( Go to Article )

title: Spitz Flattered to Be the Man to Beat
description: Mark Spitz said he had come to New York to talk about a medication he promotes, but the questions he was asked focused on swimming, and the prospect that his record of seven Olympic gold medals could soon be surpassed.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Stricter Safety Rules Favored For Con Ed
description: The Public Service Commission is right to impose increased safety requirements on Consolidated Edison and other utilities, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The commission, which oversees utilities statewide, issued an order on July 30 for tighter safety rules. The order came after a woman walking her dog in the East Village in January was electrocuted by stray voltage when she stepped on a metal plate. The order requires utilities operating in New York to conduct annual stray voltage tests on all facilities, correct hazards immediately and make permanent repairs to faulty locations within 45 days of their discovery. The order also requires that utilities develop a plan for inspecting all facilities at least once every five years. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: In the Line of Fire
description: At some point, the killing has to stop or effective humanitarian relief work as we know it today will never be the same. Relief workers are being murdered at an alarming rate because of a perceived lack of neutrality, because they are regarded as extensions of a donor nation's political and military agendas.

title: All Vegan, All the Time
description: Pure Juice and Takeaway, 125 1/2 East 17th Street, is a pocket-size dark wood and chartreuse extension of Pure Food and Wine, the plush new raw food restaurant around the corner. Matthew Kenney and Sarma Melngailis are in the kitchen here, too.

title: War and Peace, and Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 - In an election that could well turn on questions of war and peace, danger and safety, all politics sometimes seem to be security these days. And all security has an unmistakable overtone of politics, whatever the reality or immediacy of any announced threat.

title: Calling All Noshers: Hummus and Dumplings on St. Marks Place
description: St. Marks Place between First Avenue and Avenue A is a new destination for snackers. Hummus is the singular specialty of the bright little Hummus Place, left, at No. 109. Nitzan Raz, the chef, makes it fresh several times a day, spooning it into big bowls with a choice of ful (fava bean pure), whole chickpeas or a swirl of extra tahini, plus some olive oil, paprika and parsley. Ori Apple, an owner, imports the tahini from Nablus on the West Bank. The hummus is served with warm pita and little dishes of pickles, olives, harissa, green garlic-and-lemon sauce and raw onion, $4.50 to $4.95. The quaff of choice is lemonade scented with rose water, then Turkish coffee with an earthy whiff of cardamom.

title: Yanks' Lieber Literally Falls Down On the Job
description: Just before the final pitch of a forgettable outing, Jon Lieber caught his left shoe in the dirt as he strode toward the plate during his delivery. His ankle buckled and he fell forward in a heap on the mound.

title: In Drug Research, Some Guinea Pigs Are Now Human
description: Researchers at the University of Munich repeated the experiment 70 times: a healthy volunteer would receive a chemical injection, then be left alone to ride out an artificially induced panic attack.

title: Arabs Riveted And Angered By 'Fahrenheit'
description: When it opened last weekend in Beirut, ''Fahrenheit 9/11'' achieved the almost impossible: It silenced a movie audience. Although Beirut is the one capital in the region where almost all American films are shown with no censorship, screenings are somewhat more social affairs than elsewhere in the world, with people chattering on their cellphones or with their friends in the audience.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Coaches Sue In Sex Assault Case
description: Four former W.C. Mepham High School football coaches have sued the parents of three players involved in sexual assaults on teammates at the team's training camp in Pennsylvania last summer. The $20 million dollar lawsuit, filed in the Nassau County clerk's office on Friday, contends that the boys' parents should have known their sons were ''prone to acts of violence and demonstrated a vicious and dangerous propensity to commit assault and battery upon others.'' David Winzelberg (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Some Athletes Are Thrilled to Compete at the Games
description: THE Summer Games are here. Jessica Mendoza realized this last night in the Olympic Village as she watched athletes from Turkmenistan enter the dining hall.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about summer casting on Broadway misstated Jai Rodriguez's history with ''Rent,'' in which he is playing Angel. Mr. Rodriguez has played Angel before; he was not in the chorus. The article also misstated the occupation of Mimi, another character in ''Rent,'' played by Melanie Brown. She is a dancer, not a performance artist.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Panel Says Officers Should Be Punished
description: An independent police review panel has ruled that three Cincinnati police officers should be punished for repeatedly beating a man with nightsticks just before he died. The panel, the Cincinnati Citizens Complaint Authority, said Monday that the officers used excessive force against the man, Nathaniel Jones. An earlier conclusion by the Hamilton County prosecutor, Michael Allen, found that the officers committed no crimes in subduing Mr. Jones. The panel's ruling now goes to the city for consideration. Mr. Jones, 41, who died last Nov. 30, became the 19th black man to die after confrontations with the city police since 1995. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: With Eye on Iraq, Army Pushes Revamped Basic Training
description: The United States Army is pressing into place sweeping changes in its basic training program, introducing rigorous new drills and intensive work on combat skills to prepare recruits for immediate missions to Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Surprise in Chicago: A Vegetarian Wow
description: TO date, there have been barely a handful of vegetarian restaurants in the United States that would tempt the average nonvegetarian; most might as well post a ''meat-eaters keep out'' sign on their doors. People who wanted to eat extraordinary vegetarian food knew that often their best bet was to visit an establishment run by a great chef and ask for a special menu. The results were predictable: pricey and fabulous.

title: Citing Roslyn, Comptroller Widens Audits Of L.I. Schools
description: Two and a half years ago, Nassau County, hovering on the brink of bankruptcy, began implementing changes to address rampant corruption in local government. The county's school districts, however, which are monitored by the state, largely escaped any such scrutiny.

description: Kohl's Corp., Milwaukee, the discount department store chain, plans to open 11 Northern California stores that would employ 1,650 people by October.

description: Kia Motors America in Irvine, Calif., part of the Hyundai Motor Company, named six agencies yesterday to compete for its creative account along with the incumbent of five years, David and Goliath in Los Angeles. Spending was estimated at $260 million to $270 million.

title: Pocono Report Confirms Surge In Foreclosures
description: An eight-month study released yesterday by Pennsylvania officials confirms what many residents of the Pocono Mountains have long suspected: foreclosures have reached stunning levels, especially among homebuyers new to the area, many of whom paid more than market value for their homes.

title: One Arab Scholar's Otherness, And Contradictions in Otherness
description: Filmed a few weeks before its subject's death from leukemia in September 2003, ''Selves and Others: A Portrait of Edward Said'' finds this Palestinian-American cultural critic in a relaxed, reflective mood as he pores over old photographs of his family and himself and reflects on the many strands that made up the fabric of his identity -- or, as Said would have phrased it, his identities.

title: On Baseball; After Finding Postseason, A's Get Lost
description: FRUSTRATING? Yes. Would they prefer a different outcome? Sure. But let the Oakland Athletics get to the playoffs for a fifth successive season, and they will deal with whatever comes their way.

title: The Enduring Avian Flu Problem
description: It has become increasingly clear that the fight to control avian influenza will be a long, hard slog with success by no means guaranteed. Yet success is vital, for the longer the virus continues to devastate poultry flocks in Asia, the more likely it is to mutate eventually in ways that could make it both highly transmissible and lethal in humans. That could make a new influenza pandemic potentially even more deadly than the lethal but slow-moving AIDS epidemic, which is devastating countries in Africa and increasingly in Asia.

description: Nearly a year after Texas education authorities put Houston's public schools on probation for severely underreporting high school dropouts, the state has lifted the probation and restored the district's ranking, citing progress toward more accurately reporting the numbers of students who quit high school.

description: Los Alamos National Laboratory announced Wednesday that four more scientists had been put on leave as an investigation into two missing classified computer disks continued.

description: LONDON, Aug. 5 - Virgin Atlantic Airways plans to purchase as many as 26 Airbus planes worth $5.5 billion, the company's chairman Sir Richard Branson said today. The purchase would double the company's fleet as it continues its efforts to best rival British Airways.

title: JetBlue to Build New Terminal At Kennedy
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with JetBlue Airways to build a new terminal at Kennedy International Airport, a move meant to expand service and reopen Terminal 5, the airport's arching architectural landmark.

title: Many Christians Flee Iraq, With Syria the Haven of Choice
description: Abdulkhalek Sharif Nuaman likes to talk as he works, removing bubbly Iraqi bread from his ovens on long pallets. The baker is a cheerful man, yet his florid face darkens as he explains why he decided to flee Iraq.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Two Sought In Robbery And Rape
description: The authorities are looking for two men who forced a woman into a car from a street in Greenpoint early Monday morning, robbed her and raped her, the police said yesterday. The woman, whose identity was withheld, was assaulted about 3 a.m. when a man forced her into what the police believe was a red, four-door sedan. A second man drove them to a Citibank branch and forced her to withdraw money from a cash machine. Afterward, both men sexually assaulted her in the car, the police said. Anyone who has information is asked to call Crimestoppers at 1-800-577-TIPS(1-800-577-8477). Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Violence Flares Again in 2 Separatist Regions of Georgia
description: Separatist tensions flared Wednesday in Georgia when new violence was reported in separatist South Ossetia, a day after Georgia's president threatened to sink ships approaching the country's other break-away region, Abkhazia.

title: An American Debate: How Severe the Threat?
description: If the United States was in danger of a terrorist attack and faraway financial institutions were supposed to be on high alert, there was no evidence of it at Franks Diner, a 78-year-old Kenosha institution where senators mix with regular folk and the prospect of another attack seemed just part of the background noise of daily life.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Government To Sell Phone Stake
description: The Italian government will sell as much as 7.8 billion euros ($9.4 billion) worth of shares of Enel, the country's largest utility, in an effort to reduce its debt. Italy will market the shares, which amount to 20 percent of the company, to money managers and to Italian retail investors by the first half of November, the Finance Ministry said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHANNON, LARRY
description: SHANNON--Larry. A nightcap for Larry from the Gough's gang.

title: Auto Industry Debates Virtues of Diesels vs. Hybrids
description: Automakers remain divided on whether diesel or hybrid cars are the best way to improve fuel efficiency, and the split is often drawn along cultural lines.

title: Korean Missile Said to Advance; U.S. Is Unworried
description: North Korea appears closer to deploying a new mobile ballistic missile that is a worrisome increase in that nation's military capacity, but American government officials stressed Wednesday that the weapon could not reach the continental United States.

title: In the Background, a Man in the Gaming Forefront
description: IT has taken four years, but the creators of the Doom video game series have finally reached the next level.

title: Sometimes, Walls Do Talk
description: HOUSES are like books, split into chapters, filled with stories that are linked by setting. When you live in an old house, you are not just living with plaster and floorboards, but with stories. Histories you know nothing of occurred in the rooms in which you live. Someone fell in love in your kitchen, died in the spot where your bed is placed; someone did cartwheels across your lawn, had her heart broken one night; someone survived smallpox, influenza, childbirth.

title: Cowart Wants to Be The Man in the Middle
description: At times last season, Jets linebacker Sam Cowart recalled, playing defense seemed almost like some kind of maddening, 100-yard-long multiple-choice quiz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COUNES, EDNA PATRICIA KILCOYNE
description: COUNES--Edna Patricia Kilcoyne. On July 9, Of Counes' Restaurant. Condolences to lesliersaul@verizon.net.

title: Art Magazine Aims to Turn Consumers Into Connoisseurs
description: Cond Nast Publications, a company that liked the shopping magazine concept so much it had triplets -- Lucky, Cargo and Domino -- has come up with yet another periodical that will allow readers to obsess over objects. But the new magazine's focus will be on art, not shoes or handbags.

title: Meow Mix is opening a temporary cafe for felines. No dogs allowed. Cat people will understand.
description: THERE was a time not so long ago when New Yorkers complained that Fifth Avenue was going to the dogs. Now, a marketer is hoping to take it in the other direction, animalistically speaking.

description: Nanosys Withdraws Plan for Public Offering

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Bank Restrictions Eased
description: Overseas banks in China will be allowed to open more than one branch a year starting Sept. 1 as the country's banking regulator eases rules to meet China's commitments to the World Trade Organization. Under the new rules, overseas banks who provide yuan-currency services to domestic companies need to have 300 million yuan ($36 million) in operating capital, down from 400 million yuan, the China Banking Regulatory Commission said. Overseas banks providing yuan services to individuals need to have only 500 million yuan in operating capital, down from 600 million yuan, it said.

title: Suit Is Planned Over Policy To Hold 3rd Graders Back
description: The NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund is seeking plaintiffs for a possible lawsuit challenging Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's much-debated new policy to hold back third graders largely on the basis of their standardized test scores.

title: Star-Crossed Young Lovers With No Nurse to Guide Them
description: ''No nurse, no choreography,'' a dancegoer muttered at the Universal Ballet's performance of ''Romeo and Juliet'' on Friday night at the New York State Theater. No dancing was more like it, but that is a problem with most productions of the ballet.

title: Ancient Bird Had a Brain Built for Flight, Research Says
description: Scientists have determined that Archaeopteryx, the earliest known bird, was definitely birdbrained, meaning no disrespect. Indeed, they consider the fossil's brain size decisive evidence that Archaeopteryx had what it took to fly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, ESTELLE (GOTTLIEB)
description: LEWIS -- Estelle (Gottlieb). Died August 3, 2004. Born in Brooklyn in 1905, in her late teens and early twenties, she performed in Broadway musicals. She married the late Joseph Lewis, residing in Philadelphia until her passing at age 99. She had one child, the late Bernard (Buddy). She leaves behind her daughterin-law, Miriam (Mickie), four grandchildren, and six great grandchildren, sisters, Jessie and Shirley, brother, Murray, and brother-in-law, Danny. Her devotion to family was unparalleled. Shirley and Danny Rubin Barbara Miller and family

title: U.S. OPENS EFFORT TO DISRUPT PLOTS BY TERROR GROUP
description: The Bush administration said Wednesday that the United States and its allies had begun a campaign to disrupt terrorist operations around the world, including the arrest of a suspected senior member of Al Qaeda in Britain.

title: Agents Search for Anthrax Clues in New York and New Jersey
description: NEWARK, Aug. 5  Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and inspectors from the United States Postal Service conducted searches in New York and New Jersey today in connection with the 2001 anthrax attacks.

title: Bored With EBay? Try Google's Unusual Auction
description: Maybe you are a fan of Google's search engine. Or you have a few thousand dollars in your portfolio that is looking for a parking place. Or you have always felt left out when corporate bigwigs and their friends and families got in on the ground floor of initial public stock offerings.

title: Giants Hope Umenyiora Can Balance the Defense
description: Hidden in the wreckage of last season, Giants defensive ends Osi Umenyiora and Keith Washington shared a moment they would not forget, an end zone celebration both improbable and symbolic.

title: U.S. Forces Clash With Rebel Cleric's Militia in Najaf
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 5  The radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr called for a national uprising against American and coalition forces today as a two-month truce between Mr. Sadr and the United States military appeared to collapse.

title: Ambitious 'Carmen' In Seville Is Postponed
description: Ambitious plans for an open-air production of Bizet's ''Carmen'' in Seville, Spain, and for a music festival of which it was to be the centerpiece, were postponed indefinitely Wednesday. Organizers said they were unable to find a top-level conductor to replace Lorin Maazel, the music director of the New York Philharmonic, who earlier this week withdrew from the project on medical grounds.

title: Port Authority Director to Retire
description: Joseph J. Seymour said yesterday that he would retire within two months as the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: It's for You
description: At the far fringes of technology and culture -- just around the corner, in other words -- lies the cellphone. New studies suggest that cellphones are altering social behavior in ways that seem counterintuitive. One anthropologist argues that they foster ''hybrid'' interactions in which cellphones stay on when friends are together. It becomes a way of orienting oneself, an added social focus.

title: Restrictions Eased on Trucks Entering Manhattan
description: Three days after sharply increasing security in response to a federal alert about possible terrorist plots, the New York City Police Department last night partly lifted its ban on trucks and vans entering Manhattan.

title: Protesters in Sudan Oppose U.N.'s Demands
description: More than 100,000 people protested Wednesday in Khartoum, the Sudanese capital, against Security Council action on Sudan, but Secretary General Kofi Annan said the world organization would not be deterred from helping to end the violence in the country's western Darfur region.

title: Wal-Mart Is Said to Be in Talks to Settle Illegal-Immigrant Case
description: Seeking to forestall an indictment, Wal-Mart Stores is in settlement talks with federal prosecutors who are investigating whether company officials knew that its janitorial contractors were using illegal immigrants to clean its stores, lawyers close to the case said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Pilot Loses Appeal In Deaths Of Canadians
description: An Illinois National Guard fighter pilot who killed four Canadian soldiers in a mistaken bombing in Afghanistan has lost his appeal of his punishment for dereliction of duty. Gen. Hal Hornburg of the United States Air Force, commander of Air Combat Command in Langley, Va., denied the appeal of the pilot, Maj. Harry Schmidt, above, an Air Combat Command spokeswoman said. Major Schmidt will lose $5,672 in pay and assume a nonflying position. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Federal Jury Deadlocks on Extortion Charge Against North Jersey Businessman
description: After a four-month trial, a federal jury deadlocked Wednesday on an extortion charge against a North Jersey businessman accused of taking payoffs from illegal gambling operations while he was a close political ally of Albio Sires, now the speaker of the General Assembly.

title: Giving Heaps of Humbug A Comedic Heave-Ho
description: Leave it to Penn & Teller to be thinking of the future. Go ahead and have your body cryonically preserved, Penn Jillette says, but even if it turns out that it is possible to thaw and reanimate you decades from now, who do you think is likely to go to all that trouble and expense? ''Some evil scientist looking for untraceable slave labor,'' he suggests.

title: Taming the Rambunctious Garden Hose
description: GARDEN hoses can be unruly, sprawling across patios and crisscrossing lawns. Fortunately, there are new ways to keep them in line, from tidy wall-hung racks to carts on wheels. Some hose keepers stand high, others lie low, and still others have devices that reel in the hose while the gardener watches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEARLMAN, HERBERT M.
description: PEARLMAN--Herbert M. Beloved husband, father and grandfather, entrepreneur, corporate founder and builder, sponsor of medical and educational charities. The very best of men.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERMAN, HARRIET SCHACTER
description: SILVERMAN--Harriet Schacter, 78, of Rye Brook, N.Y., died on August 3, 2004 of cancer. Beloved wife of Harry, widow of the late Philip, mother of Daniel, Kenneth and Jane Schacter, grandmother of Sarah, Brian, Hannah, Emily, Gabriel and Zoe, sister of Sheldon Flanzig and good friend of many. Retired after 20 dedicated years of service as a reading teacher at Yonkers P.S. 28, Harriet was an expert bridge player, having achieved the rank of Silver Life Master. She loved opera, reading, Broadway shows and golf. Most of all, she loved and was completely dedicated to her children and grandchildren. Harriet was always full of life and energy and she will be sorely missed. Services today at 10AM at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, N.Y., 914949-0566, followed by interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, please make memorial donations to the American Diabetes Association.

title: Carnegie Hall Appoints New Executive Director
description: Clive Gillinson, managing director of the London Symphony Orchestra since 1984  and a cellist in the orchestra for 14 years before that  has been appointed executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall. He succeeds Robert J. Harth, who ran the hall from September 2001 until his death, at age 47, on Jan. 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARVER, R. DAVID
description: CARVER--R. David, 70, of Riverdale, NY, died August 3, 2004. Survived by his loving wife Rosemarie, his sons Alexander and Andrew, his daughter Christina Cahill, his son-in-law Brendan Cahill, and his four grandchildren. Also surviving are his beloved step-father, Cornelius Hurlbut, his sister Gay, his brother Douglass, nephews and nieces. Funeral 10AM, August 6 at Christ Church Riverdale, 5030 Henry Hudson Pkwy and W 252 St. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Lawrenceville School, Lawrenceville, NJ.

title: Protect Sharon From the Right
description: Not long ago, at a West Bank settlement outpost surrounded by barbed wire and guarded by dyspeptic German shepherds, I attended a joyful event: a brit milah, the circumcision of an eight-day-old boy. This outpost was home to just a handful of families, but more than 100 people came to celebrate with the boy's parents.

description: Her face grim, 60-year-old Harpal Kaur lay surrounded by neighborhood women, the television tuned to the 24-hour Hindi news channel Aaj Tak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAW, RUTH RYMER
description: SHAW--Ruth Rymer age 45 of Manhattan, died Saturday July 31, 2004 in Hampton Twp., NJ. Graduate of Univ. of NC, and Graduate of the New York University receiving her Masters in Social Work. Employed as Social Worker with N.A.D.A.P. in Brooklyn, NY. Loving Life Partner of Amy Schecter. Caring sister of George Shaw, and friend of many. For information Iliff-Ruggiero Funeral Home, 156 Main Street (Route 206), Newton, NJ 07860. In lieu of flowers memorials to the Nature Conservancy #

title: Israeli Forces Kill 4 Palestinians in Clashes in Gaza

description: A group of Vietnam veterans has bought television time in three swing states for an advertisement that attacks Senator John Kerry, accusing him of lying about his war record, including the circumstances surrounding his medals, and betraying his comrades by later opposing the war.

title: SOUTHWEST PRESIDENT LOSES CHIEF OPERATING OFFICER TITLE
description: Southwest Airlines said yesterday that its president, Colleen C. Barrett, would give up the chief operating officer title, as the new chief executive, Gary C. Kelly, reorganizes management responsibilities. Southwest said that the chief operating officer duties would be split by Jim Wimberly, executive vice president for aircraft operations, and Donna Conover, executive vice president for customer operations, who report to Mr. Kelly. Ms. Barrett, who has been president and chief operating officer since June 2001, said in a statement that she had requested the shift. She will have responsibility for marketing, leadership development, purchasing, communications, labor relations and internal audits.

title: What Spins Around Comes Around; Break Dancing Makes Comeback, and Offers an Escape
description: Melike Jamal McCrimmon wasn't even born when break dancers like Crazy Legs and the Zulu Kings were tearing up the sidewalks and bringing the South Bronx enough glory to briefly eclipse its status as America's showcase for arson, gang warfare and urban despair. Back in the early 1980's, the Grand Concourse buzzed with kids spinning on their heads or popping like robots. Hollywood caught the fever, and even Michael Jackson learned to moonwalk. But by the 1990's, break dance mania had gone the way of disco.

title: Foreigners Shun New York, Keeping Hotel Rates Down
description: More tourists visited New York City last year than any time in recent history, but international visitors continue to shun the city and daily hotel rates remain far below those in 2000, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday.

description: Responding to a request by law enforcement officials, the Federal Communications Commission tentatively concluded Wednesday that new Internet-based telephone services should be subject to some of the same laws that enable the government to monitor conversations of terrorists and criminal suspects with relative ease.

description: Six years ago, 24 mentally ill residents of a Queens adult home were coerced into having prostate surgery in a medical scheme that generated tens of thousands of dollars in government fees and proved emblematic of New York's troubled system of adult homes.

title: NAVY AGREES TO CHANGE CONTRACT WITH ELECTRONIC DATA
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said yesterday that the Navy had agreed to change its $6.9 billion contract to link 300,000 computers, a move that would let the company speed up the elimination of old software. Electronic Data, the second-largest seller of computer services, will be able to move computers from old mainframes onto the company's servers, a spokesman, Kevin Clarke, said. The changes will help Electronic Data accelerate efforts to finish the project, which has so far taken twice as long as expected. Electronic Data, which has spent more than $2.4 billion on the contract since it was awarded in 2000, said yesterday that it had received payments of $1.4 billion from the Navy. Electronic Data is based in Plano, Tex.

title: JAZZ GIFT TO THE LIBRARY
description: The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts will get a collection of some 1,000 recordings from Jazz at Lincoln Center that document performances over 17 years, the library announced yesterday. The recordings, which will be stored in the library's extensive Rodgers and Hammerstein Archives of Recorded Sound, include performances by bedrock jazz stars like Tommy Flanagan, Illinois Jacquet, Dizzy Gillespie, Wayne Shorter, McCoy Tyner and Hank Jones as well as younger players like Brad Mehldau, Dianne Reeves, Stefan Harris, Joshua Redman and of course Wynton Marsalis, the longtime artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center. The arrangement is to include future seasons as well. The recordings will become available to the public over the next two to three years as they are catalogued by the library. The 2003-4 season is available now. BEN SISARIO

title: The Good, the Bad and the Subway
description: The New York City Transit Riders Council, a citizens' oversight group appointed by the governor, conducts a survey of subway conditions from a passenger's perspective. That survey is then compared with the Passenger Environment Survey that New York City Transit uses to evaluate itself.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a campaign appearance by President Bush before a group of cardinals and other Roman Catholic voters in Dallas misstated the middle initial of the archbishop of Washington. He is Cardinal Theodore E. McCarrick, not R.

title: F.A.A. Hopes to Clip Wings At Chicago's Busy O'Hare
description: Mixing threat and persuasion, the Federal Aviation Administration on Wednesday gathered dozens of executives from 15 airlines that fly into O'Hare International Airport and asked them to cut their schedules by about 5 percent to reduce delays so extensive that they ripple from Chicago through the whole country.

title: Blur Fantasy With Reality, And Wrap It in a Puzzle
description: In 2001, an Internet game designed to publicize the movie ''A.I.'' inspired a new genre called Alternate Reality Gaming, or ARG, puzzle-centric interactive fiction that blurs the line between fantasy and reality. Two new ARG's that appeared last month promise to extend the limits of the genre.

description: The International Monetary Fund delayed a $728 million loan payment to Argentina to assess the government's progress in debt restructuring talks and in raising utility rates, the managing director, Rodrigo Rato, said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More French Students At Yeshiva
description: Yeshiva University in Manhattan has admitted 40 students from France for the fall semester, more than double the number it had last year, the university announced. Prompted by reports of growing anti-Semitic activity in France, senior Yeshiva officials visited Jewish communities in Paris, Marseille and Strasbourg to talk about the university and assess the French students' proficiency in Jewish studies and English. They found students who were seeking ''an environment that was supportive and helpful,'' said Dr. John Fisher, director of enrollment management. ''We didn't go out and actively recruit. This was a need conveyed to us. They came to us and we responded.'' Laura Lee (NYT)

title: Reyes Makes Brief Return to Shortstop
description: Jos Reyes was back at shortstop for the Mets on Wednesday night. But before the debate could start over whether Reyes or Kazuo Matsui should be the Mets' regular shortstop, General Manager Jim Duquette and Manager Art Howe matter-of-factly cut off any hint of a controversy. For now.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Group Criticizes Rules On Prisoner Treatment
description: A group including 12 former presidents of the American Bar Association and several former federal judges said the Bush administration lawyers who prepared a series of memorandums that appeared to permit torture of prisoners under certain circumstances had ignored and misinterpreted the Constitution and ''failed to meet their professional obligations.'' The lawyers had ''counseled individuals to ignore the law and offered arguments to minimize their exposure to sanction or liability for doing so,'' the statement said. Neil A. Lewis (NYT)

title: Penalty Deliberations Begin In Case of Slain Informer
description: From a prosecution witness, the jury heard how Diego Rodriguez, a Bronx heroin dealer convicted last week of capital murder, put out a cigarette in the ear of his victim as the man lay hog-tied on the floor of a Bronx apartment.

title: Rio Journal; The Devil Take August. In Brazil, It's Just Too Scary.
description: There is nothing like a Friday the 13th to unnerve people in countries all around the world. But among Brazilians, the entire month of August inspires dread -- and for those who believe that superstition, the auguries this year may be especially unfavorable.

title: Wanted: Architect With 6 Weeks Off And Looking for a Mate
description: Calling all handsome male architects. The New York City chapter of the American Institute of Architects sent its members a notice soliciting architects age 25 to 35 to interview for the third season of ''The Bachelorette,'' which resumes taping in October. Last year, Chris R., 31, a Harvard-educated architect from Miami, was eliminated in the first round by Meredith, 30, a makeup artist and model from Los Angeles.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Pipeline Deal Canceled
description: The PetroChina Company, the largest oil company in China, has canceled an initial agreement with OAO Gazprom, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Exxon Mobil Corporation on taking a stake in China's $5.2 billion pipeline across the nation to Shanghai. The Chinese company informed Gazprom, which is based in Moscow, in a letter that said the talks on a final agreement had been called off, the company said. Shell received a letter about the cancellation on Monday, said Nick Wood, a company spokesman in Beijing. PetroChina completed the main part of the 2,486-mile pipeline, which starts in Xinjiang province, and will begin sending gas on Sept. 1, said the company's parent, the China National Petroleum Corporation.

title: Criticism Starts at Home
description: Wole Soyinka's friends might be forgiven for devoting two weeks to mark his 70th birthday this summer. Mr. Soyinka -- a Nobel laureate in literature as well as a political activist of prodigious energies -- has earned a reputation as the conscience of Nigeria, and in a nation where the average life span is 52, turning 70 is achievement enough. In his case, though, it's nothing short of a miracle.

title: Gloria Emerson, Chronicler of War's Damage, Dies at 75
description: Gloria Emerson, a journalist and author who wrote with angry dignity about the effects of war on Americans, Vietnamese and Palestinians, was found dead by friends and the police yesterday morning in her apartment in Manhattan. She was 75 and left no immediate survivors.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Payment Wanted For U.S. Space Trips
description: The director of Russia's space agency said the United States would have to start paying the cost of ferrying American astronauts to the International Space Station aboard Russian spacecraft, beginning next year. Anatoly N. Perminov, the new director of the perennially short-of-cash agency, complained in remarks reported by Itar-Tass that Russia had shouldered the burden of flights to the station since the Columbia disaster in February 2003 because Russian Soyuz and Progress spacecraft were the only means of taking crews and cargo to the station. Mr. Perminov did not discuss how much NASA would have to pay. Shuttle flights are not scheduled to resume until at least next spring.

title: E*Trade Gives Project To BBDO Worldwide
description: E*Trade Financial yesterday named BBDO Worldwide in New York and its interactive division, Atmosphere BBDO, to handle an assignment in the fourth quarter. Billings for the assignment were not disclosed; E*Trade is expected to spend about $90 million on advertising this year.

title: 12 Killed as Iraqi Police And Rebels Clash in Mosul
description: Fighting flared Wednesday between the Iraqi police and insurgents in Mosul, killing at least 12 people, wounding dozens more and prompting city authorities to impose a curfew to restore order, city officials said.

title: World Juniors Play in Nyack And Get to See A Vise in Use
description: Young enthusiasts from about 20 countries gathered in Nyack, N.Y., last month for the World Junior Camp. The emphasis was on collegiality, but there was some vice; or perhaps vise. The diagramed deal, noted by Barry Rigal during the Swiss Team Championship, illustrates the point.

description: Credit Suisse reported on Wednesday that second-quarter earnings were slightly better than expected, but its Credit Suisse First Boston investment banking unit showed it was in need of a turnaround.

description: Alex Rodriguez limped around the batting cage before last night's game, not even sure he would play for the Yankees against the Oakland Athletics. Rodriguez had been hit by a pitch below his left knee the night before, and icing the knee overnight had not helped.

description: An article on Monday about the closing of a 50-mile stretch of the Erie Canal because of flooding in central New York referred incorrectly in some copies to its normal depth in that section. It is 12 feet, not 374.5.

title: Illinois G.O.P. Finally Picks A Candidate
description: More than a month after Jack Ryan backed out of the Senate race because of an embarrassing sex scandal, the Illinois Republican Party -- after courting people like a former professional football coach and a regional radio personality -- has settled on a replacement, the former presidential hopeful Alan Keyes.

title: Gehry and M.I.T.: Click and Drive
description: Even steering wheels could become obsolete in the new concept car, above, proposed by researchers at the Media Lab at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in consultation with the architect Frank Gehry and General Motors. The team was led by Ryan Chin, a doctoral candidate in the media arts and sciences program, and William J. Mitchell, a professor of media arts and sciences. The car has casterlike wheels that would enable ''smart'' parallel parking. On-board transponders would find parking spaces. Thin-film display coatings on the exterior could show messages. And steering could be done by remote control, giving new meaning to the phrase ''I'll drive you to school.'' Mr. Chin said he hopes to build a prototype by 2006. BRADFORD McKEE

title: FINANCE EXECUTIVE RESIGNS AT CHARTER COMMUNICATIONS
description: Charter Communications Inc., the cable-television operator, said yesterday that its chief financial officer, Michael P. Huseby, had resigned to join the Cablevision Systems Corporation. Mr. Huseby will leave on Aug. 20, after less than nine months on the job, Charter said. The company, based in St. Louis, has not named a successor. A Charter spokesman said he did not have additional information on why Mr. Huseby quit. Mr. Huseby was one of several executives hired in the last year to take over for four who quit or were fired after an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into the company's accounting. Charter said last month that the commission had ended that inquiry.

description: The Russian government, preparing to auction its 7.6 percent stake in the oil company Lukoil, set a minimum price on Wednesday of $1.26 billion for its shares in the business, whose proven reserves are second only to those of Exxon Mobil.

The award, $250,000, came from the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, not from New York's Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

title: A's Finally Got It Right: Chavez Didn't Get Away
description: Eric Chavez made it to the major leagues as a 20-year-old third baseman with Oakland in 1998, and he is signed to a contract that will keep him with the Athletics until at least age 32. Chavez's stability with the A's is rare in a financially challenged organization, where premier players often leave for richer pastures and the A's cringe and shrug.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Official To Advise Union On Schools
description: The departing director of charter schools for the city's Department of Education has agreed to help the teachers' union create its own charter school, Randi Weingarten, the union president, said yesterday. Jonathan Gyurko, a leader in the department's efforts to create charter schools, announced recently that he was stepping down. In a statement, Ms. Weingarten said that Mr. Gyurko would coordinate the union's ''efforts to explore the pros, cons and options in attempting to create and run'' its own charter school. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEID, CLARENCE
description: SEID--Clarence, 96, of Middletown, N.Y. on August 1, 2004 in Boca Raton, Florida. Beloved husband of Florence for 70 years. Loving father of Jane Chaves and Carol Seid. Cherished grandfather of Susan Chaves Zucker and her husband Scott; Mark Chaves and his wife Kim. Proud and caring great grandfather of Jeri and Brian Zucker, Evan and Allison Chaves. He was a remarkable man in love with life. He was a devoted advocate and proponent of the law, an avid Ham Radio Operator, President of the QCWA and was known around the world as W2KW for 83 years. Family and friends mourn the loss of this unique and multi-faceted man. Please honor Clarence's memory with a memorial contribution to a charity of your choice.

title: Univision Profit Up 63%
description: The Univision Communications Corporation, the largest Spanish-language television and radio broadcaster in the nation, said second-quarter profit rose 63 percent because it sold more advertising.

title: 'The Rock' celebrates as Spain seethes
description: GIBRALTAR:  "The Rock" celebrated the 300th anniversary Wednesday of its capture by British forces, escalating tensions that have been building all summer between Spain and Britain over control of the territory.

title: Corrections
description: The Side Effects column in Science Times on Tuesday, about the sociology of beaches, misstated the authorship of the song ''Just a Wave.'' While indeed recorded by Jimmie Dale Gilmore, it was written by Butch Hancock.

title: DEAN FOODS WILL COMBINE 3 BUSINESSES TO REDUCE COSTS
description: The Dean Foods Company said yesterday that it would consolidate three businesses -- the Dean National Brand Group, White Wave and Horizon Organic -- in a move to reduce costs. The combined businesses, which will produce about 10 percent of an expected $10.5 billion in total sales this year, will be based near Boulder, Colo. Dean Foods, based in Dallas, is trying to streamline its business, eliminating a structure that includes three sales forces and three supply chains, the chief executive, Gregg L. Engles, said in a statement. Steve Demos, founder and president of White Wave, will be president of the new operation. The consolidated group's brands will include Silk soy milk, Horizon Organic foods and Marie's salad dressings. Dean Foods also reported that second-quarter profit fell 8 percent as raw milk prices rose 87 percent.

title: Sports of The Times; Not What the N.B.A. Had in Mind
description: THE commissioner of the N.B.A. must be a little restless when his cast of Olympic superstars -- O.K., pro replacement players -- feels compelled to celebrate a must-win exhibition game against Germany yesterday like Y.M.C.A. league champs.

title: Using Trade Pacts to Stem Loss of TV and Film Jobs to Canada
description: Out-of-work film technicians those actors, prop men and other entertainment industry workers whose names unfurl on the screen as moviegoers scramble out of the theater -- are rallying behind international trade rules to stem the flow of film and television production to Canada.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Aid Workers Killed In Ambush
description: Two Afghan workers for the Malteser Germany aid group were shot and killed on a road southeast of Kabul, a spokesman for the United Nations refugee agency said. The two were traveling south of Gardez on a mission for the United Nations on Tuesday when their car was ambushed. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Group Plans Illegal Protests On 2nd Day Of Convention
description: Members of a group opposed to the Republican National Convention, many describing themselves as anarchists, said yesterday that they would carry out illegal protest activities on the convention's second day.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Security Strike Continues
description: Negotiations to end a week-old dispute between management and truck drivers at Brinks Allied, an armored delivery company, collapsed in a disagreement over security procedures, resulting in the continuation of a strike that left 70 percent of A.T.M.'s along the east coast of Ireland, including Dublin, empty during a busy holiday weekend. Machines in bank branches are expected to run out of cash by Friday. Armored trucks are a frequent target of robbers, and drivers at Brinks objected to a new requirement that they drive away from a robbery even if it means leaving a colleague behind. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Ruling Upheld
description: A Tokyo court upheld its order that UFJ Holdings cease part of its takeover talks with the Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group, a move that seems likely to complicate negotiations aimed at creating the world's largest bank. The decision was a response to an appeal by UFJ to the Tokyo District Court after the court ordered UFJ to exclude its trust bank unit from the talks. The court said the negotiations violated an earlier agreement UFJ made to sell its trust business to another bank. UFJ said it was planning to appeal the decision and would continue negotiations with Mitsubishi. Todd Zaun (NYT)

description: MOSCOW, Aug. 5 - Crude oil prices hit all-time highs today - $44.50 a barrel at one point on the New York market - amid conflicting signals from Russia about the oil giant Yukos.

title: A Turkish Architect Conquers London
description: The Turkish architect Ferhan Azman, 42, above, is making a splash in London. Among her credits are the first flagship store for Alexander McQueen, the redo of the fashion stylist Isabella Blow's house (with an all-glass bathtub) and the recent design of a Vivienne Westwood exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum. Her concrete, timber and glass house, above left, won an award from the Royal Institute of British Architects last year. Next up, ''Communicate,'' a show of British graphic design, opening on Sept. 16 at the Barbican Art Gallery; www.azmanassociates.com. MALLERY ROBERTS LANE

title: Nanosys Calls Off Initial Public Offering
description: Nanosys, the leading symbol of nanotechnology's promise to generate lucrative innovations by manipulating atoms and molecules, yesterday called off a closely watched effort to go public long before it had any products to sell.

title: The Terror Alerts
description: Our lives have changed so much since Sept. 11, 2001. We know that we may never again be free of the threat of terrorism. It's been a tough adjustment for everyone, and the burden on President Bush is especially heavy. Given the unprecedented circumstances and the costs of making a mistake, it's easy to understand why the administration has had so much trouble managing the way it informs the public about potential danger. But after 17 months in which alerts blinked from yellow to orange and back a half-dozen times, the White House should be past its learning curve. It isn't. The events of this week showed starkly that the system is not working.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Telstra To Buy Half Of Wireless Network
description: The Telstra Corporation, Australia's largest phone company, agreed to buy half of the nation's only high-speed wireless network from a company controlled by the billionaire Li Ka-shing to enter the market ahead of its nearest rivals. Telstra will buy the 50 percent stake for 450 million Australian dollars ($317 million) from Mr. Li's Hutchison 3G Australia. Both will operate competing services using the network, the companies said yesterday. Telstra's chief executive, Ziggy Switkowski, aims to lift its mobile-phone market share by offering services that allow users to make video calls before its rivals, SingTel Optus and the Vodafone Group, offer them. Mr. Li is selling assets after his third-generation networks worldwide posted a $2.3 billion annual loss before tax and interest.

title: Entr'acte : For Olympics, Greeks already lose one contest
description: LONDON  All being well, everything  at least almost everything  should be ready for the opening of the Olympic Games in Athens late next week. Yet one crucial Greek dream for 2004 will not be fulfilled. Greece had hoped to recover the magnificent 2,500-year-old sculptures known as the Elgin marbles, which were ripped from the Parthenon early in the 19th century. Instead, they remain in the British Museum. And for the foreseeable future, that is where they will stay.

title: 1929:Immigration Scam : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: WARSAW: Polish police are believed to have discovered and frustrated further exploitation of a clever scheme for the wholesale violation of the United States immigration laws with the arrest here today [Aug. 4] of Rabbi Mendel Kastenberg and the magistrate of Wawer, a small village near here. The two are charged with co-operating with one Morris Baskin, an alleged citizen of the United States. According to their story Baskin sought out sixty-two girls whose sweethearts were known to be living in America. Baskin then induced the rabbi to marry him to each of the sixty-two before the Wawer magistrate, thus enabling him to secure American visas for them as wives.

title: MANUSCRIPT THEFT
description: In a case that has stunned France's cultural world, the curator in chief of manuscripts in the French National Library has been accused of stealing and selling ancient Hebrew manuscripts. Appearing before an investigating magistrate on Friday, the curator, Michel Garel, 56, admitted stealing only one 16th-century religious manuscript, which was sold for $300,000 at Christie's in New York in 2000. He also acknowledged falsifying a document authorizing the manuscript to leave France. But the French daily Libration quoted investigators as saying that as many as 100 manuscripts may have been stolen. Officials at the library said that while they were aware of many missing documents and books, an anonymous letter tipped them off to Mr. Garel's alleged involvement. Mr. Garel, who joined the library in 1976, was arrested in his office last Thursday and released on Friday after he was formally charged. Officials said the investigation was continuing. ALAN RIDING

title: MARATHON AND HESS FACE INQUIRY INTO AFRICAN DEALINGS
description: The Marathon Oil Corporation and the Amerada Hess Corporation said the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating their payments to the government of Equatorial Guinea. The companies are cooperating with the S.E.C., spokesmen for Marathon and Hess said separately. The inquiry follows a Senate subcommittee's report issued last month on financial dealings between the Riggs National Corporation and foreign governments. Marathon, which produces natural gas off the coast of Equatorial Guinea and owns part of a methanol plant there, has paid or agreed to pay the West African country's president, Teodoro Obiang, more than $2 million to buy land to expand operations, the Senate report said. It said Hess paid officials of Equatorial Guinea almost $1 million for building leases. Of 28 leases Hess identified, 18 were with people ''connected to the government or the Obiang family,'' the report said.
