To compensate for the headache of ownership, you need not only a large garage (or small museum) and a mechanic within a day's drive -- but easy access to an underpatrolled road where on a few weekends a year you can amortize the anxiety. Gazing at exquisiteness from afar will do nicely for most of us, especially when the objects of our desires are so far out of reach that we wouldn't know what to do with them even if we got them.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Posts A Profit
description: The German bank, the HVB Group, reported a second consecutive quarterly profit as it sold assets and set aside less money for doubtful loans. Net income was 155 million euros ($187 million) in the second quarter, in contrast to a 217 million euro loss a year earlier. HVB booked a 120 million euro gain from selling stakes in a brewer and a utility company. The chief executive, Dieter Rampl, above, said that he expected profit to reach the lower end of the company's range for 2004, and that the higher end of the range was ''out of reach.'' The company previously forecast an operating profit of 1.4 billion euros to 1.7 billion euros in 2004.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Mount Holly: Flood Damage Prompts Suit
description: A group of Burlington County residents has filed a lawsuit against four municipalities, the county, the state and some private dam owners over damage to homes in recent flooding, the plaintiffs' lawyer said yesterday. The lawyer, Edward R. Petkevis, filed the suit on Tuesday in State Superior Court seeking unspecified damages, claiming failure to properly maintain dams and properly classify them. A storm in mid-July dumped more than 13 inches of rain on the area, caused a dozen dams to break, forced the evacuation of more than 750 people and caused millions of dollars in damage. The municipalities named in the suit are the townships of Evesham, Medford and Tabernacle and the borough of Medford Lakes. John Holl (NYT)

title: The Jade of China, Alive With Meaning Yet Glossily Elusive
description: A book called ''A Treatise on Superfluous Things'' was a manual of style for climbers in the courts of the Ming dynasty. It skipped over the basics that everyone knew -- you should be nice to your parents; only emperors wear yellow -- to give tips on fine points of discrimination in luxury items. Jade is among the materials discussed. And at first glance, ''superfluous'' seems just the word for the preposterously exquisite jade objects, from scepters to table screens to paperweights, on display in the Metropolitan Museum of Art's reinstalled galleries for Chinese decorative arts.

title: Very Different Birds of a Feather
description: At 5:20 p.m., the red-clad residents of this baseball capital turn toward the batting cage at Busch Stadium and behold the faces of the game.

title: City Seeks To Limit Its Liability In Ferry Crash
description: As Patrick Ryan, New York City's former director of ferry operations, stood before a magistrate in Federal District Court yesterday to be arraigned on charges of seaman's manslaughter, a lawyer being paid by the city stood at his side.

title: City Condenses Locations for 2012 Olympic Bid
description: The Bloomberg administration has made a final revision of its 2012 Olympic bid, tightening the area through which athletes would have to travel and moving a few of the sporting sites to better please the International Olympic Committee.

title: CHARTER COMMUNICATIONS SETTLES SHAREHOLDER SUITS
description: Charter Communications Inc., the cable television operator, said that it had agreed to a $144 million settlement of shareholder lawsuits over its accounting practices. Charter, based in St. Louis, said it would pay $64 million in cash and the remainder in equity to settle the lawsuits. The $64 million cash portion of the settlement will be covered by insurance, the company said. Charter, controlled by the billionaire Paul Allen, last week settled a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into how it counted subscribers. The company did not admit wrongdoing and agreed not to violate securities laws.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Sandy Hook: More Beaches Closing
description: Because of pollution caused in part by heavy rains, New Jersey experienced a significant increase in the number of beach closings last summer, and is likely to have a record number this year, according to a report released yesterday by Clean Ocean Action, an environmental group based at Sandy Hook. The information, in a broader report prepared by the Natural Resources Defense Council, said that last summer, 188 ocean and bay beaches were closed because of pollution and runoff, compared with 31 the previous summer. The report said that 43 ocean beaches and 66 bay beaches had been closed so far this summer. Karen DeMasters (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Keyes Considers Senate Race
description: Alan Keyes, the state Republican Party's latest choice to run for the Senate, said he needed time to contemplate the offer and would not make his announcement until Sunday. If he accepts, Mr. Keyes, left, a former presidential candidate who lives in Maryland, would campaign against the Democratic nominee, Barack Obama, a relatively unknown state senator who made headlines last week after delivering the keynote speech at the Democratic National Convention in Boston. Mr. Keyes, who now spends his time lecturing and writing, was chosen more than a month after Jack Ryan dropped out of the race. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: The Hamptons, A Playground For Creativity
description: ''North Fork/South Fork: East End Art Now,'' an exhibition at the Parrish Art Museum here, celebrates artists who reside seasonally or permanently in the area around what is popularly known as the Hamptons. Organized by the Parrish's curator, Alicia Longwell, with help from the independent curator and critic Klaus Kertess, this uneven but pleasantly innocuous show includes many well-known figures: Ross Bleckner, John Chamberlain, Chuck Close, Eric Fischl, Barbara Kruger and David Salle, among others.

title: Leaving His Past Behind (Electronically)
description: Batting the lashes of her large, vacant eyes and sucking her lower lip into a pout, Brittany Murphy suggests a dumbed-down Meg Ryan with a gloss of Melanie Griffith in the sweet but mostly sour comedy ''Little Black Book.'' The movie, which opens nationally today, aspires to be a dewy-eyed self-help fable for ambitious young women folded into a mean-spirited satire of Jerry Springer-style reality television.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Bankers To Testify
description: The central bank president, Henrique Meirelles, and the president of the government-run Banco do Brasil, Cssio Casseb, have been called to testify before a Senate committee over charges of tax fraud. Both officials have come under scrutiny in recent weeks after local newsmagazines published articles claiming they evaded taxes before assuming their posts in early 2003. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Killers Get Life Sentences, In Setback to Justice Dept.
description: A federal jury, after deliberating for only two hours, unanimously rejected the death penalty yesterday for two Bronx heroin dealers convicted of murder, handing a setback to Attorney General John Ashcroft's efforts to expand the application of capital punishment in the New York region.

title: Mets Revive, but Cardinals Await
description: The Mets may be ready to claim a revival of their season, having completed a three-game sweep of the Milwaukee Brewers on Thursday as David Wright had a big day at the plate and Victor Zambrano pitched into the sixth inning in his debut for the team. But a far tougher test awaits this weekend in St. Louis when they face the Cardinals, who have been the class of the National League this season.

title: In Midsummer Heat, It's Already Schooltime for Many
description: A cricket lurked in the halls of the West Jackson Primary School in Braselton, a fast suburbanizing rural town 50 miles north of Atlanta. Outside, a listless American flag hung under the fat orange sun of another steamy day. Highway 53 was choked with Jeeps and vans and pickups delivering 500 4-to-7-year-olds in new sneakers and backpacks.

title: Spacecraft Finds Belt Around Saturn Unlike Any Ever Seen Before
description: In its first month orbiting Saturn, the Cassini spacecraft has detected a new radiation belt in an unexpected place, its invisible swarm of trapped high-energy particles circling the planet inside the inner edge of Saturn's signature disk of luminous rings.

title: MEADWESTVACO WILL ELIMINATE 600 JOBS TO CUT COSTS
description: The MeadWestvaco Corporation, the maker of Five Star notebooks, said it would eliminate about 600 jobs as it consolidated its consumer and office products operations to cut costs. About 400 positions will be lost with the closure of a plant in St. Joseph, Mo., while 200 more will be eliminated when a factory in Garland, Tex., is shut, MeadWestvaco said in a statement. Both plants make office and school supplies including spiral-bound notebooks and envelopes. The move will result in a pretax charge of $45 million to $50 million.

title: Senator Is Described as a Likely Source of Intelligence Leak
description: A two-year investigation into how the news media obtained classified intercepted messages has found that Senator Richard C. Shelby, the Alabama Republican and former chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, was almost certainly a source, a government official familiar with the inquiry said Thursday.

description: Correction Appended

title: India's Economic Growth Is Expected to Slow
description: After last year's spectacular economic performance, India's growth this year will probably be trimmed by lofty oil prices and a stop-and-go monsoon that has taken rainfall to both extremes.

description: Britain aside, the response in Europe to the latest announcement of terror threats in the United States has ranged from official calm to unofficial cynicism.

title: A Future More Nasty, Because It's So Near
description: It has long been axiomatic that speculative science-fiction visions of the future must reflect the anxieties of the present: fears of technology gone awry, of repressive political authority and of the erosion of individuality and human freedom. Often these worries are expressed, and to some extent mitigated, by means of extravagant visual fantasies that picture a world of gleaming, high-rise cities, flying cars and soulful robots.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Telecom Profit Falls
description: Singapore Telecommunications said its profit fell 42 percent to 700 million Singapore dollars ($406 million) in the first quarter but income from continuing operations rose 16 percent, led by strong growth at Optus, its Australian cellphone subsidiary, and contributions from other subsidiaries. The decline in net income resulted from a one-time gain in the year-earlier period of 703 million Singapore dollars from the sale of assets. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Accounts
description: Conversion Van Marketing Association, a new group of 24 companies financed by General Motors, to the Detroit and Wenham, Mass., offices of Mullen, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $12 million to $15 million. Mullen, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, will handle tasks including advertising, interactive marketing, public relations and events.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FIORILLO, ALBERT L., JR.
description: FIORILLO--Albert L., Jr. of New York City on August 4, 2004, after a long illness. A respected conductor. A kind human being. He enriched the lives of so many Americans by bringing classic Broadway musicals to all America for more than 30 years. As music director and conductor of the Papermill Playhouse, NJ for almost a decade, as conductor of the national companies of ''My Fair Lady'', ''A Chorus Line'', and countless other Broadway classics, Albert was truly a part of musical America. The devoted son of the late Judge Albert and Bertha Fiorillo, loving brother of Alberta and Frances, brothers-in-law Edmund and Ed; adoring uncle of Amy, Judith, and Laurie; proud granduncle of Ava, Charlotte, Henry and Augustus; and dear friend of Alphonse, John, Lynne, Marcia, and Susan. The funeral will be private. A memorial gathering to honor Albert will be announced shortly.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Fiscal Law Passes
description: Argentina's lower house of Congress passed a long-sought fiscal responsibility bill, putting the legislation one step from becoming law and meeting a crucial demand to get fresh financing from the International Monetary Fund. The bill, which was already approved by the Senate, must now be signed by President Nstor Kirchner to become law. The legislation conditions increases in federal and provincial spending to economic growth. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Weekender | Fair Harbor, N.Y.
description: FAIR HARBOR is an unintentionally appropriate name for this small Fire Island community. Really, the harbor could only be considered fair, with just a few slips for boats, a ferry dock, and ragtag sailboats pulled up on the beach. But it's a prettier name than Lot 6, as this charming community was first designated in the late 1800's. Later, in 1923, a seafaring developer and his partner turned the land into a housing development for the working people of Bay Shore, the town just across the Great South Bay that separates Fire Island from Long Island.

Born in Pottsville, PA, son of Joseph and Clara Hornung, he worked for many years in New York City for the U.S. Rubber Company and later in concert management. He is survived by siblings Charles and Sister Florecita, nieces and nephews and their children, and by devoted friends, including Michael Sweeley, his partner of 54 years.

Beloved wife of Rodger, Sr. Loving mother of Mark and Rodger, Jr. and mother-in-law of Josephine and Patricia. Cherished daughter of the late Grace and Dominick Serini. Devoted grandmother of Emily, Julia and Madison. Dear sister of Rosemarie Savino. Reposing at Andrew Torregrossa & Sons, 1305 79th Street, Brooklyn, NY. Funeral Mass Monday 9:30AM at St. Bernadette RC Church. Entombment, Greenwood Cemetery. Visitation Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

title: Penalties for Nursing Homes Show a Drop in Last 4 Years
description: New government statistics show a significant decline in the number of penalties imposed on nursing homes for violations of federal health and safety standards in the last four years, even though federal officials and independent experts agree that many homes still have serious deficiencies in the quality of care.

title: Hanging With Sharks, Real Sharks
description: In ''Open Water,'' a low-budget, digital-video feature, a vacationing couple spend many hours stranded in the middle of the ocean hoping not to be eaten by sharks. The film, written and directed by Chris Kentis and produced by his wife, Laura Lau, is a minimalist thriller, made without special effects, animatronic monsters or histrionically suffering movie stars. The sharks, whose fins occasionally pierce the surface of the water and whose implacable bodies are glimpsed gliding beneath it, are real. They show no particular hostility toward Susan (Blanchard Ryan) and Daniel (Daniel Travis), even as lunchtime passes and the dinner hour approaches. Susan and Daniel, meanwhile, drift from stoicism to panic toward exhaustion as the tropical sea ripples around them.

description: The initial public offering of Tata Consultancy Services, a software services outsourcing company, was more than six times oversubscribed. Bids for more than 330 million shares were received for the 55 million shares available. Tata was selling a stake of about 13 percent of the company, hoping to raise about $1.1 billion. description: Barns and houses may not, strictly speaking, be antiques, but the examples on the Peconic Land Trust's farm tour on Sunday in Bridgehampton, N.Y., are all more than a hundred years old and shouldn't be missed. They are part of the real and rarely seen Hamptons.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Microsoft And Verizon Wireless Plan Venture
description: Microsoft, which is expanding its MSN Internet offerings to attract paying customers, will work with Verizon Wireless to sell an instant messaging and e-mail service on mobile phones. MSN Mobile will be available on three phones with Verizon's Get It Now technology for $2.49 a month for three months and $2.99 after that. Users can communicate with computers and cellphones using MSN's free Hotmail e-mail and MSN Messenger instant messaging programs, Microsoft said yesterday. Microsoft and Verizon, the nation's largest mobile phone operator, aim to increase sales by attracting customers who are buying Internet- and camera-enabled phones. The number of worldwide customers using mobile phones once a week for tasks other than phone calls will quadruple in the next year, according to the researcher, A.T. Kearney.

title: Officer Played 'Religion Card' After Nonarrest, City Says

title: No Television. No Phones. No Complaints.
description: KITTEE CUSTER is no stranger to roughing it. Yet her bones occasionally remind her that there are times when the choice of camping with a large rock for a pillow or settling into a snug backcountry cabin is really no choice at all. ''I have aches and pains,'' says Ms. Custer, a divorce and criminal-defense lawyer from Milton-Freewater, Ore., who gives her age as ''50-ish.'' ''Sleeping on an air mattress, which I require when I sleep on the ground, is great -- unless it springs a leak.''

title: Washington's Gift to Bomb Makers
description: There is no bigger and more urgent threat to the security of every American than the possibility of nuclear bomb materials falling into the wrong hands. That is why it is astonishing, and frightening, that the Bush administration is now pushing to strip the teeth from a proposed new treaty aimed at expanding the current international bans on the production of weapons-grade uranium and plutonium. With talks on the new treaty set to begin later this year, the administration suddenly announced last week that it would insist that no provisions for inspections or verification be included.

description: George Francis Kugler Jr., a prominent New Jersey lawyer who was the state's attorney general under Gov. William T. Cahill in the 1970's, died on Sunday at a hospital in Berlin, N.J. He was 79 and lived in Cherry Hill.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Helicopter Crash Kills 15
description: A Russian helicopter carrying forestry workers crashed in western Siberia, killing at least 15 people on aboard in the latest of a series of accidents involving Russian aircraft, according to news reports. The helicopter, an MI-8 traveling with another to survey forests, reported engine problems before plunging to the ground in the remote Tyumen region, not far from the Arctic Circle, where helicopters are the primary means of travel. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

description: Citing poor ticket sales during the week of the Republican National Convention, two more Broadway shows have announced that they will close to avoid a dismal week of business.

description: Two companies that measure television audiences abroad said yesterday that they would form a joint venture to offer ratings in 30 countries outside the United States. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Cardinal Law Leads Mass In Rome
description: Cardinal Bernard F. Law, who was forced to resign as leader of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston in 2002 after a long sexual abuse scandal involving clergy members, celebrated his first public Mass since becoming the head of Santa Maria Maggiore's Basilica in Rome, one of four basilicas under direct Vatican jurisdiction. He was appointed to the post by Pope John II in May, just days after the Boston diocese said it would lose dozens of parishes because of lighter collection plates and costly lawsuits resulting from the scandal. ''I thank God for the faith of the people who are here'' Cardinal Law, 72, in white robes and a golden miter, told reporters. He described the packed Mass, for the feast day of the basilica, as ''a very moving experience for me.'' Jason Horowitz (NYT)

Movable feasts for the globe-hopping professional art class and speculative boons to high-brow tourism, they are more or less well-made theatricals with limited runs, attended mostly by the party faithful. title: Technology Briefing | Software: Pixar Posts Large Profit Increase
description: Pixar Animation Studios, which plans to end its film distribution deal with the Walt Disney Company in 2005, said yesterday that second-quarter profit rose 91 percent because customers bought more home videos of ''Finding Nemo'' than it had expected. Net income rose to $37.4 million, or 63 cents a share, from $19.5 million, or 34 cents, a year earlier, Pixar said. Shares of Pixar rose in extended trading. Pixar's chief executive, Steven Jobs, is in talks with other Hollywood studios to distribute computer-animated films for the company, which is based in Emeryville, Calif. Pixar was expected to earn 37 cents a share, the average estimate of 15 analysts polled by Thomson Financial. The company was expected to have sales of $48.4 million. The company said in May that it expected second-quarter profit of about 30 cents a share. Pixar's sales rose 36 percent to $66.3 million from $48.9 million. Pixar shares rose $1.75, to $67.75 in after-hours trading. In regular trading, they fell $2.46, to $66.

title: A Hairdresser From Hell With a Scissorlike Tongue
description: Jill, a vampiric hairdresser, sees opportunity in her husband's cancer. She buys him a book called ''Your Journey to Death'' while picking up ''Your Whole Life Ahead of You'' for herself. She makes sure he knows the difference. And then she tells everyone he's dead.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Architect For Terminal Is Named
description: An $850 million, 26-gate JetBlue Airways terminal at Kennedy International Airport is to be designed by the architectural firm Gensler, with engineering by Ammann & Whitney and Arup. A development agreement between JetBlue and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was approved on Wednesday by the Port Authority's board. The new Y-shaped metal-and-glass building, Terminal 5, is to open in 2008. It will be connected to the former Trans World Airlines Flight Center, designed by Eero Saarinen. Gensler said the low profile of its design "creates a respectful background" for the birdlike concrete forms of the T.W.A. building, an architectural landmark that opened in 1962 and closed in 2001. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: Killer in a Cab, Doing His Job
description: IN ''Collateral,'' the edgy new thriller from the director Michael Mann, the city never sleeps; it doesn't even relax. Set in Los Angeles mostly after dark, after the city's sunshine has given way to cool noir, the story centers on a taxi driver, Max (Jamie Foxx), and the assassin Vincent (Tom Cruise), who hops a ride with him deep into the night. As the pair cover the city, looping over interchanges and down wide open boulevards, they travel a landscape alive with wild animals and wilder men, noisy with unfamiliar music and chatter, and punctured by the hard pop of occasional gunfire.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Budget Deficit Figure Revised
description: The Congressional Budget Office revised its forecast of the federal budget deficit, saying it would reach $422 billion for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, lower than its March forecast of $477 billion, because tax receipts improved. The office's new projected deficit is still larger than the record $374 billion budget gap set last year. The White House last week revised its forecast to $445 billion from a February projection of $521 billion.

As facilitator in the often rocky negotiations that also include North and South Korea, Russia, Japan and the United States, China appears to be taking a decisive -- if typically understated -- diplomatic initiative in smoothing communications between North Korea and the United States.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Profit At Finance Concern
description: The insurance and banking concern ING reported a second-quarter net income of 1.64 billion euros ($1.97 billion), 12 percent less than the comparable period a year earlier but more than analysts had forecast. The year-earlier income included a one-time gain of 697 million euros. Several divisions did well in the second quarter. Operating profit at its banking division rose 65 percent, to 670 million euros, and profit at its insurance unit rose 23 percent, to 935 million euros. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

Five soldiers, also from the same heavily guarded security camp in Srinagar, the state's summer capital, were killed in a similar attack last week. A little known militant group called Al Mansoorian, believed to be a cover for a banned Pakistan-based Islamic militant group, Lashkar-e-Taiba, claimed responsibility for the attack. The collapse of a section of the terminal's distinctively designed boarding hall killed four people, and other parts of the building, including the registration area and a shopping arcade, have been closed since then. Six Air France flights will use the undamaged portions of the building on Aug. 17, and other flights are expected to use the terminal in the weeks following in order to ease congestion elsewhere in the airport. A federal judge in Wilmington, Del., said a patent owned by Novo was invalid because of the company's errors in the application process, Teva and Savient said in a statement. Savient sells the hormone in 30 countries and licenses Teva to sell it in the United States under the name Tev-Tropin. Savient is based in East Brunswick, N.J., Teva is based in Israel, and Novo is based in Denmark.

title: 36 Hours | Portsmouth, N.H.
description: DRIVING into town along Market Street, it is hard to miss the fact that Portsmouth is still a working deep-water port, with scrap metal (and other goods) going out, and salt for New England roads (and other goods) coming in. Yet, beyond the state-owned Port of New Hampshire, Market Street leads to a charming downtown filled with eccentric and upscale galleries, restaurants and bars. That's the Portsmouth paradox: It's a seacoast town without a beach, an escapist retreat with a decidedly real-world spin. Settled in 1623, Portsmouth grew to importance as a shipbuilding center making wood-masted ships for the King's Navy. Four fires in the first half of the 1800's led the residents to build with brick, creating a legacy of remarkable 19th-century city architecture. For most people heading north to Maine, Portsmouth is simply an exit off Interstate 95. But anyone who takes the time to stop and explore will undoubtedly be charmed by this working-class town that has expanded to comfortably include cozy inns, unusual boutiques and a stylish vacation attitude. DAVID A. KELLY

title: CHECKPOINT AND ID SECURITY SYSTEMS SETTLE ANTITRUST SUIT

Checkpoint said it would take a charge of $14.87 million in the second quarter, which ended June 27. As a result, the company, based in Thorofare, N.J., recorded a loss of $6.44 million, or 17 cents a share, compared with profit of $8.43 million, or 22 cents a share, for the quarter a year earlier. ID Security Systems won an $79 million verdict against Checkpoint in 2002 after a jury found Checkpoint liable for antitrust violations and unfair competition. Carlyle's Asian advisory board, on which Mr. Major served, was disbanded in February, prompting the departure of the former Philippine president, Fidel Ramos, and the former Thai prime minister, Anand Panyarachun.

title: ENRON SEEKS TO BLOCK FEDERAL PENSION FUND TAKEOVER
description: The Enron Corporation has asked the court overseeing its bankruptcy case to block efforts by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation to take over four of the company's retirement plans. In court papers filed Wednesday, Enron accused the agency of frustrating its reorganization efforts and usurping the bankruptcy court's authority to consider claims against the company. The pension agency's objection to Enron's reorganization plan was overruled by the bankruptcy court, and the plan was confirmed on July 15. The pension agency is trying to proceed with an action it filed June 3 in the federal court in Houston to terminate the four underfunded pension plans. Separately, a former Enron trading executive pleaded guilty yesterday to charges he manipulated energy markets during California's power crisis in 2001. John Forney, 42, is the third Enron executive to plead guilty to manipulating electricity prices from the company's trading office in Portland, Ore., which is now defunct. Mr. Forney, the former manager of Enron's trading desk, faces up to five years in prison for one count of wire fraud. A sentencing date has not been scheduled.

description: One line among the transactions stoked the debate, as if it needed further stoking. Just days after the Mets traded their most promising pitching prospect, a young left-hander with an overpowering fastball, a former Mets left-hander who turned into another disappointment was pulling himself off the scrap heap.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Memories are tricky, and restaurant memories are among the trickiest of all. Many years pass, and what stays with you hinges as much on who you were as on what you ate. On what you brought to the experience as on what it gave you.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit For Telecom Company
description: The telecommunications company Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation said that first-quarter net profit was on target at 186 billion yen ($1.66 billion), but the year ahead would be difficult because of competition. Nippon was reporting quarterly results for the first time, so it gave no comparative year-earlier figures. Revenues for the quarter fell marginally to 2.65 trillion yen ($23.7 billion), from 2.67 trillion yen.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Two Men Arraigned In Sex Assault
description: Two men were arrested yesterday on charges of sexually assaulting a 15-year-old female acquaintance who had been drinking alcohol at a neighborhood block party. Detective Sgt. Richard Zito of the Nassau County police said that one of the defendants, Joseph Locoteta, 20, served the girl several drinks at the party in Bellmore on July 24 and offered to take her home when she said she felt dizzy. Instead, he drove to his house, in Bellmore, where his friend, Salvatore Piccarillo, 19, later joined him, the police said. The men then forced her to commit sexual acts in a basement apartment, the detective said. Mr. Piccarillo was charged with two counts of rape in the first degree and two counts of a criminal sexual act in the first degree. Mr. Locoteta was charged with two counts of a criminal sexual act in the first degree. Both men pleaded not guilty at their arraignments. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Deal Will Give City Control Of Streets at Trade Center Site
description: New York City -- and not the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey -- will own and control the streets and sidewalks that run through the World Trade Center site, under an agreement that lifts a 37-year-old cloud over ownership of the property.

title: Murphy Was a Link To a Vanishing Era
description: The reaction to Bob Murphy's death Tuesday demonstrates the hold that announcers like him have had on fans. His voice, delivery, optimism and presence through 42 seasons evoked memories of hot summer evenings, great games, a transistor radio held to one's ear, family gatherings and the history of the Mets' franchise from its inception.

title: Man Arrested in Chicago in Connection With Truck-Bomb Plot
description: Law enforcement officials on Thursday arrested a man who they say was plotting to blow up the Everett M. Dirksen Federal Building with a truck bomb containing ammonium nitrate fertilizer, the same material used in the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: A Rule to Avert Balloting Woes Adds to Them
description: When poll workers could not find Kelly Pierce's name on the registration rolls during the primary here in March, they told him to take advantage of a new election rule that allowed him to cast his vote using a provisional ballot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEDER, GERALDINE
description: FEDER--Geraldine, passed away at age 97 at her home in New York on July 19, 2004. A violin student of Leopold Auer, she concertized under the name ''Gere Cotna'' and made solo appearances with Eugene Ormandy and Ernest Ansermet. Mrs. Feder was the widow of Edgard Feder, who predeceased her in 1991. She is survived by her son, Yves Feder and her daughter-in-law, Linda Skernick, her granddaughter, Sarah Weaver and husband Michael Weaver, Connecticut residents, and by her nieces, Janine Gordon of New York City, and Judith Molle, Geri and Jeanne Steinberg of Los Angeles. Funeral arrangements are private. Donations may be made in her name to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, 1775 Broadway (Suite 300), New York, NY 10019.

title: Security Fears Are Slowing U.N. Return To Baghdad
description: John C. Danforth, the American ambassador to the United Nations, said Thursday that he hoped an international protection force could be in place in Iraq next month to permit the United Nations to return to Baghdad, but he acknowledged that finding countries willing to participate was proving difficult and frustrating.

title: Neighbors Describe the Suspects as Peaceful, Religious Family Men
description: ALBANY, Aug. 5 - The small mosque on Central Avenue is as nondescript as many of the other storefronts lining the busy streets that run west from the doors of the State Capitol here, the Laundromats, fast food places and cramped shops that sell used furniture and old records or fix broken appliances.

title: Just Skimming Texas Means Considerable
description: Let's mess with Texas.

title: Down Country Music's Back Roads
description: WHEN the convertible's top goes down, the open highway calls out and the ancient urge for exploration kicks in. A driving trip means freedom: you set the pace, you steer the car, you decide what's new. And on the best trips, when the wheels make contact with the road less trammeled, sights mingle with insights, scenic views with glimpses of a region's spirit.

title: Virginia Grey, a Veteran Of 100 Films, Dies at 87
description: Virginia Grey, who made her film debut in 1927 at the age of 10 as Little Eva in ''Uncle Tom's Cabin'' and acted almost continuously in movies and television for the next five decades, died on July 31 in Los Angeles. She was 87.

title: Into the Inferno, With a Golf Club
description: THERE'S midsummer golf where you get a bit sweaty and can't wait for the refreshment cart to come around, and then there's midsummer golf where you put your health at risk if you haven't taken the proper precautions, where the sun beats down at 120 degrees, where there's not another soul on the course, where you go to grab your 5-iron out of the bag and recoil in pain because the club head has just scalded the skin on the palm of your hand. Now that's midsummer golf.

title: That Buzz on the Lake Isn't From the Mosquitos
description: ONE afternoon last summer, John Manoush was cutting the lawn at his summer house on Sebago Lake in southern Maine when he realized that the sound of a cigarette boat was drowning out the roar of his mower. ''It's hard to imagine, I know,'' he said. ''But I literally couldn't hear myself mow, much less think.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARTIER, BRESSON, HENRI
description: CARTIER - BRESSON -- Henri. It is with profound sorrow that we note the passing of Henri Cartier-Bresson. For all of us at ICP, and the photographic community at large, Cartier-Bresson was a monumental figure who changed the history of photography and whose profound influence will long be felt. He was a visionary witness to our time; a superb artist who brought to his work unsurpassed integrity and a marvelous celebration of life. Henri's pictures have become icons and will continue to provide inspiration and enjoyment to millions. His lively presence will be deeply missed and we will all be less as a result of his absence. The staff and Trustees of ICP express their heartfelt condolences to Martine and Melanie and to their extended family and friends around the world. Cornell Capa, Founding Director Willis E. Hartshorn, Director International Center of Photography

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Prosecutors Must Share Case Files
description: Gov. Michael F. Easley of North Carolina has signed a bill that requires prosecutors to share all case files in felony cases with the defense. Prosecutors do not have to share their legal research, correspondence or draft writings prepared for trial, and can demand to see what objects the defense lawyers plan to introduce as evidence and to learn whether certain defenses will be used. The bill, which the governor signed into law on Monday, came after a series of state death sentences were thrown out by the courts because prosecutors were found to have withheld significant evidence. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: The Eye of the 20th Century
description: Henri Cartier-Bresson's long life, which ended Tuesday at 95, spanned more than half of the entire history of photography. Mr. Cartier-Bresson's work is as fundamental to our understanding of the 20th century as it is to our understanding of the photographic image. The best homage to this man is simply to look at his published photographs, one by one. Their formal perfection is inescapable -- his unrivaled awareness of just what the rectangle visible through his Leica could contain.

description: The Bank of England raised its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a point, to 4.75 percent, the fifth increase since November, as it tried to cool the economy. ''Investment and public sector consumption have both grown strongly and demand in U.K. export markets continues to pick up,'' which could lead to rising inflationary pressures, the bank said. Separately the European Central Bank left its rates unchanged. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Ocean Rescue
description: In the past year, two landmark reports have provided stark evidence that the oceans are in a serious biological decline. Both reports have also provided plausible road maps for recovery. As a rule, reports like these, however exhaustive and worthy, cause a momentary stir and then sink from view. It is thus heartening to find that several bills inspired by these reports have recently been introduced in Congress. There is not enough time left for Congress to pass them this year, but their very existence should provide momentum heading into next year. And, who knows, they may even persuade a presidential candidate or two to talk seriously about a matter that deserves far more prominence than it now has.

title: A Bush Aide (and a Mother) Emerges as a Major Player in the Antiterror Campaign
description: As the mother of two young sons, Frances Fragos Townsend, President Bush's domestic security adviser, believes that families need to know as much as possible about terror threats. That is part of the reason Ms. Townsend has moved from the shadows to a center stage role as an advocate of raising the threat level with urgent warnings of a possible attack.

Loved and missed by grandchildren Sharon Aeria, Jeffrey Yap, Jennifer Yap, Frankie Yap, greatgranddaughter Madeline Yap, sons-in-law Vernon Yap and Michael Little, and granddaughter-in-law Michelle Yap. ''Break, break, break on thy cold gray crags, O Sea!/But oh for the touch of a vanished hand/And the sound of a voice that will never come back to me.''

title: End It Like Beckham
description: For a second consecutive summer the Manchester United team has tried to convince the American public that its shirt is worth the buying, but its pale performances during its recent United States tour have once again failed to win the West. There are bucks to be made, but something seems to be missing from the formula. Could it be that the absence of a certain young Englishman whose name was prominent in theaters across the United States last year -- the guy who bends it like nobody else -- is still the major factor in the hype-deficit? Would United have done better this time around if it hadn't sent David Beckham, probably its most crucial asset, to Real Madrid, the Spanish soccer giant, a year ago?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAPALEO, JOSEPH
description: PAPALEO--Joseph, passed away in his home in Tampa, FL on August 4, 2004. An award-winning author and Professor of Fiction Literature at Sarah Lawrence College for 35 years, Joseph was a decorated veteran of World War II. He leaves behind his loving wife of 21 years, Tonie, children, Joseph, William, Robert and Anthony and grandchildren, Liana, Matteo, Nicholas, Taylor, Ryan and Aaron. Visitation will be Friday from 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM at John J. Fox Funeral Home. Mass of Christian Burial will be Saturday, 10:30 AM, at Immaculate Conception Church, Tuckahoe. Interment private.

title: Corrections

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: New Accusations Against Banker
description: Pressure mounted on the central bank president, Henrique Meirelles, left, to resign after two local newsmagazines published new accusations that he had evaded taxes before assuming his post in early 2003. Veja, Brazil's most widely read newsweekly, reported that Mr. Meirelles had failed to declare a bank account at Goldman Sachs in New York from which he transferred $50,677 in 2002 to an account belonging to black market currency dealers who are under investigation for money laundering. Another magazine, Isto, said Mr. Meirelles had declared to tax authorities that a piece of land he owns in the state of Rio de Janeiro valued at 40,000 reais ($13,115) was worth just 1 real. Mr. Meirelles denied any wrongdoing in a television interview and said he had no intention of stepping down. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Consumer Spending Falls

Japanese households spent less on housing, clothing and transportation in June compared with a year earlier, the report said. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: White Rhino Numbers Cut By Half
description: The continent's last known wild population of northern white rhinoceroses has been halved by poaching in the last 14 months, according to aerial surveys done in July of Garamba National Park in Congo. The survey estimated that 14 to 19 rhinos were shot in the park, cutting the overall population of 17 to 22, despite the birth of four calves this year, said scientists of the World Conservation Union, a consortium of government agencies and private conservation groups. Over all, rhinos are on the increase in Africa. But the northern white rhino has seen its numbers decline from more than 2,000 in five African countries in the 1980's to the few stragglers in the Congo park. Armed poachers who slaughter them smuggle the horns to Asia, where they are coveted for purported medicinal properties. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

Beloved wife of Rodger, Sr. Loving mother of Mark and Rodger, Jr. and mother-in-law of Josephine and Patricia. Cherished daughter of the late Grace and Dominick Serini. Devoted grandmother of Emily, Julia and Madison. Dear sister of Rosemarie Savino. Reposing at Andrew Torregrossa & Sons, 1305 79th Street, Brooklyn, NY. Funeral Mass Monday 9:30AM at St. Bernadette RC Church. Entombment, Greenwood Cemetery. Visitation Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

title: For Radical Visionaries, the Evil Empire Is Us
description: The Queen of Diamonds did not appear in a game of solitaire, setting off programmed Pavlovian responses, as in the 1962 film ''The Manchurian Candidate.'' And no brain-control chip had been implanted to convey a brainwashed assassin's orders, as in Jonathan Demme's recent remake.

title: Bush, a Yale Legacy, Says Colleges Should Not Give Preference to Children of Alumni
description: Correction Appended

title: An Ecuadorean Drug Defendant Who Fled Is Back in Court, 25 Years Older
description: In 1979, Mario Patricio Andretta Salazar jumped bail on drug charges in Nassau County. He fled to his native Ecuador, then spent the next 25 years enjoying a quiet life that included frequent trips to the United States. He always traveled under some variation of his name, raised a son in Miami and avoided arrest.

title: The Thorn in Ariel Sharon's Side
description: To the Editor:

title: A Legal Mind Used a Rare Tool; Now She's in the Hall of Fame
description: Very few people reach the top of the ladder in two quite different areas. One of those few is Amalya Kearse of New York City, who is a world bridge champion and also a federal judge.

title: Union May Back Carter
description: The National Football League Players Association is gathering information about the Cowboys' release of quarterback Quincy Carter to determine if a grievance is warranted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRIESTLEY, JUSTINE TYRRELL SMADBECK
description: PRIESTLEY--Justine Tyrrell Smadbeck. We mourn the passing of Justine Priestley. Her devotion to the welfare of children and to the dignity of all people inspired all who were privileged to know her. Our condolences to her husband Bob and to her children Arthur, Louis, David and Paul Smadbeck. Virginia Sloane, Peter Sloane, Gail Meyers

title: Guantnamo Inmate Complains Of Threats and Long Isolation
description: A brief unsealed in a Seattle courtroom this week contains an account by a prisoner at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, alleging that he was mistreated in several ways that may have violated the Geneva Conventions, including having his life threatened, being beaten and being kept in prolonged isolation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HINES, GREGORY
description: HINES--Gregory. Ascension And if I go while you're still here, know that I live on, vibrating to a different measure. Behind us in veil, you cannot see through. You will not see me, so you must have faith. I'll wait for the time, when we can soar together again both aware of each other. Until then live your life to the fullest, and when you need me...just whisper my name in your heart, and I will be there. --Colleen Corah Hitchcock Dance in heaven my sweet Gregory until we meet again with Jesus. I love you forever, Negrita Sadly missed and loved by Daria, Zach, Lucian, Wayne, Jessica, Gramps, Maurice, Larry, family and friends. Mass is being said for Gregory at St. Mark's Church, 277 Park Lawn Rd., Toronto, Canada at 12 Noon on Sunday, August 8, 2004. All welcome.

title: Double Life As Editor And Lyricist
description: ''Spit out the 'p' when you say 'stop whining like a wimp,'' Seth Weinstein gently instructed an actor as he sat behind a piano in a Midtown studio. Mr. Weinstein composed the music for ''How to Save the World and Find True Love in 90 Minutes,'' a musical comedy about a slacker tour guide at the United Nations who confronts love in the age of the orange alert. The show will have its premiere at the New York International Fringe Festival later this month.

title: Memphis Journal; Leaving a Little Bit of Elvis Amid an Area Renaissance
description: In 1995, Annette Neal was living in a wretched apartment at a broken-down housing project called Lauderdale Courts, two blocks from the Mississippi River on the northern end of downtown. The entire complex, built in 1938 and never refurbished, had just been deemed unsalvageable by the Memphis Housing Authority and was slated for demolition. Ms. Neal said then that her greatest hope was to move to a modern apartment, without leaking ceilings, ant and roach infestations and the rampant crime of Lauderdale Courts.

title: F.B.I. Declines To Explain Raids
description: F.B.I. officials would not explain on Friday why the New York and New Jersey homes of a doctor who has consulted on bioterrorism preparedness were raided on Thursday, saying only that the man being investigated, Dr. Kenneth M. Berry, was not arrested in connection with the 2001 anthrax attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TULIN, JEAN
description: TULIN--Jean. Beloved wife of Marshall. Loving mother of Kathryn, John and James. Cherished grandmother of Elizabeth, Alex, Victor, Christine, James, Alex and Christopher. Dear sister of Carol Hirsch. She will be missed by all. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 B'way, Hewlett, LI, 10:30 a.m. Sunday.

title: Patients With H.I.V. Seen as Separated By a Racial Divide
description: Last January in Manhattan, at the memorial service of a colleague who died of an AIDS-related illness, Joseph Bostic lost feeling in his legs and had trouble standing. A friend, Keith Cylar, hailed a cab, crumpled some bills into the driver's palm and sent Mr. Bostic home to Brooklyn. Two months later, Mr. Bostic died of heart and kidney failure related to H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. Within three weeks, Mr. Cylar, too, was dead of heart disease related to the virus.

title: Shares Drop on Weak Employment Report
description: Stocks fell sharply yesterday, setting new lows for the year, after a surprisingly weak July jobs report heightened concerns about a slowdown in economic growth. The dollar dropped and bond prices shot sharply higher, pushing yields to their lowest since the spring.

title: Ordering M.R.I.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: An Undersea Fixture for 4 Decades Is Headed to Pasture
description: A manned deep-sea submarine that for 40 years has shed its lights on the likes of new life forms, superheated sea vents, a sunken hydrogen bomb and the Titanic is succumbing to the disease most lethal for technology: obsolescence.

title: Wyeth Loses Verdict
description: Correction Appended

title: Kenya's Imperiled Reform
description: For a brief time last year, it seemed that Kenya would emerge at last from decades of ruinous despotism. In an exemplary election at the end of 2002, Kenyans selected a reputable and reformist president, Mwai Kibaki, who won on the promise of ending corruption.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Canada: Jobless Rate Falls
description: Canada's economy added 8,700 workers in July, fewer than economists expected, as government layoffs offset the biggest gain in manufacturing jobs in 21 months. The unemployment rate fell to a three-month low. Company payrolls and self-employment swelled by 38,500, including 20,700 factory jobs, Statistics Canada said in its latest employment survey, which is based on household interviews. Governments laid off 29,800.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: UFJ Posts Loss
description: The Japanese bank UFJ Holdings, the target of an unprecedented Japanese takeover battle, reported a net loss of 91.6 billion yen ($820 million) for the quarter ended June 30 as it continued to struggle with bad loans. UFJ posted bad-loan losses of 322.5 billion yen for the quarter and has been under pressure from regulators to take a more critical look at its loan portfolio and write off its shakiest loans. UFJ is in discussions about a possible takeover with the Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group, Japan's second-largest bank. UFJ did not provide equivalent consolidated profit and bad-loan figures from a year earlier but as a rough comparison its main units earned a net profit of 132.2 billion yen in the same quarter last year. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: SLOW JOB GROWTH RAISES CONCERNS ON U.S. ECONOMY
description: Job growth ground nearly to a halt last month, the Labor Department reported yesterday, raising new concerns about the economy's strength and reshaping the political debate over its performance less than three months before election day.

title: Bin Laden Sent Suspect to U.S., Officials Say
description: American intelligence officials now believe that Issa al-Hindi, the alleged Qaeda operative now in British custody, was dispatched to the United States in early 2001 by the mastermind of the Sept. 11 plot at the direction of Osama bin Laden to case potential targets in New York City, senior government officials said Friday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on July 28 about a court hearing with Microsoft, the European Commission and others, to decide whether changes demanded by the commission in Microsoft's business practices should be waived pending an appeal, misstated the name of a group that supports the commission in the case. It is the Free Software Foundation Europe, not the Free Software Federation of Europe.

title: I.R.S. IS DISPUTING SOME DEDUCTIONS, UNION PACIFIC SAYS
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said yesterday that the Internal Revenue Service was disputing deductions it took for land donations on its income tax returns for 1995 through 1998. The I.R.S. sent a preliminary notice that proposed disallowing the deductions, the company said in a regulatory filing. Union Pacific, which is based in Omaha, Neb., said it could not estimate the potential financial effect but it had money set aside for potential tax liabilities. In the filing, made with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Union Pacific said it would defend the deductions to the tax agency and, if needed, in the courts. The deductions were claimed for land along several abandoned tracks donated for recreational use, a company spokeswoman, Kathryn Blackwell, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREILICH, ELLA
description: FREILICH--Ella. On August 6, 2004 in Riverdale, NY, in her 87th year. Wife of the late Rabbi Samuel Freilich, mother of Hadassah Freilich Lieberman and Ary Freilich, grandmother of Ethan Tucker, Hana, Matthew, April and Rebecca Lieberman and Sarah and Elizabeth Freilich, great-grandmother of Eden Migdal Tucker and Tennessee and Willie Lieberman, and mother-in-law of Joseph Lieberman and Judy Freilich. She survived enormous turmoil with indomitable spirit and lived to see her family grow and prosper in a new land. Funeral services 11AM, Monday, August 9, at the Riverdale Jewish Center, 3700 Independence Ave, Riverdale, NY. May her memory be a blessing.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: State Senator Lost Position, But Not Perks
description: Earlier this week, legislative officials in Albany announced that because of what was considered less than professional behavior, State Senator Ada L. Smith of Queens had been removed from a prominent leadership post that paid her an extra $16,500 annually. At the time, the Senate Democratic leader who announced the removal called the action necessary to send a message that erratic behavior would not be tolerated.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial in some editions of Friday's Times about the presidential campaign gave the wrong location for the Quad Cities area, which lies along the Iowa-Illinois border about halfway between the Missouri and Wisconsin state lines. It is not in the area where the borders of Iowa, Illinois and Wisconsin intersect.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Lithuanian Expelled
description: Russia ordered the expulsion of Lithuania's military attach, Lt. Col. Sigitus Butkus, accusing him of ''activities that damage Russia's interests,'' the Foreign Ministry announced. It was the latest in a series of tit-for-tat expulsions of diplomats of both countries since February. Lithuania's foreign minister told state radio that Colonel Butkus was being expelled in retaliation for the expulsion of three Russian diplomats last month. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: A Son Of Soweto Ignites Rap
description: Around 9 on a recent night, South Africa's most popular new rapper could be found in the back of a white Volkswagen van. The van was leaving this city, hurtling east on the N12 toward a coal mining town called Witbank, with the heat going full blast to keep winter out.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Job Growth Slowed in July; Jobless Rate Fell to 5.5%

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROPPER, MOLLIE
description: GROPPER--Mollie, on August 6, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Alex. Loving mother of Bob, Flo and Ellen Gropper Rhoden. Cherished grandmother of Halona, Aaron, Rebecca. Devoted companion Dr. Emanuel Feldman. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM, Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels (Queens Blvd. & 76th Rd.), Forest Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAAS, HENRY
description: HAAS--Henry. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club are deeply saddened by the passing of their esteemed member, Henry Haas. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot Executive Director

title: The Thorn in Ariel Sharon's Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Matsui Thunders and Yanks Roll
description: Ever since the Yankees constructed their high-priced lineup in the off-season, the expectation was that they would overwhelm teams with clusters of runs over a long period.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Riot Trial Moved
description: The Supreme Court transferred a trial connected with the 2002 anti-Muslim riots in Gujarat State to Maharashtra State. The court moved the case of Bilkees Rasool Yaqub, who said that she was gang raped and that 14 family members were killed. The Central Bureau of Investigation found the suspected attackers, but Mrs. Yaqub expressed apprehension about a fair trial in Gujarat. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: The Nautical Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: Performers Who Take Their Cues From the Bible
description: Dancers proved that the spirit can move in many ways when ''Conversations With the Father'' opened on Wednesday night at the 14 Street Y Theater. This festival of dances on spiritual themes by various groups continues through tomorrow.

title: GLIMCHER REALTY TRUST TO SELL 25 SHOPPING CENTERS
description: The Glimcher Realty Trust, which owns the Almeda Mall in Houston and the SuperMall in Seattle, is selling 25 shopping centers for $103.1 million. The company said it had completed sales of 23 properties for $91.9 million to Bromont Investments, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., and to Dolgen Ventures of San Diego. Two other sales will close when Bromont and Dolgen receive approval to assume loans on the properties, Glimcher said. Glimcher, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, will use the proceeds to pay off loans, including a $38 million mortgage on the River Valley Mall in Lancaster, Ohio. After the sales, Glimcher said, 90 percent of its leasable space will be in enclosed malls.

title: Berkshire Reports a Decline in Profit
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the company controlled by Warren E. Buffett, said yesterday that second-quarter profit fell 42 percent because of a decline in earnings from investments.

title: Break Up the Lakers: Payton Sent to the Celtics
description: The earthquake struck the Los Angeles Lakers last month, when Shaquille O'Neal forced a trade to the Miami Heat. But tremors are still being felt, as the club's formerly star-studded roster continues to be razed. On Friday, the Lakers traded Gary Payton, one of the four probable Hall of Famers on last season's squad, and Rick Fox, a key member of the Lakers' recent three-ring dynasty, to the Boston Celtics.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Paraguay: Fire Toll Now At 408
description: The police put the official death toll from the megastore fire on Sunday at 408. A police spokesman said that 61 bodies had still not been identified. A team of investigators from the F.B.I. was on hand, helping to determine the cause of the fire at the Ycu Bolaos megastore on the outskirts of Asuncin, the capital. The authorities first said that the fire was caused by a gas leak, but now suspect a short circuit in the building's food court. Four other Ycu Bolaos stores remained shuttered, prompting protests from more than 500 employees, but were expected to reopen by Monday. Six people, including the burned store's owner, have been charged with homicide, accused of locking emergency exits to prevent theft. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Myskina Sues Magazine Over Two Topless Photos
description: Anastasiya Myskina, the French Open champion, accused GQ magazine in a federal lawsuit yesterday of failing to prevent a photographer from reselling two topless pictures from a photo shoot to a Russian magazine.

title: Gruner & Jahr Chief Intends To Cut Costs by $25 Million
description: Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing, the publisher of magazines including Fast Company, Fitness and Family Circle, will cut annual costs by $25 million and could reduce its staff of 700 employees by as much as 15 percent, J. Russell Denson, the president and chief executive of the company said yesterday.

title: Sour Surprise For Officers Who Raided Container Ship
description: The first word was ominous.

title: DRUG MAKER SAYS GRAND JURY IS INVESTIGATING EMPLOYEES
description: Aventis, the French drug maker that is being acquired by Sanofi-Synthlabo, said yesterday that some of its employees were targets of a federal grand jury investigation. The United States attorney's office in Boston is investigating Aventis sales to managed care organizations and whether those sales should have been included in the ''best price'' calculations that are used to compute Medicaid rebates, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. A regional sales manager and a former employee who was a regional account manager received letters from the government stating that they were targets of the grand jury investigation, Aventis said in the filing. Aventis disclosed the investigation in a previous S.E.C. filing, and said it was cooperating with the investigation.

title: At 40-Year Bronx Beach Party, Who Needs Sand?
description: Two old guitarists sat on folding chairs, eyes closed and heads back, singing of heartbreak and homesickness -- the kind of dreamy boleros they first crooned when their hair was dark and their hopes were bright. Nearby, younger revelers swirled and shimmied to classic salsa, their dips punctuated by tight horn flourishes. Beach towels hung on fences, and the air was thick with the sweet aroma of codfish fritters sizzling in oil.

title: The Rural Life; Victory Garden
description: The other afternoon I walked out to the vegetable garden and saw a woodchuck inside the fence, standing on its hind legs with its back to me. It was nibbling lamb's-quarters. This was like a burglar breaking into the house to shampoo the carpets. I watched for a minute or two, hoping the woodchuck would move on to some hairy galinsoga, another persistent weed. But then it turned and caught my eye. Instead of freezing like a cat about to pounce, it did a Tim Conway double take, dropped to all fours and waddled out the back of the garden. I found the gap in the fence and fixed it.

title: Hatred of America
description: To the Editor:

title: Beliefs; On the stump, in the rights arena, echoes of a religious thinker's vision live on.
description: A century ago, Walter Rauschenbusch was the leading thinker of what was first known as ''social Christianity'' and then simply as the social gospel. The textbooks say that by 1918, the social gospel, like Rauschenbusch himself, was on its deathbed; but in fact its genes lived on in religious responses to the Depression and helped shape the civil rights movement of the 1960's.

title: Bloomberg Waited to Speak Publicly of Alert
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he knew of the terror alerts concerning financial institutions in Washington and the New York region two days before the Bush administration publicly released the information.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Internet Provider Slips
description: South Korea's largest Internet access provider, the KT Corporation, posted its fifth consecutive drop in profit and cut its 2004 net income forecast amid sluggish demand for Internet access and fixed-line phone services. Second-quarter net income unexpectedly fell 22 percent from a year ago to 223 billion won ($192 million), while sales rose 2.9 percent to 3 trillion won, KT said. KT is losing fixed-line business as people switch to mobile phones, while its Internet access revenue is slowing because South Korea already has the world's highest concentration of broadband users, equivalent to three-quarters of the country's homes.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The area my clinic's in is essentially a suburb of the Third World. It's a shame no one seems to know that the problem in Africa looks like the problem in inner-city Houston, Chicago and New York.''

title: BRITISH HOME BUILDER AGREES TO SELL DIVISION IN U.S.
description: Barratt Developments, a British home builder, has agreed to sell a division in the United States for $165 million to focus on Britain, where a housing shortage has helped push up prices. Three of Barratt's American managers, with backers including Bank of America, offered to buy the business, the chief executive, David A. Pretty, said. Proceeds will help cut debt and buy land in Britain. Michael D. Pattinson, president of the unit, Barratt American, for the last 13 years, instigated the deal by approaching Barratt with an offer after he helped return the business to profit, Mr. Pretty said. The American unit specializes in the sale of homes in Southern California at an average price of $300,000.

title: A 32-Year-Old Wound Still Healing
description: Ankie Spitzer arrived at the 1972 Munich Olympics intending to be only a spectator.

title: Close Relationship to U.S. Did Not Help Liberia Much
description: In their brave film ''Liberia: An Uncivil War'' Jonathan Stack and James Brabazon make us witnesses to the continuing implosion in one of Africa's failed states. But they do something else as well in the documentary that has its premiere tonight on the Discovery Times Channel. They also show how the United States has turned its back on the land it created as a colony in 1821. In one of the film's many riveting images, three United States warships loom in the haze off Liberia's coast while thousands of civilians are slaughtered on shore by a ragtag army wielding American-made weapons.

Loving mother of Francis, James (Deborah Bowler) and Priscilla (Christopher Deering). Devoted grandmother of Michael, Josie, Mary and Odessa. Graduate of Hunter College, Columbia Graduate School and retired NYC high school teacher. Visitation Sunday, 3-5 and 7-9, Fairchild Funeral Home, Manhasset. Mass Monday, 10 AM, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset.

description: New Jersey Transit conductors say they are being rattled by small packages the agency has been sending to their homes as the Republican National Convention nears and security measures in New York widen.

title: Geraldine Peroni, 51; Film Editor Worked With Robert Altman
description: Geraldine Peroni, an Academy Award-nominated film editor known for her work with Robert Altman, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan, said her sister, Pamela O'Grady. She was 51.

title: HSBC to Pay $1.75 Billion For Stake in Chinese Bank
description: HSBC Holdings, Europe's largest bank by market value, will pay $1.75 billion for a fifth of the Bank of Communications, HSBC's third acquisition in China and the biggest by an overseas lender.

title: Two Great Bachs on Opposite Trajectories
description: Now that the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra has revitalized itself under its new music director, Louis Langre, the players have less to fear from visiting ensembles, which used to outshine them routinely. This season festival organizers lined up an enticing series of concerts by some eminent visitors. It began on Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall with the Freiburg Baroque Orchestra, a leading period-instrument ensemble from Germany, in a program featuring works by two great Bachs.

description: To the Editor:

title: Coach Causes Trouble, But Mostly for Rivals
description: Let other coaches spend hours dissecting films, analyzing computer breakdowns and poring over the tendencies of opponents as they try to solve strategic problems on the football field.

title: Political Memo; Repetition As a Tool Of Persuasion For a Stadium
description: There is a theory in salesmanship that if the virtues of a product are repeated over and over again, people eventually start to believe in them, no matter how unreal those virtues are.

title: Federal Roadblocks and Checkpoints Creating Capital Maze, City Officials Say
description: Each day seems to bring a new reminder that this is a city under siege by an invisible enemy.

description: Cantab Hall appeared to be the favorite for the Hambletonian at the Meadowlands until three weeks ago, when he developed a condition that made him questionable.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Freddie Mac's appointment of a president, Eugene M. McQuade, a former executive at FleetBoston and Bank of America, misstated his last title at FleetBoston. He was president and chief operating officer, not chief executive.

title: Hussein's Judge Takes Risk And Abandons Anonymity
description: American troops with M-16 rifles patrol the corridors outside his office. At his door, Iraqi bodyguards lurk with holstered pistols. Outside, Humvees wait to escort him to his home, where his wife and their three small boys live behind concrete blast walls designed to withstand rockets and vehicle bombs.

title: A Comic-Book Response To 9/11 and Its Aftermath
description: Unlike most cartoonists, the Pulitizer Prize winner Art Spiegelman, 56, tends to focus on the big traumas of contemporary history and their impact on his life. Mr. Spiegelman's graphic novels about how his Polish-Jewish parents survived the fires of World War II, ''Maus I'' and ''Maus II,'' sold 1.8 million copies in the United States, according to his publisher, Pantheon Books. Next month Pantheon is releasing ''In the Shadow of No Towers,'' Art Spiegelman's artistic response to the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, as well as an expression of his deep opposition to the war in Iraq.

title: ELIZABETH ARDEN FORECASTS SIZABLE PROFIT GROWTH
description: Elizabeth Arden Inc., the perfume maker, said yesterday that it expected fiscal first-quarter earnings to rise as much as 600 percent, to 14 cents a share. The company expects net income to climb to 12 cents to 14 cents a share, from 2 cents a year earlier. Sales in the period ending Sept. 30 will rise to $213 million to $218 million, from $199 million, said Marcey Becker, senior vice president for finance. Elizabeth Arden, which is based in Miami Lakes, Fla., has introduced new fragrance lines, reorganized its finances and consolidated distribution sites.

title: Bad News on the Job Front
description: There is no sugarcoating yesterday's employment report. The consensus forecast was for the American economy to add more than 200,000 new jobs in July. The actual number was 32,000. June's already weak report was revised downward, to 78,000 jobs from 112,000. Even May's hopeful numbers turned out to be less so, with 27,000 fewer jobs created than originally reported. The report's immediate impact will be to neutralize, if not undercut, President Bush's campaign boasts of a strong economic recovery.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 1 about Muslims in Salt Lake City misstated the number of their co-religionists who died in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, when Mormons came forward to offer comfort. Although a precise figure is unknown, a spokesman for the Islamic Circle of North America, a prominent Muslim group based in Queens, said it was probably 50 to 75, not 500. A reader pointed out the error the next day; this correction was delayed for research. ( Go to Article )

description: AFRICA

title: Nymex Rejects A Buyout Offer
description: Nymex Holdings Inc., owner of the New York Mercantile Exchange, rejected a takeover bid by a buyout firm, Parthenon Capital, after some exchange members said the offer was too low.

title: Edwards May Face Two-Year Suspension
description: A review panel of the world governing body in track and field has recommended that the sprinter Torri Edwards be suspended for two years for taking a banned stimulant, her lawyer said yesterday.

title: Adelphia Sets Labor Day As Beginning Of Auction
description: The Adelphia Communications Corporation, which has operated under bankruptcy protection for the last two years, said yesterday that it would start accepting bids to buy the company after Labor Day.

title: California Softens Plan to Control Auto Emissions
description: California gave some ground to the auto industry on Friday in its ambitious plan to regulate global warming emissions from tailpipes, but the state is unlikely to avert a legal challenge from carmakers.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Chief To Review 1987 Rape Case
description: Chief Harold L. Hurtt of the Houston police said he would review a 1987 case that experts say has led to the imprisonment of an innocent man for 17 years. On Thursday, defense lawyers filed a report in court from six forensic experts saying that the man, George Rodriguez, was erroneously identified in a rape investigation by an official of the city's crime laboratory who either lacked basic knowledge of blood typing or gave false testimony. They said that ''similarly false and scientifically unsound'' reports and testimony might have been offered in many other cases and they called for a comprehensive audit. Chief Hurtt, who came to the department this year, said that problems that occurred in testing in the past were ''an embarrassment'' and that the laboratory, now under a new director, was determined to ''right any wrongs.'' Mr. Rodriguez remains in prison while lawyers for the Innocence Project, based in New York, seek his release. Maureen Balleza (NYT)

title: Giants Look Forward to Hitting Someone Else
description: It is common for National Football League teams to invite other teams to their training camps to provide outside competition and to break the monotony of wearisome drills and the unchanging schedule. But in the nine seasons the Giants have been practicing on the campus of the State University at Albany, no N.F.L. team has visited their summer home in upstate New York.

description: Taking Risk, Iraqi Judge Abandons Anonymity

title: 22 One-Man Bands, Along With a Conductor
description: Twenty-two trumpeters arranged themselves on the small stage at Tonic on Wednesday, and that began the Festival of New Trumpet Music.

title: As Convention Week Nears, Many Plot Escapes
description: When the Republican National Convention arrives in Manhattan on Aug. 30, tens of thousands of visitors will swarm the city, eating, protesting and hatching political strategies. But many New Yorkers plan to be well out of earshot.

title: Hartford Journal; Getting Back to Bland, or Heading Forward to Hip
description: It might seem that a city that spent six months aching for an end to a scandal that ultimately forced Gov. John G. Rowland from office would be relieved to return to its sedate self.

title: Rick James, Rebel Rocker of 'Punk-Funk,' Is Dead at 56
description: Rick James, the unabashedly bawdy funk-rock pioneer who had a run of hits, including ''Super Freak,'' from the late 1970's to the mid-80's, died yesterday at his home in Los Angeles, his record company, Universal Motown, announced. He was 56.

title: Indonesia Court Voids 4 Convictions in 1999 East Timor Strife
description: An Indonesian appeals court has overturned the convictions of three army officers and one policeman for crimes against humanity during violence in 1999 over East Timor's independence that left some 1,500 people dead.

title: Games Come Home
description: The Olympics return to Athens, where they began more than 2,000 years ago.

The Maimed
description: Thank you for compelling us to look at the surviving victims of war and for choosing the young, whose lives are still before them (photographs by Gillian Laub, July 18). What you did not -- could not -- show us is the future each of them faces. Years ago, at age 11, my legs and feet were severely burned in a gasoline explosion. Now, at age 66, I will undergo yet another surgery trying to diminish what that fire did to my body. During the intervening 55 years, I have wrestled to reduce the scars that it left on my soul. Your pictures mark but the beginning. Such wounds are a lifetime struggle.

title: Just Do It (Again)
description: THERE is a good detective story lurking in the exhibition ''Games of the Gods: The Greek Athlete and the Olympic Spirit,'' at the Museum of Fine Arts here through Nov. 28. It involves a work lent by the Kimbell Art Museum, in Fort Worth, a larger-than-life bronze head with the modern title ''Head of an Athlete Cleaning His Scraper (Strigil).'' On its own it is a haunting and somewhat baffling work, but in its temporary digs, surrounded by a supporting cast, this reticent ancient figure turns out to have an engrossing tale to tell, of the adulation paid to ancient athletic heroes and the flourishing art market that catered to a sports-crazed public.

title: Crime
description: Sue Grafton's abecedarian mysteries are so consistently enjoyable you have to wonder what her secret is. She is a precision stylist with a forthright voice, but no literary barnburner. And while she tells a substantive story, there is nothing daunting about her plots. Without oversimplifying the complex (and yes, mysterious) process of any author's craft, I'd like to say Grafton is one of the most confident writers in the field. She knows her strengths, doesn't agonize over her weaknesses and pays no mind to whatever demons might be urging her to move outside her comfort zone. Any chances she takes in furthering the life and career of her outspoken and extremely likable California private eye, Kinsey Millhone, are controlled-risk ventures -- never crash-and-burn kamikaze missions. In a word, readers can trust Grafton. But will they trust her to deviate from her formula for success, which she shows signs of wanting to do in R IS FOR RICOCHET (Marian Wood/Putnam, $26.95)?

title: QUICK BITE/Toms River; What Is Round, Brown and a Thing of Beauty?
description: We are so accustomed to assembly-line doughnuts, even the addictive Krispy Kremes, that a fresh, homemade doughnut is a revelation. And there are few better places to fulfill that revelation than Ob-Co's Donuts in Toms River. My friend Sal Principato says that in the 1960's his family went there every Sunday after church. Choosing didn't take long, as there were only two varieties: plain and powdered. As I pulled into Ob-Co's gravel parking lot recently, I worried about what I'd report back to Sal. A sign on the sloping roof announced ''Ob-Co's Ice Cream.'' My fears subsided as I stepped up to the walk-up window of the building with red aluminum siding. Ob-Co's had merely added ice-cream treats to the menu; its raison d'tre is still doughnuts.
