title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PALMER, NANCIE B.
description: PALMER--Nancie B. Aged 86, has died peacefully in Ridgewood, NJ, on August 2nd. Born Nancie Harriet Brown on October 12, 1917, in Milwaukee, WI, she was the daughter of Victor L. Brown and Harriet Z. Brown, longterm residents of Milwaukee. Her father Victor, an immigrant from Denmark, graduated in the very first class of Harvard Business School and became a successful financier. His Milwaukeebased firm, Motors Acceptance, pioneered automobile finance in the United States. Nancie attended Downer Seminary in Milwaukee, Rosemary Hall in Wallingford, CT, and Vassar College. In 1938 she was married to Thomas Nichols of New York, NY, then an executive with E.I. DuPont and subsequently a member of the U.S. Government War Production Board and the Harriman Mission to London. They were divorced in 1944 and in 1947 she married George J. Stewart of London, UK, and New York, NY. Mr. Stewart was a wellknown Lloyds underwriter and broker, whose firm Stewart, Smith maintained offices in many countries. From 1956 to 1974 Mr. Stewart was the owner of Sam Lord's Castle in Barbados. They lived in New York City and London. Mr. Stewart died in 1975 and Nancie married Harold C. Palmer. The couple lived in New York City and Indian Wells, CA. Palmer died in 1988. For many years, Nancie played a very prominent role in numerous New York City charities. In addition to being a vice president of the Junior League, from 1956 to 1970, Nancie was Chairman of the Day Care Council of New York City, a pioneering agency for early childhood care and education, and subsequently became a national vice president of that agency. She was also active with the International Social Service and the Hunger Task Force. For many years Nancie had been a member of the Colony Club and Cosmopolitan Club in New York City, and the Eldorado Country Club in Indian Wells, CA. She is survived by her four children: Timothy Nichols of Annapolis, MD, and Jamaica, VT, George J. Stewart of San Francisco, CA, Victor E. Stewart of Ridgewood, NJ, and Caroline Nation, of New York City, as well as three grandchildren. An older sister, Victoria, died in 1958. A funeral service is planned for Tuesday, August 10, at 11 am, at the St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church in Ridgewood, with interment at a later date in the Brown family plot in Milwaukee. For information, contact C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, Ridgewood, www.vanemburgh.com

title: Rhythmic Gymnastics
description: In the late 19th century, a new form of gymnastics developed, combining conventional gymnastics and dance - with a twist. Rhythmic gymnastics required the agility and grace of artistic gymnastics, but used props: a rubber ball, a nearly 20-foot satin ribbon attached to a baton, a hula hoop and two clubs resembling bowling pins. The women gymnasts leap, contort and flip while incorporating the props into their routines. It made its Olympic debut in 1984 in the individual all-around. In 1996, the group events, which feature five gymnasts at once, were added to the Games. At Athens, Russia is favored to win the group event. In the all-around, Alina Kabaeva of Russia, the 2000 bronze medalist and 2003 world champion, is the top contender. She returned to competition last year after a one-year suspension for using a banned diuretic.

Malheureusement, Roxeanne's French husband chooses this moment to walk out on her. title: A Real New York Speedway
description: Looking for a way to expand around the country, Nascar now has its eye on Staten Island. The Nascar team is studying a site near the Goethals Bridge which once housed an oil-tank farm but is now abandoned territory. There are environmental issues, like protection of nearby wetlands and assurances that the site has been properly cleaned up. But the big problem is the traffic -- not on the track but on the overloaded roads around it. Staten Island, overdeveloped but underserved by decent transportation alternatives, has some of the worst traffic problems in the metropolitan area. Bringing in another 80,000 people could only make that mess worse.

title: Trampoline
description: Primitive versions of the trampoline first bounced into the world long before the sport made its Olympic debut in 2000. Eskimos used walrus skins to catapult their friends into the air by lifting and lowering the skins. In circuses, trapeze artists used springy nets for safety. In 1936, after seeing those circus nets, a University of Iowa student, George Nissen, a diver and a gymnast, fastened a piece of canvas to a steel frame with pieces of rubber inner tube. His invention was used for exercise in universities, then for more serious pursuits like training American pilots in World War II. Now, the sport of trampoline, part of the International Gymnastics Federation, consists of a routine of twists and somersaults, some done at more than 30 feet in the air. The gold medalists from 2000, Aleksandr Moskalenko and Irina Karavaeva of Russia, will be back at the Games, but last year's world champions, Karen Cockburn of Canada and Henrik Stehlik of Germany, are two of the favorites.

title: Are You My Mother?
description: As recently as eight months ago, though she no longer recognized me, my mother and I could ''talk'' by trading lyrics from the old standards. I would sit beside her, hand on her forearm, and tell her that my father's name was Harry, and she would sing the main phrase from Eubie Blake's ''I'm Just Wild About Harry'' in her still-strong contralto. Saying that it was a beautiful morning elicited a vast smile and the second line of that song's chorus, ''oh, what a beautiful day.'' After almost six decades of her tirades, these light exchanges were a gift.

title: The Shield That Failed
description: The case against Kobe Bryant may end before it begins. Anyone surprised? The prosecution has lost its bid to exclude evidence of the accuser's sexual history from the trial. Underlying the entire mess is one simple, largely unacknowledged fact: The legal system is inadequate to the task of resolving acquaintance rape cases, and the media actually exacerbates the original injustice -- be that a rape, or a false accusation of rape.

title: Works for Me
description: In her essay ''The End of the Novel of Love,'' Vivian Gornick describes turning the last page of Jane Smiley's novella ''The Age of Grief'' and realizing ''that love as a metaphor was over.'' Gornick found Smiley's story of a married couple weathering the wife's adultery ''a small good thing,'' but not a book that left her ''stirred to a sense of larger doings.'' In great classic novels -- ''Anna Karenina,'' ''Madame Bovary'' and ''The Age of Innocence'' are three Gornick mentions -- choosing love over marriage was momentous; the hero or heroine would have to sacrifice ''everything'' (that is, the bourgeois respectability that defined his or her existence) for passion. Because in real life so few people made that sacrifice, passion's transformative powers went unquestioned, and romantic love could stand for all the happiness, understanding and fulfillment people usually forfeit to get along in the world.

title: On Finland's Royal Road
description: LONG before Nokia, centuries before Finland was ever a country, its southwest land was a busy thoroughfare, tramped by crusaders, traders, Swedish kings and Russian czars. The route they took -- now dubbed the Royal Road -- cuts a scenic swath from east to west through farmland and lakes, rivers and thick forest. It skirts coastal waters and Finland's most popular seaside resorts. It winds past castles, ancient manor houses and historic towns, connecting Finland's cosmopolitan hub, Helsinki, with the country's medieval capital, Turku. It's a fascinating window on this tidy country and the tides of history that have long swept through the northern Baltic.

But Fed officials predicted last month that the recent ''soft patch'' would be temporary, and they are almost certainly loath to change gears after having warned investors for months about the need to raise rates gradually from their lowest levels since the 1950's. But even if the federal funds rate rises from 1.25 to 1.5 percent, it will still be below zero after accounting for inflation. Edmund L. Andrews

title: Anthony Mann, Hollywood Soldier
description: THE Film Society of Lincoln Center is calling its gratifyingly large retrospective of the director Anthony Mann ''Dark Streets and Vast Horizons,'' a rubric that pretty accurately evokes the elusive, almost self-contradictory nature of this remarkable filmmaker's career. Those dark streets and those vast horizons refer to the genres in which Mann did a good deal of his most striking work, more or less successively: film noir in the late 40's, westerns in the 50's; the horizons, it should be said, are also on the vast side in his big-budget historical epics of the early 60's, ''El Cid'' and ''The Fall of the Roman Empire.'' But even the Film Society's attractive binary formulation can't quite account for the weird volatility of Mann's work. The 25 pictures screening at the Walter Reade Theater in Manhattan between Wednesday and Aug. 29 reveal a filmmaker who is, in every sense, all over the map.

title: 'Monumental Propaganda'
description: In February 1956, on the day the 20th Congress of the CPSU ended, in the Dolgov District House of the Railroad Worker, Khrushchev's secret speech about Stalin's personality cult was read to the local Party core of activists. The reader was the second secretary of the district Party committee, Pyotr Klimovich Porosyaninov, a plump, well-nourished, red-cheeked, bald man with thick, moist ears covered in whitish bristles-his surname, with its obvious resemblance to the Russian word for "piglet," suited him very well. In fact, in Dolgov there were many people with names that had meanings. There was even a period when the town possessed simultaneously a head of militia called Tiuryagin (an obvious hint at the word "tiuryaga," or jail), a public prosecutor called Strogii (meaning "strict") with a deputy who rejoiced in the name of Vorovaty ("light-fingered"!), a judge called Shemyakin (reminiscent of the seventeenth-century hanging judge Shemyaka) and a head of the department of public education called Bogdan Filippovich Nechitailo (a surname which could be interpreted to mean "illiterate").

Nowadays, quoting its intricate, absurdist, often riotously profane dialogue earns you coolness points in widely disparate circles. Some would even say that the cult of ''The Big Lebowski'' is going mainstream.

It made its Olympics debut in Atlanta in 1996 as a two-on-two event. In Athens, the tandem of Dain Blanton and Jeff Nygaard are favored to win a third consecutive gold medal for the American men. The women's twosome of Misti May and Kerri Walsh are the world champions, but had their prospect of winning the first women's medal for the United States jeopardized when May sustained an abdominal sprain in late May. title: Basketball

It was first played with a soccer ball, with peach baskets as goals. In 1936, the United States won the first Olympic gold medal in basketball, 19-8 over Canada, on a muddy outdoor court. Naismith awarded the medal. The United States won every gold medal until the Soviet Union prevailed on a controversial call during the 1972 Games.

Saddled with that profoundly alien name, Gogol wanders through his coming-of-age in his adopted homeland, becoming a charmingly spazzy young man and, finally, an oblivious cuckold. ''Lahiri is a supremely gifted writer,'' Stephen Metcalf wrote here in 2003, and though her novel is unsatisfying in some respects, it ''is unfailingly lovely in its treatment of Gogol's relationship with his father.''

description: GILL--Madeleine Henriette. Of Water Mill, NY, and Staten Island, NY, on August 7, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Austin Gill. Loving mother of Helene A. Demisay. Dear mother-in-law of Nicholas Demisay. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Peter and Bernadette Demisay and greatgrandmother of Michelle, Danielle and Nicole Demisay. Madeleine Gill was a native of France. She was educated at the Sorbonne in Paris and held degrees in English Literature and Art History. She remarried in Scotland where she taught French at the University of Edinburgh. She was General DeGaulle's Representative in Scotland during WWII. She lived in Paris from 1945-1955 where her husband was the Director of the British Council. They lived in Oxford, England where her husband was a Professor of French at Magdalen College and where she taught French language. In the 70's, where they lived in Glasgow, Scotland, she was a special guide in the Glasglow Museum and the Burrell Collection, specializing in the art of the Middle Ages and French impressionist painting. She was an avid world traveler. She visited the United States in the summer for 30 years and came to stay permanently with her daughter in 1993. Reposing Harmon Home for Funerals, 571 Forest Ave, Staten Island, Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Sacred Heart of Jesus and Mary Church, Southampton, Long Island, Monday, 11 AM. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERRY, MARY ANN
description: BERRY--Mary Ann. 82, died in her home on East 56th Street August 5th. She was born in Hoboken, NJ, on August 24, 1922, to James and Katherine (Jenne) Fowler into a family of four girls and one boy. She attended public schools in Hoboken. Mary Berry worked in New York City for 32 years at William Douglas McAdams, Inc., the very first medical advertising agency, and during the latter part of this period was also involved with programs for Medical Tribune. Many long lasting friendships were made during this time. She leaves a daughter, Judith Dunn, a granddaughter Sarah Madole and husband Wayne, a great-granddaughter Alexandria, all residents of Port Charlotte, FL; sisters Elizabeth Mission of Manchester, NJ, and Catherine Meginley of Clermont, FL. She was predeceased by sister Helen Kleiber, brother Clifford Conway, former husband Robert C. Berry, and two greatgrandchildren, Christopher and Katherine Madole.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARTIER, BRESSON, HENRI
description: CARTIER - BRESSON -- Henri. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of Henri Cartier-Bresson, whose passionate curiosity and uncanny talent changed the way we see the world. A prisioner of war for part of World War II, he discovered at its end that the Museum, believing that he had been killed, was planning a posthumous restrospective of his photographs. Thus began a close relationship that thrived for six decades and led to major exhibitions in 1947, 1968, and 1987. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Martine Franck, daughter Melanie, and their family. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. title: Dispute Threatens State Ethics Laws
description: AT a time when government ethics has become a leading issue in the state, a dispute over a vote on the Finance Board in New Milford is emerging as a court battle that could determine whether local ethics commissions have the power to punish public officials with anything more substantial than a slap on the wrist. The case is being closely watched in Hartford because, depending how the court rules, state ethics laws may be re-examined. With Hartford slowly extricating itself from the tangled scandals of former Gov. John G. Rowland's administration, the New Milford case threatens to sidetrack a Legislature trying to restore public trust in government. Judge John Pickard of Litchfield Superior Court, who is hearing the case, said last month that his initial research had found nothing in state statutes that give local commissions much enforcement power. If he rules that way, lawmakers say it could set precedent throughout the state, keeping the commissions from publicly investigating or recommending sanctions against public officials who violate ethics rules.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Before O. J.
description: Fatty Arbuckle was one of the brightest stars of the silent film era -- at least until 1921, when he was accused of raping and murdering a young actress named Virginia Rappe in a San Francisco hotel room. Though he was tried three times and found not guilty, the notoriety wrecked Arbuckle's career. In I, FATTY (Bloomsbury, $23.95), a novel by Jerry Stahl, the author of the memoir ''Permanent Midnight,'' Arbuckle tells his own story, beginning with his birth to a poor family in Kansas and ending with the alcohol- and drug-induced haze of his post-scandal years. Despite Stahl's aggressive wordplay, ''I, Fatty'' resembles more than anything one of those Hollywood rise-and-fall biographies on television, a collection of short episodes united by the protagonist's determination to explain himself, usually as a victim of circumstance. Comedy was Arbuckle's response to his abusive father, his drug addiction the fault of a crooked doctor and the Rappe scandal happened because of a combination of heartless studio heads, a puritan establishment and an insatiable tabloid press. It all sounds familiar, and that's perhaps the principal insight of ''I, Fatty'': that in 80 years, Hollywood hasn't changed all that much. Campbell Robertson

title: Wiring the Vast Left-Wing Conspiracy
description: As Matt Bai points out, the Democratic Party has been focusing on winning individual elections. But winning an election generally requires an appeal to the political center. Since the center has been moving steadily right, the Democrats have drifted in that direction as well. We need a long-term strategy with the ultimate goal of moving the center to the left.

title: Wiring the Vast Left-Wing Conspiracy
description: Calling him ''overwrought,'' referring to his ''angry brand of populism'' and calling his campaign in the end no more than a ''liberal crusade in the Jerry Brown mold,'' Matt Bai sells Howard Dean seriously short. In fact, his candidacy may well prove to be one of the seminal moments in the modern history of the Democratic Party. Dean reached out to a new generation that John Kerry might well never have touched; he set forth an entirely new paradigm for grass-roots fund-raising; he was among the first to argue against the war in Iraq, which has since been a keystone in the case against President Bush; and perhaps most intriguingly, he challenged the whole Party to recreate itself and was among the first politicians to address the issues that your article seeks to draw out.

title: What Olympic Ideal?
description: The official mascots for the 2004 Summer Olympic Games in Athens are a pair of fanciful, brightly colored cartoon humanoids, and they're very, very cute; you'd never guess, just by looking at them, who they're supposed to be. Each figure has the shape of an inverted triangle, with a vestigial face and a couple of winsome, vaguely marsupial four-toed feet. One figure is an orangey red, and the other is a vivid blue, and if you didn't know anything else, you'd be right in suspecting that one's a boy and the other's a girl.

title: Out of Thin Air, Nigel Short Conjures Up a Crushing Attack

title: A Show That Works Even When Its Jokes Fall Flat
description: It's not clear why bad singers -- the ones who get a career bounce after being vituperated on ''American Idol'' -- can inspire maternal feelings or glee, while bad comics induce nausea and sorrow. But ''Last Comic Standing'' demonstrates a keen awareness of this principle, and prudently stays away from too many scenes of sad sacks bombing onstage. This summer, in its second season, NBC's talent show has won strong ratings mostly by packing the hours with -- of all things -- good jokes. The final showdown, to be televised on Tuesday, will not only resolve the continuing competition: it will also probably provide laughs instead of laughingstocks. (A public vote will follow the broadcast, and the results will be announced on Thursday.)

description: AFTER a fire on June 15 destroyed the Herald Community Newspapers offices in Lawrence, the company had its hands full just getting the newspapers out.

title: Stockholm Style
description: COOL. Stockholm is cool. During a long weekend that my boyfriend, Dan, and I spent there, I found myself chirping like a 13-year-old over whimsical hotel light fixtures and exquisite potato mashers, river buoys shaped like human hands, folding accordion-pleated ice cream dishes, and a functioning cocktail bar sculptured entirely from ice. So cool.

title: Postcards From the Fringe
description: IS there such a thing as too many options? It can feel that way with the New York International Fringe Festival, that behemoth showcase that takes over the downtown theater scene every August. With performances beginning Friday and running through Aug. 29, the eighth annual fringe features 194 low-budget productions from nine countries and 30 American cities, being shown at 20 sites -- all of which make it the biggest theatrical crapshoot in North America. Pity the poor theatergoer trying to sort through the menu of eye-catching titles (''The Cosmic Calamities of Henry Noodle,'' a ''new sci-fi musical comedy adventure''), exercises in irony (''Jonestown: The Musical'') and proudly tasteless provocations (''Die, Die, Diana: A Musical'').

title: A Touch of Milan in Hamptons
description: CITTANUOVA is Milan in the Hamptons. The name means new town in Italian and the sharp, authentic-looking newcomer is making a big splash on Newtown Lane in East Hampton. Go for an espresso, a glass of pinot grigio, a draft Moretti, a bowl of homemade gelato, an undulating panna cotta, a wild mushroom pizza, housemade ravioli or crispy chicken Milanese.

title: Seeking Prehistory

It provides a readable and authoritative account of Mary Anning, Gideon Mantel, Richard Owen and the other Georgians and Victorians who uncovered the story of the amazing fossils found in the cliffs of Lyme Bay.

description: MYERS--Howard Benjaman, of New Castle, PA, Morristown & Mtn Lakes, NJ, and Plano, TX, died August 4, 2004. He was 67. Mr. Myers was an Attorney for 40 years. He also worked for 20 years as a teacher at Temple B'nai Or in Morristown, NJ. He served on the board of trustees for The Barn Theatre in Montville, NJ, and was also a theatre critic for a local NJ newspaper. He was born in Beaver Falls, PA, graduated from New Castle HS, attended Cornell University, and obtained his law degree from Columbia University. He was married for 45 years to Ruth Adams Myers who died in April 2004. He is survived by four children & three grandchildren. Ruth & Howard can be remembered at the 18th St beach bench in Barnegat Light, NJ. ''May his soul be bound in the eternity of life.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BURNHAM, JEANNE WILLARD
description: BURNHAM--Jeanne Willard, 98, formerly of New York City and Glendale, CA, died August 6, 2004. She was the widow of William Burnham. She was born in Waltham, MA on August 21, 1905 to George Bartlett Willard and Alice Maude Barton. Her life revolved around history, genealogy and books and in pursuit of those passions, she worked as a librarian and rare book cataloger. After graduating from Simmons College she worked at the Hispanic Society in New York and later at the Yale Divinity School, the New York Society Library, the New York Historical Society and the Society of Colonial Dames. She leaves a son Jeremiah and daughterin-law Raun and countless cousins. She lived a full life and will be sorely missed.

The group said jobs in the state were susceptible to being transferred to countries where workers are paid less for the same tasks. The study, which did not list the number of jobs already lost, recommends that the state fight the outsourcing trend by promoting better-paying jobs to replace lost jobs, supporting unionization and increasing the minimum wage.

title: Surprise: Von Trier Isn't the Horror Story
description: BRYCE DALLAS HOWARD will never be able to lie about her age. Her birth in 1981 was something of a public event, reported in the press as a milestone in the life of her famous father, Ron Howard, and her mother, Cheryl. Her name disappeared from print until a few years ago, when it began appearing in New York theater reviews (although not too many critics showed up when she and her friends produced ''No Exit'' in the Times Square subway station at midnight). Ms. Howard made film industry news last year when the Danish director Lars von Trier chose her to star in ''Manderlay'' after Nicole Kidman dropped out. (Set in a town where slavery has lingered into the 1930's, it is the second film in his proposed American trilogy, which began with ''Dogville.'') And now that M. Night Shyamalan's eerie new costume drama, ''The Village,'' has opened big, she's in the public eye for good. She plays a blind woman who must venture into the menacing forest that surrounds her remote utopian community. A week before the movie's opening, she spoke with Sylviane Gold about Mr. Shyamalan, Mr. von Trier and how hard it is to break up with your director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REARICK, WILLIAM R.
description: REARICK--William R. Renowned art historian W.R. Rearick, 73, died in Venice, Italy on July 31, 2004. A memorial service was held on the island of San Michele on August 4. Curator of many exhibitions and author of numerous books and articles, he specialized in Venetian paintings and drawings from the 15th through the 17th centuries, and was perhaps the foremost authority on many Venetian artists, including Veronese and Bassano. Prof. Rearick was Prof. Emeritus in Art History and Archaeology from the University of Maryland, an honorary citizen of Bassano del Grappa and a resident of Venice. He was a member of the Board of Directors of Save Venice Inc. since 1993 and was an instrumental figure on Save Venice's Projects Committee. Save Venice is deeply grateful for his dedication, commitment, and wisdom, and notes his passing with profound sorrow.

description: The Department of Education has banned any new special education schools pending a review of the expensive programs. About 20,000 students, 9 percent of those classified with disabilities, are served in specialized schools and their home districts pay their tuition. New Jersey has the highest rate of such out-of-district placements, said Barbara Gantwerk, director of the Office of Special Education Programs; the national average is 2.9 percent. She expects the ban to last six months. ''We want to ensure that new, separate programs are only approved when they will serve an unmet need,'' she said. ''We want to make sure that our procedures aren't causing this proliferation.'' Debra Nussbaum

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLY, JOHN LOVE
description: KELLY--John Love. 80, died August 5, 2004, in Sarasota, FL, where he resided with his wife, the former Helen Hanrahan, since 1986. Former residents of Cortlandt Manor, NY. Upon retirement in 1985 he was advertising and public relations director of Avtex Fibers Inc. of New York and Valley Forge, PA. A graduate of St. Peters College, Jersey City, in 1951 he was a buyer for R.H. Macy, followed by the position of marketing executive with Sanforized Division of Cluett Peabody Co., New York. He was Catholic Co-Chairman of the Peekskill NCCJ 1961-1964, Councilman Town of Cortlandt, New York 1962-1966, current member of the Interreligious Affairs Committee and Chairman of the Catholic/Jewish Speakers Bureau of the Diocese of Venice, FL, Board member of the Siesta Key Association, Siesta Key, FL, a member of Mission Valley Country Club, Laurel, FL, and University Club, New York City. He was a lifelong Roman Catholic and Democrat. Survivors: his wife of 52 years, son J. Scott, sisters Edna Leahy, Kathryn Conway, and Florence Brady; four grandchildren, Lisa Spring, Paul, Matthew and Marc Alegi; and two greatgrandchildren. Funeral Mass 10 am, August 14, St. Thomas More Catholic Church, Sarasota, FL.

title: The Iraq Reconstruction Fiasco

Now some of those same State Department experts are quietly being called back to try to repair the damage. Their re-emergence is welcome, but late in the game. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALLMAN, DOROTHY ANN (NEE BRIDWELL)
description: HALLMAN -- Dorothy Ann (nee Bridwell). 44, of Brewster, NY, on August 6, 2004, at her home from complications of ovarian cancer and a recent stroke. Ms. Hallman co-led the Challenge Program in the Bedford Central School District, NY, since 1994. In addition, she was a choreographer, dancer and actress in professional and non-profit theater productions with Brewster Theater Company, Pawling Theatre Company, and Musicals at Richter in Danbury, CT. A former dancer, she studied for 13 years at Tulsa Ballet Theatre under the tutelage of Roman Jasinski and Moscelyne Larkin of the world-renowned Ballet Russe. Ms. Hallman achieved her Bachelor of Arts degree at New York University and her Master of Arts in Education degree at the University of Connecticut. She will be remembered as a loving and giving mother and wife, a dedicated teacher, choreographer, dancer and actress whose creativity in all endeavors knew no bounds. Ms. Hallman is survived by her husband, Bob, a senior vice president and partner in the New York City office of Fleishman Hillard International Communications, and their daughter, Laura, both of Brewster, NY; her parents, James B. and Peggy Bridwell, of Tulsa; her brother Matthew Bridwell and his family, of Tulsa; her aunts, uncles, cousins, nephews, nieces, inlaws, friends, fellow teachers, every student she ever taught, and many performing arts enthusiasts. Calling hours will be at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, on Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday in the funeral home at 11 am. Burial will be at St. Patrick's Cemetery, DeKalb Pike, Norristown, PA. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Dorothy A. Hallman Education Fund by making out a check to ''BCSD - T&A - Hallman'' and mailing it to Ms. Nancy Sasso, Treasurer, Bedford Central School District, P.O. Box 180, Mount Kisco, NY 10549.

title: Mistrusting the Drug Managers
description: New York has joined a host of other states that are suing or investigating pharmacy benefit managers, companies that purchase drugs for millions of patients. Attorney General Eliot Spitzer filed a suit last week against Express Scripts, the nation's third-largest pharmacy benefit manager, accusing it of pocketing drug savings that it was supposed to pass on to a state insurance program for active and retired government employees. The accusations are strongly denied by Express Scripts. However that legal battle turns out, the growing effort to force pharmacy benefit managers to make their operations more transparent is a welcome development. In the absence of government regulation of drug prices, the nation is relying heavily on such companies to negotiate the lowest possible prices from the pharmaceutical companies.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Subway Suicide
description: A man was killed yesterday after he jumped onto subway tracks at West 231st Street in Kingsbridge and was struck by a train, the police said. The man, whose name has not been released, was standing on the southbound side of the tracks at 12:07 p.m. when he jumped in front of an approaching train, the police said. His death is being considered a suicide, the police said. The tracks at the 231st Street station, which serves the No. 1 and 9 lines, are on an elevated platform, and witnesses said that part of the man's head fell from the tracks and landed on the street below, Broadway. Police did not provide details, but passers-by described a chaotic scene. ''People were running and screaming,'' said one man, who would not give his name. ''It was terrible.'' Colin Moynihan (NYT)

Terra said the plant in Trinidad would reduce production costs for nitrogen-based fertilizers, while Mississippi Chemical's pipeline terminal in Donaldsonville, La., would give it access to new markets in Illinois and Indiana. Mississippi Chemical is operating under bankruptcy protection.

The purchase also includes the assumption of $14 million in Smith & Hawken debt. Scotts plans to expand the market for Smith & Hawken's items by selling them at retailers like Home Depot and the Lowe's Companies, which already carry Scotts's products. Scotts is buying the chain from DDJ Capital Management, a private investment company.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Economic Growth Slows
description: The growth of Italy's gross domestic product slowed in the second quarter, an indication the recovery in the country remains tentative and could stumble in the coming months if consumer confidence does not improve. Italy's gross domestic product, the value of goods and services produced in the country, grew 0.3 percent from April to June compared with the first quarter, the country's statistics office reported. That comes after growth of 0.4 percent in the first quarter and zero growth in the last three months of 2003. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

title: MIM TO ACQUIRE CHRONIMED FOR $80 MILLION

MIM will pay 1.025 shares for each Chronimed share, the companies said. That values Chronimed at $6.27 a share, a 14 percent discount to Friday's price. Chronimed's shareholders will own 37 percent of the company, which will be named BioScrip; MIM shareholders will own 63 percent. Chronimed's chief executive, Henry Blissenbach, will be the chief executive of BioScrip; MIM's chief executive, Richard H. Friedman, will be the chairman.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint To Offer Partial Refunds
description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that it would offer partial refunds to new corporate customers for poor call service. New wireless contracts will promise refunds of as much as 30 percent to customers if Sprint's nationwide network has too many dropped or failed calls during a month, the company said. Sprint is the first American wireless carrier to give a service guarantee to all of its business customers, said Eugene Signorini, an analyst at the Yankee Group. Customers can request a 10 percent refund of monthly charges for each of three problems: if more than 2 percent of calls made within Sprint's coverage area do not connect; if more than 2 percent of completed calls are involuntarily disconnected; or if Sprint's network is not running 99.9 percent of the time. Customers can check a Web site each month to view Sprint's network performance and request a refund if it failed.

title: 1904:'Black Hand' Bomb : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: NEW YORK: Italians in America have an organization called the "Black Hand," strongly resembling that notorious secret society, the Mafia, in Italy. Various crimes of revenge and terrorism have lately been traced to this gang. The latest outrage in New York attributed to the "Black Hand" occurred yesterday [Aug. 8], when a bomb was thrown into the midst of a crowd of Italians who were being entertained "al fresco" by a saloon-keeper. Twenty persons, mostly women and children, were wounded, fortunately none of them fatally. During the panic which followed the crime the dancing platform collapsed, injuring more people. Donnetto, the Italian who threw the bomb, was among the most seriously injured. When arrested, he refused to explain the motive of the crime.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Symantec Cuts Profit On Accounting Error
description: The Symantec Corporation said yesterday that it cut its previously reported first-quarter profit and sales to reflect an accounting error. Net income for the quarter that ended July 2 was cut by 4 cents a share to 33 cents, from 37 cents earlier, the company said. Sales were cut by $20 million to $557 million from the $577.1 million that Symantec reported on July 21, the company said. Symantec, based in Cupertino, Calif., erred in how it calculated overseas sales of subscriptions to its security software, which includes antivirus programs for personal computers, the company said. As a result, it overstated by $20 million how much ''deferred revenue'' was recorded as sales in the quarter. Because of the increase in deferred revenue, the company raised its forecast for sales and profit in the second quarter ending Oct. 1. It now expects sales of $588 million, up from a forecast of $580 million, and net income of 35 cents a share, up from a forecast of 34 cents. Shares of Symantec fell $1.37 to $44.20 in after-hours trading. They rose 6 cents to $45.57 in regular trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDE, DAVID W.
description: GOLDE -- David W. The Boards of Overseers and Managers and staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center note with sorrow the sudden death of David W. Golde, former Physician-inChief of Memorial Hospital. At the time of his death, Dr. Golde was head of the Molecular and Cellular Hematology Laboratory at the SloanKettering Institute and Attending Physician, Leukemia Service, Department of Medicine, Division of Hematologic Oncology. Dr. Golde was renowned for his contributions to the understanding of normal and leukemic blood cell growth and development, and for applying these discoveries clinically. A valued friend and colleague, he played an important role in every aspect of our organization as clinician, scientist, institutional leader, and mentor during his thirteen years at Memorial Sloan - Kettering. His work will continue to benefit patients with cancer now and in the future. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife and family. James D. Robinson III Honorary Co-Chairman of Boards Douglas A. Warner III Chairman of Boards Richard I. Beattie Vice Chairman of Boards Louis V. Gerstner, Jr. Vice Chairman of Boards Harold Varmus President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center Robert W. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Rise
description: Japanese machinery orders rose faster than expected in June as companies increased spending on telecommunications and precision equipment. The 3.9 percent increase in orders from May, seasonally adjusted, was almost four times faster than the 1 percent median forecast. Orders in the April-June quarter increased a record 10.3 percent from the previous three months, the Cabinet office said in Tokyo. Core machinery orders, which exclude shipping and utilities, rose to 1.04 trillion yen ($9.4 billion), the highest since November of 2000, from 997 billion yen. Orders in the nonmanufacturing sector rose 10 percent, the first rise in two months, while orders for the manufacturing sector dropped 2.8 percent. (Bloomberg News)

title: 1929:'Scarface' Al Moved : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: PHILADELPHIA: "Scarface" Al Capone, Chicago's notorious gang leader, who is serving his first prison sentence, has been transferred from the Holmesburg County Prison to the Eastern State Penitentiary, following threats made against his life by other prisoners, it became known today [Aug. 9]. It is said that the gang leader's prison mates had become jealous as a result of the large number of visitors whom he has received since he was sentenced two months ago. The transfer was ascribed officially to the over-crowded condition of the Holmesburg jail. It has been learned from other sources, however, that prison officials felt that "perhaps Capone would be safer at the Eastern 'Pen' than at Holmesburg." It is reported that Capone had been a model prisoner, but that the attitude of others had caused alarm for his safety. His bodyguard, Cline, who was convicted at the same time, remains at Holmesburg. Each is serving a one-year sentence on charges of carrying concealed weapons.

Saying he believed it to be the first such action taken by a state labor federation, President Denis M. Hughes, left, said that with the largest state federation in the country -- with two and half million members -- New York should set an example. The resolution bars officers and staff members from accepting ''inappropriate contributions or other things of value'' from individuals, corporations, businesses or others seeking to exert ''improper influence.'' title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Telecom Profit Rises

The company, which reiterated a full-year pretax profit forecast of 1.4 billion to 1.7 billion euros, earned 183 million euros and reported 2.96 billion euros in sales in the second quarter of last year. KPN attributed its improved performance, in part, to cost-cutting programs and increasing demand for its mobile phone and Internet broadband services. The company's fixed-line telephone business continued to be a drag on results, with net sales down 6.3 percent to 1.8 billion euros. KPN is struggling to offset lower prices for fixed-line service required in part by regulators along with an increasing number of customers abandoning fixed-line phones for mobile ones. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Wall Street Roadblocks Upheld
description: A challenge to the roadblocks operated by the New York Stock Exchange at intersections around its headquarters has been rebuffed by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court. The decision last week reversed an order by Justice Walter B. Tolub, who said in March that the ''specter of private police forces patrolling public streets is unacceptable.'' Justice Peter Tom of the Appellate Division, writing for a five-judge panel, said there was ''some degree of official scrutiny'' over the stock exchange's security operation, borne out by the number of city police officers in the area. The Wall Street Parking Garage sued the exchange, saying that blockades and street repairs had ruined its business. It still plans to pursue its damage claim since the court preserved its right to do so, its lawyers at Jenkens & Gilchrist Parker Chapin said yesterday. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: Photographer and His Art Are Home at Last
description: Shortly before his death last winter at 83, Helmut Newton found a way of closing the circle of his life. He created the Helmut Newton Foundation in Berlin, his birthplace and the city where he learned to be a photographer. He also picked a suitably symbolic home for the foundation, a former Prussian army officers' club that stands beside the railroad station where, as an 18-year-old Jew, he boarded a train to flee Hitler's Germany in December 1938.

description: A 70-year-old Pennsylvania woman whose son kept a 400-pound Bengal tiger in her Harlem apartment will not face charges, officials in the Manhattan district attorney's office said yesterday. The case against the woman, Martha Yates, was adjourned with contemplation of dismissal yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Officials said Ms. Yates had been charged with endangering the welfare of a child because she baby-sat in the apartment where her son, Antoine, 37, kept a tiger named Ming. Mr. Yates pleaded guilty to reckless endangerment last month and will be sentenced on Sept. 16. Ming was given a new home in October on a wildlife preserve in Ohio. Susan Saulny (NYT)

They followed a tiny path through the mob, serenaded by a chorus of camera shutters and the jostling of dozens of television camera operators.

title: The Shame of New York
description: In this presidential year, the election systems of swing states like Florida are being subjected to considerable scrutiny. Other states' systems, which may be just as troubled but unlikely to produce a crisis in the presidential vote count, are being ignored. New York, in particular, has one of the nation's most dysfunctional, opaque and patronage-ridden structures for running elections. It needs an overhaul, starting with the New York State Board of Elections, which should be dismantled.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: China: Bid For Hungarian Airline
description: The Hainan Airlines Company, whose biggest shareholder is the financier George Soros, left, plans to bid for Malev, Hungary's unprofitable airline, to expand overseas. ''We are in preliminary talks with Malev about taking a stake in the company,'' said Song Chenliang, a Hainan Airlines spokesman, who declined to provide details. Hungary plans to seek bids for Malev next week in a fourth attempt to sell the carrier. Hainan is adding overseas routes to compete with larger competitors like Air China and China Southern Airlines. Hungary, a new member of the European Union, is selling assets to reduce its budget deficit and debt and qualify for the euro currency by 2010.

title: No Major Complications for Separated Twins, Doctors Say
description: Clarence and Carl Aguirre, the 2-year-old Filipino twins once joined at the top of their heads, have made it well beyond the crucial 72-hour period after their separation surgery without showing any signs of major complications, doctors said yesterday.

title: Seeking The Beauty Of Stillness
description: Certain moments in my life are like sharply focused snapshots that never fade. I was in my flannel pajamas watching TV in my parents' bedroom in Douglaston, N.Y., the day Neil Armstrong stepped onto the moon. More than a decade later, when news broke of John Lennon's death, I was cramming for a test in my dorm room at Boston University.

title: Federal Reserve Raises Short-Term Rates a Quarter Point

title: In the Hands of Young Surgeons
description: Being operated on by a surgeon in his or her first years of independent practice is no more dangerous than being in the hands of more established surgeons, a new British study has concluded.

title: Albany Budget Near, but Pataki's Intentions Are Unclear
description: By adding some spending and restoring some money that was previously cut, New York's two top legislators said on Monday that they planned to enact a state budget this week that is about $1.2 billion more than the roughly $100 billion plan that Gov. George E. Pataki sent them in January. They also said they would reject some proposed taxes and fees.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Charge In Wife's Death
description: A Salt Lake City man was charged with first-degree murder in the death of his wife, Lori Hacking. Mrs. Hacking, 27, was last seen on July 18. A probable-cause statement released by prosecutors said that Mark Hacking, 28, had shot his wife after she learned of one of his numerous deceptions -- the fact that he had never been accepted to a medical school in North Carolina. In the statement, Mr. Hacking's two brothers said he had told them, ''Lori's dead and I killed her.'' Mrs. Hacking's body has not been found. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: New Leader For Rights Group
description: The Rev. Fred Shuttlesworth, an 82-year-old Cincinnati minister and a pioneer of the nation's civil rights movement, will lead the Southern Christian Leadership Conference over the next year. Mr. Shuttlesworth helped found the Atlanta-based rights group in 1958 with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the Rev. Ralph Abernathy. Mr. Shuttlesworth is pastor of the Greater New Light Baptist Church. Albert Salvato (NYT)

title: Banning Bad News in Iraq
description: As interim prime minister, Ayad Allawi is supposed to be guiding Iraq toward democratic elections. Yet in his first six weeks he has begun yielding to the same kind of authoritarian mentality that has stifled democracy in too many neighboring states. His latest target is Al Jazeera, whose sometimes sensational news coverage is the Arab world's principal source of uncensored information. Claiming that Al Jazeera's extensive coverage of terrorist kidnappings and other crimes encourages continuing violence, Mr. Allawi's police shut down the station's Baghdad bureau on Saturday for at least 30 days. The office will be allowed to reopen only if Al Jazeera agrees to change its policies.

title: Casting Performers and Preachers for the Republicans' Big Show
description: When the curtain goes up on the Republican National Convention on Aug. 30, the supporting cast will include gospel-and country-music performers, elaborate videos, and celebrities doing what they can to help market President Bush's ideas and vision for America, one of the convention's organizers said yesterday.

title: U.S. Security Officers Will Take Over Passenger Screening on Helicopter Tours
description: Federal security officers will take over the screening of all passengers on helicopter tours in New York City, after officials found that suspected Qaeda operatives in Pakistan had photographs, a brochure and other information about the tours.

title: Past Wrongs, Future Rights
description: Political earthquakes, like real earthquakes, often come in pairs. Last month a special prosecutor indicted a former Mexican president for genocide -- and the case was dismissed the very next day. Even in Mexico, where we have plenty of experience with these phenomena, this was a double earthquake of the highest magnitude.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Cyberguard Ends Bid For Secure Computing
description: The CyberGuard Corporation, which sells firewall and other security software to government agencies and businesses, said yesterday that it was no longer trying to acquire Secure Computing, based in San Jose, Calif. CyberGuard, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., will instead focus on integrating existing acquisitions, the company said. Last month, CyberGuard offered to swap one of its shares for each share of Secure Computing, which rejected the unsolicited offer.

title: 8 Agencies Involved In Arby's Review
description: Arby's, the sandwich shop chain owned by the Triarc Companies, named eight agencies to participate in a review for the creative part of its national branding account, with spending estimated at $15 million. The assignment had been handled since 1987 by Doner in Southfield, Mich., which decided against taking part when the review began in July.

title: How Is a Martian Rover Like a Bear?
description: Winter is bearing down on the southern hemisphere of Mars, where the days are growing shorter and colder, and the dimming Sun seems to be running out of energy. That means it's time for the two robotic rovers there, Spirit and Opportunity, to be going into a kind of hibernation.

title: U.S. RESTAURANT PROPERTIES PURCHASES COMPETITOR
description: U.S. Restaurant Properties, which leases properties to restaurants including Burger King and Pizza Hut, agreed to buy CNL Restaurant Properties for $1.3 billion to create the largest company providing financial and real estate services to the country's restaurant industry. The price makes up $700 million to $750 million in U.S. Restaurant's common and preferred stock and $540 million for 18 CNL Income Funds, of which $450 million is in cash and the rest preferred stock, CNL Restaurant's chief financial officer, Steve Shackelford, said. The combined company will own 1,900 properties and have financial interests in about 3,000 sites in 49 states.

title: Court Says Author Can't Sell His Book on Evading Taxes
description: A federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled yesterday that Irwin Schiff, the nation's best-known tax protester, cannot sell his book ''The Federal Mafia'' because it gives fraudulent advice and encourages people to evade income taxes. Anyone but Mr. Schiff or his associates may sell the $38 volume.

Rowland in the impeachment inquiry that prompted his resignation, is joining a private law firm's white-collar criminal defense and government investigations practice. Mr. Garber, 37, left his position as the governor's in-house legal counsel shortly after Mr. Rowland resigned effective July 1. He will become a partner at Shipman & Goodwin, a Hartford firm where he was an associate before he left to run for state treasurer in the 2002 election. Mr. Garber, a Republican, joined Mr. Rowland's administration after losing the 2002 race. William Yardley (NYT)

title: 1929:Suicide Is Curable : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: DETROIT: The suicide impulse is a curable disease, according to Dr. J. Clark Moloney, of the division of neuropsychiatry at Henry Ford hospital. Dr. Moloney has conducted research for several years on the causes and the cure of suicidal tendencies. Dr. Moloney points out that despite the growing prevalence of suicide little is done to try to prevent it, though in his opinion suicide is curable, the same as tuberculosis, cancer, diphtheria and other diseases which have brought about huge preventative campaigns. "The direct cause of suicide is the awareness of the frustration of ideals or ambition, said Dr. Moloney. This may be either real or imagined. The loss of hope that he will ever be any different is by far the most important symptom, and it is hope which must be built up at the beginning of the cure."

title: Sale of a Picasso Lifts Sotheby's in Quarter

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Executive Extends Term
description: The British clothing retailer Marks & Spencer Group said Paul Myners, left, would remain as chairman until the company's annual meeting in July 2005. Mr. Myners will step down from the board of a cellphone company, MMO2, and as a trustee of the Charities Aid Foundation to make more time for Marks & Spencer, though he will stay on the boards of the Guardian Media Group and Aspen Insurance Holdings, said Lisa Attenborough, a spokeswoman for the retail company. Marks & Spencer has been looking for a new chairman since Luc Vandevelde announced his intention to leave in May. Mr. Myners, 56, accepted the position on an interim basis at the end of that month. ''The company now needs a period of stability in order to focus on the day-to-day running of the business,'' Kevin Lomax, senior independent director, said in a statement. ''We are grateful that Paul has freed up more time in order to be able to continue for longer than he had originally planned.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NACHMAN, MARVIN L.
description: NACHMAN--Marvin L. On August 8, 2004. Devoted husband, father, grandfather, uncle, brother-in-law, fatherin-law and friend. We will miss your warmth, kindness and humor. May you rest in peace.

title: Heartache and Its Consolations,Rendered With Musical Grace
description: A certain smile kept crossing Sarah McLachlan's face as she sang at the Continental Arena here on Monday night. It wasn't a toothy, show-business grin or the beginning of a laugh. It was more private, serene and beatific, the expression of someone touched by grace. It's the feeling she wants for the aftermath of her songs, which confess deep sorrows and longings, then proffer consolation. Her music is something to sink into, like a featherbed after a good cry.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Karzai To Face 17
description: The country's election commission has approved 18 candidates for the presidential election on Oct. 9, among them the head of the transitional administration, President Hamid Karzai, and two main rivals, the Tajik leader Muhammad Yunus Qanooni, and the Uzbek general Abdul Rashid Dostum, from northern Afghanistan. The 18 were approved despite more than 100 complaints lodged with the election commission against various candidates, accusing them of maintaining illegal militias and even crimes against humanity. The commission said that none of the candidates had been found guilty of such crimes in a court of law. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Twist in Bryant Rape Case As Accuser Files Lawsuit
description: The rape case against the basketball star Kobe Bryant, which is scheduled to begin with jury selection in two weeks, took a sharp twist on Tuesday when his accuser filed a lawsuit against him in Federal District Court in Denver, seeking monetary damages.

title: Three Lawyers in a Room
description: New York's Legislature has returned to cobble together a budget and try to finish a session that should win the nadir award for dismal legislative failure. Since January, legislators and the governor have achieved nothing. The budget is breaking new records for lateness every day -- a considerable achievement for a Legislature known nationally for its dysfunctionality. A plan for budget reform is in limbo. A minimum-wage bill, vetoed by Gov. George Pataki, has not gone to the floor for an override vote. Lobbying reform is stalled. And the one big thing Albany needed to do -- deal with a court-ordered reform of school financing -- has been a total failure.

title: Ferry Owner Agrees to Pay $800,000 In Fee Dispute
description: New York Waterway, the largest ferry operator on the Hudson River, has agreed to pay the city $800,000 to settle a dispute over landing fees at Pier 11 in Lower Manhattan that began in the months after the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Up, Up and Away, With Many Balloons
description: Danny Morgan (Rhys Ifans), the blond, sleepy-eyed hero of the Australian comedy ''Danny Deckchair,'' lives out a fantasy entertained by every child who has ever watched a helium balloon float into the sky and developed a lump in the throat as it disappeared. What would it be like to go along for the ride, drifting over the landscape to a destination determined by the whims of the wind?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POLEN, EDWARD
description: POLEN--Edward. On Friday August 6th, age 77, died from lung cancer. He is survived by his loving wife of 51 years, Shirley, as well as his children Signe Adam of Eastford, CT, Russell Polen of Woodmere, NY, and Tara Polen of New York City and six grandchildren, Jocelyn, Zachary, Bennett and Natalie Polen and David and Ross Adam. Ed was born in Brooklyn, attended Townsend Harris High School and CCNY. He volunteered to serve in the US Navy and worked on submarine electronics, as well training sonar technicians in WW II. After his service he completed his education at Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute earning a degree in electrical engineering. He began his career as a design engineer and quickly became a plant manager. Shortly after that he founded a company in Brooklyn which grew to become the largest privately held manufacturer and distributor of transformers in the United States. From 1953 to 1983 Signal Transformer grew to eventually employ over 350 people in New York and Puerto Rico. Edward and Shirley relocated to Florida in 1987 where they enjoyed active retirement. He was a Bronze Bridge Life Master. In January 2003 they celebrated the 50th anniversary of their marriage with a lovely wedding ceremony and unforgettable celebration. His generosity, kindness, intelligence and sense of humor will be missed by all. Should friends desire contributions can be made to: American Foundation for Chinese Medicine, Strang Cancer Prevention, 428 East 72nd St. New York, NY 10021. For information Star of David Funeral Home, N. Lauderdale, FL.

title: With a Bit Of Love, The Blues Are Just Fine
description: HANG around enough old salts, and sooner or later one of them will recount his favorite recipe for bluefish: Nail a few fillets to a plank of seasoned hardwood, stick them over a fire, and when their edges crisp and curl, throw away the fish and eat the plank.

title: HOOPER HOLMES QUESTIONS ITS CHIEF'S DONATIONS
description: Hooper Holmes Inc., which conducts physical examinations for insurance companies, said an ethics inquiry at the company is preventing KPMG from finishing its second-quarter audit. Hooper, based in Basking Ridge, N.J., said it hired an independent counsel to examine reimbursements to its chief executive, James McNamee, for charitable donations and other expenses. Details of the donations and expenses were not revealed. They were made in Hooper's name, a violation of its code of ethics and a breach of Mr. McNamee's fiduciary duty, the company said. Mr. McNamee did not return a telephone message seeking comment.

description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLF, ALEXANDER, JR.
description: WOLF--Alexander, Jr. Resident of Lattingtown, N.Y. since 1967, died peacefully on August 10, 2004 surrounded by his family. Mr. Wolf was founder of Alexander Wolf and Company, a graduate of NYU Law School, member of the American Bar Association since 1956 and member of the Real Estate Board of New York since 1958. Mr. Wolf served on the Board of the Lattingtown Harbor Property Owners' Association and was the President of the Association on four occasions. Survived by beloved wife of 23 years, Joan Castellvi-Lulewich. Devoted father of Alexander III (Sharon), Robert (Heidi), Ken, John (Barbara) and Richard (Heidi). He was also father to Joan's children, Chris and Michael Kocis, Blair and James Griesmeyer, Allison and Ed Godfrey, Bart and Cecilia Castellvi. Loving grandfather of 21. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, Canine Companions for Independence, or Saint Jude's Children Research Hospital. Services will be held at McLaughlin Kramer Megiel Funeral Home, Glen Cove, N.Y. on Thursday, August 12th, from 7-9PM and Friday, August 13th, from 35PM and 7-9PM, at which time a memorial service will be held.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the number of new low-income jobs compared with high-income jobs misstated figures from an analysis of Labor Department payroll data conducted by Economy.com, an economic research firm. Since January, industries ranked in the bottom fifth in terms of median wages have generated 177,000 jobs, not 477,000. Industries in the top fifth generated 135,000 jobs, not zero.

title: U.S. to Give Border Patrol Agents The Power to Deport Illegal Aliens
description: Citing concerns about terrorists crossing the nation's borders, the Department of Homeland Security said on Tuesday that it planned to give border patrol agents sweeping new powers to deport illegal aliens from the frontiers with Mexico and Canada without providing them the opportunity to make their case before an immigration judge.

title: A Neglected Neighborhood Builds Itself a Village
description: Fruitvale Village may startle some visitors who see it for the first time from the platform of the BART train station. From that vantage, the festive ''village'' looks very much like an upscale suburban shopping center, set incongruously amid the brick buildings and dilapidated wooden houses of a once-fearsome neighborhood.

description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System, the largest pension fund in the nation, posted its biggest annual return in six years because of gains in its stocks, bonds and real estate holdings.

They followed a tiny path opened through the mob, serenaded by a chorus of camera shutters and the jostling of dozens of television camera operators.

title: U.S. Chief Pushes Oil Giant's Moves Beyond Australia
description: Woodside Energy, Australia's largest oil and gas company, is proud of its all-Australian pedigree that stretches back to unsuccessful wildcat exploration in southern scrubland 50 years ago. The company went on to discover the North West Shelf gas deposits that have become as much an icon to Australians as the Sydney Opera House.

description: BRANT--Lorraine, 1927-2004. Beloved wife of the late S. Jack Brant, Esq. Devoted mother of Stacy Ellen Brant & Dr. Marvin Feinstein. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Scleroderma Foundation, 12 Kent Way, Suite 101, Byfield MA 01922. title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Soviet-Era Hotel To Be Torn Down
description: First the Intourist came down and then the Moskva. Now Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov of Moscow has signed an order to tear down another of the city's famous hotels, the Rossiya, a hulking stone and glass monument to Soviet central planning. Erected in 1967 on an embankment of the Moscow River with spectacular views of the Kremlin, the Rossiya is one of the largest hotels in the world, with more than 3,000 rooms, concert halls and dozens of restaurants and bars still offering Soviet-style service. Begun under Khrushchev and completed under Brezhnev, the Rossiya was a center of Soviet politics and culture before falling into disrepair in the new Russia. According to Russian news reports, the hotel, whose construction destroyed dozens of buildings in one of the oldest parts of the city, will be replaced by a new hotel and entertainment complex, though so far no plans for the site have been made public. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Just Like Great-Grandpa's Peep Show
description: When the Canadian director Guy Maddin passes from this mortal coil, here's hoping that he bequeaths his gloriously strange brain to science or at least to one of the nation's leading film schools. Given Mr. Maddin's flights of imaginative fancy, which soar as high as Icarus but to happier end, and given too his passion for old movies, film students would do well to study this noggin shaped by the codes and lyricism of early cinema. If nothing else, they would learn that before Steven Spielberg created ''Jaws,'' F. W. Murnau lighted up the theater dark with ''Sunrise.''

description: Traveling here through Florida's conservative Panhandle, President Bush told supporters Tuesday that he had a new backer for his decision to invade Iraq: Senator John Kerry.

title: HOLLINGER SPENT $7 MILLION IN LEGAL FEES IN 2ND QUARTER
description: Hollinger International Inc., which publishes The Chicago Sun-Times and The Daily Telegraph of London, said it spent about $7 million in the second quarter on legal fees related to its investigation into payments to company executives. Hollinger formed a committee of independent directors in June 2003 to study transactions involving payments to certain executives from company asset sales, the company said in a quarterly filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Hollinger, which is based in Chicago, will not file its second-quarter earnings with the S.E.C. until the investigation is complete, the company said in the filing. Hollinger sued Conrad Black, its former chief executive, in January, contending that he deceived directors and misappropriated $200 million.

title: A New Chicken in Town, Full of Guatemalan Spice
description: The line went around the block at 4506 Fifth Avenue, Sunset Park, Brooklyn, last week at the opening of Pollo Campero, the second New York store in this fried chicken chain. The scene was the same when the first Pollo Campero opened last month at 103-26 Roosevelt Avenue, in Corona, Queens. The popularity of the chain, which originated in Guatemala and has restaurants in Los Angeles, Houston and Washington, is deserved. Its deeply burnished chicken, especially the dark meat, is moist beneath its crunchy mantle and leaves a spicy glow on the palate. Neil Colley, the managing partner of the New York franchise group, said the dark meat outsells white. The best sides are beans, mashed potatoes and rice. Prices start at $2.95 for two pieces of dark meat. More Pollo Camperos are planned in East Harlem and Brentwood, L.I.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Thursday about federal indictments in the fatal crash of a Staten Island ferryboat last fall referred imprecisely to the job status of Patrick Ryan, New York City's director of ferry operations, and Richard J. Smith, the ship's pilot. They were both suspended with pay, not without. The article also misstated the given name of Mr. Ryan's lawyer. He is Thomas Fitzpatrick, not William. Because of another editing error, the article referred incorrectly to the United States attorney in Brooklyn. The prosecutor, Rosslyn R. Mauskopf, is a woman.

description: Robert Tisch, a co-owner of the Giants, has inoperable brain cancer and is undergoing treatment, a family spokesman said yesterday.

description: In Las Vegas, a place resolutely dedicated to fantasy and the pursuit of dreams, the all-too-real possibility that terrorists of Al Qaeda focused on several casinos has prompted city officials and casino operators into a frenzy of assurances that all is safe here.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Stooge Sounds Invade Ring Tones
description: Sound effects and one-liners from the Three Stooges have been turned into ring tones, which could be either good news for fans of the comedians or the latest reason to hate cellphones. Aside from the troupe's famous exclamations -- like ''woo-woo'' and ''nyuck-nyuck'' -- 2ThumbZ Entertainment is making available such gems as Moe Howard, the leader, yelling, ''You idiot, I ought to kill you'' to replace the pre-packaged ring on cellphones. Sales of ring tones are becoming a crucial source of revenue for carriers as the price of phone calls drops because of unrelenting competition. The 167 million cellphone subscribers in the United States have turned sales of ring tones and other data-oriented services into a $1-billion-a-year revenue generator for some carriers.

title: Torre Can Manage Steinbrenner's Barbs
description: Joe Torre has survived and thrived for nine years as the manager of the Yankees by knowing how to deal with George Steinbrenner, the team's principal owner. Whether it is Steinbrenner's instant criticism, his blustery remarks or his high expectations, Torre treats every noise from him as if a button fell off his shirt. No big deal.

title: Edwards, U.S. Sprinter, Receives Two-Year Ban for Doping
description: ATHENS, Aug. 11  Torri Edwards, the sprinter who had made the United States team in the 100 meters and 200 meters, was officially suspended for two years today by the United States Anti-Doping Agency.

title: Globalist : Meal with an Eichmann in a borderless Europe
description: ZILL, Germany  There is a pleasant country inn here where Germany meets Austria, a frontier that now exists only in name, recalled by the quaint wooden border posts used by customs agents before the European Union put them out of work. Stout Bavarian women of placid mien and manner serve roast lamb and duck, killed that day on the farm, and tall glasses of turbid white beer. It is hard to imagine a better combination.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fischer Moved
description: After almost one month in detention at Narita Airport in Tokyo, Bobby Fischer, the former world chess champion, has been transferred to a longer-term detention center in Ushiku, 40 miles northeast. Mr. Fischer, 61, is fighting a decision to deport him to the United States, where he is wanted on charges that in 1992 he defied an international embargo on travel to the former Yugoslavia to earn more than $3 million in a rematch against Boris Spassky. Masako Suzuki, his lawyer, says Mr. Fischer wants to renounce his United States citizenship. James Brooke (NYT)

title: About New York; On Dirtiest Beach, Not So Much Filth
description: HANGING over the city yesterday was a haze created by current weather patterns and continuing reports of imminent terrorist attack. Hazy, crazy, but hardly lazy; that is the summer of '04.

title: Thai as Theater, Restaurant as Stage
description: IN Kittichai's liberally and fantastically interpreted Thailand, the orchids do not bloom in vases on the tables. They twist in an ersatz spider web above a dark reflecting pool in the center of the dining room. Buoyant votive candles skitter across the pool's surface, unless the manufactured currents are not working right. In that case, a server or a manager pokes and prods the recalcitrant props into action.

title: U.S. Forces, Close to Attack in Najaf, Decide to Hold Off
description: NAJAF, Iraq, Aug. 11  After spending today preparing for a major attack against insurgents loyal to the rebel Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr, American forces called off the assault, at least for now.

title: Cool Melon and Earthy Nori Meet for a Summery Waltz
description: AT 10:30 on a recent Tuesday morning, Josh DeChellis sat at the bar of Sumile, the Manhattan restaurant where he is executive chef. A telephone was clapped to his ear as he hunted down live blue crabs.

description: Timo Lumme was named marketing director for the International Olympic Committee, a post that had been vacant since Michael Payne became director for global broadcast and media rights for the committee. Mr. Lumme had been vice president for Europe, the Middle East and Africa at the ESPN unit of the Walt Disney Company.

title: What Happens in Vegas ...
description: LAS VEGAS  Usually, when cheers erupt on the casino floor, its because some lucky guy at the craps table is throwing doubles, or the dealer busted at blackjack. But shortly after 11 p.m. Tuesday at the Bellagio , the gamblers were clapping before the cards were even dealt, as Senator John Kerry ambled over to watch an aide play a few hands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELLIOTT, MARGARET
description: ELLIOTT -- Margaret, in Westport, CT, August 8, 2004. Wife of the late Robert F. Elliott Sr., mother of Robert F. Elliott Jr., Margaret Markovic, Kathleen Elliott and Mary Sikorski. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. To Supply Computers To Circuit City
description: I.B.M. has won a contract to supply computers and consulting services to Circuit City Stores. Terms were not disclosed. I.B.M. will provide computers and other hardware, including wireless checkout devices, to Circuit City's 600 stores, the companies said yesterday. I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., will begin work early next year. I.B.M. won an order in June from Pep Boys-Manny, Moe & Jack, which sells auto parts and service. I.B.M.'s chief executive, Samuel J. Palmisano, is pushing for increased sales of consulting services, which accounted for about half of the company's $89.1 billion in revenue last year. Shares of I.B.M. rose $1.44, to $84.99. Circuit City shares rose 44 cents, to $13.06.

title: Stressful Job of Keeping the Governor Unruffled
description: IN her shoebox office at the Connecticut Capitol, M. Lisa Moody flashes the grin of a just-caught schoolchild and opens a desk drawer to reveal a cache of toys -- ''stress reducers,'' she calls them, squeezing a few of the candy-colored, rubber-furred Koosh balls piled there.

title: REVENUE LOWER THAN EXPECTED
description: The Democratic National Convention last month gave Boston's economy only a $14.8 million lift, far short of the $154 million that city officials had projected, a study by a research organization, the Beacon Hill Institute, has found. The institute, which is affiliated with Suffolk University, had originally forecast that the convention would result in an $8.2 million net loss. The event brought in $156.7 million, the group estimates, but that was offset by $141.9 million in lost business from those who avoided the city during the convention. Matt Viser (NYT)

description: COHEN--Alan. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. description: After an eight-year absence, Tiger Woods has returned to Wisconsin -- older, wiser, richer, but still under the microscope.

description: The Walt Disney Company said on Tuesday that attendance at its theme parks and growth in its cable network business helped improve performance in its third quarter and that it was on track to meet analysts' expectations for the year.

description: ALL signs point to Washington or Northern Virginia, except one large sign that doesn't, and the message on that sign is the one that has to be reconciled before the Montreal Expos can ship their bats and balls to R.F.K. Stadium in the nation's capital.

title: A Vacation With Ghosts
description: My first six summers were American suburban, filled with the familiar thrills of Slip 'N Slides and sprinklers, the smell of gasoline lawnmowers and the tickle of grass blades sticking to my skin. Then, the summer I was 7, my mother took me to Japan to visit my grandmother. It was my first trip outside the United States.

title: Convention Protesters Drop Deal For Rally, Pushing Anew for Park
description: Organizers of the largest protest planned for the Republican National Convention yesterday backed out of an agreement with the city to rally along the West Side Highway, and said they would push to hold the event in Central Park despite the city's opposition.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Cuts Forecast
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation cut its first-quarter sales forecast yesterday, citing customer efforts to cut inventories and weaker-than-expected orders for flat panel display chips and cellphone parts in China. The shares fell 8.9 percent in extended trading. Sales will fall as much as 5 percent in the quarter ending Aug. 29, to $543 million to $548 million, compared with $571.2 million in the previous quarter, the company said. It previously said sales would be ''flat to up 3 percent.'' National Semiconductor's shares fell $1.39, to $14.31, in extended trading. They rose 8 cents, to $15.70, in regular trading.

title: Want a Little Beef With Your Garlic?
description: GRILLED steak with a load of garlic is one of the few interesting dishes to have emerged from Romania, where it is called fleica. That statement is probably a little unfair to a cuisine also known for mamaliga, a cornmeal mush that is indistinguishable from polenta, but never mind. Cooking steak in this way turns even the most mundane cut into something great.

title: A Dance as Lighthearted Goddess Worship
description: In a converted soap factory near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, in a studio down a hallway paved with glistening whorls of mosaic glass and up three steep flights of wood stairs, a motley collection of dancers were gyrating and chanting on Saturday as they summoned the powers of Saraswati, the Hindu goddess of learning and the arts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHERNEY, PAULA

We extend our deepest condolences to the entire family. Our thoughts are with you. Ralph Herzka, President and CEO Aaron Birnbaum, Executive V.P.

description: Gov. James E. McGreevey signed legislation on Tuesday that will protect more than 400,000 acres of land as well as drinking water for more than 5.4 million state residents.

title: Challenging Lawyers' Training, And Finding Some Ethics
description: In the Polish city of Radom, back before World War II, Norman Rosenbaum practiced law. Then the Germans invaded and under their statutes stripped Jews of their rights and ultimately shipped them to death camps. By the time Mr. Rosenbaum emerged from Bergen-Belsen and made his way to America, he had lost faith in two former certainties: God and the law.

title: Toasting Olympic Athletes With Greek Authenticity
description: Greek restaurants are celebrating the Olympic Games, which start on Friday in Athens, with food and drink, of course. At En Plo, 103 West 77th Street, Peter Spyropoulos and Katerina Kampouroglou have installed an ouzo bar, which they call an ouzerie, with television. They are ready to pour 20 varieties of ouzo, Greece's famous anise-flavored spirit ($7 to $8). They also serve ouzo-based cocktails including, from right, the lime-infused Paros; the Ios, made with peach Schnapps; and the rosy Hydra (all $9). Delicious zucchini and eggplant chips are among the snacks available for munching.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Sentence For Father In Cold-Medicine Deaths
description: A man who admitted that he gave his two children a lethal dose of cold medicine in 2002 was sentenced to six years in prison. The man, Robert Henderson, 31, of Aurora, pleaded guilty to criminally negligent homicide and second-degree assault for giving his 5-year-old son and 4-year-old daughter adult cold medicine to get them to nap. Mindy Sink (NYT)
