description: ''It feels strange,'' Andy Pettitte said. ''Weird.''

title: Parties to Use the City as a Symbol, But of What?
description: When the Republicans chose New York City as the site of their national nominating convention, the symbolism seemed to play to the president's strength. But Democrats are hoping to turn the convention's location to their advantage.

title: Democrats Give Republicans a Fight for the Elderly
description: When President Bush signed a Medicare bill into law in December, Republicans thought it would allow them to make sharp inroads into elderly voters.

title: Fresh-Tasting Guacamole With a Secret
description: Looking for a fresh twist for guacamole and chips? Frontera Foods, started by Rick Bayless, the chef of Frontera Grill in Chicago, has introduced a guacamole mix based on tomatillos, an ingredient that home cooks often ignore. Add three avocados to an 8-ounce jar (about $3.99) and you have a dip with a refreshing tartness and just enough spice. For dipping, polenta chips ($2.49 to $3 for 5 ounces) made by Good Health Natural Foods in Northport, N.Y., are close to irresistible, especially in the mellow barbecue flavor. They also come plain, in hot jalapeo and in tangy guacamole. The chips are sold at Whole Foods and other markets; the mix, at some Whole Foods, will be available in New York in about a month.

title: Global Oil Demand Expected to Exceed Forecasts, Report Says
description: PARIS, Aug. 11 — Global oil demand is expected to be higher in 2004 and 2005 than initially forecast, increasing pressure on oil producers to boost their output at a time when rising oil prices may hurt a recovering world economy, according to a report by the Paris-based International Energy Agency.

title: On Other Side of the Aisle, Bruised Feelings Linger
description: The Republican congressman chosen by President Bush to head the Central Intelligence Agency initially resisted efforts in Congress two years ago to create an independent commission to investigate the Sept. 11 attacks, Democratic Congressional officials who were involved in the legislative battle say.

title: Legislature Passes Education Budget, Providing $300 Million More to New York City
description: Lawmakers began passing the first pieces of the latest budget in New York State's history here on Tuesday by approving a bill on the issue that had confounded them all year: education spending.

description: SCOTT CONANT, below, the chef at L'IMPERO in Tudor City, will soon have a kitchen downtown, too. Next month, he will open BAR TONNO, 17 Cleveland Place (Kenmare Street), specializing in Italian raw fish dishes. His partners are CHRISTOPHER CANNON and JANE EPSTEIN (his partners at L'Impero), and FREDERICK TWOMEY, an owner, with Mr. Cannon, of the Bar Veloces. With a staff of knife-wielding Japanese chefs, Bar Tonno, to be open from 6 p.m. to 3 a.m., will serve plates of fluke with baby porcini and seaweed salad and anchovies with marinated eggplant.

title: Mapuche Indians in Chile Struggle to Take Back Forests
description: Before the conquistadors arrived, and even for centuries afterward, the lush, verdant forests of southern Chile belonged to the Mapuche people. Today, though, tree farms stretch in all directions here, property of timber companies that supply lumber to the United States, Japan and Europe.

title: 1954:Forger on Trial : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: LUEBECK, Germany: A 41-year-old penniless German artist went on trial here today [Aug. 10] charged with faking medieval frescoes in a historic church and a cathedral. Lothar Malskat, the artist, brought on charges against himself two years ago after he said he was tired of not getting credit for his talent. At the same time, he admitted forging paintings and selling them as valuable "old masters." Three others were implicated: Dietrich Fey, an art dealer; Dr. Bruno Fendrich, architect of the ancient Marienkirche here, and Theo Dietrich, a fellow artist. In a pre-trial statement, Mr. Malskat declared that 15th-century frescoes, almost erased by age, were uncovered in the Marienkirche after it was burned out by an Allied air raid. Mr. Fey was commissioned to restore them, Mr. Malskat said, and hired him and Mr. Dietrich as artists. After examining the frescoes the four decided that they had deteriorated too much to be restored. So brand-new frescoes were painted on the walls. The "restored" frescoes were praised in the art world as "old masterpieces."

description: To the Editor:

title: BOARD APPROVES NEWS CORPORATION'S MOVE TO U.S.
description: The News Corporation, the media company controlled by Rupert Murdoch, said its board unanimously endorsed the company's plan to shift headquarters to the United States from Australia. News Corporation's shareholders will get one share in the United States company for every two shares they now own, the company said in a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange. The News Corporation, which is currently based in Sydney, will have its primary listing in New York and secondary listings in Sydney and London. The plan will be presented to the Securities and Investments Commission of Australia and Australian courts for approval, before shareholders vote on the proposal later this year, the News Corporation said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Companies To Help Minority Businesses
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that seven major companies, including Macy's and I.B.M., had joined a citywide program to promote businesses owned by minorities and women. Under the program, run by the city's Department of Small Business Services, the companies have agreed to solicit bids for projects from companies owned by women and minorities that are listed with the city. The other companies in the program are Altria, Colgate, J.P. Morgan Chase & Company, NBC Universal and Pfizer. Mayor Bloomberg also said the city would form an advisory board to expand access to opportunities for businesses owned by minorities and women. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Blown Pipe in Japan Nuclear Plant Accident Had Been Used, but Not Checked, Since 1976
description: A section of steam pipe that blew out Monday, killing four workers at a Japanese nuclear power plant, had not been inspected in 28 years and had corroded from nearly half an inch to a thickness little greater than metal foil, authorities said Tuesday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ban Sought On Foods High In Lead
description: Imported candies and other foods that contain high levels of lead would be banned from sale in New York City under legislation that was announced yesterday by the Council speaker, Gifford Miller, and Councilman Lewis A. Fidler, of Brooklyn. Tamarind fruit candy from Mexico, for instance, has been linked to elevated levels of lead. Calling lead-containing products a poison to the city's children, Mr. Miller said it was necessary to take steps to ''eliminate this ridiculous option.'' Under the proposed legislation, a storeowner who sells the product could be charged with a misdemeanor and fined up to $2,000 for each violation. Mr. Miller said this was the next logical step after the Council's passage of a strict lead paint law in February. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Sidestepping Reform at the C.I.A.
description: As the Sept. 11 commission made clear, the nation urgently needs to reorganize its intelligence agencies. Nominating a new candidate for the old, unreformed job of director of central intelligence, as President Bush did yesterday, is not the logical or appropriate place to start. Last week, Mr. Bush attempted to transform the powerful new position of national intelligence director, as proposed by the commission, into a neutralized bureaucratic cipher by depriving the office of any real authority. Now he once again seems intent on draining momentum from the idea of systematic intelligence reform.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: 321 Studios To Aid Antipiracy Effort
description: 321 Studios Inc., which closed and stopped selling DVD-copying software amid litigation with the movie and video game industries, agreed yesterday to contribute money to the studios' antipiracy efforts. 321 Studios agreed to make ''a substantial financial payment,'' the Motion Picture Association of America said. The money will be used in a consumer education program intended to curtail illegal copying. The company, based in St. Louis, shut last week after three courts ruled that it could not sell its DVD-copying software while infringement lawsuits were pending. The judges rejected arguments by 321 Studios and its supporters that there were legitimate reasons to copy DVD's. The agreement, which includes a pledge by 321 Studios to stop selling its software worldwide, settled a lawsuit the company first filed against the movie industry to get a court ruling that the software was legal. A lawyer for 321 Studios did not immediately return a voice-mail message seeking comment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPIEGEL, EDWARD
description: SPIEGEL--Edward. The Board members of the Lymphoma Foundation mourn the untimely death of our colleague and dear friend Edward Spiegel on August 8, 2004. Ed served on the Board of the Lymphoma Foundation with a powerful desire to contriubute to cancer research and the related research of neurofibromatosis that could and would save many lives. Ed contributed his compelling energy, his compassionate nature and his personal resources to the Lymphoma Foundation to help so many of his friends, his family and countless anonymous persons who benefited from his generosity. Ed was a pillar of support to his entire family and an extraordinary loving husband and father. We offer our sincere condolences to his wife Deanne and his children Elana and Brad, and want them to know that we are here to offer them any help we might contribute to their well-being during the stress of this immediate time and into the future. Mortimer J. Lacher, M.D. President of the Lymphoma Foundation

title: To Take the Crown, Princess, You'll Need a Ring
description: In the cardboard kingdom of Genovia, the setting for the new feature-length fairy tale ''The Princess Diaries 2: Royal Engagement,'' the streets are as scrubbed of dirt and personality as a Disney theme park. A mythic European country where everyone speaks English accented by way of Britain, France and Brooklyn, Genovia is the adopted home of Princess Mia (Anne Hathaway), a onetime San Francisco teenager turned old-world pretender. Unlike Pinocchio, Mia doesn't hang her wish on just any star; she hangs it on the movie-made promise that every girl can find her inner princess and, like, you know, rule.

title: Corrections

The official, Li Xiaobing, is a division chief, not a deputy director. He works for the Department of West Asian and African Affairs at the Ministry of Commerce, not the Ministry of Trade.

description: The Yankees' Jason Giambi reported to Tampa, Fla., on Tuesday to begin his rehabilitation as he tries to return from a benign tumor.

title: It's Little Italy, but the Red Isn't Marinara
description: NEIGHBORHOOD names sometimes lag behind neighborhood realities. This is especially true at the bustling intersection of Grand Street and Baxter Street, technically within the boundaries of Little Italy, though most of the shops nearby are stocked with ginseng and bok choy rather than mozzarella and soppressata. Culturally, visually and culinarily, this bit of Little Italy is really Chinatown. For added proof, consider Li Hua, a Korean restaurant that opened on this corner a month ago.

title: Singapore's New Prime Minister Goes With the Tried and True
description: Two days before his swearing-in as Singapore's prime minister, Lee Hsien Loong announced his cabinet on Tuesday. The long-awaited lineup includes his father, Lee Kwan Yew, the founder of modern Singapore, in the new position of ''minister mentor,'' and his predecessor, Goh Chok Tong, as senior minister.

title: Meal With an Eichmann in a Borderless Europe
description: ZILL, Germany -- There is a pleasant country inn here where Germany meets Austria, a frontier that now exists only in name, recalled by the quaint wooden border posts used by customs agents before the European Union put them out of work. Stout Bavarian women of placid mien and manner serve roast lamb and duck, killed that day on the farm, and tall glasses of turbid white beer. It is hard to imagine a better combination.

title: James S. Rockefeller, 102, Dies; Was a Banker and a '24 Olympian
description: James Stillman Rockefeller, who helped capture an Olympic rowing title for the United States before a banking career with a company that eventually become Citigroup, died yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn., his family announced. He was 102.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Consumer Confidence Rises
description: A gauge of Japanese consumer sentiment rose to its highest level in 13 years in July as the outlook for jobs and for income growth improved, the government said. The nationwide consumer confidence index rose to 48.7 in July, from 44.9 in June. The July score was the highest since the index hit 49.4 in June of 1991. The improvement in confidence bodes well for Japan's two-year economic recovery. While the rebound has been driven mostly by rising exports so far, signs of growing consumption, which accounts for more than half of the economy, are providing hope the recovery will continue into a third year.

description: As Donald J. Trump's publicly traded casino company, Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts, goes into a bankruptcy reorganization, Mr. Trump has to invest $55 million of his money in the enterprise to maintain a large ownership stake.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: New Sentencing Trial For Killer

title: Fit to Be Tied

Most of the contemporary objections are structural: because the college is apportioned on a state-by-state basis, with most states then choosing their electors through a winner-take-all popular election, the system could lead to what is known as a ''minority president'' -- as it did four years ago, when George W. Bush lost the popular vote but still won the presidency.

title: TV OFFICIAL BACKS HOST'S POLITICAL APPEARANCE
description: The MSNBC cable channel defended an appearance by a host of one its programs at a stump rally for President Bush in Pensacola, Fla., saying the channel has different rules for news anchors and what it called opinion anchors. Joe Scarborough, host of the nightly ''Scarborough Country'' program, could be seen on news reports on Tuesday standing and applauding numerous times during the president's speech. Mr. Bush even cited him in his speech, saying he appreciated Mr. Scarborough's presence in the district he once served as a Republican congressman. ''I'm glad he did it,'' said Rick Kaplan, the president of MSNBC, said of Mr. Scarborough's appearance. ''It was good for the profile of the show to remind people he has an inside view of politics.'' Mr. Kaplan said the channel had separate standards for what it considered its news anchors, who include all four others who lead prime-time programs on the channel: Chris Matthews, Dan Abrams, Deborah Norville and Keith Olbermann. Bill Carter (NYT)

title: Being Clear About Present Dangers
description: Within the last week, both the United States and the British governments have come in for criticism about how they alert their publics of impending terrorist attacks. In London, the minister for home affairs, David Blunkett, was accused of keeping the public in the dark over the extent of the terrorist threat to Britain; Tory opponents challenged him to release as much detail as the Bush administration had in the United States. In America, the secretary for homeland security, Tom Ridge, was accused of playing election-year politics by ratcheting up the alert level while praising ''the president's leadership in the war against terror.'' The problem reached such a crisis that it now appears that a substantial intelligence asset was compromised in one official's desperation to convince the news media that yes, there really was information about an imminent attack even though some of it was years old.

The legislation would require pharmacies to submit a list of their top-selling drugs and their prices twice a month to the city's Department of Consumer Affairs. That information would then be made available to city residents. ''This will allow New Yorkers to make more informed choices, keeping prices in check and making life-saving medicine more widely available,'' Mr. Gioia said. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nikon's Profit Rises
description: The Nikon Corporation reported a surge in profit for the most recent quarter, helped by healthy demand for digital cameras and rising sales of semiconductor-manufacturing equipment. Nikon reported net profit of 1.72 billion yen ($15.6 million) for the quarter ended June 30, compared with a profit of 69 million yen last year. Sales rose 22.5 percent, to 138.2 billion yen, from 112.9 billion yen. Nikon is a leading manufacturer of machines that make computer chips and its sales are growing amid robust demand for the chips that power cellphones, cameras and computers. Nikon is also benefiting from a boom in sales of digital cameras though it trails Sony, Canon and several other manufacturers in that market. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: A New Chicken in Town, Full of Guatemalan Spice
description: The line went around the block at 4506 Fifth Avenue, Sunset Park, Brooklyn, last week at the opening of Pollo Campero, the second New York store in this fried chicken chain. The scene was the same when the first Pollo Campero opened last month at 103-26 Roosevelt Avenue, in Corona, Queens. The popularity of the chain, which originated in Guatemala and has restaurants in Los Angeles, Houston and Washington, is deserved. Its deeply burnished chicken, especially the dark meat, is moist beneath its crunchy mantle and leaves a spicy glow on the palate. Neil Colley, the managing partner of the New York franchise group, said the dark meat outsells white. The best sides are beans, mashed potatoes and rice. Prices start at $2.95 for two pieces of dark meat. More Pollo Camperos are planned in East Harlem and Brentwood, L.I.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Woman With Ties To Militant Held
description: An Israeli woman who has served as a human shield for a wanted Palestinian in the West Bank has been arrested on suspicion that she helped plan attacks against Israel, the police said. The woman, Tali Fahima, 28, has made several trips to the West Bank town of Jenin, saying she wanted to protect Zacaria Zubeidah, 29, the local leader of Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, a group that has carried out many shootings and bombings against Israel. Mr. Zubeidah has survived several Israeli attempts to kill him. Ms. Fahima was arrested Monday and was being investigated for ''terror-related security offenses,'' a police spokesman said. She has not been charged, but the police can keep her in custody for nine more days. Greg Myre (NYT)

RWE, based in Essen, said it earned 1.36 billion euros ($1.67 billion), up from 621 million euros a year earlier. The company sold stakes in Consol Energy, a coal mining company based in the United States, and Heidelberger Druck, a maker of printing machinery, among others. Operating profit grew 12 percent to 3.28 billion euros ($4 billion), resulting from higher power prices and cost-saving measures at RWE's core businesses power, gas and water operations. The company reduced its debt by 2.1 billion euros, to 15.1 billion euros. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBINSON, DR. ROSCOE ROSS, ''IKE''
description: ROBINSON--Dr. Roscoe Ross, ''Ike'', 74, died on Saturday, Aug. 7 after a lengthy illness. A 1954 graduate of the University of Oklahoma Medical School, Dr. Robinson received his post-graduate training at Duke University and Columbia University. He then spent 24 years working at Duke, where he started and headed its first Division of Nephrology and where he later served as the Chief Executive Officer of Duke Hospital. In 1981, Dr. Robinson came to Vanderbilt as Vice Chancellor for Health Affairs, a position he held until 1997. Under his leadership, Vanderbilt experienced a period of major growth and development in the areas of patient care, faculty, facilities, and research. Upon his retirement, Vanderbilt and friends recognized his contributions to the university by the establishment in his name of two endowed chairs, a lectureship, and a library collection. In addition, the Ann and Roscoe Robinson Medical Research Building was named in his honor. Dr. Robinson was the recipient of many awards and honors recognizing his work in academic medicine and as a civic leader. He served as president of both the American and International Societies of Nephrology, was a past chairman of the Nephrology Board, and was the founding editor of the most prestigious journal in nephrology, Kidney International. He was a trustee at Duke University, a life trustee at Montgomery Bell Academy in Nashville, and a past member of the boards of Cheekwood, the YMCA, the United Way, and Hospital Hospitality House, all in Nashville. He served on the boards of Sun Health, Inc., ClinTrials, Inc., and First American Corporation. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Ann Allen Robinson, and two daughters, Brooke Robinson of Nashville, and Susan Solberg of Baltimore, Md. Two grandchildren, John Robinson Solberg and Sarah Allen Solberg, both of Baltimore, and his sister, Lucy Hill of San Marcos, Texas, also survive him. Donations may be made to the Robinson Medical Student Scholarship Fund at Vanderbilt, Vanderbilt Gift Processing, Vanderbilt University, PO Box Station B, Nashville, Tenn., 37235-7727, or to the charity of the donor's choice.

The Bank of England has raised interest rates five times since November in an attempt to curtail inflation. Economists still expect more rate increases, but the decline in inflation may persuade the bank to wait before making another increase. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Poison Fruit Plot Described
description: The white-supremacist group Boeremag planned to poison blacks with tainted oranges as part of a broader plan to overthrow South Africa's government in late 2002, a defendant testified in the treason and terrorism trial of 22 Boeremag members in Pretoria. Henk van Zyl testified that the group's chaplain was in charge of the plot, which involved tossing poisoned oranges into the streets of Soweto, the black township outside Johannesburg. The poisonings were to kick off a coup plan that included bombings of Johannesburg's airport and stock exchange and the seizure of radio stations and military bases, but the orange-throwing was called off in September 2002 when it became clear that the police knew about it. Michael Wines (NYT)

The Faculty of the Steinhardt School of Education at New York University deeply mourn the loss of Lowell Swortzell, beloved colleague for forty years, and a founder of our Educational Theatre Program. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THOMPSON, CLEMENT M.
description: THOMPSON--Clement M. of North Chatham, NY, died peacefully in his sleep on August 8 at age 85. Born in Troy, Alabama, the son of Walter and Edna Jones Thompson, he was raised in Akron, Ohio. He is survived by several nieces and nephews, including Harry Dixon, Laverne Flynt, Patricia Lawson, Estelle Moore, Mose Thompson, and his 30-year business partner and closest friend, John Pakulek. After serving in General Patton's army in World War II, he earned his B.A. from City College of New York in 1946, with a major in Psychology and a minor in Education. He continued his education at New York University, earning both M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in Clinical Psychology in 1948 and 1958 respectively. In 1962, he was hired at Bronx Community College at City University as a full professor and Dean of Students. He was Dean during much of the period of student unrest and the start of open admissions. In 1974, he retired from the University and was appointed Dean Emeritus and Professor Emeritus by the City Board of Higher Education. From 1974 to 1988, he served as Visiting Professor at the C.W. Post Campus of Long Island University. He was a member of a number of professional organizations in the field of Psychology, and served as a member of the Executive Board and President of the Association for Humanistic Education and Development. In retirement, he was the owner of a successful Bed & Breakfast in Amagansett, Long Island, which was the subject of a feature article in the ''New Yorker''. Calling hours will be Thursday from 7-9pm at the Raymond E. Bond Funeral Home, Valatie, NY. For those who wish, contributions may be made to either the American Red Cross or the Salvation Army.

description: Nassau County officials said yesterday that a raccoon killed in a fight with a dog in Brookville on Friday had tested positive for rabies. It is the first known case of a rabid raccoon in the county in at least 40 years, they said. Cynthia Brown, a spokeswoman for the county's Health Department, said three people in the home where the dog was a pet and a wildlife trapper who removed the raccoon would receive vaccinations. The dog, which had been vaccinated, is to get a booster shot. Rabies can spread by contact with saliva from an infected animal and is fatal to humans if not treated promptly. A hot line -- (516) 571-2500 -- has been set up for Brookville area residents to volunteer their property to trappers and report dead animals and animals they have seen acting abnormally in the last month. title: NEW POET AT THE TOP
description: The Library of Congress said yesterday that it would name Ted Kooser, left, whose poems often depict the Midwest, as the nation's poet laureate. The appointment of Mr. Kooser, a visiting professor in the English department at the University of Nebraska at Lincoln, who lives in Garland, Neb., is to be formally announced today. Mr. Kooser, 65, a retired life insurance executive, has written 10 poetry collections, including ''Delights & Shadows'' this year, and ''Winter Morning Walks: One Hundred Postcards to Jim Harrison,'' which won the 2001 Nebraska Book Award for Poetry. Of the appointment, the Librarian of Congress, James H. Billington, said: ''Ted Kooser is a major poetic voice for rural and small town American and the first poet laureate chosen from the Great Plains. His verse reaches beyond his native region to touch on universal themes in accessible ways.'' Mr. Kooser said, ''We poets out here don't get a lot of attention, and now I will and I have some trepidation over that.'' Mr. Kooser will take over the position from the Pulitizer Prize-winning poet Louise E. Glck, 60, who is a writer in residence at Yale University, on Oct. 7 with a reading of his work. ELIZABETH OLSON

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC And BellSouth Can Buy Back Licenses
description: SBC Communications Inc. and BellSouth can buy back wireless licenses in California and Indiana that the companies sold four years ago when they secured federal antitrust approval for their Cingular Wireless venture, the Justice Department said yesterday. The announcement is a preliminary step toward antitrust approval of Cingular's planned $41 billion purchase of AT&T Wireless Services. The Justice Department said it had not made a decision on that accord. When they formed Cingular, SBC and BellSouth signed a settlement in which they agreed to sell wireless businesses in California and Indiana markets to AT&T Wireless. Cingular would reacquire those licenses in a takeover of AT&T Wireless. In its announcement yesterday, the Justice Department said the new agreement modified the original settlement so that SBC and BellSouth would not be in violation of the accord once they acquire AT&T Wireless. The Justice Department said new competition in the Indiana and California markets had eliminated the antitrust concerns that prompted the 2000 settlement.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Youth Pleads Guilty In Blaster Worm Case
description: A Minnesota teenager who was arrested last year for propagating a version of the Blaster computer worm pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Seattle to charges of intentionally causing and trying to cause damage to a protected computer. Federal prosecutors said the teenager, Jeffrey Lee Parson, 19, created a worm that affected an estimated 48,000 computers last August. Mr. Parson's lawyers, however, questioned that number. Under the terms of a plea agreement, Mr. Parson admitted modifying the original Blaster worm into what became known as Blaster.B, which allowed him access to already infected computers. Mr. Parson's application quickly spread and eventually directed a computer attack against a Microsoft Web site. Mr. Parson is scheduled to be sentenced Nov. 12.

title: Some Heavy Artillery Is Aimed at the West Side Stadium Plan
description: The battle over the Jets' proposed stadium on the West Side of Manhattan escalated this week when opponents hired Arthur Finkelstein -- master of the political attack ad and confidant of Gov. George E. Pataki -- to join the fray by producing anti-stadium television commercials.

title: Tyranny In the Name Of Freedom
description: So it has come down to this: You are at liberty to exercise your First Amendment right to assemble and to protest, so long as you do so from behind chain-link fences and razor wire, or miles from the audience you seek to address.

title: Adolescent Angst Is on Location in Harlem
description: Charlie approaches the school, a look of dread on his face. He's about 16, pudgy, hair in cornrows, and wearing big, baggy jeans. Just released from ''juvie,'' juvenile detention, he is facing his first day back at the W.E.B. Du Bois High School, an imposing red-brick building on West 119th Street in Harlem with iron grates on the windows. How long will it be before the street swallows him again into its dark center?

title: Mozart Gives Late-Night TV Competition

description: Because of an editing error, an article in World Business yesterday about a dip in the growth of industrial production in China erroneously rendered as a direct quotation in some copies what was in fact a paraphrase of a comment by Andy Xie, an economist at Morgan Stanley. It said that a further increase in output last month from an already high level a year ago made it likely that the Chinese economy had slowed only very slightly.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: State Backs Town On Prayer
description: The state attorney general, Henry McMaster, filed a brief in support of a town's battle in federal court to continue referring to Jesus in official prayers at council meetings. The town, Great Falls, has appealed to the full United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit after a three-judge panel of the court said last month that the council had unconstitutionally advanced ''its own religious views in preference to all others.'' Mr. McMaster said in his brief that the ruling ignored the ''overarching secular purpose'' of the prayer. He said many governmental bodies in the state, including the House and Senate, regularly invoked Jesus in prayer. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES WILL DELAY FILING OF ANNUAL REPORT
description: Interstate Bakeries, the maker of Wonder Bread and Hostess Twinkies, is delaying the filing of its annual report with the Securities and Exchange Commission because it is restating earnings for its second and third quarters. The report will cover the fiscal year that ended May 29; the company had planned to file it today but will request an extension to Aug. 27, an Interstate spokeswoman, Linda Thompson, said. Interstate, based in Kansas City, Mo., said on Monday that it would reduce earnings to reflect a $40 million charge for increased expenses related to workers' compensation insurance.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Four Charged In Pay-Phone Theft Scheme
description: Four Bronx men, including a coin box collector for Verizon, were charged yesterday in a scheme to steal more than $50,000 in nickels, dimes and quarters from the telephone company's pay phones. The Bronx district attorney, Robert T. Johnson, said the Verizon employee, Mario Colon, 35, repeatedly siphoned coins from the telephones he serviced into canvas bags, and transferred the bags to the other men before driving his company truck back to the Verizon garage. Edison Burgos, 32, Raphael Burgos, 31, and Louis Ortis, 30, were also charged with grand larceny. Mr. Johnson said that the charges covered thefts by the four men since April, and that they were ''suspected of having engaged in this criminal conduct for many years, costing Verizon hundreds of thousands of dollars.'' Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

The teacher, Eldridge Pettway, 41, of Lodi; the teacher's aide, Jackie L. Thompson, 36, of Paterson; and another man, Darren L. Holland, 29, a mortgage broker from Paterson, appeared before a judge yesterday on robbery, carjacking, kidnapping, conspiracy and weapons charges, said Capt. description: BAKU, Azerbaijan, Aug. 12  The government of Azerbaijan, the only Muslim nation contributing foreign troops to American-led coalition forces in Iraq, has no intention at present of withdrawing its 150 soldiers from the stabilization effort there.

title: The Protesters' About-Face
description: An agreement on where to hold the largest protest planned for the week of the Republican convention came apart this week. The organizers, who had reluctantly agreed to take their rally to the western edge of town, are now demanding sites in Central Park. Their frustration is understandable, but they gave their word, and the convention is now less than three weeks away. While the demonstrators' original arguments for access to the park were good ones, they have no justification for backing out on the deal they made with the city.

title: People
description: Peter McHugh was named managing partner and chief creative officer at Carmichael Lynch, Minneapolis, effective on Oct. 1. He assumes the creative chief duties from Jack Supple, who continues as managing partner and chairman. Mr. McHugh had been partner and executive creative director at 180, Amsterdam, and before that was a group creative director at another Minneapolis agency, Fallon Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe. Carmichael Lynch is owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Architects Get Physical At the Venice Biennale
description: KURT W. FORSTER says that directing the ninth Venice Architecture Biennale has required ''divine guidance.'' First, the Italian government cut the show's budget, which was already spaghetti-thin, forcing him to become a ''beggar on every corner in Europe,'' he said. Then he had to postpone the opening after organizers of the Venice International Film Festival, which attracts large crowds to the city, decided to hold their event a week later than planned, creating a conflict with his own.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Rises
description: Pressed by rising utility rates and gasoline prices, inflation in Brazil rose to a 15-month high in July, reducing the chances that the central bank will cut interest rates again this year, economists said. The government's IPCA consumer price index, the central bank's main gauge in setting interest rates, rose 0.91 percent last month after rising 0.71 percent in June. The spike in July was the highest monthly increase since April 2003. In the first seven months of the year, accumulated inflation reached 4.42 percent, while the index has risen 6.81 percent in the 12 months through July. Most economists expect Brazil to finish the year with inflation of about 7.4 percent, just below the central bank's ceiling of 8 percent. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Where Bar Patrons Can Get a Glow Before the First Drink
description: Beneath the roof of a 30-foot-high palapa, or thatched pavilion, colorful lanterns glitter over the bar at Agua, a poolside restaurant by Adam D. Tihany in San Jos del Cabo, Mexico. For the whimsical effect, Mr. Tihany spent three days buying old-fashioned lanterns at markets in Guadalajara. Local workers modernized the sockets and, to keep the lanterns from swinging in coastal gusts, fashioned a web of nearly invisible guy wires, as if, Mr. Tihany said, ''Spider-Man visited us.'' Similar lanterns, made in Morocco and scaled down to suit the eight-foot ceilings in many apartments, can be purchased at Marrakech East, a shop at 434 East 11th Street (Avenue A), for $65 to $150; (212) 387-9630. Mr. Tihany's studio is at (212) 366-5544.

title: HANGER ORTHOPEDIC SHARES FALL AFTER PROFIT WARNING
description: Shares of the Hanger Orthopedic Group tumbled 41 percent yesterday, a day after the company said that its second-quarter profit would decline sharply and would not meet estimates. Hanger, which makes prosthetic and orthotic devices, issued the profit warning after the close of trading on Tuesday and said that it would delay the filing of its quarterly report with the Securities and Exchange Commission because of a previously disclosed investigation of its billing practices. It estimated that pretax income for the quarter that ended in June would be $2.5 million, well below the $15.8 million the company reported in the quarter a year ago. Hanger attributed the expected decline to a drop in same-center sales, along with increases in material costs and administrative expenses. Its stock fell $3.87 yesterday, to $5.64 a share.

title: Security for the Homeland, Made in Alaska
description: As the Pentagon shipped thousands of military police to Iraq over the last year, it had to move quickly to replace guards at important installations around the country, including Fort Bragg, N.C., and West Point. So it turned to the private sector and quietly awarded multimillion-dollar contracts without putting out competitive bids.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Brewer Posts Profit
description: Companhia de Bebidas das Americas, the Brazilian brewer known as AmBev, posted a second-quarter profit of 265.1 million reais ($87.5 million), more than double the amount it earned in the year-earlier period. AmBev, which is being acquired by Interbrew of Belgium, said strong revenue in foreign markets helped offset a 7.3 percent drop in beer sales at home. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, a measure of cash flow, rose 33 percent in the quarter, to 735.1 million reais, while revenue rose 17 percent, to 2.23 billion reais. AmBev, whose beer brands include Brahma, Antrtica and Skol, finished June with 66.3 percent of Brazil's beer market.

title: For a Moment, the Mighty Sonny Rollins Shows Fans His Intimate Side
description: When Sonny Rollins fulfills the role of Sonny Rollins -- tall, powerful jazz improviser, bringer of catharsis -- he goes on and on. His improvisations are a long process, and the power and invention of his harmonic and rhythmic ideas accumulate as the minutes tick by.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Former F.B.I. Clerk Arrested In Green Card Fraud
description: A former F.B.I. clerk was arrested yesterday on federal charges of pretending to be a government official in a scheme to defraud immigrants of more than $43,000. Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney in Brooklyn, said the former clerk, Rosana Frederick, 57, of Brooklyn, left, falsely claimed that she could help people get alien registration ''green cards.'' Ms. Frederick was convicted of a similar scheme in 1992 while she was an F.B.I. employee and was sentenced to 18 months imprisonment. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Halliburton Is Faulted By Pentagon On Accounts
description: An internal Pentagon audit has found that the Halliburton Company failed to adequately account for some of the $4.2 billion it has received so far for providing logistical support to troops in Iraq and Kuwait.

title: A Scot's Favorite Deal, in Miami
description: As in many other areas, bridge in the New World often receives an infusion of talent from the Old World. Half a century ago Boris Koytchou, a Russian by birth, crossed the Atlantic after representing France and played for his adopted country. Sami Kehela moved from England to Canada and was a strong candidate for world titles. Sam Lev came from Poland via Israel and contends regularly. This year Bjorn Fallenius, who has won many medals for Sweden, earned the right to play for the United States in Istanbul next October.

title: NIKE BUYS OFFICIAL STARTER AND ENTERS DISCOUNT MARKET
description: Nike Inc., the sneaker maker, said yesterday that it had acquired Official Starter Properties and Official Starter for about $43 million, gaining several brands of sports apparel that sell in discount stores. The businesses, which own and license the Starter, Team Starter and Asphalt brands, will be operated by the Exeter Brands Group, a new operating unit, Nike said. Nike, based in Beaverton, Ore., also gains the Shaq and Dunkman brands of clothing, footwear and accessories. With the purchase, Nike will have brands in Wal-Mart and Kmart stores for the first time, a Nike spokeswoman, Joani Komlos, said. Official Starter Properties and Official Starter acquired the assets of the bankrupt Starter Corporation in 1999.

title: BRINKER SAYS INCOME WILL NOT MEET ANALYSTS' FORECASTS
description: Brinker International Inc., the operator of the Chili's Grill and Bar and Romano's Macaroni Grill restaurant chains, said yesterday that income in its current quarter would be 45 cents to 47 cents a share, less than analysts' estimates. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected the company to earn 51 cents in the period, which ends Sept. 29 and is the first quarter of Brinker's fiscal year. Brinker, based in Dallas, also released fourth-quarter results. The company said that income rose 60 percent from a year earlier, to $64.5 million, and sales rose 16 percent, to $1 billion. But sales at Chili's restaurants weakened in May and June, while sales at the Romano's Macaroni chain declined in all three months of the fourth quarter.

The Ventaglio dining table has a plank top (shown in two versions at left). It also has free-form legs (above) that look like something from 1938, though she designed the original in 1972 for her chalet in Mribel, France. Cassina USA will be showing the table (about $6,600 in ebonized or natural oak) in the fall at 155 East 56th Street (Lexington Avenue); (800) 770-3568; www.cassinausa.com.

The S.E.C., in a letter received July 20, requested information and documents relating to Price Legacy's sale of 1.88 million Mace shares, Mace said in a regulatory filing. The S.E.C. also requested information on Price Legacy's payment of $8.95 million to Mace in exchange for the company's removal of a sales restriction from 1.75 million of the shares that were sold, Mace said. The company, based in Mount Laurel, N.J., disclosed the Price Legacy transaction in April, saying it agreed to remove the selling restriction on Price Legacy's shares in exchange for half of the proceeds.

title: NATIONAL-OILWELL TO BUY VARCO INTERNATIONAL

The transaction values Varco at $24.30 a share, above its closing price Wednesday of $23.62 a share. National-Oilwell has acquired 21 companies since 2000. The combination would create the nation's largest equipment maker for oil field services companies, surpassing FMC Technologies. Both companies are based in Houston.

Sultry and sweaty are words that few would use to describe Ms. McGovern, whose image of self-containment, efficiency and wide-eyed perkiness is more suggestive of a high-powered executive secretary than a woman letting her hair down. She sings the way some people type, at the musical equivalent of 120 words a minute without making an error. The clarity and discipline of her performances are so reliable you can almost bank on them.

title: Shiite Muslims Condemn U.S. For Attacks On Holy City
description: The American military's advance into the holy city of Najaf in Iraq to crush a Shiite rebel uprising aroused anger and frustration on Thursday among Shiite Muslims abroad. Many blamed the United States for what they described as an intentional and brutal humiliation by an occupying force that would provoke outrage if any holy shrines were destroyed.

title: Africa's Health-Care Brain Drain
description: As Africa tries to fight AIDS, the single most serious obstacle is a desperate shortage of health workers. Yet at the same time, doctors, nurses and pharmacists in English-speaking African countries are emigrating in droves to Britain, the United States, Canada and Australia. In Ghana and Zimbabwe, three-quarters of all doctors emigrate within a few years of completing medical school. Randall Tobias, President Bush's global AIDS coordinator, said in a recent speech that there were more Ethiopian-trained doctors practicing in Chicago than in Ethiopia.

title: Disappointing Dayne Raises Hopes Again
description: With more than 30 players in a Giants uniform for the first time, including nine new starters, the Giants' opening preseason game Friday night is far more than the first round in the celebrated competition between quarterbacks Kurt Warner and Eli Manning.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Charges Against Former Governor Stand
description: Judge Rebecca R. Pallmeyer of Federal District Court refused to throw out racketeering and fraud charges against former Gov. George Ryan, court documents show. Mr. Ryan, who gained national attention for clearing the state's death row in 2003, has maintained his innocence. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FITZGERALD, CELIA
description: FITZGERALD -- Celia. Died peacefully surrounded by family and friends on Tuesday, August 10, 2004 after a long and heroic battle with cancer. Celia was born in Cork, Ireland on November 22, 1941. She immigrated to New York in October, 1969. Celia was instrumental in the development and expansion of a Manhattan-based consulting engineering firm that focuses primarily on the buildings of federal, state and city govermental agencies in New York City. Celia is survived by her companion Albert P. Kung of Forest Hills, N.Y., daughter Louise and son-in-law Douglas Hepworth and a grandson Dashiell of New York City; son Jerry and daughter-inlaw Bernadette Scanlon and grandchildren Emer, John, Stephanie and Kate of Dublin, Ireland. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, Friday 7-9 PM with a service on Saturday at 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell.

Fisher Center for the Performing Arts at Bard College -- designed by Frank Gehry -- has become a must-see destination for travelers working their way through a culturally hip checklist: Dia:Beacon in Beacon, N.Y.; Mass MoCA in North Adams, Mass.; Mr. Gehry's recently unveiled Jay Pritzker Pavilion in Chicago; and, of course, the holy grail of the architecturally savvy set, the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, also by Mr. Gehry.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Payment To Oil Executive
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group will give Walter van de Vijver, former head of exploration and production, a one-time payment of 3.8 million euros ($4.6 million) in connection with his departure in March. Mr. van de Vijver and the former chairman, Sir Philip Watts, were ousted from Shell after the company unexpectedly lowered its reserve estimates by 20 percent in January. Mr. van de Vijver remains on the payroll until Sept. 1, and is eligible for a yearly pension of 385,388 euros ($472,459) in 2015, Shell said. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Europe Picks Dutch Official To Enforce Antitrust Law
description: Neelie Kroes, a former Dutch transport minister, was nominated on Thursday as Europe's competition commissioner, the European Union's chief antitrust enforcer.

title: GENERAL MEDIA'S PLAN TO LEAVE BANKRUPTCY IS APPROVED
description: A judge approved a plan by General Media, the publisher of Penthouse magazine, to leave bankruptcy by transferring ownership of the company to its bondholders from its parent, Penthouse International. Penthouse International, which owns 100 percent of General Media's common stock, will not receive anything. The bondholder group, which is owed more than $40 million, has sought to own the company and its magazine for months. Judge Stuart M. Bernstein of United States Bankruptcy Court confirmed the plan at a hearing in New York. Penthouse International, based in New York, opposes the plan and may seek to have it overturned, said Robert S. Wolf, the company's lawyer.

title: Kicking the Tires, From Afar and Online
description: SANDY GERLI'S eBay car habit started three years ago. He wanted to buy a first car for his teenage son, so he went online and bid successfully on a used Mercedes diesel sedan for $1,700. When a truck totaled the car a year later, he went back and bought another for $1,300. It only lasted a few months, but ''we got our money's worth,'' he said. He bought a third for $2,500 last year.

title: Report Finds Tax Cuts Heavily Favor The Wealthy
description: Fully one-third of President Bush's tax cuts in the last three years have gone to people with the top 1 percent of income, who have earned an average of $1.2 million annually, according to a report by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office to be published Friday.

title: How the Greek Vase Shaped Many Styles And Western Design
description: If you are among the people who will see an exhibition just because the title makes you laugh out loud, add ''Vasemania'' at the Bard Graduate Center to your itinerary. If you are undeterred by the show's all-kidding-aside subtitle, ''Neoclassical Form and Ornament in Europe: Selections From the Metropolitan Museum of Art,'' you may be a certifiable vasemaniac. For everyone else, this thoughtful, elegantly installed show offers an airy, inspiring glimpse of artistic osmosis, assimilation and conversion.

title: For New Jersey Republicans, an Inviting Target Vanishes
description: For months New Jersey Republicans had smelled blood in the water and were lining up to take on Gov. James E. McGreevey. A state assemblyman, a state senator, a businessman, a small town mayor and perhaps a federal prosecutor were all considering the prospect of challenging the Democratic incumbent.

Cherished uncle of Zachary Stewart and Samara Geller, devoted companion to his beloved animals, Bojack, Nikko and Howard, loyal friend to many. Rick was devoted to all animal causes. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Output Rises
description: Industrial output in India climbed 7.3 percent in June, compared with 6.2 percent growth in the previous month, helped by rising farm incomes and healthy consumer demand. The government's Central Statistical Organization said industrial production rose 6.7 percent in the month. Manufacturing rose 8.0 percent in June and consumer durables like refrigerators and washing machines grew 14.1 percent. The capital goods segment, an indicator of industrial activity, grew 17.5 percent in June. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Washington Post Rethinks Its Coverage of War Debate
description: The executive editor of The Washington Post, Leonard Downie Jr., said in yesterday's newspaper that he and other top editors had erred before the war in Iraq by not giving front-page prominence to more articles that cast doubt on the Bush administration's claims that Saddam Hussein was hiding weapons of mass destruction.

title: U.S. Switches Tactic in Najaf, Trying Isolation
description: Faced with a populist Shiite cleric who has bunkered a heavily-armed militia force in the sect's holiest shrine, American commanders in this city of 500,000 resorted reluctantly on Thursday to a scaled-down objective, throwing a wide cordon of troops and armor around the city's heart and announcing that they planned to ''further isolate'' the militiamen.

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Art on Saturday about excursions on the Hudson River misstated the circumstances of the sinking of the steamboat Henry Clay. Although it hit another steamboat on July 28, 1852, both vessels continued on their journeys; the Henry Clay sank only after a fire broke out later that day. The Op-Art also misstated a detail of a voyage by the steamboat Mary Powell; it traveled from New York to Poughkeepsie in 3 hours 19 minutes, not to Albany. In addition, Breezy Point's borough was misidentified. It is Queens, not Brooklyn.

title: New York Unplugged, 1889
description: Last year's blackout -- when we were rudely reminded that electricity is the lifeblood of our civilization -- still holds the dubious honor as America's biggest blackout. The nation's first struck Manhattan on Oct. 14, 1889, when New Yorkers stepped out into a bleak, rainy dusk to find what was called ''A Night of Darkness -- More than One Thousand Electric Lights Extinguished.''

description: A confidential report conducted by the United Nations in cooperation with the Department of Homeland Security has found that airport inspectors with the power to summarily deport illegal immigrants have sometimes intimidated and handcuffed travelers fleeing persecution, discouraged some from seeking political asylum and often lacked an understanding of asylum law.

description: A California teenager paralyzed by a defectively designed semiautomatic handgun lost his bid in federal bankruptcy court yesterday to buy the company that manufactured the gun.

title: World's Second-Oldest Profession
description: ON a recent muggy Sunday afternoon, Tom Mullan and 10 or so men stood outside the clubhouse at the racetrack in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., doing a brisk business in tipsheet sales. If it weren't for their pitches and the brightly colored papers they held aloft, the younger men in the bunch, casually clad in shorts and short-sleeve shirts and wearing a mullet or two, might have been mistaken for 30-somethings headed for that evening's Dead concert at the performing arts center downtown.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alstom Raises Funds
description: Alstom, the maker of trains and power stations, raised 1.75 billion euros ($2.14 billion) in a government-led bailout to avoid bankruptcy. Alstom, which is based in Paris, sold as much as 1.28 billion euros in new stock, the government converted 231 million euros of debt into shares and the company's banks converted 240 million euros. The government will own 21.4 percent of Alstom after investing 415 million euros in the sale, said Severine Gagneraud, a company spokeswoman. Shares of Alstom rose 19 percent.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''My truth is that I am a gay American.''

title: F.D.A. ALLOWS EPILEPSY DRUG TO BE SOLD FOR MIGRAINES
description: Johnson & Johnson received federal approval to market its Topamax epilepsy pills for preventing migraine headaches. The Food and Drug Administration cleared Topamax for the added use after two clinical trials showed daily doses of the drug reduced the number of migraine episodes, said Stephanie Scott, a spokeswoman for Johnson & Johnson. The approval adds the United States to a list of 22 countries that allow Johnson & Johnson, the maker of Tylenol, to promote Topamax for use against migraines. Johnson & Johnson is based in New Brunswick, N.J.

description: WEST

title: Two Glimpses of a Filmmaker Who Put Poetry on the Screen
description: When the avant-garde filmmaker Stan Brakhage died last year at age 70, he left behind an enormous and varied body of work, much of which seems to belong less to the history of cinema than to its future. We take it for granted that film is a narrative, representational art form, which makes it hard to assimilate an artist for whom it was just as obvious that film was no such thing -- or at least did not have to be. It is perhaps a measure of the continued challenge that Brakhage poses to our habitual ways of thinking about art and its various media that his films, which are mostly without dialogue, text or words of any kind, are more often compared to poetry than to other, presumably nearer forms of visual expression.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Congressman Drops Primary Challenge
description: Representative Ciro D. Rodriguez, left, abandoned his challenge to the primary he lost by 58 votes and conceded the Democratic Congressional nomination in the 28th District to Henry Cuellar, a lawyer from Laredo. The State Supreme Court twice declined to hear the arguments of Mr. Rodriguez, who said hundreds of ballots in the May election were cast by ineligible voters. The primary was initially awarded to Mr. Rodriguez, who took office in 1997, but a recount gave the victory to Mr. Cuellar. Mr. Rodriguez, 57, said he would enter the 2006 primary against Mr. Cuellar, 48. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Columbine Ruling
description: Tapes and diary entries made by Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold before their 1999 shooting rampage at Columbine High School are public records, the State Court of Appeals ruled. The two, students at the school, killed 12 students and one teacher and injured many others before killing themselves. A local newspaper sought the release of the materials, but a state district judge ruled that they were not criminal justice records and therefore were not public. The appeals court sent the case back to the lower court to determine if ''disclosure of the recordings is contrary to the public interest.'' Mindy Sink (NYT)

Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Deutsche Telekom Posts Strong Earnings
description: Deutsche Telekom's second-quarter earnings rose stronger than expected, driven by continuing growth at its broadband and mobile communications units. The company said yesterday that quarterly earnings climbed to 1.66 billion euros ($2.03 billion), from 256 million euros in the second quarter a year ago, helped by an increase of 1.8 billion euros in the value of wireless licenses in the United States and 200 million euros in gains from asset sales. Excluding the special items, earnings rose to 728 million euros. Revenues grew 6 percent, to 14.4 billion euros ($17.65 billion), with particularly strong growth at the wireless unit T-Mobile USA. The company raised its earnings forecast to 2.5 billion euros for the year. Petra Kappl (NYT)

description: City Councilman Bill Perkins was fined $2,500 yesterday and ordered to return $33,135 for improperly spending public campaign funds.

title: Olerud Is Prepared to Carry His Hot Bat Back to Seattle
description: John Olerud used words like awkward and strange to describe how he expects to feel when he returns to Seattle on Friday with the Yankees. He was in his fifth season with the Mariners, but they released him on July 27, and he became a Yankee nine days ago.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany, Romania: A Son's Journey
description: For the first time, Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schrder, visited the grave in Romania of the father he never met. Three years ago, Mr. Schrder learned that his father, who died six months before his son was born, was buried in Ceanu Mare in the Transylvania region. Mr. Schrder's father was killed there in 1944 at the age of 32 while serving as a solider in the German Army. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Amid Tight Security, Greek Olympics Blaze to a Start
description: ATHENS, Aug.13 - The Summer Olympic Games opened here today with an opening spectacle drawing heavily on the pure forms of ancient Greek mythology and with massive security precautions for the modern age of terrorism.

title: Counting Medals in Athens
description: The Olympic Games are back again, and many of us will stay glued to our television sets for the next two weeks, joining the rest of the world in rooting for the home teams and waiting for that memorable human drama: the star runner who stumbles or the tiny gymnast who nails a landing on a sore ankle. Inevitably, we'll also be hoping for some Cinderella moments, like an underdog Greek who captures the marathon, or more stellar performances by the beleaguered Iraqi soccer team, which won an upset victory yesterday.

title: On a Fast Track: Power, Turmoil and a Crashing End
description: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Afghanistan: Copter Crash Kills Marine
description: A United States Black Hawk helicopter crashed in eastern Afghanistan, killing a marine and wounding 14 others, the military announced. The crash was not caused by hostile fire, but occurred in Khost Province where there has been fighting with Taliban and Al Qaeda forces on the border with Pakistan. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Steel Maker's Profit Rises
description: Thys-senKrupp, the German steel and heavy industry giant, said its third-quarter profit increased 28 percent from the period a year earlier, as steel prices rose and the automotive unit's performance improved. The company said it earned 274 million euros ($335.8 million), up from 214 million euros a year earlier. Sales rose 21 percent, to 10.7 billion euros ($13 billion), exceeding analysts' expectations. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: BUILD-A-BEAR SEEKS TO SELL UP TO $125 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Build-A-Bear Workshop, a chain of stores where customers make their own stuffed animals, filed yesterday to sell up to $125 million in common stock in an initial public offering. The retailer, which is based in St. Louis, did not disclose the number of shares it expects to offer or an estimated price for the shares. The company said it would use the proceeds from the offering to finance the opening of new stores and for working capital and other general purposes. Some of the shares will be sold by current shareholders, the company said.

title: Retail Sales Rise as Initial Jobless Claims Drop
description: United States retail sales rose last month and initial jobless claims unexpectedly declined to the lowest level in five weeks, according to reports released yesterday, signs that the economic expansion regained momentum in the third quarter.

title: Protecting the Right Not to Remain Silent
description: SIMONE LEVINE looks so serious in the shabby, low-ceilinged offices of the National Lawyers Guild in Midtown Manhattan. And why wouldn't she? Ms. Levine is a lead organizer of the guild's campaign to protect the rights of protesters during the Republican National Convention later this month.

title: Indonesian General Cleared Of Shooting Protesters in '84
description: The chief of Indonesia's powerful special forces, Maj. Gen. Sriyanto Muntrasan, was acquitted Thursday of human rights violations for having ordered his troops to open fire on 3,000 protesters in 1984. At least 23 people were killed.

title: Worker Dies as Freight Elevator Malfunctions in Times Sq. Tower
description: An elevator operator in one of Times Square's newest towers was killed yesterday when a freight elevator malfunctioned and propelled his cab up into a rooftop bulkhead above the 37th floor.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Economies Grow
description: Europe's recovery gained momentum in the second quarter, with Germany reporting economic growth of 0.5 percent and France, 0.8 percent. The results in France surpassed the expectations of economists, while Germany's performance was in line with forecasts. Demand for exports fueled the economies, which troubled some analysts, who said Europe was vulnerable to a global slowdown. The Dutch economy unexpectedly contracted 0.2 percent in the quarter. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Bush's Own Goal
description: A new Bush campaign ad pushes the theme of an ''ownership society,'' and concludes with President Bush declaring, ''I understand if you own something, you have a vital stake in the future of America.''

title: Under Eye of U.N., Billions for Hussein In Oil-for-Food Plan
description: Toward the end of 2000, when Saddam Hussein's skimming from the oil-for-food program for Iraq kicked into high gear, reports spread quickly to the program's supervisors at the United Nations.

title: 36 Hours | Buffalo
description: PROSPERING where East Coast canal boats and railroads met Great Lakes cargo, Buffalo was a rich city around 1900, a time when a dynamic group of innovators was transforming American architecture. Wealth and vision came together in major works by Frank Lloyd Wright, Louis Sullivan, H. H. Richardson, Frederick Law Olmsted, Eliel and Eero Saarinen, and more -- arrayed amid blocks of Victorian houses and lavish mansions. When industry collapsed, a shaken and considerably poorer Buffalo slowly realized it had a legacy. Now Buffalonians are working to preserve their architectural collection and are eager to show it off. The time to visit is summer, when Buffalo gets a glorious payback for its snowy winters with some of the best weather in the nation -- three months of mostly sunny, dry days with temperatures in the high 70's and low 80's. BARBARA IRELAND

description: On the first day of the P.G.A. Championship on Thursday, the neighborhood bully was not as tough as everyone thought.

title: Being Tender and Robust With Keyboard and Baton
description: The German pianist and conductor Christian Zacharias is an excitable musician with a penchant for wild ideas, like performing and conducting all of Mozart's 21 piano concertos by memory in seven concerts over a couple of weeks, as he did in 2000 at the Edinburgh International Festival. By comparison, his stint at the Mostly Mozart Festival this week was modestly conceived, though it showcased his skills as chamber musician, pianist and conductor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLUB, LEON

title: Unknown Golfer Challenges the Elite in P.G.A.'s 2d Round
description: HAVEN, Wis., Aug. 13  The P.G.A. Championship could have another surprise winner. Or it could go to a talented veteran who has flirted with major championships all season.

title: In Pursuit of Fabulousness
description: ONE sure way a destination can raise its public profile is by piggybacking on the reputation of a better-known spot that may, in the eyes of trend seekers, be losing some of its heat. Thus, Columbia County, in upstate New York, becomes known as the new Hamptons; Fort Lauderdale promotes itself as the next South Beach; and Atlantic City puts out the word that it is giving Las Vegas a run for its money.

title: Sports of The Times; After an 81, Daly Is Facing Two Very Unkind Cuts
description: WITH every slashing stroke in a quadruple-bogey 8 on Whistling Straits' treacherous 18th hole en route to an embarrassing 81 yesterday, it was as though John Daly were swinging the ax that would cut him from the Ryder Cup team.

title: Asset Mix Took Toll on United's Pension Fund
description: United Airlines, which appears likely to default on its pension plans in the coming months, invested a larger-than-average share of its $6.6 billion pension portfolio in illiquid investments, while also investing liberally in junk bonds, technology and pharmaceutical start-ups, even a gold mining company in Ghana.

title: For Movie and Its Marketing, A Marriage of Convenience
description: In this era of infomercials and magalogs, the line between entertainment and advertising has grown increasingly blurred. With ''Yu-Gi-Oh!,'' a Japanese animated film that opens nationally today, that line has been emphatically erased.

description: Even the most devoted Anglophile might have trouble guessing which member of the British royal family can fix a car engine and drive a truck. A new exhibition in London reveals that it's Queen Elizabeth II.

title: Ashcroft's Quiet Prisoner
description: David Joseph is a little guy, about 5-foot-5, maybe 115 pounds. He's 20 years old, looks younger, and has the sluggish demeanor and sad expression of one who is deeply depressed. He has nightmares and headaches. He spends his days dressed in the blue fatigues of detainees at the federal Krome Detention Center, washing dishes at mealtimes, staring listlessly at television images broadcast in a language he doesn't understand, and praying.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; The Absolutely Noirest of the Noir
description: Last week's release of Michael Mann's new urban thriller, ''Collateral,'' set a lot of critics, including Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott of The New York Times, to thinking about that particular brand of film noir native to Los Angeles. Mr. Mann's film, like many of the L.A. noirs before it, presents the city in its sinister, nocturnal mode, a landscape from which most human figures have vanished, to be replaced by gliding four-wheeled fortresses and shadowy palm trees waving against a purple sky.

title: Across the State, Sympathy and Skepticism
description: Pat Howell hung up the phone around 3:45 p.m. at McGovern's Tavern in Newark and broke the news to a dozen regulars. ''The governor is resigning,'' she said.

description: President Hugo Chvez said Thursday that victory in the referendum on his rule on Sunday was inevitable, as his adversaries mounted large rallies to marshal momentum in a last-ditch effort to end his presidency.

title: Florida Takes One Storm's Punch, Braces for Another's
description: As Tropical Storm Bonnie drenched the Florida Panhandle, the state prepared on Thursday for that storm's more powerful pursuer, Hurricane Charley, which is expected to be the fiercest storm to hit the Tampa Bay since 1921.

title: Pilots' Study Warns US Air On Finances
description: US Airways will go out of business within months if it cannot significantly cut its costs and adopt a leaner operating structure, a financial report commissioned by its pilots union concluded yesterday.

title: The Governor's Secret
description: Sooner or later, it was bound to happen: a major elected official's calling a press conference to tell constituents that he or she is gay. Yesterday, New Jersey's governor, James McGreevey, described his coming to grips with his sexual orientation with uncommon grace and dignity, offering an extraordinary glimpse into the private torment that can accompany a public life lived in the closet. ''My truth is that I am a gay American,'' he said. If that had been the beginning and the end of the story, we would be celebrating Mr. McGreevey's candor, not assessing his resignation. But the story -- like Mr. McGreevey's statement -- was incomplete.

title: A Year After the Big Blackout, a Film Festival Flickers to Life
description: Like everyone who experienced it, Tom Keefe has a story to share about last year's extensive blackout. His involved a missed job interview, an eccentric new landlord, several East Village bars and a chin covered with stubble.

title: A Racing Tradition
description: TIPSHEETS printed on colored paper and the colorful hawkers who sell them have long been part of the scene at Saratoga, where late summer has meant thoroughbred racing for more than a century. Page 8.

description: RASKIN--Dr. Martin B. Died suddenly Saturday, August 7. He is survived by his wife Dr. Gladys Raskin, sons Raymond (Rosary) and Jay (Janis), granddaughters Diane, Elaine, Jillian and Annie.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Returned Exile Attacked
description: Ngugi wa Thiongo, a leading novelist and playwright who returned to Kenya last month after 22 years of self-imposed exile, was robbed and assaulted in Nairobi during his homecoming tour. Mr. Thiongo, who had been arrested in 1977 and detained for a year without trial, kissed the ground upon arriving in Kenya. But he and his wife were hospitalized after robbers forced their way into their apartment, burned him with cigarettes, assaulted him with a gun butt, and tried to rape his wife. His best-known works, written in his mother tongue of Kikuyu, include ''Weep Not Child,'' ''A Grain of Wheat'' and ''Devil on the Cross.'' Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Interest Rate Cut
description: The Bank of Korea cut its benchmark interest rate to 3.50 percent from 3.75 percent, citing a slowdown in the economy and concern that rising oil prices might restrict economic growth. The surprise move was the first cut in the rate since July 2003. In a statement, the bank said that even though high oil prices had put upward pressure on prices, inflation was expected to remain within its target range because of subdued domestic demand. Andrew Salmon (NYT)

title: Unfit for Bottom? Then Try the Top
description: Working for the Central Intelligence Agency is not for everybody. Just ask Porter J. Goss, a onetime covert operative.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Few restaurants have as unusual a marriage of ambience and menu as Strata. Its setting is a mammoth, shiny, black-hued room with pin spotlights beaming down from the ceiling. It shouts ''Saturday Night Fever.'' The food includes deviled eggs, chili, fish and chips, macaroni and cheese and, for dessert, ice-cream sandwiches. It says Sunday afternoon at grandma's.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Violence In South Ossetia
description: Officials called for emergency meetings after overnight fighting flared in the separatist region of South Ossetia, leaving as many as three people dead. South Ossetia has been out of Georgian control since the early 1990's and the new Georgian president, Mikhail Saakashvili, has made its reintegration a priority. Mr. Saakashvili, who has charged that Russia, which has peacekeepers in the region, seeks to aggravate the conflict, said his government would show restraint. ''We should not let external forces drag Georgia into full-scale armed confrontation on its own territory,'' he said in a statement. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Tentative Merger Deal in Japan to Create Largest Bank
description: The Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group, Japan's second-largest bank, reached a preliminary agreement to take over the struggling UFJ Holdings in a deal that would create the world's biggest bank.

title: PAYLESS PLANS TO CLOSE OR SELL 292 MORE STORES
description: Payless ShoeSource, the shoe retailer, plans to close or sell an additional 292 stores after second-quarter earnings declined and sales fell for the 10th time in the last three years. About 260 Payless ShoeSource stores in the United States and Canada will be closed and 32 in Peru and Chile will be sold or shut, the company said. Net income fell 29 percent, to $3.7 million, or 5 cents a share, from $5.2 million, or 8 cents a share, a year earlier. Payless, based in Topeka, Kan., already planned to shut or sell about 411 stores, including 181 of its Parade and 230 of its namesake locations.

title: AMERICAN SEAFOODS DELAYS INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING
description: The American Seafoods Corporation, a harvester and wholesaler of seafood, postponed its initial public stock offering, citing ''adverse market conditions.'' The company, based in Seattle, said it would pursue its offering at a later date. ''Although we remain confident in the strength of our business, the current market environment has proved disappointing,'' the American Seafoods chief executive, Bernt O. Bodal, said in a statement. The company said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing this week that it had lowered the price it expected to receive in its offering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSS, LOIS
description: ROSS--Lois. A resident of Westport, CT for over 18 years, died peacefully in her sleep at her home on August 10, 2004, after a long and difficult struggle with lupus. She was 62 years of age. A former spokesperson for Kodak in their National Campaign on Family Portrait Photography during the mid 1980's, her family became the ''Kodak Family'' appearing in publicity photos taken at Ca d'Zan, the John and Mabel Ringling Winter Residence on Sarasota Bay in Sarasota, FL. by the internationally acclaimed photographer Christopher Der Mannuelian, of San Mateo. Her career began in fashion modeling in the 1970's and grew into fashion consulting, staging many fashion events for Neiman Marcus, Macy's, Bloomingdales, Saks Fifth Avenue, J C Penney and Filene's, locally, and from Washington DC to Boston. Ultimately she produced major fashion events for the Stamford Town Center amphitheater in Stamford, CT. During this period she appeared in numerous tv commercials, print ads and billboards for major US companies, from AT&T, Pepsi and Charmin, a member of SAG and AFTRA, and was a very busy hand model for major products, as well. She completed her undergraduate studies at Syracuse University, Finch College and Columbia University as an art history major. She leaves behind Arthur, her beloved husband of 44 years, three adult children, Cheri Sarner of Jupiter, FL, Robert Ross of Darien, CT and Steven Ross of Sterling, VA, as well as five beloved grandchildren, Harrison and Arden Sarner, and Morgan, Madeleine and Meridith Ross. She was the daughter of the late Seymour and Syde Goldberg of Purchase, NY and Palm Beach, FL, and is survived by her step-mother, Bella Goldberg of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Services will be held on Friday, August 13, 2004 at Riverside Memorial Chapel at noon at 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY (914-664-6800). Burial services will follow at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. Lois will be sorely missed by her friends and family. In lieu of flowers please make a memorial donation in memory of Lois Ross to the Lupus Foundation of America, Inc., 2000 L Street, NW Suite 710, Washington, DC 20036.

title: In Trying to Make Art, Success Can Be as Damaging as Failure
description: We're all familiar with the idea of being trapped by failure -- or fate. There's the grinding poverty into which so much of the world is plunged. But there are also the vast numbers of people with decent jobs who nonetheless feel pinned into lower-mid-level positions that they don't like or don't feel reflect their best abilities, yet to which they are bound by family or financial obligations or simply by the fear of trying something scary and new.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Unemployment Rate Rises
description: The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate in Australia rose in July to 5.7 percent from 5.6 percent in June, continuing its rise from a 23-year low set in May. While the number of part-time jobs is increasing, full-time jobs have stagnated, the Australian Bureau of Statistics said. Most of those losing their jobs, the bureau said, were women. title: AVID TO ACQUIRE MIDIMAN FOR $174.5 MILLION
description: Avid Technology Inc., which makes software and computers for editing digital audio and video, agreed to buy Midiman Inc. for about $174.5 million to add products for the home recording-studio market. Avid will pay $80 million in cash and issue two million shares of its common stock valued at $47.26 each, the average closing price for the previous 30 trading days, said Dean Ridlon, the director of investor relations for Avid. The company will also assume about $13.7 million in Midiman stock options. Midiman does business as M-Audio and makes equipment for recording digital audio at home. M-Audio, based in Irwindale, Calif., would become a unit of Avid's Digidesign audio division, which makes digital-audio recording equipment for home and professional studio markets. Avid is based in Tewksbury, Mass.
