title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHILD, JULIA
description: CHILD--Julia. The staff of Parade magazine mourns the loss of a friend and colleague. Julia Child, one of America's best loved chefs, was a television icon, a cookbook author, and food editor of Parade from 1982 to 1986. Her column, ''From Julia Child's Kitchen,'' gave Americans an extra dose of Julia's unique style, character, and culinary expertise. She remained a friend to Parade throughout the years. We will miss her kindness and enthusiasm. Walter Anderson, Chairman Parade

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICHTMYER, DAVID C., JR.
description: RICHTMYER--David C., Jr. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of David C. Richtmyer Jr., associated with The Times from August 1959 until retiring in September 1994.

title: Central Park: Field of Protest, or of Grass?
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Ministries
description: To the Editor:

title: Manning and Dayne Give Giants Fans New Reasons to Cheer
description: The grandstand was less than half full, but those inside Giants Stadium for Friday night's preseason game knew why they had come. In row upon row they sat, draped in new No. 10 Giants jerseys, the name Manning stitched across their shoulders.

title: Rell Adds 2nd Federal Corruption Investigator to Her Team
description: Gov. M. Jodi Rell has hired an F.B.I. agent to be a deputy commissioner of the state's Transportation Department after his retirement. He is the second federal official with experience in government corruption investigations she has tapped for her administration.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Conviction In Seminary Sex Scandal
description: A court in St. Plten, near Vienna, convicted a former student priest of downloading hundreds of images of child pornography during his studies at a seminary in St. Plten. Reports of homosexual behavior and collections of pornographic material at the seminary have rocked the Roman Catholic Church in Austria. The court handed down a six-month suspended sentence to the defendant, a 27-year-old Pole identified as Piotr Z.; he faced up to two years in prison. He is the only person charged in the scandal. The Vatican closed the seminary on Thursday. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: LET THE GAMES BEGIN
description: ANSWER KEY

title: Google's Slow Search for a Good Share Price
description: Every second, Google combs through billions of Web pages to answer questions as people check out everything from potential lovers to prospective lasagna recipes.

title: Free-Spending Chvez Could Swing Vote His Way
description: In an extraordinary referendum after years of political turmoil, Venezuelans will vote Sunday on whether to dismiss President Hugo Chvez, who has alienated the Bush administration with his anti-American bombast and polarized the nation with promises to use oil wealth for a social revolution.

title: As Its Two Track Stars Face Possible Disqualification, Greece Is Reeling
description: The drama surrounding Greece's premier Olympians, the sprinters Konstantinos Kenteris and Katerina Thanou, deepened Friday as their potential disqualification consumed the country the same day the Summer Games officially began without them.

title: McGreevey's Web: The Personal and the Political
description: To the Editor:

title: Google's Way May Not Be S.E.C.'s Way
description: It takes a lot of self-confidence to start a company aimed at solving a problem that everyone else thinks has already been solved. And when it turns that out the solution is a hugely successful one, it is understandable if the people who started the company acquire still more confidence in their own judgment.

title: Wolfgang Mommsen, 73, Historian Of German Social and Political Ideas
description: Wolfgang Mommsen, a scion of a dynasty of German historians who is best known in the United States for his scholarship on the historian Max Weber and the origins of imperialism, especially in Germany, died on Wednesday while vacationing on the island of Usedom, in the Baltic Sea. He was 73 and a resident of Dsseldorf, on the Rhine.

title: Storm Weakens but Still Packs a Punch as It Heads North
description: ARCADIA, Fla., Aug. 14  Hurricane Charley raced up the Atlantic seaboard Saturday, hitting the Carolinas with gusty winds and rain, after leaving Florida grappling with some of the worst storm devastation in its recent history.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE RISES. Orange juice prices gained as Hurricane Charley threatened the orange crop in Florida. In New York, juice for November delivery climbed 1.9 cents, or 3.1 percent, to 63 cents a pound.

title: A Minnesota Town and Its Not-So-Favorite Son
description: Nearly half a century ago, a scrawny youth whose artistic temperament and creative spirit had made him a misfit here left town to seek his fortune. Some people hope he never comes back.

title: MIRAMAX FILMS IS LAYING OFF 65 EMPLOYEES
description: Miramax Films, a division of the Walt Disney Company, laid off 65 employees yesterday, cutting its staff by 13 percent, to 420, said Matthew Hiltzik, a Miramax spokesman. Miramax is expected to release 18 movies this year, down from the 31 released in 2002, when it last had layoffs. Miramax faced a budget crisis this year after a spending spree during the first half of its fiscal year. Harvey Weinstein, the co-founder of Miramax with his brother, Bob, is trying to negotiate an agreement to produce movies independently while his brother would continue to make movies for Disney. The two sides met this week and the negotiations were described by representatives as both cordial and productive. Laura Holson (NYT)

title: After a Long Wait, Harvest of Success; Former Waitress Serves Up Songs To Dixie Chicks And Other Stars
description: Patty Griffin's loyalists need not squint at the credits to know that the Dixie Chicks rode to gold and glory singing songs that she wrote -- ''Top of the World,'' ''Truth No. 2'' and ''Let Him Fly.''

title: Religion Journal; Peyote, Indian Religion And the Issue of Exclusivity
description: What makesomeone a member of a religion? Is it something gained as a birthright, at a baptism, a result of devotional church attendance or even race? A case in Utah over peyote use has unearthed such questions, and the discussion seems to be just getting started.

title: Ukraine Vows To Maintain Troops in Iraq
description: The government of Ukraine, one of the largest contributors of foreign troops to Iraq, ended speculation over its commitment to the American-led mission by announcing Friday that a fresh brigade would be sent to replace the one rotating home this fall.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 26 about a Korean family's struggle with the United States' health care system misstated the affiliation and title of Adam Gurvitch, an advocate for immigrants. He is director of health advocacy for the New York Immigration Coalition -- not director of a group called Health Advocacy.

title: Stealing Not Just an 11th Trick; One Fruit of Age Is Often Guile
description: This column recently coined the word scorage, which is the product of a player's chronological age and the percentage score in a duplicate game. The record was set in April by Nan Field of Hobe Sound, Fla., with an 84 percent game the day after her 88th birthday for a scorage of 7392.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TEPEDINO, JEAN. (NEE CERASO)
description: TEPEDINO--Jean. (nee Ceraso). On August 11, 2004. Beloved wife of Vincent. Loving mother of Carol Ann O'Donnell, Robert Tepedino, and the late Vincent, Jr. Cherished grandmother of Vincent, Megan and Amanda. Dear mother-in-law of Dennis and Madeline. Reposing at Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons Bethpage Funeral Home, 20 Hicksville Road (1 mile north of Southern State Parkway, Exit 29). Visitation Friday 7:00-9:30 pm; Saturday and Sunday 2:00-4:30 and 7:00-9:30 pm. Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial Monday 9:45 am at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Interment Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn. Memorial contributions may be sent to Homes for Autistic Children and Adults, 585 Stewart Ave., Garden City, NY 11530.

title: More Trouble on the Turnpike
description: My fictional alter ego, a disgraced political operative, once suggested a motto for the Garden State: ''New Jersey: you got a problem with that?'' Maybe you have to be from Jersey (we leave out the ''New'') to appreciate the slogan. Jersey is all about confrontation; we dare you to see just how much we'll tolerate before things get ugly.

title: McGreevey's Web: The Personal and the Political
description: To the Editor:

title: With Danger at the Door, a Diverse Florida Bonds
description: Dorothy L. Martin has lived here for 28 of her 51 years, but never felt compelled to leave her home until Friday, when she took shelter in a high school gymnasium with more than 800 other people fleeing Hurricane Charley.

title: Niedermayer Gets Devils' Richest Deal
description: A judge in Toronto yesterday awarded Devils defenseman Scott Niedermayer a $7 million salary for the 2004-5 season, matching the high in a National Hockey League arbitration case, awarded four years ago to John LeClair of the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Missed Cut Jeopardizes Kelly's Shot at Ryder Cup Team
description: Jerry Kelly will suffer through a long weekend, hoping he is named to the United States Ryder Cup team on Monday.

title: Central Park: Field of Protest, or of Grass? (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A French Employee's Work Celebrates the Sloth Ethic
description: Finally, instead of dissembling behind ambiguous notions of Gallic joie de vivre, someone in this leisurely land has declared outright that the French should eschew the Anglo-Saxon work ethic and openly embrace sloth.

title: For a Hopeless Generation, A Rebel Militia Fills a Void
description: Muhammad Hussein was always the baby of the family. His hero was an Iraqi soccer player. He liked Indian cinema. With his brothers already grown, he spent a lot of time alone.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Trade Surplus Rises
description: Canada's merchandise trade surplus hit a record 8.6 billion Canadian dollars ($6.5 billion) in June, Statistics Canada said. The surplus, which was well above the forecasts of economists, resulted from increased demand worldwide as well as the economic recovery in the United States, the agency said. The government agency said that exports from Canada rose 4.4 percent during June. At the same time, imports fell 3.7 percent. Much of the decline in imports reflected reduced imports of machinery and other equipment, particularly from the United States. Over all, Canadian exports to the United States rose 2.9 percent while purchases from the United States declined 3.6 percent. Canada's trade surplus with the United States stood at 10.7 billion Canadian dollars, its second-highest level in history. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Man Arrested Over Photos After 9/11 Is Deported
description: The Pakistani immigrant who was detained on suspicions of terrorism in the fall of 2001 after he took a photograph near a water-treatment plant near Hudson, N.Y., has been deported, officials confirmed on Friday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: General Motors Corp., Detroit, promoted the head of the expanding Cadillac division to run North American marketing and named a new leader for the Hummer brand amid declining sales.

title: Publisher Says Memoir Is Probably Fiction
description: The Australian unit of Random House said yesterday that an internal investigation had concluded that a best-selling memoir by Norma Khouri, published in 2002 under the title ''Forbidden Love,'' was probably a work of fiction.

title: Terror and the Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Central Park: Field of Protest, or of Grass?
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of Spotlight, Bush Overhauls U.S. Regulations
description: Correction Appended

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Telecom Stake Sold
description: The private equity firm Warburg Pincus sold a 3.3 percent stake in India's second-largest mobile phone service company, Bharti Tele-Ventures Ltd. According to a statement to stock exchanges yesterday, Brentwood Investment Holdings, a unit of Warburg Pincus, sold 62 million shares. Citigroup Global Markets, which arranged the sale, said Warburg Pincus was paid $207 million for the shares, according to Bloomberg News. Warburg Pincus, based in New York, retains a 15.17 percent stake in Bharti. Singapore Telecommunications also holds a stake in Bharti. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Trade Deficit, $55.8 Billion, Sets Record
description: The United States trade deficit ballooned in June to a record $55.8 billion as imports of crude oil surged and slowing growth in Japan and Europe curbed export demand.

title: On Tape, Greek Ceremony Was a Little Lost in Translation
description: Only the Greeks could produce an Olympic opening ceremony with evocations of Homer, Euclid and Archimedes; a massive stylized statue of a giant head that magically broke into many smaller floating sculptures; and humans portraying ancient Olympians, but without their historically accurate nakedness (doubtless an act of obedience to the Federal Communications Commission in the post-Janet Jackson era).

title: Hurricane Intensified Unexpectedly Near Florida
description: In spinning up from a relatively unremarkable Category 2 storm to the extreme Category 4 level in just five hours yesterday, Hurricane Charley illustrated the limits that still dog hurricane forecasting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOFFMANN, MARY B. (NEE BYRNE)
description: HOFFMANN--Mary B. (nee Byrne), 76, Somers, NY, August 13. She is survived by her husband H. Ross O'Sullivan and children Mary Byrne Hoffmann, Jean Ward, Laura Hoffmann, Heather Mullally, Chris Hoffmann, Eileen Shaw, Beth Porell and Joan Thompson, her sisters, Sr. Eileen Byrne, O.P., Joan Murphy and 19 grancdhildren. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 10AM, St. Elizabeth Seton Church, Ridgefield, CT. Visiting at the Kane Funeral Home, Ridgefield, CT on Monday from 2-4pm & 7-9pm

title: Criticism Takes Toll on Judge in Bryant Sexual Assault Case
description: Judge W. Terry Ruckriegle, who presides over the Kobe Bryant rape case, has become the man people love to hate.

title: The Saw Is the Star (Never Mind the Role)
description: Some users of DeWalt's 14.4-volt, 5 3/8-inch circular trim saw, a jaunty little machine that looks like a yellow and black flashlight with a jagged CD slapped on one side, are so enamored of it that they have posted testimonials on the Web. One posting, fondly titled ''The Little Saw That Could,'' raves, ''I have found this saw to be very capable of doing most of the cutting that I do around the house.''

title: A New Czech Voice With an Old
description: Where would classical music programming be without composer anniversaries as the criterion for special tributes or entire seasons? Marking these dates is a weapon against the randomness of the past and its true distance and irretrievability. Musical heroes feel closer when the grand events of their lives are yoked to our own humble calendars. Today is your mom's birthday; tomorrow is Dvorak's.

title: A Winding Path to Gay Marriage
description: The distress of gay and lesbian couples was understandable in San Francisco when the California Supreme Court voided 4,000 same-sex marriages. But the court's reasoning, in finding that Mayor Gavin Newsom had overstepped his authority, was understandable as well. We agree with its reasoning on this narrow question of mayoral powers. We also sympathize with the affected couples and hope for a happier outcome on the far more substantive challenge, now working its way through the courts, of whether state law is unconstitutional in limiting marriage to a union of a man and a woman.

title: For Yankees, Late Innings Are as Easy As 1-2-3
description: The clubhouse attendant who assigned lockers to the Yankees for their series with the Texas Rangers at Ameriquest Field apparently watches the way Manager Joe Torre handles his bullpen. Torre typically prefers using Paul Quantrill first, then Tom Gordon, and calls Mariano Rivera to close games.

title: The Blackout in Congress
description: Today is the first anniversary of the biggest blackout in North American history. It is also an occasion to reflect on how little Congress has done to make sure that the electric power industry does not repeat the same sloppy mistakes that triggered a chain of events that eventually left 50 million people in the United States and Canada without power.

title: DEPARTURE OF CHIEF HURTS CONSECO SHARES
description: Shares of Conseco Inc. fell to their lowest level since it emerged from bankruptcy last September on investor concern that the departure of its chief executive, William Shea, would delay the company's recovery. Conseco, a life insurer based in Carmel, Ind., said late Thursday that Mr. Shea had stepped down and that William Kirsch, the company's general counsel, had replaced him. The shares dropped $1.41, or 8.2 percent, to $15.74. Conseco said that Mr. Shea, 56, decided to leave the company after helping it emerge from bankruptcy and return to profitability. Analysts said they were surprised by Mr. Shea's departure and had expected him to stay longer after the company raised $1.6 billion in May to pay off debt. Mr. Kirsch was a managing partner with Kirkland & Ellis before becoming Conseco's general counsel last year. He was Conseco's principal outside corporate counsel throughout the bankruptcy.

title: Oil Above $46 and Far Above OPEC's Ceiling
description: After oil prices fell to about $9 a barrel in 1998, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries showed remarkable discipline, restraining production and managing supplies to get oil back above a $22-a-barrel floor and keep it there.

title: U.S. Asks That Court Halt United's Plan for Pensions
description: The federal government said yesterday that the total shortfall in United Airlines' pension plans had grown more than previously disclosed, to $8.3 billion, and it asked the judge overseeing United's bankruptcy proceedings to strike a recent loan agreement that requires the airline to suspend its contributions to the plans.

title: A writer's remembrance of Julia Child
National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Media Campaign Leads To Transplant
description: Todd Krampitz, 32, a Houston photographer, underwent liver transplant surgery at Methodist Hospital after a media campaign by his family helped him find an organ donor. Mr. Krampitz's wife, Julie, and his sister coordinated an effort that included a toll-free telephone line, a Web site and two billboards. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Kurdish Rebels Blamed For Bombs
description: The police said that separatists from the guerrilla group formerly known as the Kurdistan Workers Party but now called Kongra-Gel were behind the hotel bomb attacks in Istanbul that killed two people and injured 11 this week. Sebnem Arsu (NYT)

title: New Bush Spot Renews Sharp Attacks
description: President Bush's campaign will begin a blistering new attack against Senator John Kerry on Monday questioning his attendance at Intelligence Committee hearings in an advertisement that ends a brief pause in confrontational advertising by Mr. Bush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAMER, SYLVIA (HAMEROFF)
description: KRAMER--Sylvia (Hameroff). Age 90, on August 12, 2004. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted mother of Morris and Stephen and mother-in-law of Pearl. Loving grandmother of Jeremy, Liza, Oliver and Joseph and sister of Gerald and the late Henrietta. She was loved and will be missed by all. Services Sunday 1PM at I.J. Morris Funeral Chapel, Flatbush Avenue and Ave L, Brooklyn.

title: Mickey Rooney, Recapping a Long Career
description: Mickey Rooney seemed absolutely elderly in ''Sugar Babies'' on Broadway in 1978, but he was only 58. Maybe that's the curse of the child star. Now he really is getting old (84 next month), and he's performing another exercise in nostalgia, this time Off Broadway and with his eighth wife, Jan Chamberlin Rooney.

title: Throwing the Book at 'Em
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  John Kerrys latest book has hardly made the best-seller list, but that is probably because its not exactly for sale. The Democratic presidential nominee is, however, trying to give them away as fast as he can.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Paraguay: Disaster Chief Dismissed
description: President Nicanor Duarte Frutos dismissed the country's chief disaster relief administrator, Manuel Sarquis, after accusations that he misused aid donations sent from around the world to help victims of a deadly fire at a shopping center on Aug. 1. The death toll from the fire at the megastore in Ycu Bolaos, on the outskirts of Asuncin, stands at 388, with 5 people missing. An investigation concluded this week that the fire started after a spark ignited grease and charcoal that had accumulated in a chimney over a grill in the building's food court. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Black Loses Effort to Halt Lawsuits
description: Conrad M. Black, the controlling shareholder of Hollinger International Inc., has lost a court bid in Ontario to halt the company's lawsuits against him outside Canada.

title: With Discretion, Two Women Stand By the Governor in His Time of Tribulation
description: Correction Appended

title: Venezuela's Fake Democrat
description: The most important struggle for democracy in the Western Hemisphere is now playing out in Venezuela, one of Latin America's oldest continuing democracies, and a leading supplier of oil to the United States.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Casino Ballot Question Is Ruled Out
description: Judge Daniel A. Procaccini of Superior Court ruled that a ballot question asking voters to establish a $600 million resort-style casino in West Warwick would be illegal. The State Supreme Court issued a similar advisory opinion on Thursday. Matt Viser (NYT)

title: In First Rulings, Military Tribunals Uphold Detentions of 4
description: In their first decisions, military tribunals considering the status of the people held at the United States naval base in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, ruled yesterday that four detainees had properly been designated as enemy combatants who may be held there indefinitely.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Terror Suspect Ordered Held 28 Days
description: A London judge ordered that Babar Ahmad, a 30-year-old computer specialist arrested by British authorities this month at the request of American officials for allegedly aiding the Taliban and other fighters, be held in custody until a hearing on Sept. 10. The United States is seeking the extradition of Mr. Ahmad, a British citizen, alleging he used United States-based Web sites to raise money and support for terrorist causes abroad, and officials suspect him of ties to Qaeda operatives. A lawyer for Mr. Ahmad called his arrest ''politically motivated.'' Richard A. Oppel Jr. (NYT)

title: A Rightist From the East Builds Support in Germany
description: THE press and the comedians make fun of her hairdo, a sort of emblem of her lack of glamour. One survey showed her getting a rank of 7 out of a possible 100 on the charisma scale. When she started in politics as the person her then-patron, former Chancellor Helmut Kohl, used to call ''the girl,'' she reportedly broke down in tears in cabinet meetings when the going got tough.

title: American Caught With Taliban Seeks Review of 20-Year Term
description: Lawyers for John Walker Lindh, the young American captured in Afghanistan after joining the Taliban and now serving a 20-year prison sentence, called on the Justice Department on Friday to review his case in light of the department's announcement this week that it might soon free another American captured with the Taliban.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Economic Growth Slows
description: Economic growth in the 12 nations sharing the euro unexpectedly slowed in the second quarter. Gross domestic product, the value of all goods and services, expanded 0.5 percent from January to March, when it grew 0.6 percent, the European Union's statistics office said.

title: Iranian Judo Champion Refuses to Face Israeli
description: Arash Miresmaeili, the Iranian world judo champion who carried his country's flag in the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games last night, has pulled out of the tournament rather than fight an Israeli.

title: Basque Group Renews Attacks, Spain Charges
description: The Interior Ministry said Friday that four bombings in northern Spain in the last week showed that ETA, the Basque separatist group, had resumed attacks after keeping a low profile since the March 11 terror attacks here.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of the Tammany Hall leader Carmine G. De Sapio on July 28 misstated the given name of the man he chose as the first native-born Puerto Rican to serve as a Democratic Party district leader in New York City. He was Antonio Mendez, not Anthony.

title: Caring for victims, war zone by war zone
description: MILAN:  When Gino Strada was performing surgery in a Pakistani field hospital in 1987, it took him four months to ask himself why his patients were mostly women and children.

title: Machinations In Albany Foil Bill to Expand Javits Center
description: After 10 years of false starts, the proposed $1.4 billion expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center finally got going in June with lots of fanfare and promise.

title: Central Park: Field of Protest, or of Grass?
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Group Asks Court To Halt Chemical Incineration
description: An environmental group has sought an injunction seeking to halt a $2.4 billion plan by the Army to incinerate about 7.4 million pounds of nerve and blister agents stored at the Umatilla Chemical Depot. The organization, called the Group Against Social Predation, or Gasp, says the 30,000 people living near the depot are at risk because toxins will be released during the incineration. The Army says the incineration method is safe. Brian Alexander (NYT)

title: Republicans Say Governor Should Quit Immediately
description: A day after Gov. James E. McGreevey turned the political world in New Jersey upside down by announcing that he had engaged in a sexual relationship with another man and would resign on Nov. 15, a group of Republican officials gathered outside the State House in Trenton to repeat their call for him to step down immediately and allow for a special election on Nov. 2.

title: A Sweet Mozart Finale Disguises a Bitter Pill
description: What happens at the end of Mozart's opera ''Cos Fan Tutte''? There may be no other work by Mozart whose conclusion is so disorienting and so resistant to ordinary dramatic sense. Jonathan Miller's elegantly witty production, which can be heard tonight for the last time as part of Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart festival, offers a darkly cynical suggestion for the finale. But Mozart's ending poses a mystery that demands closer scrutiny.

title: It's an Underground Monster World Series
description: Twentieth Century Fox threw its baby to the wolves yesterday, opening ''Alien vs. Predator'' nationally on Friday without holding advance screenings for film reviewers. That's often a sign that a movie is a major disaster, but the film turns out to be no worse than most mindless summer action films, and even has some solid formal qualities thanks to the director, Paul W. S. Anderson.

title: Israel Could Safely Withdraw From Golan, Army Chief Says
description: Israel's senior army commander says his country could safely withdraw from the Golan Heights in any future peace settlement with Syria, without retaining any occupied territory there as a buffer.

title: Christie's Reports Rise in Sales at Auctions
description: Christie's International, the auction house, said yesterday that the amount it raised at auctions rose 19 percent in the first half, helped by sales of postwar and contemporary art in New York.

title: Julia Child, the French Chef For a Jell-O Nation, Dies at 91
description: Julia Child, who turned the art of French cooking into prime-time television entertainment and brought cassoulet to a casserole culture in the two volumes of her monumental ''Mastering the Art of French Cooking,'' died yesterday at her home in Santa Barbara, Calif., two days before her 92nd birthday.

title: Mayor Takes Union Leaders to Task on Their Presentations
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sought yesterday to drive a wedge between police officers and firefighters and their union leaders, saying that the uniformed workers could be getting big raises if only the labor leaders presented the city's offers to the membership.

title: Seven Words You Can Never Say on the Campaign Trail
description: The political season is starting to take on the tone of a George Carlin routine.

title: KEY ENERGY SEEKS MORE TIME TO FILE FINANCIAL REPORTS
description: Key Energy Services Inc., a Texas oil field contractor, requested more time from lenders to finish belated financial reports because an audit prompted by suspected employee fraud probably will last beyond a Sept. 30 deadline. The company is in talks with providers of a $175 million revolving loan for an extension to file its financial statements from 2003 and the first quarter of 2004. Failure to get a waiver before Sept. 30 would result in a default, the company said. Key, which is based in Midland, Tex., missed reporting deadlines because of internal and external inquiries that began after auditors said employees, who have since been fired, misappropriated funds and misrepresented the value of a business the company bought.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Commercial Real Estate page of Business Day on July 28 about the sale of an office building in Rye Brook, N.Y., by the Altria Group misstated the time on the market for another corporate site in Westchester County. Texaco's headquarters property in Harrison was sold to Morgan Stanley after a few months -- not several years.

title: Sports of The Times; Dancing Around the Enemy Within
description: BENEATH the wondrous Calatrava roof, with its graceful wingspan and bone structure of a stingray, the Olympic stadium morphed into a temporary healing center for the Greek culture of persecution last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, ALAN N.
description: COHEN--Alan N. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Educational Alliance are saddened by the passing of Alan N. Cohen, beloved father of former trustee and Assistant Treasurer, Gordon S. Cohen. Alan was an extraordinary philanthropist whose generosity will leave a lasting legacy. The Alliance is pleased to be counted among Mr. Cohen's numerous charitable associations and is most fortunate to have been able to honor Mr. Cohen at our 1998 annual benefit. We extend our sincere condolences to Alan's wife, children and the entire Cohen family.

title: McGreevey's Web: The Personal and the Political (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: To Some, an Issue of Patronage Trumps Issues of Sexuality, Infidelity and Politics
description: Like many people across New Jersey, Betty Williams, a 53-year-old homemaker from Cherry Hill, felt a mix of puzzlement and respect at first.

title: Philharmonic Downshifts From Jet Travel to Buses
description: When the New York Philharmonic announced last month that it was pulling out of a planned tour to Spain and Italy in early September, little alarm bells went off. This was the third tour that the Philharmonic had canceled within a single year. What was going wrong? Had the touring of orchestras become as economically unfeasible as live broadcasts and recording contracts? Was the Philharmonic somehow mishandling its tour negotiations? Was the orchestra outmoded and classical music dead, as people variously fret these days?

title: U.S. Looks to Settle Down After Unsettling Tuneups
description: On a crowded stage surrounded by his players, Larry Brown nudged his glasses back to the bridge of his nose, the professor standing with his students for the class picture.

title: McGreevey's Web: The Personal and the Political
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Names Debate Moderators as It Awaits Bush and Cheney's Pledge to Take Part
description: The commission in charge of setting up the presidential debates named the list of moderators for the four events it plans to hold this fall. Now all it needs is for President Bush to agree to show up.

title: Gay Marriage Becomes A Swing Issue With Pull
description: Supporters and opponents of same-sex marriage called this week's California Supreme Court decision nullifying San Francisco's marriage licenses a minor prelude to bigger battles at the ballot box. Both social conservatives and gay rights groups say their debate is becoming increasingly intertwined with the presidential election.

title: Sports of The Times; Woods Grinds It Out and Makes the Cut Again
description: ONCE upon a time, it wasn't a major unless Tiger Woods was in the hunt for another golf title on the weekend.

title: Starters Prove Jets' Strength, and Reserves Expose Their Weakness
description: If they took nothing else from last night's preseason opener against the Saints, the Jets learned that, for the most part, what they've been seeing from their starting lineup at training camp has not been an illusion. The running game worked. The quarterback moved the offense crisply and efficiently. And the aggressive defense produced a turnover the second time it took the field.

title: Dr. David Golde, 63, Expert On Blood Disorders, Is Dead
description: Dr. David W. Golde, an expert in blood disorders who was chief physician at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City, died on Aug. 9 at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 63.

title: Police Tactic Against Terror: Let's Network
description: In January, their mission was to speak before a mosquito sprayers' convention in Harrisburg, Pa. In April, the detectives attended a meeting of self-storage business owners in Atlanta. This summer, they were in Naples, Fla., mingling with propane gas vendors at their trade association's annual conference.

title: Making Sense of New York, From 86 Stories Up; Views From the Empire State Building, Mapped Out in Steel
description: Despite terror alerts, persistent humidity and the seemingly inevitable weekend with scattered showers, it is the summer of the tourist in Manhattan. It was hardly surprising, therefore, that Raymond Ayotte, a vacationing retired insurance manager from Montreal, was recently heard asking: ''But where is Times Square?'' Though he was nowhere near it -- being atop the Empire State Building -- it did not deter Keith Godard, a graphic designer, from explaining: ''Times Square is over here.'' He pointed to ''Times Square, Crossroads of the World,'' on an eight-foot panel interpreting the view from the Observation Deck of the Empire State Building.

title: Corrections

title: JUDGE SAYS ARCH COAL CAN PURCHASE TRITON MINES
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that Arch Coal could complete its $364 million purchase of the Wyoming mines of the Triton Coal Company. The judge rejected government arguments that the takeover would lead to higher prices for low-sulfur coal used to generate electricity. Judge John Bates of United States District Court in Washington rebuffed a challenge to the transaction by the Federal Trade Commission and six states where almost half the low-sulfur coal is consumed. The government can appeal Judge Bates's ruling, which denied a request for a preliminary injunction, to a federal appeals court. The F.T.C. said the acquisition would result in more than 80 percent of production of Wyoming's Southern Powder River Basin being controlled by three companies.

title: With the Cameras Rolling, Phelps Is Set for His First Four Minutes of Fame
description: The Olympic celebrity-makers could not ask for a better way to begin competition on Saturday: in swimming's first race, the 400-meter individual medley, Michael Phelps will start his quest for seven gold medals competing in one of his strongest events.

title: PALMSOURCE CHAIRMAN TO RESIGN FROM BOARD
description: PalmSource Inc. said its chairman, Eric Benhamou, would resign from its board after the next annual meeting as the company further separated itself from its former parent, PalmOne Inc. Mr. Benhamou plans to remain chairman of PalmOne, the world's largest maker of hand-held computers, PalmSource said. PalmSource makes software for Palm devices. PalmSource was spun off in October from PalmOne, formerly Palm Inc., so it could sell software to other companies. PalmSource, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., has no immediate plans to name a successor, a spokesman said. PalmOne is based in Milpitas, Calif.

title: Ms. Child Departs the Nation's Table
description: Even her wonderfully warbling voice seemed untelegenic. But, meal by meal across the decades, the authenticity of Julia Child glowed forth from the television screen to overpower any quibbles and doubts about the presence of such a marvelously honest woman who dared to show the nation that fine cooking could be plainly taught. ''You're alone in your kitchen,'' Ms. Child famously ad-libbed once when she flipped the day's specialty out of reach and blithely slung it back into focus as an unplanned lesson for her viewers.

title: For Slain Councilman's Kin, Paternity Claim Is Latest Jolt
description: It has been more than a year since City Councilman James E. Davis was killed in City Hall by a rival seeking to unseat him, a murder that shocked the city and led to increased security at New York's seat of government. But the effects of that shooting extended far beyond that Wednesday afternoon of July 23, 2003. It has shaken the Davis family in ways that have been profound and unpredictable, often in the glare of unfavorable publicity.

title: Mob Figure Admits Roles In Murders, Including Judge's
description: The man prosecutors say is the acting boss of the Colombo crime family pleaded guilty yesterday to racketeering charges and acknowledged playing a central role in one of New York's most nightmarishly botched mob murders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROCHE, MARY ALICE
description: ROCHE--Mary Alice. On July 29, 2004 in Caldwell, NJ. Born in Ohio in 1917, Ms. Roche moved to Caldwell in 1945 where she opened a horticultural photography studio with her husband. In 1971 she helped establish the Sensory Awareness Foundation and served as Managing Secretary and Editor of its publications for twenty years, while conducting Sensory Awareness workshops. Ms. Roche became a Director of The Lifwynn Foundation in 1993 and was instrumental in integrating its human relations research program and Sensory Awareness. A memorial service is planned for October in NYC.

title: Bush and Kerry, in the Northwest, Again Cross Paths
description: President Bush and Senator John Kerry campaigned on Friday a few miles apart here in a state decided by the slimmest of margins four years ago, tangling over taxes in light of a new report that Mr. Kerry said bolsters his argument that Mr. Bush's tax cut mostly benefited the wealthy.

title: In Brooklyn, a Defendant Who Struck Fear in Witnesses Finally Falls
description: Brooklyn prosecutors added a conviction last week to the rap sheet of a 30-year-old man with a street name and a criminal record dating back to his teenage years. That accomplishment would not ordinarily draw much notice.

description: A federal district judge in Washington on Thursday dismissed an antitrust lawsuit that contended medical residents are forced to participate in a system that ensures they work long hours for low wages.

title: NEGATIVE OUTLOOK FOR LEUCADIA CREDIT RATING
description: Standard & Poor's put the credit rating of the Leucadia National Corporation, a holding company, on negative outlook as a result of the company's offer to buy at least half the shares of the telecommunications company, MCI. Leucadia, which cleared regulatory hurdles for its offer this week, could pay about $2 billion for half or more of MCI's stock. Given MCI's exposure to the turbulent long-distance phone market, Standard & Poor's said Leucadia would be adding assets that could increase its credit risk. The agency also noted Leucadia's investment in another telecommunications company, the WilTel Communications Group, and said Leucadia ''may have a strong interest in making more acquisitions in the telecommunications sector, which could put pressure on the ratings.'' Leucadia's long-term counterparty credit is now rated BBB-. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Indispensable Allies on Iran
description: Iraq provides a textbook lesson for a superpower about the dangers of going it alone in the world, but the Bush administration seems to suffer from attention deficit disorder. Some of its more hawkish officials are now pressing to confront Iran over its nuclear weapons development, regardless of whether America's main allies are convinced that diplomacy and inspections have been exhausted. Nobody in Washington proposes invading Iran, but administration officials hint darkly about starting an effort to destabilize Tehran's clerical dictatorship. Iran's ruling mullahs are justifiably unpopular. But unilateral American bullying is one sure way to rally flagging support for them among nationalistic Iranians.

title: AMERISOURCEBERGEN MAY BUY BACK $500 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The AmerisourceBergen Corporation, a drug wholesaler, forecast little change in sales and earnings for fiscal 2005 and said it might repurchase as much as $500 million in stock to increase per-share profit. An updated forecast will be given in November, when the company reports 2004 results, AmerisourceBergen said yesterday. Based on the company's stock price yesterday, the repurchase plan would allow AmerisourceBergen to buy back about 9.4 million of its 112 million shares outstanding. Earnings growth at AmerisourceBergen is being stifled by the loss of two big accounts, including a contract with the Department of Veterans Affairs that generated $1 billion in quarterly sales. Stock in the company, which is based in Valley Forge, Pa., fell $3.09, or 6 percent, to $49.91 a share.

title: Globalist : To understand France, look around its villages
description: CHERENCE, France  The 11th-century Romanesque church of this village is a minor jewel. But not all of it is old. Concealed within the steeple, just below the proud cock that sits atop the spire, is an antenna recently installed by France Telecom that affords the 146 residents an excellent cellphone reception.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Export Outlook Raised
description: Citing stronger-than-expected exports in the first seven months of the year, Brazil's government raised its forecast for the trade surplus for 2004 to $30 billion, up from a record $24.8 billion in 2003. The trade ministry also said that it now expected exports to total $90 billion at the end of the year, up from a previous estimate of $88 billion. Last year, Brazilian exports rose 21 percent, to $73 billion. President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, who took office in January 2003, has said that he expects annual exports to reach $100 million before the end of his four-year term. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KING, MAY TARLTON ''TOPSY'' DOUGHERTY
description: KING--May Tarlton ''Topsy'' Dougherty, 90, passed away at her home on Monday, August 9, 2004. She was born December 30, 1913, in Austin, Texas to James R. and Genevieve Dougherty. Mrs. King attended the Hockaday School in Dallas and later the University of Texas in Austin. Mrs. King was preceded in death by her husbands, Bruce Beverly Baxter, Jr. and John Allen King; her sons, Bruce Beverly Baxter, III and Frank William Carr, Jr.; sister, Rachael Vaughan; and brothers, James R. Dougherty, Jr. and Dudley Tarlton Dougherty. She is survived by her daughter, Caroline Baxter Pauley, and her husband, Peter Sanford Pauley of Greenwich, Connecticut, and Frances Carr Tapp and her husband, Felix Cowan Tapp of Corpus Christi, Texas; five grandchildren; four great-grandchildren; and many relatives. A Mass was celebrated at 11:00 A.M., Friday, August 13, 2004, at St. Patrick's Catholic Church in Corpus Christi, Texas. Interment followed at Rose Hill Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in Mrs. King's name to the Dougherty Historical Foundation, P.O. Box 640, Beeville, Texas 78104.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GURTNER, GREGORY JOHN, MD
description: GURTNER--Gregory John, MD, gastroenterologist and scientist at Washington University, St. Louis, MO, August 11, 2004 at the age of 36. Born in Buffalo, NY and raised in Baltimore, MD, attended Gilman School, received his undergraduate degree at Vanderbilt, TN followed by medical school at NY Medical College, Valhalla, NY and then moved to St. Louis, MO where he received post-graduate training in Internal Medicine and Gastroenterololgy. While working with world-renowned scientists at Washington University, Dr. Gurtner became interested in understanding the fundamental mechanisms of human disease and developing novel approaches for their cure. He enjoyed traditional American tavern cuisine, St. Louis Cardinals and Rams and was an accomplished musician. Survived by his mother, Nancy (nee Cash) Gurtner, Ed.D of Ridgefield, CT, his brother Geoffrey Gurtner, MD of Manhattan, NYH. Services, Monday, 1pm, St. Andrew's Lutheran Church, Ridgefield, CT. Burial to follow. Visiting at the Kane Funeral Home, 25 Catoonah St, Ridgefield on Sunday, 4pm to 7pm. A memorial service will be held at Washington University, St. Louis, MO at a date to be announed. description: THE martial-arts epic "Hero," which opens on Aug. 27, is the product of an unlikely collaboration between two dazzling visual stylists: the Chinese director Zhang Yimou and the Australian cinematographer Christopher Doyle. That they had never before worked together is not surprising. Mr. Zhang ("Raise the Red Lantern," "Shanghai Triad"), a former cameraman, is known for the quiet beauty of his carefully composed shots; Mr. Doyle ("In the Mood for Love," "Chungking Express"), who prides himself on his ability to improvise with the camera on his shoulder, prefers, as he says to "find the film" as he is shooting it. Mr. Zhang makes still lifes; Mr. Doyle is an action painter.

title: American Pastoral
description: POETS have long used imagined rural worlds as refuges from, and symbols for, our own: simplified, purposely unrealistic shepherds, gardeners and fishermen let writers from Theocritus to Milton weave pastorals whose forests, fields and brooks encode claims about politics, religion, dead friends, living rivals or difficult loves. Modern poets have made their own versions of pastoral: for some, it includes any poem about a way of life or a setting remote from poet and readers, any fictive site or imagined retreat older and simpler than the way we live now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHILD, JULIA
description: CHILD--Julia. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, Staff and Volunteers of Educational Broadcasting Corporation, licensee of Thirteen/WNET and WLIW21, we note with great sadness the passing of Julia Child-a remarkable woman who revolutionized cooking, and pioneered one of public television's most enduring and popular forms of programming. When Ms Child launched her series ''The French Chef'' in 1963, public television proudly delivered her inimitable wit and masterful cookery to America. Four decades later, the tireless proponent of fine cuisine remained one of our most respected and beloved partners, as she continued to share her lifelong passion for food that satisfies the body and stirs the soul. Julia Child was larger than life. She showed us the meaning of good taste as no one else before her. We will miss her generous laughter and her grand spirit. But her delightful lessons will remain with us everytime we step into the kitchen. Steven R. Rattner, Chairman William F. Baker, President

He was 93

title: Past, Prologue and Paris
description: ON the last morning of a three-week stay in Paris, I left my apartment on the Rue du Bac and headed for my favorite city retreat: the Parc Monceau. An oasis of tranquillity with golden gravel paths that curve beneath a canopy of tulip trees, magnolia grandiflora and copper beech, the park is hidden away, only a 10-minute stroll from the busy streets that surround the Arc de Triomphe. Ringed by elegant 18th- and 19th-century mansions, the Monceau is a place of cool greenery, miniature waterfalls and the trilling sounds of birds calling back and forth.

title: Stem Cell Battles
description: Stem cell research moved to the forefront of the presidential campaign last week. The Democratic candidates said they would ease the Bush administration's restrictions on federal funding and quadruple the money available. Republicans retorted that they were the first to finance embryonic stem cell research and that the Democrats were cruelly inflating expectations for instant cures. Just as the debate was heating up, two developments suggested that the Democrats were right to call for expansion of this important research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, ALAN N.
description: COHEN--Alan N. The National Basketball Association notes with sadness the death of our colleague Alan N. Cohen. A longtime and highly respected member of the NBA family, Alan began his association with the league in 1974 when he was named CEO and Chairman of Madison Square Garden, which owned the New York Knicks. He later served in ownership roles for the New Jersey NETS as well as the Boston Celtics during the team's championship years of the 1980s. As an executive, team owner and Chairman of the NBA's Board of Governors, Alan made enormous contributions to the growth of the league, most notably as an architect of the NBA's landmark revenue sharing/salary cap system in 1983. In addition to his relationship with the NBA, Alan was distinguished as both a successful businessman and generous humanitarian. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Carol, daughters Rebecca and Laurie, son Gordon and sister Beryl. Jerry Colangelo, Chairman David J. Stern, Commissioner

title: Tortured by Slaps, Punches and (Gasp!) Engelbert
description: For the better part of an hour and 40 minutes, without intermission, in Irvine Welsh's play "You'll Have Had Your Hole," a petty criminal from the Edinburgh underclass is tortured and molested by two lowlife cronies in an abandoned recording studio. With a gag in his mouth, the victim Dex (Zack Calhoon), is punched, slapped, and forced to listen on headphones to a loop of Engelbert Humperdinck's "Release Me," played at deafening volume.

The increased enforcement was prompted by a fatal crash on the parkway last month that left one person dead and three people seriously injured. The county said both speed and alcohol were factors in that crash, which is still under investigation.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: JOURNAL OF THE DEAD: A Story of Friendship and Murder in the New Mexico Desert, by Jason Kersten. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $12.95.) In the summer of 1999, two friends from the Boston area wandered into sun-blasted Carlsbad Caverns National Park with three pints of water between them and got lost; when a ranger found them four days later, one was badly dehydrated, the other stabbed to death by his friend. The mystery is why he was killed. This ''ruminative, wholly absorbing'' account unfolds with ''quiet authority, lending unexpected dignity to the whole affair,'' our reviewer, Bruce Barcott, wrote in the Book Review last year.

title: What's the 5:20 Without a Smile and a Doughnut?
description: FOR many of the still sleepy commuters at the Fairfield train station, Nancy Torok is a gentle wake-up call. For almost nine years she has greeted them with a smile, kind words, and most importantly, a cup of coffee made just the way they like it. But the concession she runs is about to change hands, and while people may still get doughnuts, still get coffee, they may not be getting it from Mrs. Torok.

title: LIVING IN/West SoHo; Eschewing a Name and Becoming an Address
description: IT is located just below West Houston Street, but Manhattan's hottest ''new'' neighborhood is so hot and so new it doesn't even have a name anybody can agree on. No SoHo, no TriBeCa, no NoLIta. Nothing like SpaHa, what the uptown me-too crowd with a case of downtown envy now calls Spanish Harlem. A Spring Street bar selling $3 beers gamely calls itself NoCa, as in North of Canal Street, but as obvious as it is, not even that name has caught on in this little spit of a Lower West Side enclave whose dominant feature seems to be the entrance to the Holland Tunnel.

This wasn't grandstanding, but the recognition of a deep and genuine tie between Wray and the building that helped make her famous.

title: Horses, of Course
description: Books on horses fall into two camps. One type, with glossy photos of galloping thoroughbreds against majestic backdrops, is geared toward riders enamored of the creatures. Another category is meant for riders for whom the honeymoon is over, who are ready to move onto more practical matters, like what to pack for trail rides. ''Horsing Around in New Jersey: The Horse Lover's Guide to Everything Equine'' (Rutgers, $19.95) is the latter.

title: Key Biscayne Makes Way For Even More Affluence

The new home, built for a local orthodontist in an ''Old World Mediterranean'' style, will have 6,500 square feet of living space and a third-floor observation deck looking toward Biscayne Bay and the Miami skyline.

title: Page Two: Aug. 8-14; STRINGS ATTACHED

Federal officials said that was the only way to ensure the money goes to illegal immigrants. But Hispanic civil rights groups said the prospect of such interrogation would deter undocumented immigrants from seeking care. Robert Pear

title: By Lang And Sirk, En Route
description: FAMILIAR to most Americans in its musical version, ''Carousel,'' Ferenc Molnar's Hungarian play ''Liliom'' has been filmed half a dozen times -- but never more effectively than by Fritz Lang in 1934. This neglected masterwork, which Lang directed during a Paris stopover on his way from Nazi Germany to Hollywood, has at last been released on DVD by Kino on Video, and though the transfer is not ideal (it appears to be from a tape source rather than a film print), it's a crucial addition to any cinephile's library.

Afternoons, they come out in greater numbers and for longer spells, cultivating plants, draping laundry and gazing down at the children playing volleyball or stickball.

title: Sacrifice of Another Lifts Thorpe to Gold
description: ATHENS, Aug. 14 - When Craig Stevens of Australia withdrew from the men's 400-meter freestyle event at the Olympics, he said he wanted to watch a riveting duel between his teammates Grant Hackett and Ian Thorpe, the world-record holder, who took Stevens's place. On Saturday at the Olympic Aquatic Center, Stevens got his wish.

title: Hospitals in Crisis
description: Westchester Medical Center has hemorrhaged millions of dollars since spinning free of county control in 1998: $32 million this year and $43 million last year. An outside management firm has been working to stabilize things while a cluster of worried public officials, including County Executive Andrew Spano and William Ryan, chairman of the Board of Legislators, pace the waiting room and keep a wary eye on the county's bond rating. (The hospital is independent, but the county backs its debt.)

title: How Donated Dollars Turn Into Pennies
description: RAISING money for the children of slain police officers has proved a costly proposition for the International Narcotic Enforcement Officers Association. Since 1997, this nonprofit group, based in Albany, has used a professional fund-raising company that hits the phones to seek donations on its behalf. Its 2002 drive seemed a success, raising over $428,000. But that was before the fund-raiser's cut. The association's final take was a little over $57,000, just 13 percent of the total.

title: Storm's Economic Impact Could Surpass $20 Billion
description: Damage inflicted by Hurricane Charley as it ripped across the midsection of Florida on Friday and early yesterday could exceed $20 billion, making it one of the most costly storms in history, economic analysts said.

title: Believing Is Seeing: Faith in All Its Permutations
description: Anyone who loves the lyrics of Tom Lehrer, Ira Gershwin and Gilbert and Sullivan will revel in the rhymes created by Michael Holland in this musical-comedy adaptation of Adrien Royce's stage play "Everything That Happens in the Woods Is Real.'' Set in 1980 in a Hollywood editing suite, a vitamin shop, a ranch in the Shasta Mountains of California and other locations, this show tells the story of Nicolai (H. Clark Kee), whose life's work is proving the existence of the Bigfoot species, and Arlene (Christina Norrup), a lonely television writer who gets roped into writing a documentary about him, when she would rather make a film about the ravages of the IUD.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZAHN, HILDA
description: ZAHN--Hilda. Of Great Neck, NY, died peacefully at home August 13 after a long and courageous battle with ovarian cancer. Survived by her loving husband of 56 years, Leonard; daughters Claudia Zahn of Seattle (and Manhattan) and Dr. Laura Rosenthal, Malibu, CA; son-in-law Walter Rosenthal and beloved grandsons Joe and Will Rosenthal; sister Charlotte Sackrin (Jerry), and sister-inlaw Harriet Guyer. Hilda was a former Democratic Party Committeewoman, an honor graduate of Queens College and loved her work as a docent at the Nassau County Museum of Art. Funeral at 11 AM, Monday, August 16, Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck (opp. LIRR). The family will sit shiva Monday and Tuesday.

title: A Plan for the High Line
description: Nature -- apart from the human kind -- rarely gets a chance to reclaim Manhattan. But nature has done just that on the High Line, the derelict railroad track that runs from the Javits Convention Center to Gansevoort Street above the far West Side. The High Line was finished in 1934 and abandoned in 1980. What was once a stark industrial corridor, a relic of the Depression, began to seed itself with grasses and wildflowers, as if it were the site of a novel experiment in island biogeography.

title: Cue the Pop Ballad, Warn the Critics

Along comes Frank Wildhorn, the Broadway composer responsible for such lavish spectacles as ''Jekyll & Hyde'' and ''The Scarlet Pimpernel,'' and he's looking to adapt your book. What can you do as Mr. Wildhorn thrashes through the Signet Classics on the way toward your work? In the public domain, no one can hear you scream.

description: Long Island Bus has agreed to continue operating three routes on the South Shore that serve Bishop Kellenberg Memorial High School in Uniondale after a code of conduct was drawn up for students riding the buses. Long Island Bus, which is part of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, had said that it was discontinuing service after Kellenberg students vandalized a bus in June.

title: Shouting in Color
description: After a divine visitation in her kitchen in 1934, Gertrude Morgan, then 34, left her family in Georgia; eventually she arrived in New Orleans, where she sang and preached the Gospel in the streets. Some two decades and several revelations later, she was instructed to become the bride of Christ and to add the making of art to her activities in the service of the Lord. The image of the black missionary dressed in bridal white (a uniform that she wore every day until her death at 80) and holding hands with Jesus recurs in Morgan's inspired paintings, blending biblical stories and autobiography. In TOOLS OF HER MINISTRY: The Art of Sister Gertrude Morgan (American Folk Art Museum/Rizzoli, $35), the art historian William A. Fagaly, who knew Morgan personally, gives a terrific portrait of this self-taught artist, who looks to us both endearing and egotistical, a bit spooky and as loud and commanding as her art. With no more than a third-grade education, Morgan achieved considerable fame in her lifetime for her paintings -- which she used as teaching aids and advertisements for her ministry -- thanks both to her fanatical drive and the efforts of an art dealer, Larry Borenstein, who discovered her shouting through her paper megaphone on a street corner around 1960 and invited her to perform and show her work at his gallery in the French Quarter. Of her miraculous talents, Morgan said: ''Just be sure and give Jesus credit for what I do. . . . He's the one that made me do it.'' Hilarie M. Sheets

title: Susanna Clarke's Magic Book
description: It is impossible to read Susanna Clarke's ''Jonathan Strange & Mr. Norrell,'' as I have, without thinking of Neil Gaiman (John Hodgman, Aug. 1). It isn't just Clarke's easy handling of a subject matter that the multihonored Gaiman seems to own. Her narrative voice echoes with his as well. Yet Clarke's book is far more than imitative fan indulgence. Frankly, I haven't read anything as deliciously entertaining in a very long time. Maybe ever. For the first hundred pages I was thinking of Gaiman. For the next 675, I could only wonder, Who in the world is this woman, and how has she managed to compose such a marvelous first novel? Thanks for answering the question.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLIKEN, JOHN F.
description: MILLIKEN--John F. The Board of Directors, volunteers, and staff of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society express deep sorrow on the passing of John F. Milliken, who died August 6 at the age of 84. Mr. Milliken's 50 years of service with the National MS Society began with the Chicago Chapter, where he served on its Board of Trustees from 1954 to 1980. In 1980 he became a Trustee of the Maine Chapter. He was elected to the Society's National Board of Directors in 1973, and in 1996 was named an Honorary Life Director. Mr. Milliken had a long career as an insurance executive, and was Vice President of Alexander & Alexander, Inc. in Chicago. He is survived by his wife; their children, Amelia Rowell, Alida Zimmerman, John Jr, MD, Mark and Scott; 14 grandchildren; and one greatgrandchild. Mr. Milliken's commitment and dedication to the MS cause will be truly missed, and we extend our sincere sympathy to his entire family. Donations may be made in his memory to the National MS Society. Edward A. Kangas Chairman of the Board Mike Dugan President and CEO

title: Dusty's Latest Daughter
description: A GIRL CALLED EDDY -- There's a tradition of white women carving out devastatingly lonely and soulful variations on pop singing; it seems as if half of them are English and the other half avowed Anglophiles. They have in common a respect for the sensual end of disappointment and resignation, for the erotic implications of the stiff upper lip. Dusty Springfield presides over them all; Chrissie Hynde, Beth Gibbons, Tracey Thorne, Aimee Mann and Beth Orton are her descendants; and the newest is Erin Moran, who performs as A Girl Called Eddy. (She's not to be confused with the actress from the old ''Happy Days'' series.) Ms. Moran comes from Neptune, N.J., and recorded ''A Girl Called Eddy'' (Anti-), her first full-length album, in England, produced by Richard Hawley of the band Pulp. The record includes 11 slow reveries about being glad to be unhappy, with a big, elegant sound and a songwriting aesthetic somewhere between Carole King and Portishead.

title: Mouthfuls
description: There are a couple of good reasons for knowing the word huitlacoche. The first is social. It can be embarrassing trying to say it for the first time in front of a waiter and a tableful of diners. The second reason is pure self-defense. Huitlacoche (pronounced wheat-luh-COACH-ay, with a long ''a'' at the end, like ''bay'') is, in fact, a fungus that grows on corn. Sometimes translated as ''corn smut,'' it ranks as a delicacy in Mexico, where cooks use it to impart a rich, mushroomy flavor to food.

In Lasse Hallstrom's sweet, sensitive comedy MY LIFE AS A DOG (1985), set in 1950's Sweden, Ingemar (Anton Glanzelius) is sent away to the country because his mother is dying of tuberculosis. Staying with his uncle, the boy meets lots of eccentric characters and learns that one way to repress difficult emotions is to bark instead of speaking. This was the year's best foreign-language film, according to the New York Film Critics Circle, the Independent Spirit Awards and the Golden Globes -- Monday at 10:15 a.m and 4 p.m., Friday at 4 p.m. and Saturday at 11:30 a.m. on IFC.

title: Saying No to Turkey
description: Having failed to persuade Europe's leaders to enshrine Christianity in the final draft of the constitution of the European Union, the Vatican has found a new way to try to conflate European and Christian identity. The Holy See would like to block Turkey's candidacy to the European Union. In an interview last week with Le Figaro magazine, the Catholic Church's top theologian, Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, said that Turkey, a predominantly Muslim secular republic of 70 million people, is ''in permanent contrast to Europe'' and that linking it to Europe would be a mistake. To drive home his point about Turkey's disqualifying otherness, he cited the Ottoman Empire's incursions into the heart of Europe in centuries past.

The use of political handlers tends to provide voters with a one-dimensional picture of the candidate, not unlike the handlers at the dog show: although it may look like a superb specimen, can it really hunt?

The poll gave Mr. Kerry, the Democratic presidential nominee, a double-digit lead on issues including the war in Iraq, which was the respondents' top concern. In the combined category of terrorism and security, the gap narrowed, with Mr. Kerry leading Mr. Bush by only four points. By a margin of more than 2 to 1, voters also said that Mr. Bush had divided the nation he pledged to unite. The poll, conducted after the Democratic National Convention, surveyed 624 registered voters around the state. Jessica Bruder

title: 'The Candidate'
description: The S-3B Viking jet descended from the cobalt-blue sky at somewhere between 125 and 150 miles per hour and approached the flight deck of the USS Abraham Lincoln. On its way home to Everett, Washington, after an almost ten-month-long tour of duty as part of the operations in Iraq, the aircraft carrier was positioned in the Pacific Ocean thirty miles off the coast of California near San Diego. The pilot of the snub-nosed, 53-foot-long four-seater, Commander John Lussier-a "mature" flyer, to quote a navy colleague-was known for his smooth landings. Carefully, Lussier guided the jet in its descent until it touched down, still zooming ahead at full speed, onto the flight deck, catching its tailhook on a metal cable stretched across the deck and coming to a dead stop so abruptly that it produced a g-force twice that of gravity. The local time at touchdown was 12:16 p.m. The date was May 1, 2003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BABSON, JAMES ARTHUR
description: BABSON--James Arthur. 84, of Wilmette, IL, died on Sunday August 8, 2004. Beloved husband of Jean for sixty years. Father of Nicholas (Mary), Stephen (Nancy), Cindy (Troy) Gustafson, Henry (Leslie) and Jean Drummond. Grandfather of Aric, Blake and Derek Babson, Ayla and Zach Gustafson, and Alexei, Tessa, David and Jennifer Drummond. Jim was a graduate of Deerfield Academy, attended the University of Pennsylvania, and in 1944 received his degree from the United States Merchant Marine Academy, as well as his commission as Ensign in the United States Navy. During the war, he served in both the Atlantic and Pacific Theaters. Jim, as an entrepreneur, designed and managed the first seaside motel in the New England area in 1951; with his wife, Jean, established ''The Sentry Post,'' a specialty gift shop in Winnetka, IL, and served as vice president of Babson Bros. Co., and President of G. Babson Farms. His life-long commitment and generous support for the United State Merchant Marine Academy was honored in 2004 by his election to the USMMA Hall of Distinguished Graduates. Jim was an avid collector of vintage toys, lead soldiers and antique trains, which he donated to the Chicago Historical Society. He was also a member of the New York Yacht Club of New York and the Indian Hill Club of Winnetka. Services and interment private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The USMMA Foundation Fund, Babson Center, USMMA, Kings Point, NY 11024-1699. For further information contact Wm. H. Scott Funeral Home: 847-251-8200,

title: Decarcerate?
description: If a time traveler from the future showed up in our world today, which of our practices would strike him as most barbarous? This question makes for an excellent parlor game. When we look back at supposedly civilized societies in the past, we are amazed at how complacently they accepted such obvious evils as slavery, child labor and torture. Surely, people in centuries hence will be similarly astonished at our own moral blind spots. But what might they be? After a little reflection, you may wish to hazard a guess. Here's mine: punishment by imprisonment.

description: GUTMACHER--Nat, 88, on August 5, 2004 in Orlando, FL beloved husband of Ruth, father of Jon, Karen and Glenn; grandfather of four boys; friend and colleague to many, also leaves two dear siblings, Ida and Harris (Skee). Growing up in Coney Island, Nat enjoyed a fulfilling business career, mainly in the garment industry. He coowned Shackamaxon Golf & Country Club, Scotch Plains, NJ (1954-57) but lived 51 years there. Following often-decorated service for USAF pilot missions against Germany during WWII, he spent his last career years working with Skee and late brother Marty in the family garment business, Marty Gutmacher Inc. In retirement, Nat enjoyed golf, skiing, managing family investments, using PCs since 1982, coordinating the annual family reunion for his last 15 years--his mind sharp until the end. In lieu of flowers, donate to your favorite charity or Jewish Federation of Central NJ (www.jfedcnj.org). Donation acknowledge ments: Gutmacher, 14834 Oldham Dr., Orlando, FL. 32826. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREEN, STANLEY JOSEPH, PH.D.
description: GREEN -- Stanley Joseph, Ph.D. In profound sorrow we mourn the loss of husband, father and grandfather who died on August 10, 2004 at age 84 in Palo Alto, CA. Devoted husband of Alice (Denenholz). Beloved father of David, Douglas and Ronald. Grandfather of Andrew, Joshua, Ashley, Matthew and Kevin. He was Director of the Steam Generator Project Office, Nuclear Power Division, at the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) in Palo Alto, CA which he retired from in 1991. From 1954 to 1977 he worked at the Bettis Atomic Power Laboratory of Westinghouse Electric Corporation. Dr. Green worked on the Manhattan Project during WWII. His work in the area of heat transfer advanced the applied technology for steam generators in nuclear power plants. Though he was a wellknown authority in the heat transfer field, he will be most remembered by his family and friends for his integrity, ethics and quest for knowledge. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSS, LOIS
description: ROSS--Lois. A resident of Westport, CT for over 18 years, died peacefully in her sleep at her home on August 10, 2004, after a long and difficult struggle with lupus. She was 62 years of age. A former spokesperson for Kodak in their National Campaign on Family Portrait Photography during the mid 1980's, her family became the ''Kodak Family'' appearing in publicity photos taken at Ca d'Zan, the John and Mabel Ringling Winter Residence on Sarasota Bay in Sarasota, FL. by the internationally acclaimed photographer Christopher Der Mannuelian, of San Mateo. Her career began in fashion modeling in the 1970's and grew into fashion consulting, staging many fashion events for Neiman Marcus, Macy's, Bloomingdales, Saks Fifth Avenue, J C Penney and Filene's, locally, and from Washington DC to Boston. Ultimately she produced major fashion events for the Stamford Town Center amphitheater in Stamford, CT. During this period she appeared in numerous tv commercials, print ads and billboards for major US companies, from AT&T, Pepsi and Charmin, a member of SAG and AFTRA, and was a very busy hand model for major products, as well. She completed her undergraduate studies at Syracuse University, Finch College and Columbia University as an art history major. She leaves behind Arthur, her beloved husband of 44 years, three adult children, Cheri Sarner of Jupiter, FL, Robert Ross of Darien, CT and Steven Ross of Sterling, VA, as well as five beloved grandchildren, Harrison and Arden Sarner, and Morgan, Madeleine and Meridith Ross. She was the daughter of the late Seymour and Syde Goldberg of Purchase, NY and Palm Beach, FL, and is survived by her step-mother, Bella Goldberg of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Services were held on Friday, August 13, 2004 at Riverside Memorial Chapel at noon at 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY (914-664-6800). Burial services will follow at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. Lois will be sorely missed by her friends and family. In lieu of flowers please make a memorial donation in memory of Lois Ross to the Lupus Foundation of America, Inc., 2000 L Street, NW Suite 710, Washington, DC 20036.

Twenty-one guests at an outdoor party near mosquito-thick marshes in upstate New York were well spritzed one humid evening in late July. Seven hours later, they found no bites.

Mr. Chavez, though, seems to have the upper hand. Awash in petrodollars, Venezuela's government has been on a spending spree. Education and agricultural programs are expanding. The impact has been swift. Struggling with 30 percent support last year, Mr. Chavez now has the backing of about 50 percent of Venezuelans. The big question is will the opposition attract the 20 to 30 percent of Venezuelans who are undecided, obtaining the 3.76 million yes votes needed for recall. Juan Forero

title: Wearable Ads, From Comics Past

Designed for men and women, the cotton shirts are silk-screened with eerily familiar graphics and slogans for products like X-Ray Vision Specs, the Whoopee Cushion and the Fear No Man Kung-Fu Karate chart. The company is named for the former Scam-Co novelty store, founded 60 years ago in Times Square by Alfred and Leon Scaminovitz, brothers who gave the world many of these novelty items, and the word scam. The shirts, which are machine-washable, are sold at www.shopstylecouncil.com and cost $42 to $78.

title: Summer Reverie

But the evenings were the best times, sitting by the campfire with my mother and father and older brother watching the flames of the fire reduce the thick logs of firewood to smoldering chunks of flickering embers.

title: TRUMP IN BANKRUPTCY
description: Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts shareholders approved a bankruptcy reorganization last week that would reduce the company's debt as well as Donald J. Trump's stake in the company. If approved by a judge, the plan will cut the debt to about $1.25 billion, from nearly $1.8 billion, with infusions of money from Credit Suisse First Boston and Mr. Trump himself. Mr. Trump, who will step down as chief executive but remain as chairman, will have to come up with $55 million in cash and $15.9 million in Trump Casino Holdings notes to keep a 25 percent interest in the company, down from 56 percent. Credit Suisse will own about two-thirds of the company. Mr. Trump will also give up licensing rights to his name and likeness, but they will still be used to promote the company's casino-hotels in Atlantic City: Trump Plaza, Trump Marina and Trump Taj Mahal. The reorganization is expected to be complete by March. Robert Strauss

title: A Summer Poncho With Cardigan Envy
description: For summer nights -- (and autumn days) that require a bit more warmth than a crocheted poncho can provide, Sonya Madden has designed a chic and useful alternative. Made from lightweight cashmere in a spectrum of sorbet colors, the Cardi-Wrap ($345 at Henri Bendel) has the back and long sleeves of a traditional cardigan. In place of closures on the front, though, it has two rectangular lengths of fabric that can be draped, swung, slung or tied in a variety of ways. (Like an Herms scarf, it comes with a little booklet demonstrating the possibilities.) On a crisp but not-too-cold evening, the wrap looks best unwrapped, hanging loose over a slim pair of jeans or a bare halter dress. And in a drafty movie theater, it can be taken off and stretched out to make a very nice blanket for two.

title: Sharon's Wars
description: At the point where the twisting road from Jerusalem leaves the hills and straightens out on Israel's coastal plain, you turn south at Latrun junction for the drive to Ariel Sharon's ranch. On a rise to your left, set in olive groves, is the red-roofed Trappist monastery of Latrun. It has always been something of a surprise to me how lightly Israel's landscape, if not its people, wears its heavy past. From a car rushing along this modern highway, the only clue to the centuries of violence that envelop the Latrun hill is a limestone ruin on the crest, above the monastery. It is the remnant of a 12th-century Crusader fort. From that height, Christian soldiers, like the Romans long before them and the Arab Legion long after, controlled the routes from the Mediterranean coast and from Egypt to Jerusalem.

title: 1954:Loudest Town Crier : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: HASTINGS, England: An ancient ceremony was revived in this English town yesterday [Aug. 14] and you could hear the revival for miles. Twenty-two of the biggest-lunged men in Britain sucked in their breaths and let go with all they had in the annual National Town Criers' championship. For the sixth year in a row and for the seventh time in his life Ben Johnson, a Cornishman, outyelled them all. Mr. Johnson and his competitors all opened their performances with the traditional town criers' attention-getter: "Oyez! Oyez! Oyez!" Then he let go a spiel which involved some loud bits of news and a few announcements. The bellowing was much better than Bill Cruttenden, of Hastings, could put out and the local crier took second place. Each crier wore his costume of office. It usually started off with a three-cornered hat, wig, lace collar, velvet coat, waistcoat, knickers, tight socks and silver-buckled shoes. Everyone had a big bell and clanged away to draw attention. They performed in front of William the Conqueror's castle, which was built soon after the Battle of Hastings in 1066.
