title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENICK, NITA H.
description: HENICK--Nita H. 79, died on August 14 after a courageous six year fight against cancer. ''It was a second honeymoon,'' said her beloved husband of 55 years, William, referring to the nonstop schedule of family visits, world travel, the theater, the opera and visits with friends. She will be greatly missed by her children, Daniel (Rita), Arthur (Sharon Cromwell), and Susan (Jack Bellis) and by her grandchildren, Maggie, Adam, Ian, Jessica and Kira. She is also survived by her sister, Dr. Ruth Lebovitz and her nephews, Richard and Roger Lebovitz. Nita was dedicated to her family and to her profession. She was a social work supervisor at the Coler - Goldwater Hospital Complex for over 25 years. She served on the long-term care panel for the Health Systems Agency, the federal overseer for NY hospitals, and on the board of the NYC Health and Hospitals Corporation, its successor organization. In addition, she served the NYC Chapter of the National Association of Social Workers in many capacities and served as its president for two years. In all her endeavors, Nita showed uncommon zestful energy, expertise, and determination. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of the donor's choice. Services will be held on Monday, August 16 at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills at 12 noon. Shiva will be observed at 2110 33rd Road, Long Island City on Tuesday, August 17 and Wednesday, August 18.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLY, GEORGE A. MSGR.
description: KELLY--George A. Msgr. In an age of 'the Ordinary' how refreshing it became for many of us to meet 'the Extraordinary.' Such was the dynamic priest, George Kelly. Not unlike his own mentor, John Monahan, he found himself in his younger days on the front lines of the struggling labor union movement. Soon thereafter, he graduated to confront the siege situation of the American family by launching the National Catholic Family Movement. In his final chapter, no less colorful than earlier ones, he entered the fray battling for the minds of a nation's young on the blackboards of America's Catholic Universities by awakening leadership to the treasury of learning in Aquinas and the tenets of Catholic Scholarship! He founded the Fellowship of Catholic Scholars. The landscape of our lives is measurably diminished! Heaven favor his journey home! William B. O'Brien

description: Half a century ago only a handful of enthusiasts could watch the action at a bridge table. Today, thanks to the miracle of the Internet, thousands around the world can observe some of the play at an international event. This was true of the European Championships in Malmo, Sweden, this summer, on the spot and in other countries. On the diagramed deal from a match between Sweden and Israel, neither the players nor the commentators spotted a subtle possibility. It was left to a Canadian expert, Bryan Maksymetz, to point it out after watching from a seat in the Vugraph theater.

title: Oil Prices Retreat From a Record High After Chvez Victory
description: PARIS, Aug. 16  Oil prices retreated from a record high today after President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela claimed victory in a recall election, easing concerns about possible disruptions in the country's oil exports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAKSS, ROSE LUDMER
description: DAKSS--Rose Ludmer. We note with great saddness the passing of Rose Ludmer Dakss on August 14, 2004. In her 94 years, she enriched the lives of everyone who knew her. A unique woman and a life long learner, she received her Bachelor of Arts in 1930 and her Master of Science in Education in 1965. As a devoted kindergarten teacher for 25 years, she recognized the inherent goodness in all children. Her roles as wife, mother, grandmother and great grandmother were characterized by unconditional love and enormous generosity. She danced through life and she will be greatly missed. Donations may be made to the Rose L. Dakss Early Childhood Education Fund at Montclair State University, Department of Curriculum and Teaching, College of Education and Human Resources, Normal Avenue, Montclair NJ 07043. The graveside service will be held on Wednesday, August 18 at 1:30 PM at Beth Moses Cemetery in Farmingdale NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENE, LOUISE
description: GREENE--Louise. Died August 15 after a long illness. Beloved wife of Arthur, loving mother of Michael and Sheila, grandmother of Julia, Daniel and Melissa. Loving aunt, loyal friend and retired teacher. She gave freely to all who knew her and will be deeply missed. Services Tuesday, August 17, 11:15 A.M. at ''Sinai Chapels,'' Fresh Meadows, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Columbia University ALS Gift Fund.

title: Looking For Bigfoot And Other Lost Souls
description: The New York International Fringe Festival opened over the weekend with its characteristic mix of inventiveness, talent and eccentricity. The more than 200 theatrical companies that perform through Aug. 29 range from the inspired to the dreadful. Below are reviews of shows at both extremes. A complete listing of performance schedules and locations is at www.fringenyc.org, or available by calling (212)279-4488 in New York or (888)FringeNYC out of town.

Chapel services at Schwartz Bros. Forest Park Chapel, Queens Boulevard, 12 noon on Monday, August 16. We will forever miss her love and laughter.

Also survived by ten grandchildren, three greatgrandchildren. A woman of great wisdom and strength who made everyone in her large circle of family and friends feel special and loved. title: A Cellist Who Enjoys Taking Chances
description: It used to be that soloists would blow through the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center like a brisk but evanescent breeze, sometimes two or more in a single program, leaving behind little distinct impression. Now the festival's stepped-up evolution has brought miniresidencies involving late-night performances as well as regular concert appearances.

description: With Palestinian politics in an extraordinary ferment, Yasir Arafat has survived the latest challenge to his authority from a younger generation of frustrated politicians, outmaneuvering an American favorite, Muhammad Dahlan, 42, a former security chief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARLIS, HARRY ROBERT, M.D.
description: ARLIS--Harry Robert, M.D. Craniofacial plastic surgeon, on August 13, 2004. Born in Manhattan and raised in Bayside, Queens, received his undergraduate degree at Yale University followed by medical school at Cornell Medical College. He received his postgraduate training at Beth Israel Hospital, MA, and Manhattan Eye and Ear, NY. He completed his craniofacial fellowship at Washington University, St. Louis. He continued his career at NY Hospital/Cornell Medical Center where he dedicated his life to mastering new techniques in craniofacial surgery and improving the lives of his patients, especially children. Beloved son of Anthony and Chrissie Arlis, Port Washington, NY. Cherished brother of Stephanie and Rowland Mayor, Guilford, CT. Loving uncle to Michael, Santhi and Athena. Adored nephew of Athena Peters and Theodora Periheros. He was truly loved and will be missed by many. Visitation at Fairchild Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, NY, Monday evening. Funeral services Tuesday 9:30 AM, Archangel Michael Greek Orthodox Church, 108 Warner Avenue, Roslyn Heights, NY.

title: George Yardley, 75, Shooter Who Broke N.B.A. Record
description: George Yardley, a Hall of Fame forward who was the first National Basketball Association player to score 2,000 points in a season, died Thursday at his home in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 75.

title: Student Chic Is Remaking Itself, Trading Grunge for Cable Knit
description: Last year, Benjamin Spoer, a college sophomore in Berkeley, Calif., was just another grungy teenager, with his long hair, dirty jeans and favorite black T-shirt with a gory red bird on the front. Now he is transformed. He has cut his hair, and in a couple of weeks, he plans to go shopping for some blue button-down shirts.

title: Land of Cheap Retirement Becomes a Broken Paradise For the Most Brittle Victims
description: Donalyne Poudrier loved her big screened porch at Palmetto Mobile Home Park, but you would not have caught her lounging there often, even at 83.

title: Security a Selling Point for 2012
description: Each of the five cities bidding for the 2012 Summer Olympics promoted its transportation system, green space and readiness to upgrade sports facilities Sunday. But, in a sign of the times, the real subtext of their pitches was the security infrastructure.

title: Command Performance
description: Golden Commander overtook Irish Colonial in the deep stretch, then held off the late-closing Foreverness by a half-length to win the West Point Stakes for New York-breds at Saratoga Race Course yesterday.

title: Outside Iraq, an Iraqi Reason to Believe
description: The Iraqi men's soccer team continued its unlikely run in the Olympics when it beat Costa Rica, 2-0, on Sunday night to make the quarterfinals with one round of qualifying matches left.

description: I DIDN'T need to see Puerto Rico rout the United States to know that the world is playing great basketball; didn't need to see the United States shoot 35 percent to know that the team we've sent to the Olympics has no outside shooter, and maybe only an outside shot at the gold medal.

description: LEWIS -- Evelyn Frances. Mother of Kenneth Lewis Lowenstein and Lewis Frank Schlossinger. Was the oldest surviving relative of Commodore Uriah P. Levy who owned Monticello, which remained in the family for 75 years. A member of the DAR.

title: Bush Makes a Final Swing Before Convention
description: After a five-day cross-country campaign swing and a visit to hurricane-damaged Florida, President Bush will concentrate on the Midwest battleground states in a series of trips that begins today.

title: For Bronx Land With Spotty Past, No Lack of Plans
description: For more than a decade, only poplar trees have grown between the stacked cinder blocks and rusted sheet metal on a 28-acre tract in the South Bronx. But suddenly the Oak Point garbage dump on the East River, abandoned in 1990 under a tangle of lawsuits, talk of mob ties and $60 million in debt, is sprouting with plans. The city wants to put jails there. The community hopes for an industrial recycling facility.

title: Honk if You Love to Sing Bumper Stickers; Israeli Author Turns Slogans Into Rap Hit
description: Several days after Yitzhak Rabin was murdered in 1995 by an assassin opposed to the peace process, the Israeli author David Grossman was driving through a forest preserve just outside this city. He noticed a car stopped on the shoulder of the road and slowed to see what might be the matter. The motorist, he saw, was scraping off a bumper sticker that said, ''Rabin Rotzeach'' (''Rabin is a Murderer'').

title: Rape of Girl on Rooftop Leaves Residents Scared, Not Surprised
description: From its broken front door to the stairwell leading to its desolate, trash-strewn roof, there was already enough about the Wise Towers housing project on the Upper West Side to keep its residents fearful and on edge. A woman on the 11th floor had been tied up and killed four years ago. Strangers roamed the halls. Doors blew open and shut in the wind.

title: FLORIDA ASSESSES DAMAGE IN WAKE OF DEADLY STORM
description: Two days after Hurricane Charley tore across the state, the death toll was inching up, but far slower than officials had feared and tens of thousands of people who were left homeless by one of the worst storms ever to hit Florida were pondering their next step.

title: Treasury Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week include today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: As a Business Gets Bigger, Its Radios Get Smaller
description: With fee-based satellite radio gaining a foothold in the United States, the two companies that offer the service are hoping to expand their customer base by selling smaller after-market receivers with a range of new capabilities.

title: Ex-Aide Tells Israeli Paper Of a Relentless McGreevey
description: Golan Cipel, the political appointee said to have had an affair with Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey, was quoted in an Israeli newspaper as saying that he is heterosexual. He portrayed himself as a victim of unwanted advances by the governor.

title: Fighting the Next War
description: ''The United States has reached a dead end in Iraq, like a trapped wolf,'' Ayatollah Ali Khamenei recently said at a gathering of Shiite clerics. ''It is trying to frighten people by roaring and clawing. But the people of Iraq will not allow the United States to swallow their country.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FIELDS, FRED F.
description: FIELDS -- Fred F. Berlin, Shanghai, Lake Success, NY, Hallandale, FL, died peacefully August 14, 2004. Beloved husband of Yvette (Simon). Adored father of Norman, Peter and Barbara. Cherished Opa of Daniel and Nina.

description: The American women bounded into the Summer Games as gymnastics world champions to envy, with the label as favorites, a Karolyi to guide them and charmed ability.

title: A Farewell to Phish
description: Phish made its farewell in Vermont over the weekend in true Phish style: playing its own musical marathon, swarmed by adoring fans and isolated from the rest of the world.

title: A Packed Day in Swimming
description: Ian Thorpe held off Pieter van den Hoogenband and Michael Phelps to win the men's 200-meter freestyle on Monday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Economic Growth Slows
description: Indonesia's economy slowed in the second quarter, expanding 4.3 percent compared with the period a year earlier after growing 5 percent in the previous three-month period. Growth in consumer spending, a crucial component of economic growth, slowed to 5.3 percent from 5.7 percent in the first quarter despite record-low interest rates. Economists said the evidence that growth was slowing would put pressure on the country's central bank not to raise rates despite signs that inflation might be rising. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: And the Band Played Scared
description: As a teenage drummer with dreams of rock stardom, nothing could fuel my ambition like an outdoor summer concert. A warm breeze, the smell of grass, and clouds sailing through dusk into darkness made for the best stage I could imagine.

description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILOSZ, CZESLAW
description: MILOSZ--Czeslaw. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be mourned by the world of literature.

title: Behavior May Cost Protesters 'Privileges,' Bloomberg Says
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg told a group of volunteers who plan to toil at the Republican National Convention yesterday that he expected most protesters who come to the event later this month would ''be reasonable,'' but he warned that ''if we start to abuse our privileges, then we lose them.''

title: Conflict Erupts on Effort to Identify Travelers
description: A leading Democratic lawmaker said on Monday that a multibillion-dollar effort to better protect the nation's borders from terrorists had so far been ''a striking failure,'' but Bush administration officials defended the ambitious project.

title: CALPINE TO SELL CANADIAN ASSETS TO PRIMEWEST ENERGY
description: The Calpine Corporation, owner of power plants in 20 states, agreed to sell its Canadian natural-gas reserves and petroleum assets to the PrimeWest Energy Trust for 825 million Canadian dollars ($631 million) to raise cash to pay debts. The sale includes the equivalent of about 221 billion cubic feet of proven gas reserves that produce about 61 million cubic feet a day, Calpine said. It also included Calpine Natural Gas Trust's 25 percent interest in the equivalent of about 80 billion cubic feet of proven reserves. Calpine is selling assets to reduce debt that has almost quadrupled since 2000 to about $18.1 billion.

title: 'Pataki Pass' Is Hot Item For Delegates
description: It is the MetroCard for the movers, shakers and hobnobbers at the Republican National Convention, giving the bearers entree not to the IRT or the BMT but to parties at Tavern on the Green and the Copa, among others.

title: C.I.A. Officer Denounces Agency and Sept. 11 Report
description: A senior officer for the Central Intelligence Agency who led the unit that tracked Osama bin Laden has written a blistering letter to the Sept. 11 commission, attacking both the C.I.A. and the commission itself over what he sees as a failure to punish ''bureaucratic cowards'' in the intelligence agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHN, MILDRED E. (ELIAS)
description: COHN--Mildred E. (Elias) of Woburn, MA. August 15, 2004. Devoted wife of the late Richard. Loving mother of William of Detroit, MI and Kenneth of Arlington, MA. Sister of Doris E. Brown of Fort Lauderdale, FL. Grandmother of Andrew, Matthew, Dylan, Benjamin, Lincoln, and Max. Beloved aunt to Clifford, Jim, Thomas and Deborah. For funeral service information please contact Kenneth Cohn. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Mildred may be made to the American Cancer Society, 30 Speen Street, Framingham, MA 01701. For more information contact Keefe Funeral Home, 781-648-5544.

title: For One Coach, Chivas Is Inviting
description: The entry of Chivas USA into Major League Soccer next season has been hailed and belittled. Don Garber, the M.L.S. commissioner, believes his ''new soccer nation'' must appeal to the vast Hispanic population of the United States. Detractors worry that the Chivas team, which will play in Los Angeles, will be composed of only players with Hispanic backgrounds. The reality is probably somewhere in the middle. The team has two players (both from Chivas in Guadalajara, Mexico) and no coach.

title: Study Finds Climate Shift Threatens California
description: A scientific study released on Monday presents an alarming view of climate changes in California, finding that by the end of the century rising temperatures could lead to a sevenfold increase in heat-related deaths in Los Angeles and imperil the state's wine and dairy industries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIERREPONT, NANCY
description: PIERREPONT--Nancy. The lyricism of your interiors inspired kindness in our conversations and brought to our hearts, joy. Francis X. Morrissey, Jr.

title: Iraqi Conferees Decide to Send a Delegation to Embattled Holy City
description: As fighting between American forces and Shiite militiamen flared again in the southern city of Najaf, a conference of Iraqis gathering here to form a national assembly decided on Monday to send a delegation to the city.

title: Safety Gap Grows Wider Between S.U.V.'s and Cars
description: The gap in safety between sport utility vehicles and passenger cars last year was the widest yet recorded, according to new federal traffic data.

title: U.S. Wins First Fencing Gold Since 1904
description: ATHENS, Aug. 17  As the American fencer Mariel Zagunis yelled in triumph, her teammates rushed her and hurled her into the air. What made their celebratory gesture especially notable was that Zagunis was still holding, and waving, her sword.

title: US Air to Seek 5-Year Extension for Pension Fund Payments
description: US Airways, facing a cash shortage as it tries to avoid another bankruptcy filing, said yesterday that it would seek government permission to stretch out $67.5 million in contributions it owes to the pensions of its mechanics and flight attendants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, ALAN N.
description: COHEN--Alan N. The President and Trustees of Columbia University express deep sorrow at the passing of our esteemed alumnus Alan N. Cohen, a graduate of the Columbia College class of 1952 and the Columbia Law School class of 1954. He was a former member of the Boards of Visitors for both Columbia College and the Law School, and his leadership as a chair of the Law School's Annual Fund was marked by enthusiasm and distinction. Columbia University extends its profound sympathy to his wife, Mrs. Carol Cohen, and their family. Lee C. Bollinger, President of the University David J. Stern, Chair of the Trustees

title: Political Fallout In New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: SLAIN JOURNALIST'S FAMILY MAKES REQUEST
description: The family of Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter beheaded in Pakistan two years ago, has requested that his name not be used in a political context after Vice President Dick Cheney invoked it on Thursday in response to Senator John Kerry's pledge to fight a ''more sensitive war on terror.'' Mr. Cheney said, ''The men who beheaded Daniel Pearl and Paul Johnson will not be impressed by our sensitivity.'' Mr. Pearl's father, Judea, 67, said that the request was a general one and was not directed at Mr. Cheney in particular, and that it was intended to prevent the stoking of moderate Muslim ire. ''We don't take sides between Bush and Kerry,'' Judea Pearl said. ''I don't even know who I'm going to vote for.'' Mr. Kerry had vowed to wage ''more effective, more thoughtful, more strategic, more proactive, more sensitive war on terror that reaches out to other nations and brings them to our side.'' Mark Glassman (NYT)

title: Yukos Official Denies Talk Of Imminent Bankruptcy
description: A top Yukos executive said on Monday that the company should be able to produce and sell oil at least until the end of September.

title: Goodby, Silverstein Wins Subway Business
description: Subway Restaurants said yesterday that it had cut short a review for the creative and strategic planning duties on its account by awarding the assignments to Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $250 million to $300 million.

title: Geico Returns to New Jersey After 28 Years
description: The Geico Corporation, the auto insurer owned by Berkshire Hathaway Inc., sold policies in New Jersey yesterday for the first time in 28 years after the state stopped requiring insurers to cover all drivers.

title: Government to Take Over Watch-List Screening
description: Domestic security officials said Monday that they planned to begin screening airline passengers against a list of potential terror suspects, taking over a responsibility now carried out by the airlines.

title: 50 Years Later, Newport Swings With 'Real Jazz'
description: During its early years, starting in 1954, the Newport Jazz Festival was post-beat and pre-hippie. The music was probably at its greatest high, but its reach and status in American society and the marketplace hadn't been properly gauged. The words classic, smooth, brunch and cruise were yet to be hooked up to it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEIDENBERG, DR. BERNARD
description: SEIDENBERG--Dr. Bernard. With deep sadness we mourn the loss of our esteemed Board Member, Dr. Bernard Seidenberg. We were honored by Bernie's invaluable service to Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center and thus to the community, during a critical time in the history of the institution. He served on the Joint Conference and Compensation Committees and was a member of Boards of the Rutland Nursing Home and Holding Company, KHCF, Inc. In 2004, he received the United Hospital Fund's Trustee of the Year Award for his distinguished service to Kingsbrook. He breathed new life into Kingsbrook with his wise counsel, integrity, kindness, interest and caring for others. We extend our sincerest sympathy and kind wishes to his family. Henna White, Chairperson Board of Trustees Edward Lieberstein Chairperson RNH Board of Directors Linda Brady, MD President and CEO Kingsbrook Jewish Med. Ctr.

title: Spanish Spur Wins at Saratoga
description: A perfect trip it was not. But after being steadied in the final furlong, before being moved wide in the stretch, only to alter course back to the inside, Spanish Spur somehow split horses and drew away for a three-length victory in the inaugural running of the John's Call Stakes at Saratoga Race Course yesterday.

description: Going with experience, Hal Sutton named Jay Haas and Stewart Cink on Monday as his captain's selections for this year's United States Ryder Cup team.

description: Oil prices retreated from record highs on Monday after President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela claimed victory in a referendum on his rule, easing concerns about possible disruptions in the country's oil exports.

title: From Retirement to the Medal Stand
description: When he had no more moves to make, no more clocks to check, Jimmy Pedro Jr. collapsed into the arms of his coaches. His body sagged until he looked into the crowd and saw his father and younger brother.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Deer Park: Call To Extend Financing For 9/11 Panel
description: Representatives Timothy Bishop of Southampton and Steve Israel, left, of Huntington, both Democrats, called on Congress yesterday to extend financing for the 9/11 Commission while recommendations in the commission's final report are debated. Speaking at a news conference, they said that without Congressional intervention, money would run out on Aug. 21, and they called on Congress to reconvene immediately to consider additional financing. John Rather (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Intercontinental Cuts Ties To 2 Travel Sites
description: The InterContinental Hotels Group, the world's largest hotel operator by rooms, said it would no longer let Expedia.com and Hotels.com sell its rooms because the online travel sites, owned by InterActiveCorp, do not meet its standards. InterContinental, which is based in Windsor, England, and operates about 3,500 hotels, said yesterday that Travelocity, part of Sabre Holdings, will now be its main online travel agency. InterContinental pledged in April not to work with Web sites that do not show customers the commissions they charge and that fax bookings to hotels rather than automate their reservations. Peter Gowers, executive vice president for global brand services at InterContinental, said, ''We are taking a stand in the Wild West of the Internet world.'' He declined to give details on how Expedia did not meet the company's standards, saying, ''We weren't able to reach agreement on key terms such as customer and brand protection.''

title: Phaithful Phlock to the Phinish As the 21-Year Jam Ends in Tears
description: Phish made its farewell here this weekend in true Phish style: playing its own musical marathon, swarmed by adoring fans who understood every in-joke, flaunting Vermont roots, and isolated from the rest of the world. In its last sets, as always, Phish balanced simplicity and convolution, whimsy and strategy, meticulous planning and winging it.

title: Three on Trial In Afghanistan Gain Access To F.B.I. Files
description: Three Americans on trial Monday on charges that they ran a vigilante jail and interrogation operation here accused the F.B.I. of removing evidence needed for their defense, and they were given a seven-day extension to prepare after the agency returned the evidence later that day.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: McAfee To Acquire Foundstone
description: McAfee Inc., the world's No.2 maker of antivirus software, said yesterday that it planned to buy the closely held company Foundstone Inc. for $86 million in cash to add software that helps customers protect their computer networks. The transaction should be completed in two months, McAfee said. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it would begin selling Foundstone's products this year. The purchase of Foundstone will add more than 400 customers, including AT&T and Motorola, McAfee said. McAfee sold its network software business and changed its name from Network Associates Inc. last month to focus on security products to compete with Symantec, the top antivirus software maker. Shares of McAfee rose 64 cents, or 3.7 percent, to $18.13. Computer viruses like MyDoom, the fastest-spreading virus ever, have increased sales of products that analyze network weaknesses, with the market expected to reach $1.6 billion by 2008, McAfee said, citing industry research.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 3 Are Charged In Strangling
description: Two men and a woman were arrested yesterday in the slaying of a woman whose body was found Aug. 9 in a stairwell of the Murphy Houses in the Bronx, the police said. The victim, Diana Almestica, 32, with no known address, was found strangled and partially clothed on the second floor of 1010 East 178th Street. Gerald Watkins, 24, and Doris Edwards, 38, were charged with second-degree murder, and Jeffrey Chitty, 21, with hindering prosecution. All three live in the building. The killing may have been drug-related, with the victim owing money, the police said. On Jan. 22, another woman, Jeannie Faulmino, 34, was found strangled in a third-floor stairwell. That case remains under investigation. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Brazil Starts to Crack Down on Counterfeit Goods
description: When Brazilian police arrested the suspected leader of one of the country's biggest rings involved in smuggling counterfeit goods on June 1, officials here hailed the move as proof that Brazil was finally cracking down on copyright piracy after years of looking the other way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OKEN, ETHEL (NEE GREENSTEIN)
description: OKEN--Ethel (nee Greenstein). Of Boynton Beach, FL., formerly of Bayside and Glen Head, N.Y., died August 15, 2004 at age 81. She was born in The Bronx, graduated from NYU, and received her Master's degree from Columbia University. She was a long-time teacher and chair of Health and Physical Education at Bayside High School. She was an avid tennis and golf player. She is survived by her husband of 57 years, Morton, daughter Marilyn (Jeffrey) Margulies of Stony Brook, N.Y., son Barry (Melanie Fried) of Portland, OR., six grandchildren (Amy, Paul and Lee Margulies; Kiva, Adam and Corey Oken), sister Frieda Nelson and brother Philip Green. Funeral services will be held at Sinai Memorial Chapel, 15200 Jog Road at 10:30 A.M. on Wednesday, August 18th.

title: Keeping Guns Out of Children's Hands
description: When it comes to children and guns, there is some good news to report: According to a national study published in June in the journal Pediatrics, the rate of both fatal and nonfatal injuries inflicted by guns on children 14 and younger declined by more than 50 percent in the 1990's.

title: Candidate for Democratic Party Arrested in China
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 17  An already heated election campaign for the legislature here took an unexpected turn today with an announcement by the Democratic Party that one of its candidates had been arrested in mainland China on charges of soliciting a prostitute and had been sentenced without trial to six months in detention.

title: Detective Caught In Internet Sting Over Child Sex
description: A 16-year veteran of the New York Police Department, who supposedly called himself a ''boy hunter'' in an online profile, was arrested on Monday after the Westchester district attorney, Jeanine Pirro, said he tried to have a sexual rendezvous with an investigator from her office who had posed on the Internet as a 14-year-old boy.

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Switzerland: Swatch Investigation Dropped
description: The watchmaker Swatch said the United States Department of Labor had dismissed complaints brought by two former employees, who claimed the company used its Asian unit to evade taxes and customs duties. The Labor Department said it did not have jurisdiction in the case; Swatch's share prices rose 4 percent on the news. The stock fell sharply last week after the accusations became public. Swatch said on Friday that an internal investigation had failed to find any wrongdoing.

title: Vodafone Taps Executive at Rival to Lead Japanese Unit

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Drug Executive Sells Shares

While the shares, which were traded on the New York Stock Exchange, represent about 1.9 percent of Biovail's equity, Mr. Melnyk remains the company's largest shareholder, with a 13.5 percent stake. Biovail, based in Mississauga, Ontario, said that Mr. Melnyk would acquire call options for three million Biovail shares to give him ''the opportunity to maintain his position in the common stock.'' Both the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Ontario Securities Commission are looking into insider trading accusations involving Biovail, Canada's largest publicly traded drug company. title: NORTEL SAYS IT FACES CRIMINAL INVESTIGATION IN CANADA

The police elevated a review of accounting that began after Nortel fired Frank Dunn, the chief executive, and two of his top deputies. In March, Nortel said it would restate results for a second time. The company said in May that federal prosecutors in Texas were demanding company documents as part of a criminal investigation.

She graduated from Mount Holyoke College in 1943 and remained active in the Mount Holyoke Alumni Association. For many years she was the President of F.G. Montabert and Company, a multinational packaging company, located in New York City and Midland Park, N.J.. She is survived by her husband of 61 years, Carlton J. Condon. and by her children Fred M. Condon (Carlene) of Martha's Vineyard and Jacqueline Condon Johnson (David) of Ridgefield, Conn. She was a loving and vibrant grandmother to Scott, Sean, Christopher, Matthew, Alexis and MacKenzie. A gathering of family and friends to celebrate her life will be held Saturday, August 21 3pm-5pm at her home, 10 Tamarack Lane, (Farm Neck), Oak Bluffs, MA. title: CAMPAIGN TO GIVE MILLIONS TO COMMITTEES
description: The Kerry-Edwards campaign, which raised roughly $225 million to set campaign finance records in this year's race, said yesterday that it would give $6 million to two committees charged with electing Democrats to Congress. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in the House and the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee in the Senate will each receive $3 million from the campaign, which is unloading its surplus after it stopped raising money in July in favor of accepting public financing. The campaign did not say how much it would transfer to the Democratic National Committee, which is supporting Mr. Kerry's candidacy and is actively raising money for the presidential race. Glen Justice (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint To Offer Blackberrys On Network
description: Shares of Research in Motion Ltd., maker of the BlackBerry wireless e-mail device, rose yesterday after it announced that Sprint planned to offer the device on Sprint's nationwide PCS network. Sprint was the only major carrier not offering the BlackBerry. Deepak Chopra, a National Bank Financial analyst, said the news was important because it was another indication of the demand for BlackBerry. Customers are asking for the device, so carriers have to respond, he said, noting that Sprint had marketed several other wireless e-mail services before turning to the BlackBerry. Research in Motion shares gained $2.98, to $56.27, in United States trading. While the Sprint news was positive for Research in Motion, based in Waterloo, Ontario, its shares are off about 21 percent since July 1, as investors await a Federal Circuit Court ruling on its patent-litigation dispute with NTP Inc. Last year, a lower court in Virginia ruled that Research in Motion had violated five NTP patents. The judge awarded NTP, a patent-holding company, $53 million in damages, as well as an 8.5 percent royalty on the bulk of BlackBerry sales in the United States. The judge also issued, but immediately stayed, an injunction on BlackBerry sales in the United States, pending the appeal. A decision could come as early as this month, or as late as year-end, according to analysts.

title: COLORADO'S ELECTORAL VOTES
description: Colorado residents will vote in November on whether to scrap the state's winner-take-all system of distributing Electoral College votes. The secretary of state said that enough valid signatures had been gathered to put the proposal on the ballot. The rule would become immediate if it passes, meaning that the state's nine electoral votes would be distributed proportionally to the presidential candidates based on the percentage of the vote each earned statewide. President Bush won the state in 2000 with just less than 51 percent of the vote. The state went from eight to nine electoral votes as a result of the 2000 census. Kirk Johnson (NYT)

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg vetoed two City Council actions yesterday, a bill that would have made it unlawful to sell or install certain audible car alarms and a resolution that would have loosened the oversight of pay phone franchises. Mr. Bloomberg said that the city's noise code already substantially regulated car alarms and that the proposed law might increase car theft. He also rejected a resolution that would have made it easier for some pay phone franchise owners to keep their franchises without city intervention, saying, ''The only possible benefit might be to a very narrow business interest, that is, those in the pay phone industry.'' The Council has historically had enough votes to override each veto by Mr. Bloomberg. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENICK, NITA H.
description: HENICK--Nita H. 79, died on August 14 after a courageous six year fight against cancer. ''It was a second honeymoon,'' said her beloved husband of 55 years, William, referring to the nonstop schedule of family visits, world travel, the theater, the opera and visits with friends. She will be greatly missed by her children, Daniel (Rita), Arthur (Sharon Cromwell), and Susan (Jack Bellis) and by her grandchildren, Maggie, Adam, Ian, Jessica and Kira. She is also survived by her sister, Dr. Ruth Lebovitz and her nephews, Richard and Roger Lebovitz. Nita was dedicated to her family and to her profession. She was a social work supervisor at the Coler - Goldwater Hospital Complex for over 25 years. She served on the long-term care panel for the Health Systems Agency, the federal overseer for NY hospitals, and on the board of the NYC Health and Hospitals Corporation, its successor organization. In addition, she served the NYC Chapter of the National Association of Social Workers in many capacities and served as its president for two years. In all her endeavors, Nita showed uncommon zestful energy, expertise, and determination. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of the donor's choice. Services will be held on Monday, August 16 at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills at 12 noon. The discounter had forecast a gain of 2 percent to 4 percent from a year earlier. Wal-Mart, based in Bentonville, Ark., updated results of stores in the United States open at least a year through Friday in a recorded call. Consumers in the East and Southeast bought tuna, duct tape, flashlights and playing cards in anticipation of a tropical storm and a hurricane, Wal-Mart said. description: A Queens man sought for 20 years on charges that he tried to run down an officer was arrested on Friday as he entered the United States from Canada at Champlain, N.Y., the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said in a statement yesterday. The man, Jean Roland Saint Surin, 66, fled to Montreal after being indicted in 1984, accused of driving a van toward a police officer in Queens. title: TRYING TO COUNTER SWIFT BOAT GROUP'S ADS
description: The liberal group MoveOn.org will begin showing new advertisements to counter a spot from a group of Vietnam veterans that accuses Senator John Kerry of lying to obtain some of his military decorations. The group said it would first show a new commercial today on CNN and stations in four cities in Ohio, West Virginia and Wisconsin where the veteran's group, Swift Boat Veterans for Truth, is running its spot. In the MoveOn spot an announcer says, ''George Bush used his father to get into the National Guard, was grounded and then went missing,'' and, ''now he's allowing false advertising that attacks John Kerry.'' It ends with comments by Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, condemning the Swift boat group's advertisement and calling on Mr. Bush to do the same. The White House says that Mr. Bush met all of his military requirements and received an honorable discharge and that it has nothing to do with the Swift boat group. A MoveOn spot later this week will make specific accusations about Mr. Bush's service record. Jim Rutenberg (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
MEMO PAD
description: SHIFTING FORTUNES -- New figures show how sharply the fortunes of the big airlines and their low-cost rivals have diverged since the industry's peak year of 2000. The discount carriers flew 20 percent more seats in May than four years earlier, according to a report by the Transportation Department's Office of Inspector General, while the network airlines capacity was down 16 percent. Reflecting the relentless pressure that low-cost carriers have kept on their bigger competitors, average air fares for a 1,000-mile trip dropped to $116 from $147 over that period. Underlining the trend toward driving rather than flying short distances, the report said that there were 27 percent fewer scheduled flights of under 250 miles in May than in May 2000, but there were 9 percent more flights of over 1,000 miles. Southwest had a 59 percent share of the low-cost market in May, followed by America West with 12 percent and Air Tran with 8 percent. Meanwhile, the propeller-driven airplane is rapidly becoming scarce on commercial flights. Flights by turboprop and piston-engine aircraft fell 63 percent in May over May 2000. Flights by regional jet increased 180 percent.

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Bids For Oil Study
description: The oil companies Royal Dutch/Shell and BP are competing to conduct a technical assessment of Iraq's largest oil fields, spokesmen from the companies said. They were among more than two dozen oil producers and independent engineers who had been invited by the Iraqi oil ministry to submit bids by Aug. 15 to evaluate the oil fields. The project will be the most comprehensive study of Iraq's oil fields in about two decades. Several independent engineering firms have also submitted bids. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl and Man Hurt As Shooting Erupts
description: An 8-year-old girl and a 27-year-old man, both believed to be bystanders, were shot in an exchange of gunfire last night, the police said. They were discovered shortly after 7 p.m. in front of 1677 President Street, in Brownsville, the girl with a wound to her lower left leg and the man with a wound to his right leg. Earlier, investigators said, a dispute erupted between two groups and several shots were fired in front of 1663 President Street. The identities of the wounded were not disclosed, though the police said they were in stable condition last night at Kings County Hospital Center. The motives for the shootings remained unclear, and there were no arrests as of early today, the police said. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOMRIGHAUSEN, LINDSLEY
description: HOMRIGHAUSEN -- Lindsley. On August 10, age 58, after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Lindsley was the daughter of Robert B. Harvey and Joan Blackman Harvey Miner, and the step-daughter of Charles H. Miner, Jr., all of Kingston, PA. A graduate of Lake Erie College, Mrs. Homrighausen worked in PR for Mutual of New York and then entered the field of philanthropy and institutional development with the Surdna and Edward John Noble Foundations and Pace University. She is survived by her husband of 34 years, David Homrighausen, daughter Sarah and son Benjamin, all of Manhattan, her sister Emily Harvey Mahon of Hawthorne, NJ, and her step-grandmother June Blackman Baumstark of St. Louis. Memorial donations may be made to the Dr. Edwin Lame Conservation Fund for the Pocono Mountains, C/O The Nature Conservancy, PO Box 55, Long Pond, PA 18334. A private service will be held for the family.

title: Misconceived Military Shuffle
description: The troop redeployment plan announced yesterday by President Bush makes little long-term strategic sense. It is certain to strain crucial alliances, increase overall costs and dangerously weaken deterrence on the Korean peninsula at the worst possible moment. Meanwhile, it will do nothing to address the military's most pressing current need: relieving the chronic strain on ground forces that has resulted from failing to anticipate the long, and largely unilateral, American occupation of Iraq.

description: When Rod Keenan arrived in Manhattan from Kansas more than a decade ago, transported by dreams of becoming a kind of contemporary Charles James, he took to the benighted habit of wearing a hat, a practice that yielded certain demographic discoveries. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POLLACK, HONORABLE MILTON
description: POLLACK--Honorable Milton, age 97, United States Senior Judge for the Southern District of New York, died Friday, August 13, 2004. He was the son of the late Julius and Betty Pollack and was born September 29, 1906 in Brooklyn, New York. Judge Pollack was blessed with two outstanding careers and two wonderful marriages. After more than thirty years as a distinguished trial lawyer in New York, he was appointed by President Lyndon B. Johnson to the Federal Judiciary in 1967. In 1932 he married Lillian Klein who died in 1967. In 1971 he married Moselle Baum Erlich of Houston who died February 13, 2004. Beloved father of Stephanie and William Miller, Daniel and Susan Pollack, Joan and Marvin Kaplan, Judy and Rodney Margolis, and Phyllis and George Asch. Adoring and proud grandfather of Drs. Debra Singer and Hal Stein, Drs. Marcy Singer Gabella and William Gabella, Samuel and Laura Pollack, Gabriella Pollack, Jill and Jeff Levenson, Elizabeth and Daniel Treinish, Karen and Roy Brooks, Susan and Forrest Bruch, Deborah and Richard Kaplan, Nancy and Robert Risman, Melanie and Lawrence Margolis, Elizabeth and Randolph Guggenheimer, Mark and Tonya Miller, Drs. Rachel Miller and Kent Becker and Dr. Steven Miller. Cherished great - grandfather of 23. Brother of Muriel Brody and Lillian and Leo Morse and the late George Pollack. Services Wednesday, August 18th, 11 AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: Exactly What Does a Doctor Sound Like?

I was fast asleep, but when I shifted in my seat to face the aisle I woke up. There in the aisle next to me were two feet, toes pointing up. The pilot and a couple of flight attendants, as quietly as they could, were giving CPR to the person lying there.

title: TYSON FOODS MAY BE SUED BY REGULATORS OVER DISCLOSURE
description: Tyson Foods Inc., the world's largest meat processor, said that it might be sued by the Securities and Exchange Commission because it did not adequately report $1.7 million paid to Don Tyson, its former senior chairman. It said a notice from the S.E.C. accused the company of not properly disclosing the payments for the fiscal years 1997 to 2003. The company said Mr. Tyson had paid back about $1.52 million. The S.E.C. may seek a monetary penalty, Tyson said. In March, the company said the S.E.C. was investigating benefits provided to John H. Tyson, the chief executive. Tyson is based in Springdale, Ark.

title: Phelps Picks Up Two More Gold Medals

After he fulfilled that goal on the first day of competition with a world record in the 400 individual medley, he exploded with a display of exuberance he had seldom displayed in his 19 years.

title: EDWARDS FOCUSES ON RURAL AREAS
description: Senator John Edwards yesterday unveiled several initiatives focusing on the economic and social problems of rural areas. Speaking to a backyard gathering in the farming community of Willard, Mo., above, Mr. Edwards said a Kerry-Edwards administration would work to bring venture capital to small towns with a $1 billion initiative over four years that would help finance small businesses and double financing for a program that helps small and midsize manufacturers adopt new technologies. In addition, he called for full financing for a federal program that provides for the hiring of law enforcement officers to combat the increasing production of methamphetamines, and he promoted further extension of broadband Internet into rural areas. ''There are many places in rural India where Internet makes it easier for an international business to do business than in rural Missouri,'' he said. Mr. Edwards, who was raised in small towns in the Carolinas, is seen by the Kerry campaign as potentially bolstering the ticket in rural areas. Thomas Crampton (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PUTTERMAN, PEARL
description: PUTTERMAN--Pearl. 96, died August 15th. Wife of the late Isaac; mother of Arnold and Susan Putterman; Judy Lewis (Stan); David and Laurie Putterman. Grandmother of Michael, Daniel, Jonathan, Jordan, Tobi and Eric. Greatgrandmother of Abigail, Isaac, Sydney and Oliver. Sister of Leah Janus and aunt to devoted niece Raizi and nephews Barry and Micah. Attorney, teacher, childrens' advocate in family court, a leader in Hadassah, and the voice of numerous recordings in Yiddish for the Blind. She was a woman ahead of her time yet steeped in the traditions and values of her Jewish heritage--family, education and charity towards others. She was blessed with a full, long and healthy life and will be deeply missed but always remembered and appreciated for all that she gave us. Burial is private. Shiva will be observed at her daughter's home Tuesday 4:30-9PM, and Wednesday and Thursday 25PM and 7-9PM. For those who wish to do so, donations may be made in her memory to Hadassah.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garrison: Rain Halts Service On Metro-North Line
description: Rainwater that overwhelmed a culvert washed out the earth yesterday morning beneath a 25-foot section of railroad tracks midway between the Garrison and Peekskill stations on the Hudson line of the Metro-North Railroad. With the tracks suspended in midair, officials suspended service between the stations yesterday, ferrying passengers by bus. Because of traffic, however, passengers were delayed for more than an hour. Officials said they hoped to have service restored on at least one of the two tracks by today's morning rush. The washout, which occurred about 8:30 a.m., also caused Amtrak to limit service between Albany and New York through today. Michael Luo (NYT)

The commission was expected to decide today whether to approve the deal or start an investigation. That deadline has been put back to Aug. 25, Ms. Torres said. She would not say why, but such a delay usually means that the commission is assessing changes to the deal by the companies involved. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN TO BUY STAKE IN TEXAS RAILROAD
description: Kansas City Southern, the railroad, agreed to buy 51 percent of a Texas railroad from Grupo TMM for $32.7 million as part of a plan to gain control of Mexico's biggest rail network. Kansas City Southern said that it was buying the stake in Mexrail, which links its domestic lines with Mexican rail tracks controlled by TMM. Kansas City Southern, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., must buy the rest of Mexrail for $31.4 million by Oct. 31, 2005, a spokesman, Warren Erdman, said. The transaction may signal that TMM, Mexico's biggest transportation company, and Kansas City Southern can resolve a year-old dispute over Kansas City Southern's plan to buy Mexico's largest railroad, which TMM owns.

title: Corrections

Sarah Graves, not Christopher Riederer, is the housemate of Sarah Bardwell. ( Go to Article )

title: It's Ready, Aim, Wait for the Mighty Wind Gusts to Die Down, and Fire

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Valley Stream: Boy, 3, Chokes To Death On Popcorn
description: A 3-year-old boy at the movies with his parents died Sunday night when he choked while eating popcorn, the Nassau County Police said yesterday. The police said the boy, Deontea Riley, of Queens, was with his parents at the Sunrise Multiplex Cinemas in Valley Stream when he began to choke. His parents performed the Heimlich maneuver to dislodge the popcorn, and police officers attempted CPR, but they could not revive the boy. Deontea was pronounced dead at Mercy Medical Center shortly before 8 p.m. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit For Financial Conern
description: Allianz, Europe's biggest financial-services company, reported higher-than-expected profit in the second quarter as its Dresdner Bank unit posted a second consecutive profit because of cost reductions and lower loan provisions. Net income at Allianz was 614 million euros ($759 million), down from a restated 662 million euros in the year-earlier period, after a tax gain was not repeated. Dresdner earned 129 million euros in the second quarter after cutting 4,700 jobs and shedding bad loans.

title: Parents to Lead Ceremony Honoring Victims of 9/11
description: The ceremony commemorating the third anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack will closely follow the script for last year's event. But officials said yesterday that there would be a change in the cast: instead of the victims' children taking center stage, the victims' parents and grandparents will.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Applied Materials To Buy Metron Technology
description: Applied Materials, the world's biggest producer of machines that make computer chips, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Metron Technology for $85 million to expand its services business. Applied, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it would also assume ''certain Metron liabilities.'' Metron supplies parts and materials and offers maintenance services for chip plants. The transaction is the fourth this year for the chief executive, Michael R. Splinter, who is expanding Applied's business of offering materials, parts and servicing. Applied shares closed unchanged at $15.64.

description: State lawmakers have approved the first tax credit to benefit film and television productions in New York, and many in the industry say the incentive will help lure more film productions to the city and the state and counter the flight of film jobs to Toronto, Vancouver and Montreal.

description: Two weeks before her guests plan to arrive, the hostess cannot remember their travel arrangements or even their names.

title: LOJACK BUYS BOOMERANG TRACKING OF CANADA
description: The LoJack Corporation, which makes devices for recovering stolen cars, agreed to buy Boomerang Tracking Inc. for about 64 million Canadian dollars ($49 million) to expand into Canada. LoJack will pay 2.95 Canadian dollars a share in cash or a combination of cash and stock for Boomerang, which also makes stolen-vehicle recovery equipment, LoJack said. LoJack, based in Westwood, Mass., also gets Boomerang's cash balance of $12 million. Boomerang, based in Montreal, is the biggest seller of auto-tracking systems in Quebec, Ontario and British Columbia, LoJack said. Boomerang had 26.2 million Canadian dollars in sales in its year ended in April.

title: Ferry Pilot Is Said to Reach Deal With U.S. Prosecutors
description: The captain of the Staten Island ferry that crashed on Oct. 15, killing 11 people, has reached an unusual cooperation deal with federal prosecutors that is expected to be announced in court this morning, a person involved with the investigation said last night.

title: Bag It
description: Last week four screeners for the Transportation Security Administration were arrested at Kennedy and La Guardia airports for stealing money, jewelry and other valuables from checked bags. The agents were caught in a sting operation after a torrent of complaints about luggage thefts. These arrests likely represent only a fraction of the abuses nationwide.

title: Phelps's dreams meet not-so-bad realities
description: ATHENS:  Imagine, just for the length of a breezy, sun-kissed summer evening in Athens, that you had not heard a word about Michael Phelps before these Olympics began. That you knew nothing about his childhood in Baltimore; the failed Olympic dreams of his older sister, which pushed him to make the most of his obvious talent; the serial breaking of world records; the real or imagined link with Mark Spitz and his seven Olympic gold medals.

title: G.M. TO SELL HALF-INTEREST IN 9 SHOPPING MALLS
description: General Motors Asset Management agreed to sell a half-interest in nine regional shopping malls it owns to the Mills Corporation, a developer and manager of retail centers, in a deal valued at $1.03 billion. Mills said it planned to finance the purchase through the assumption of $170 million of existing property debt, about $377 million from new mortgages on four of the malls and the rest in cash. The acquisition will increase Mills' retail space by 28 percent. The properties are in California, Ohio, Maryland, Michigan, Nevada and Florida. Mills is based in Arlington, Va.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Rochester: Doctor Possessed Child Smut
description: The former chief of pediatric emergency medicine at a Rochester hospital pleaded guilty in Federal District Court yesterday to a charge of possessing child pornography. Dr. Julius Goepp, 46, admitted to having up to 150 images of child pornography on two computers that the authorities seized in his home last March. Dr. Goepp was suspended after his arrest, said Teri D'Agostino, a spokeswoman for Strong Memorial Hospital, who added that no patients had come forward to report abuse. Dr. Goepp was one of 900 people arrested worldwide as part of an Internet investigation by the federal authorities. He faces up to 10 years in prison during his sentencing, which is scheduled for Nov. 3. Michelle York (NYT)

title: Guiding a Child Into College Is Now Part of the Job
description: When her daughter Shayna began looking at colleges, Desiree Holder-Walker found the process daunting. She knew college admissions had changed since she attended school, and her job in Manhattan made it difficult to meet with her daughter's guidance counselor in Brooklyn during the day.

title: China's Long March Is Retraced With Artistic Steps
description: Wang Wenhai, the 53-year-old self-proclaimed Yanan Clay Sculpture King, has three goals. First, he wants to build a 426-foot-tall statue of Mao Zedong in Yanan, the Chinese Communist Party's historic revolutionary base in the northwest. Then he wants to make a giant memorial commemorating Mao's philosophies, with possibly a nod to Karl Marx. Finally, if he has time, he wants to carve 25,000 tiny statues of Mao to leave along the route of the Long March, the 6,000-mile trek that members of the fledgling Communist Party made in the mid-1930's.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Cincinnati Schools In Budget Trouble
description: Cincinnati Public Schools must tap its reserves for $21.7 million after overspending in the last academic year and may be forced to ask voters to approve a second levy in November unless spending is cut, school district officials said. Unexpected expenses for lead removal in schools, increased costs for natural gas, payments to charter schools and teacher raises from a new contract forced the extra spending, officials said on Monday. Before the new gap, the district had predicted a $48 million deficit within three years, even if voters approved a five-year levy renewal on the November ballot to raise $65 million. Albert Salvato (NYT)

description: A former stockbroker who once handled the personal investments of the real estate executive James M. Weichert has been charged with plotting to kidnap Mr. Weichert's 21-year-old son, James Jr., the authorities said yesterday.

title: Bomb Defused in Sardinia After Berlusconi and Blair Visited
description: ROME, Aug. 18  The police defused a bomb today in Porto Rotondo, Sardinia, the same town where Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi had entertained British Prime Minister Tony Blair and his wife Cherie hours earlier.

title: China Holds Candidate From Hong Kong on Prostitution Charge
description: An already heated election campaign for the legislature here took an unexpected turn on Tuesday with an announcement by the Democratic Party that one of its candidates had been arrested in mainland China on charges of soliciting a prostitute and had been sentenced without trial to six months in detention.

description: The American ambassador, responding to an appeal from the Afghan government, helped broker a cease-fire on Tuesday in the four-day-long fighting in western Afghanistan and won an agreement from the aggressor, a militia commander named Amanullah Khan, to withdraw his troops, American and Afghan officials said.

title: N.J. Voters in a Pickle
description: Gov. James McGreevey's exit strategy has put New Jersey voters, and democracy itself, in a terrible bind. Under the timetable announced last week during his bombshell news conference, Mr. McGreevey will resign his office on Nov. 15 and hand the reins of government to Richard Codey, the president of the State Senate. Executive power will thus reside for three months with a lame-duck governor crippled by scandal and then, for the next 14 months, with an interim governor who has no mandate from the voters.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Airline Restructuring Advances
description: Air Canada took another step toward emerging from bankruptcy protection as its creditors approved a restructuring that would give them a 45.8 percent stake in the surviving company. The plan, which was approved by 99.6 percent of the creditors, is subject to approval by a court in Ontario. Under the plan, existing shares in Air Canada, based in Montreal, will stop trading around Sept. 30 and be delisted from the Toronto Stock Exchange. The new airline will be known as Air Canada Enterprises Aviation Holdings. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Lefties Have Rights, Too
description: Jean-Pierre Foucart, left, the captain at Le Bernardin in Midtown, is an observant man. When he notices a left-handed diner struggling with the fish knife, whose blade is designed for a right-handed person, he replaces it with a regular knife and reverses the setting to make dining more convenient, with the knife on the left and the fork on the right. (Table settings for righties and lefties are shown here.)

title: Iraq's Soccer Team Overcomes Odds
description: PATRAS, Greece, Aug. 18  Iraq's national soccer team does not play home games because other teams are afraid to visit. Fearing for their own security, the Iraqis left their country under military escort, and in disguise, to catch a flight out to the Olympics.

title: Unusual Alliance Is Formed to Clean Up Mine Runoff
description: An unusual partnership linking the federal Forest Service, the environmental group Trout Unlimited, the ski resort owners Snowbird Corporation and Tiffany & Company has been created to clean the acidic mine runoff from the American Fork watershed -- and perhaps spur similar alliances around the West, where mining waste has polluted the headwaters of 40 percent of all watersheds.

title: 8 Suspects in Terror Plot Appear in British Court
description: LONDON, Aug. 18  A British prosecutor said today that authorities had seized 100 computers containing thousands of computer files and had issued 52 terrorism-related warrants in the investigation that led to charges against eight men for conspiracy to commit murder in an alleged terror plot.

title: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CHOOSES CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, the biggest North American maker of wood panels for floors and roofs, said Richard Frost would become chief executive after the retirement of the current chairman and chief executive, Mark Suwyn, on Oct. 31. Mr. Frost, 53, joined Louisiana-Pacific in 1996 and now manages its biggest business, oriented-strand board, as well as its other engineered wood products business. As chief executive, he will also sit on the board, Louisiana-Pacific said. Mr. Suwyn, 61, joined Louisiana-Pacific in 1985 and became chief executive in January 1996. Louisiana-Pacific is based in Nashville.

title: Market Place; Facing higher costs and a tough trading climate, some mutual funds are calling it quits.
description: SOME of the nation's more than 8,000 mutual funds are shutting their doors, as their managers confront a lackluster stock market, greater regulatory scrutiny and higher costs.

title: Panthers Are Motivated By Their Latest Failure
description: The failures of the past were painted over last season, the record books rewritten and the anguish erased by a team that had gone through so much since entering the N.F.L in 1995.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: The Chrysler Center, at 155 East 42nd Street, next to the Chrysler Building, is now home to CAPITAL GRILLE, part of a steakhouse chain based in Atlanta. The restaurant has 250 seats and includes the Trylons, a room with soaring prismatic glass and metal supports designed by Philip Johnson to reflect the distinctive architecture of the building, right. Other dining areas and private rooms are done in dark wood, in the boardroom style typical of many steakhouses. The menu has steaks at $33.95 to $36.95 and seafood. The wine list is lengthy, and lockers are available for lease to store wines bought at a discount from the restaurant.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 7 about a speech by President Bush to a convention of minority journalists referred incorrectly to a scene in the movie ''Fahrenheit 9/11'' that Senator John Kerry cited when he spoke to the journalists and criticized the president's handling of the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001. The movie shows Mr. Bush, having learned of the attacks, continuing to listen to schoolchildren read a book with their teacher; it does not show the president reading to them. (The error also appeared in an article on Aug. 6 about a campaign appearance by Mr. Kerry in which he questioned the president's leadership on Sept. 11.)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about Senator John Kerry's financial backers misstated the outcome of Mr. Kerry's first campaign for public office, a primary contest in 1972 for a seat in the House of Representatives, and referred incorrectly to the amount of money he raised in that race. He was successful, not unsuccessful, in the primary; he lost the general election. The $268,000 Mr. Kerry raised then was for both the primary and the general election campaigns, not just the primary.

title: Inquiry Into F.B.I. Questioning Is Sought
description: Several Democratic lawmakers called on Tuesday for a Justice Department investigation into the Federal Bureau of Investigation's questioning of would-be demonstrators about possible violence at the political conventions, saying the questioning may have violated the First Amendment.

title: Plea by Contributor Is Called Imminent
description: A New Jersey developer who is one of the nation's top Democratic campaign contributors is scheduled to plead guilty to criminal charges on Wednesday morning in a case in which he is accused of hiring a prostitute to blackmail a witness in a federal investigation in an attempt to silence him, according to lawyers involved in the case.

description: After a surprisingly strong showing in the recent federal parliamentary election, Quebec separatists have suddenly begun fighting among themselves over strategies to win independence for the province.

title: Kerry Will Campaign During Republicans' Convention
description: Breaking with tradition, Senator John Kerry plans to campaign for at least one day during the Republican National Convention, venturing to Nashville to speak at the American Legion's national convention.

title: Financial Advice From Stockbrokers
description: Beware of stockbrokers bearing investment advice. In a regulatory misadventure now five years in the running, the Securities and Exchange Commission has exempted stockbrokers from the standards faced by registered financial advisers. This comes at a time when the distinction between the two has become increasingly fuzzy, as the brokerage industry shifts from a commission-driven model to a fee-based one in which brokers typically proffer advice as well as stocks.

title: No Medal for U.S. in Equestrian Event
description: It was a case of easy come, easy go for the United States equestrian team today after results in the three-day team event were shuffled and reshuffled. Initially, it appeared that Germany had won the Olympic gold medal after the final day of competition, with France taking the silver and Britain the bronze.

title: HERSHEY TO BUY GRUPO LORENA, MEXICAN CANDY MAKER
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation agreed to buy Grupo Lorena of Mexico, the maker of Pelon Pelo Rico spicy candy, to expand in Mexico and in the Hispanic market in the United States. Grupo Lorena had sales of more than $30 million in 2003, Hershey said. Hershey, based in Hershey, Pa., did not disclose terms of the purchase, which is being made by a subsidiary, Hershey Mexico. Juan-Carlos Zayas, Hershey Mexico's director of marketing, said his operation makes adult-oriented chocolate products and the deal would give it products in the youth market in Mexico. Grupo Lorena is based in Guadalajara.

When the solace of time-tested conventions beats the exhilaration of newfangled conceits. When you crave something fixed in its culinary place, not fused with an exotic interloper.

title: Setbacks on Press Protections Are Seen
description: A ruling last week ordering a reporter for Time magazine to jail for contempt and a subpoena later issued to a reporter for The New York Times in the same case are the latest examples in what legal experts characterize as an ominous trend for journalists: the weakening of fundamental protections for the gathering and publishing of news that had been generally viewed as settled since the Watergate era.

title: Borders Posts 89% Rise in Quarterly Profit
description: The Borders Group, the bookstore chain, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 89 percent, topping analysts' estimates, helped by sales of former President Bill Clinton's memoir. The company raised its annual profit forecast.

title: Key Evidence Cast in Doubt On a Claim Of Terrorism
description: Federal prosecutors acknowledged possible flaws yesterday in a major piece of evidence used in their case against two leaders of an Albany mosque on charges that they supported terrorism.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Investor Confidence Falls
description: Investor confidence in Germany fell for the first month in three in August amid concern about record oil prices and slowing growth in the United States and Japan. The index of institutional and analyst sentiment compiled by the ZEW Center for European Economic Research fell to 45.3, from 48.4 in July. The drop in confidence adds to evidence that German economic growth may slow this quarter. ''The recent economic data from the U.S. gives reason to be concerned that the very strong export demand in Germany up to this point could weaken,'' the center said. ''In addition, the high oil price reduces the purchasing power of consumers and puts pressure on domestic demand.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITE, MARJORIE POWERS
description: WHITE--Marjorie Powers. 79, of NYC, at Heron Island, ME, died August 8th, 2004. Married to Willard D. White Jr., mother of Shawn, Stephen, Catherine and Nicholas White, and grandmother of Zoe Frederick and Nicholas Jr., Katie and Patrick White. She was the daughter of Frank T. Powers Sr. and Mary D. Powers of Glen Cove, NY. She was an enthusiastic alumna of Sarah Lawrence College. Later she attended the Art Students League of NY and the Academy of Fine Arts in Florence, Italy. Though a life long artist and writer, she was shy about publishing. She was a great admirer of light-moon, stars, Christmas and sunsets. Travel, the subject matter of many of her poems, prints and photographs, found its seeds in her early association with the Experiment in International Living. She said she would get another cat in a minute, go to Mexico in a minute, but she did not want to go to Australia unless Willard did--then she would go in a minute. Her love of books and libraries was voluminous. Memorial donations may be made to NY Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, Room 73, NY, NY 10018. There will be no services.

title: Oil Prices Set Another Record
description: PARIS, Aug. 18 — Oil prices climbed above $47 a barrel today, setting yet another record, after figures showed supplies in the United States were down for a third consecutive week while a report from OPEC highlighted the threat of high oil prices for world economies.

Devoted father of John G. and his wife Jane, Patricia, William and Daniel. Cherished grandfather of John III and Michael. Loving brother of May. Memorial service Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9PM, McLaughlin & Sons, Third Ave. at 97th St, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DONNATIN, JAMES L.
description: DONNATIN--James L. On August 15, 2004. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Loving father of Timothy James. Cherished son of Francis and the late Sophie. Brother of Frank (Rose), Ron (Sue), Lorraine (John), Arlene (George). Beloved uncle to many nieces and nephews. Loving companion of all the cats. Friends may visit Wednesday 2-4:30PM and 79:30PM at the New Hyde Park Funeral Home, 506 Lakeville Rd, New Hyde Park, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 9:15AM at Notre Dame RC Church, New Hyde Park. Cremation to follow at Fresh Pond Crematory, Middle Village, NY.

title: COURT APPROVES TRAVELERS' ASBESTOS PLAN
description: A federal bankruptcy judge approved a plan by the Travelers Property Casualty Corporation to pay $500 million to settle claims against it by people with asbestos-related diseases linked to the Johns-Manville Corporation. More than 600,000 people sued Travelers, contending that it knew about the hazards of asbestos and failed to disclose them over the course of about 30 years as Manville's primary insurer. The settlement means asbestos victims will receive extra compensation as the trust that Johns-Manville set up in 1988 to pay asbestos claims runs out of money. The trust resolved 623,400 claims for $3.3 billion and held investments valued at $1.6 billion as of June 30, according to court papers. It has 37,000 claims pending. Judge Burton R. Lifland of United States Bankruptcy Court approved the agreement at a hearing in New York.

title: Museum Review; Slavery's Harsh History Is Portrayed in Promised Land
description: Gaze out the southern windows of the National Underground Railroad Freedom Center and it is easy to see why this new museum devoted to slavery and resistance has found such a resonant home here. A suspension bridge -- John A. Roebling's rococo prelude to his Brooklyn Bridge -- stretches away from the museum, spanning the Ohio River. On the bridge's far side, in Kentucky, human beings were once owned and inherited, bought and sold. But on this spot in Ohio, now inside the curved walls of the handsome buildings whose shape echoes the river's meanderings, those same slaves would have been free. Before the Civil War, the Ohio River marked the borderland dividing the Southern slave states from the North. The Ohio was, in song and lore, the Jordan; across it lay the Promised Land.

They also joined in opposing the commission's call for the C.I.A. to cede to the Pentagon the authority for covert paramilitary operations.

title: Time To Quit Iraq (Sort Of)
description: Many Americans now believe that the United States is depleting its military strength, diplomatic leverage and Treasury to pursue unrealistic aims in Iraq. They are right. Democracy seems to interest few Iraqis, given the widespread Shiite proclivity to follow unelected clerics, the Sunni rejection of the principle of majority rule, and the preference of many Kurds for tribe and clan over elected governments. Reconstruction was supposed to advance rapidly with surging oil export revenues, but is hardly gaining on the continuing destruction inflicted by sabotage and thievery. And in any case, it is unlikely that the new Iraqi interim government will be able to oversee meaningful elections in a country where its authority is more widely denied than recognized.
