description: The Bush administration's education program received a devastating setback this week when long-awaited federal data showed that children in charter schools were performing worse on math and reading tests than their counterparts in regular public schools. Among other things, the data casts doubt on a central provision of the No Child Left Behind Act that encourages the states to hand over failing schools to commercial companies and nonprofit community groups that want to run them as charter schools.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Acid Rain Rules Go Into Effect
description: The state has decided to enact the acid rain rules that a New York judge threw out in May, arguing that further delay would endanger public health and the state's natural resources, Erin M. Crotty, left, commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, announced yesterday. The rules, which seek to reduce emissions of nitrogen and sulfur, had been opposed by several energy companies. A State Supreme Court judge invalidated the rules on a technicality but upheld the department's authority to adopt such stringent regulations. The department has appealed the judge's decision. Ms. Crotty said in an interview that she was hopeful that the energy companies that brought the suit would not challenge the emergency regulations. A spokeswoman for NRG Energy, one of the companies, said officials were still reviewing the announcement and had not decided how they would respond. Kirk Semple (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Crackdown On Money Laundering
description: The police began a big nationwide crackdown on money laundering, striking at black-market currency dealers accused of illegally transferring money abroad. Some 800 federal police agents were deployed in eight states to arrest 123 ''doleiros,'' as black-market money changers are known. The biggest sweep took place in the financial capital, So Paulo, where the police arrested Antnio de Oliveira Claramunt, one of the country's best-known currency dealers. Mr. Claramunt is accused of sending about $500 million abroad from 1996 to 2002. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Profit At Airline
description: Swiss International Air Lines reported its first quarterly profit since emerging in 2002 from the remains of the Swissair Group. The profit came as a legal settlement with a former Swissair unit provided a one-time gain. Second-quarter net income was 45 million francs ($36 million), in contrast to a loss of 133 million francs, or 2.52 francs a share, a year earlier, the chief financial officer, Ulrik Svensson, said. Revenue declined 10 percent, to 922 million francs, from 1.03 billion francs. The airline reiterated a forecast of an operating loss for 2004, citing fuel prices. ''Swiss is out of the intensive care unit, but it's still in the hospital,'' the chief executive, Christoph Franz, above, said.

description: Applied Materials Inc., the world's biggest maker of semiconductor production equipment, yesterday reported its largest quarterly profit in almost four years after chip makers doubled purchases of its machines. Its net income of $440.6 million, or 26 cents a share, was in contrast to a loss of $36.8 million, or 2 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales in the third quarter that ended Aug. 1 rose to $2.24 billion, the company said. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., was expected to earn 25 cents, the average of 29 analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Shares of Applied Materials rose 43 cents, to $16.07.

title: CANTOR TO SPIN OFF PERSON-TO-PERSON BROKERAGE UNIT

Once BGC is separate, Cantor will employ 1,100 people globally in investment banking, asset management, institutional fixed-income and equity brokering.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Region's Prices Down In July
description: Prices eased slightly in July after rising steadily for six months, according to data released yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The Consumer Price Index for the New York City region was down 0.2 percent, with prices for items like gasoline, transportation and food purchased at supermarkets all showing declines. Housing prices, which have steadily risen, remained stable, while electricity rose 2.8 percent. Prices rose by 3.4 percent over the six months ending in June, with much of the increase attributable to gas prices that rose more than 30 percent and increases in housing and food costs. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORGENS, FRANK
description: MORGENS--Frank. Born in Lodz, Poland, January 8, 1911, died August 16, 2004. A gentleman in every sense of the word. Marie, his wife of over 60 years, died in 1998. Father of Sylvia Karchmar and Anne Lewin. Grandfather of David and Matthew Lewin, and Lara and Dorian Karchmar. Great grandfather of Benjamin and Dylan Orr; Noah and Milo Sobel-Lewin, and Violet Kotzin. Holocaust survivor. While he and his family were living as Christians in the town of Olsztyn, Poland, he served in the Home Army (the AK). Poland awarded him the Partisan Cross and the Silver Service Medal and he received the Rabbi Harold Schulweis Award for recognizing the obligation of Jews to honor Righteous Gentiles. He personally sustained many individual Gentile rescuers in their material needs, providing for their medical care and the education of their children. ''Years At The Edge of Existence,'' his memoir chronicling the family's wartime experiences, was published in 1996. His bravery and unwavering moral compass saw his family and numerous others safely through the war, and will continue to provide a model for the generations that succeed him. Memorial service Thursday, August 19, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam Ave, 11:15AM.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Court Orders Review Of Riot Cases
description: The Supreme Court ordered new investigations of 2,472 cases filed after Hindu-Muslim violence in Gujarat State in 2002 and dismissed by the police. At least 1,100 Muslims were killed in the rioting. The authorities in Gujarat have been accused of not taking action to stop the riots and doing little to prosecute the rioters. More than half the 4,252 cases filed after the riots were dismissed, while others resulted in acquittals. The Supreme Court has already ordered some cases moved to neighboring Maharashtra State for retrial. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PUTTERMAN, PEARL
description: PUTTERMAN--Pearl. 96, died August 15th. Wife of the late Isaac; mother of Arnold and Susan Putterman; Judy Lewis (Stan); David and Laurie Putterman. Grandmother of Michael, Daniel, Jonathan, Jordan, Tobi and Eric. Greatgrandmother of Abigail, Isaac, Sydney and Oliver. Sister of Leah Janus and aunt to devoted niece Raizi and nephews Barry and Micah. Attorney, teacher, childrens' advocate in family court, a leader in Hadassah, and the voice of numerous recordings in Yiddish for the Blind. She was a woman ahead of her time yet steeped in the traditions and values of her Jewish heritage--family, education and charity towards others. She was blessed with a full, long and healthy life and will be deeply missed but always remembered and appreciated for all that she gave us. Burial is private. description: The convenience store chain 7-Eleven Inc. acquired the automated teller machine network in its stores from the American Express Company for about $44 million to add to its financial services business and increase customer traffic. The purchase involves A.T.M.'s in 5,483 company-operated, franchised and licensed convenience stores in the United States. The acquisition will help 7-Eleven add to financial services, like sales of money orders and check cashing, a 7-Eleven spokeswoman, Margaret Chabris, said. title: Hugo Chvez Wins
description: It is time for President Hugo Chvez's opponents to stop pretending that they speak for most Venezuelans. They do not, as the failure of a recall referendum, promoted by the opposition, decisively demonstrated on Sunday. The reason Mr. Chvez survived the challenge, despite his authoritarian impulses, is not hard to figure out. Unlike most of his recent predecessors, he has made programs directed at the everyday problems of the poor -- illiteracy, the hunger for land and inferior health care -- the central theme of his administration, and he has been able to use higher-than-expected oil revenues to advance social welfare. Some of his programs have been poorly designed and shamelessly used to build and mobilize political support. All the same, they are understandably appreciated by the millions of Venezuelans who have felt like the neglected stepchildren of the country's oil boom.

title: Between Faith and Medicine, How Clear a Line?

Legislators are pondering minimum requirements for medical practice, rules of professional ethics and standards for quality of care. title: TRUE BUT NOT SO TRUE
description: Norma Khouri, below, the author of a best-selling memoir that was withdrawn by her Australian and American publishers over questions about its truth, has admitted that she changed some facts about her background and made up names, dates and locations of some events in the book. But in a television interview broadcast yesterday in Australia, Ms. Khouri insisted that the basic story was true. ''Forbidden Love,'' also published in the United States as ''Honor Lost,'' tells of a female Muslim friend in Jordan who was killed by her father because of her relationship with a Christian man. Ms. Khouri said she had ''literary license'' to make the changes to protect friends still living in Jordan. Rather than living most of her life in Jordan, as she previously claimed, she said in the interview she lived there for only 12 years. EDWARD WYATT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, J. IRWIN
description: MILLER -- J. Irwin. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art note with sorrow the passing of J. Irwin Miller, a businessman, philanthropist, and advocate for exceptional design. Irwin began his relationship with the Modern in 1960, when David Rockefeller introduced him, and his wife Xenia, to the Museum's then curator, Dorothy Miller. Miss Miller suggested some galleries to visit where the couple was introduced to and began collecting works by Wassily Kandinsky, Mark Rothko, Sam Francis, and Milton Resnick. Ten years later, Irwin was elected to MoMA's Board of Trustees and served for five years, after which he became a Life Trustee. Of course, Irwin's greatest legacy is the very town in which he lived. Through the Cummings Engine Foundation, Irwin turned Columbus, Indiana into a living repository of modern architecture by commissioning public works from masters such as Eliel and Eero Saarinen, I.M. Pei, and Richard Meier. He embodied corporate responsibility as one of the first executives to believe that corporations should engage in the communties where their businesses were located. In doing so, Irwin forever changed the face of a city. He will never be forgotten, but he will be sorely missed. We extend our sympathies to the entire family. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Patricia Phelps de Cisneros, Chairman, Trustee Committee on Architecture and Design Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, N.Y.

Pirro. Prosecutors said that last August, the woman, Wanda Green, 18, of Yonkers, and another roommate subjected their 15-year-old roommate to forcible sexual contact for hours at St. Vincent's Westchester Hospital in Harrison. The victim, who has severe developmental disabilities, was spending her first night away from her parents. Mrs. Pirro said the plea was accepted to spare the victim and her family the trauma of reliving the crime in court. Ms. Green is to be sentenced Nov. 1 for the crime, a felony punishable by up to seven years in state prison. The other roommate, 15, pleaded guilty earlier. Lisa Foderaro (NYT)

title: TROUBLE FOR 'SPRINGER' ON BROADWAY
description: A dispute among producers over the budget of ''Jerry Springer -- The Opera'' could put the Broadway transfer of the West End musical in jeopardy. The irreverent show, which imagines the talk show host in hell, is to open on Broadway in October 2005. As was originally reported in The New York Post, Allan McKeown, one of the producers, said the show should not be mounted for more than $7 million, considerably less than the $11 million that his partner, Avalon Promotions Ltd., is aiming for. ''I believe that we have to reduce its scale for it to be a success,'' Mr. McKeown said. He added that the cast of 33 would need to be trimmed to 15. ''I hope we reach an agreement, but until such time, the New York production will not go on,'' said Mr. McKeown, who has two other Broadway shows in the works for next year, including the musical ''Lennon,'' featuring John Lennon songs, and a star vehicle with Tracey Ullman, left. A representative for Avalon Promotions said they didn't need Mr. McKeown to mount the show. ''Avalon Promotions holds the American rights to 'Jerry Springer -- The Opera,' and Allan McKeown is not involved,'' said a spokesman for the production. ''They look forward to producing the show on Broadway next season.'' JASON ZINOMAN

title: Shopping on 1, Sleeping on 2
description: IN Lincoln Park, one of Chicago's more crowded and costly city neighborhoods, Tania and Scott Janos can shop as if they lived in the suburbs. There's the Bed Bath & Beyond on North Broadway, the Borders, the Petsmart, the T. J. Maxx. Mr. Janos, 34, said a ''pretty swank'' Home Depot is nearby, but not as nearby as Best Buy, which is just downstairs in their 57-unit condo building, Lincoln Park Commons. The Best Buy, at 30,000 square feet, takes up most of the street level of the building, on a site that once held a Chicago Transit Authority bus barn.

title: CONMED TO BUY BARD'S ENDOSCOPIC UNIT FOR $80 MILLION
description: The ConMed Corporation, a maker of surgical instruments, said yesterday that it would buy the endoscopic unit of C.R. Bard Inc. for $80 million, gaining products used to treat diseases of the digestive tract. Bard's endoscopic business, with sales of about $54 million last year, is based in Billerica, Mass., and employs about 200 workers, the companies said. ConMed, which specializes in medical instruments for sports medicine and had sales of $497.1 million last year, said the purchase would add about 12 cents a share to next year's earnings, before certain costs. ConMed, based in Utica, N.Y., said it would leave the endoscopic business mostly intact.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Islamic Terrorists Held
description: Five suspected Islamic terrorists have been detained in Russia in recent months, an Interior Ministry official said. The official, Yury Demidov, said one of the detained men is a member of Hizb ut-Tahrir and has lived illegally in Russia since 2000 and established secret cells, according to the Interfax news agency. Hizb ut-Tahrir aims to put Islamic leaders into power in Arab countries, but says it pursues peaceful methods. Three others are accused of being members of the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan, a group that fought alongside Al Qaeda and the Taliban. The fifth is a Tajik accused of organizing bombings in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. Russia is considering extraditing the Uzbeks and Tajik to their home nations. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Bomb Materials at Campus Reactors
description: While experts worry that loosely guarded nuclear materials in foreign countries might fall into the hands of terrorists, six civilian research reactors at American universities continue to use weapons-grade uranium that could go a long way toward making a nuclear bomb. Although the reactors may not be particularly tempting targets for terrorists or criminals, they are disturbingly accessible ones -- their security is far less rigorous than that imposed by the government for its own bomb-grade uranium stockpiles. It is time for the Energy Department to accelerate the universities' conversion to less dangerous fuels.

title: How Can You Tell if a Violin Is Really, Really Happy? Listen
description: The German violinist Christian Tetzlaff may have been exhausted by the end of his two performances at the Mostly Mozart Festival on Tuesday night, but one imagines that his violin was supremely happy. After all, the instrument had scaled two peaks of the literature in a single night: Mozart's Sinfonia Concertante and a Sonata and a Partita by Bach. It's hard to speculate about the meaning of bliss for a box of wood with strings, but this combination of music might be pretty close.

Buffett, files such requests to prevent copycat investing; it sought one year of confidential treatment for a security it held in the fourth quarter of 2003 and the first quarter of 2004. In an order Tuesday, the S.E.C. denied the request without identifying the security. The rejection means Berkshire may have to file amended disclosure statements for the quarters. The S.E.C., which denied a similar request by Berkshire in 2002, said the company had failed to show how disclosing the holding would hurt it. Berkshire's chief financial officer, Marc D. Hamburg, said that he had not received or been informed of the S.E.C. letter.

title: BRITISH REGULATOR INVESTIGATES CITIGROUP'S BOND TRADES
description: Britain's market regulator, the Financial Services Authority, said yesterday that it was investigating ''unusual trading activity'' by Citigroup in the European bond markets on Aug. 2. The bank sold about 11 billion euros' worth of government debt over the course of a few minutes that day, most of it through electronic trades, then bought some of it back at much lower prices less than an hour later, bond traders say. Though Citigroup's activities were not illegal, they angered rival bond houses, who said the bank violated an unspoken agreement not to flood the market to drive down prices. The regulator said the investigation might lead to disciplinary proceedings. Citigroup said it was cooperating in the inquiry. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intuit Says Loss Widened To $42 Million
description: Intuit Inc., the world's largest maker of tax preparation software, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss widened as the introduction of products for small businesses increased costs. The net loss widened to $42.1 million, or 22 cents a share, from $24.7 million, or 12 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales at the company, based in Mountain View, Calif., rose 13 percent, to $275.9 million in the quarter, which ended July 31. Expenses rose 16 percent, to $331.9 million. Intuit, the maker of TurboTax software, gets most of its sales during the United States tax season of January through April and typically reports a loss in the fourth and first quarters. The company is expanding its QuickBooks software products to tap small businesses, many with fewer than 100 workers, that do their own accounting and bookkeeping chores. Shares fell 29 cents, to $38.80, in extended trading. They rose 4 cents, to $39.09, in regular trading. Intuit said its loss this quarter would be 25 cents to 29 cents a share, compared with a 24-cent average estimate by 10 analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. The company said sales would be $251 million to $263 million, compared with the $265.5 million average estimate of nine analysts. For the fiscal year 2005 ending on July 31, 2005, the company said it expected a profit of $1.82 to $1.90 a share on sales of $1.97 billion to $2.02 billion.

description: Shares of Network Appliance Inc., whose products store and distribute data for clients including the Vatican and Coca-Cola, rose about 13 percent after the company said profit and sales could top analyst estimates in the current quarter, the company's fiscal second quarter. The shares rose $2.31, to $19.70. The company expects to earn 13 cents or 14 cents a share in the quarter, on sales that will rise to as much as $379.9 million, executives said yesterday. It was expected to earn 13 cents a share, the average estimate of 22 analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call, on sales of $370.9 million. Network Appliance, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said its first-quarter net income jumped 73 percent, to $46.9 million, as sales surged 38 percent, in part because it took customers from the Hewlett-Packard Company. Corporate governance regulations require customers to store and copy more data, fueling demand for Network Appliance's storage computers and software.

title: Bush Campaign Adviser Quits as Sexual Misconduct Case Is Recalled
description: Deal W. Hudson, the publisher of the conservative Roman Catholic journal Crisis and the architect of a Republican effort to court Catholic voters, says he is resigning as an adviser to the Bush campaign because of a Catholic newspaper's investigation into accusations of sexual misconduct involving a female student at a college where he once taught.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Greenport: Height Of Planned Cement Plant To Be Lower
description: St. Lawrence Cement, under pressure from environment advocates and citizens groups, has decided to reduce the height of a proposed coal-burning cement plant to be built here by 115 feet. The company said yesterday that the new design would increase the project's cost by $33 million but would ensure that the plant would not be seen from more than 90 percent of the surrounding region. The concession fell well short of placating opponents concerned that a lower smokestack would make the surrounding population more vulnerable to harmful emissions. ''On first blush it appears to be minor window dressing on a flawed proposal,'' said Ned Sullivan, the president of Scenic Hudson, one group in a coalition opposed to the plant. Kirk Semple (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIRD, RUTH CAROLINE (NEE CLARK)
description: BIRD--Ruth Caroline (nee Clark). Loving wife to the late James R. Bird and devoted mother to Ray Bird and his wife, Anita. She passed away after a long illness in Point Pleasant, NJ, on Monday, August 16, 2004. A longtime resident of Plainfield and Bay Head, NJ, she was a devout parishioner of All Saints Church in Bay Head, serving both as president of the Altar Guild and an officer of the Women's Guild. She was a past president of the Junior League and the Garden Club, both of Plainfield. She was also an active member of Bay Head Yacht Club, the Seaweeders Club, and the Clams Investment Club and the Nassau Club of Princeton. Born in Plainfield and raised in Bound Brook, she was an alumna of the Hartridge School, St. Mary's Hall, and Douglass College. A funeral service commemorating Ruth Bird's life will be held at All Saints Church in Bay Head on Friday, August 20. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations kindly be given to the Altar Guild, All Saints Church, 500 Lake Avenue, Bay Head, NJ 08742. For information, call Van Hise and Callagan Funeral Home in Point Pleasant Beach.

title: Youth and Experience Join To Honor a Ballet Veteran
description: Eleanor D'Antuono began her long career performing with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, which she joined at the ripe old age of 14. She went on to dance with the Joffrey Ballet and most notably with American Ballet Theater, where she performed for 25 years before leaving to teach, stage ballets and judge international ballet competitions. A ballerina who could perform just about everything, sometimes at very short notice, she has been the ultimate trouper but also a dancer known for the obvious pleasure she has taken in her work and in the passing along of her heritage.

description: GlaxoSmithKline, the European drug maker, gave up a fight to protect a patent for its top diabetes medication in China. The company said it believed that it could protect Avandia because it had two other patents on the treatment.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Merger Of Cigarette Licensing Urged
description: State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi called yesterday for the creation of a joint state and city license for cigarette vendors after an audit showed that the convoluted system now in place has led to sales by unlicensed vendors and underpaid state taxes. His proposal was one of several recommendations in a report calling for greater coordination between city and state licensing agencies. Retailers, wholesalers and distributors who sell cigarettes in the city are required to have both a city and a state license. The city's license -- which must be renewed every two years -- is issued by the city's Department of Finance and Department of Consumer Affairs. The state certification -- which must be renewed annually -- is issued by the state Department of Taxation and Finance. The report noted that more than 3,500 cigarette retailers have a valid state license but not a city one; of the surveyed city vendors, 153 -- or 48 percent -- had underpaid state taxes for a total of nearly $613,000 in 2002. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Martha Graham Center Wins Dance Rights
description: The United States Court of Appeals in Manhattan ruled yesterday in favor of the Martha Graham Dance Center in its three-year legal battle over the rights to Graham's dances. The rights had been claimed by Ronald Protas, her heir and the director of the Graham Trust, which licenses the dances. The court found that the center owns Graham's sets and costumes and all but nine of her dances, and it directed Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum of Federal District Court, who had found in favor of the center, to reconsider the issue of ownership of seven dances, including ''Phaedra.'' Mr. Protas's ownership of ''Seraphic Dialogue'' and ''Acrobats of God'' was confirmed. But he was found to have breached his fiduciary duties to the Graham school and center, which he once directed, and to be liable for damages. Jennifer Dunning (NYT)

title: A Decommissioned El Building Is Back in the Loop

A former power station for the El dating to 1880, top, has a restaurant in its future, for it has been acquired by Jerry Kleiner, the owner of several award-winning Chicago restaurants. Mark Steinke, a banker turned antiques dealer, bottom, has already turned the front of the building, into Revival, a store on three levels selling antiques, stained glass and objects like a Pan Am Globe, below, which was made in the 1940's and given to Pan Am's top travel agents. The globe, which turned up in a small Wisconsin town, sold last week for $700. Revival also sells architectural fragments, including some terra-cotta panels that seem to have come from other South Loop buildings. Revival, 19 East 21st Street, is open Monday through Saturday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., and Sundays from noon to 4 p.m.; (312) 842-4002. FRED BERNSTEIN

title: Apartment Dwellers in Need of a Nursery Pitch a Tent
description: Colette Trang McDonough, right, 9 months, has a room of her own that is portable, unbreakable and won't fall down. Her parents, Michael McDonough, a Manhattan architect, and Corinne Trang, a cookbook author, wanted to build her a room in their SoHo loft, but not something permanent. So they pitched a tent for her, the Eureka! Tetragon 8. It is 60 inches high, 7 1/2 feet wide, 8 1/2 feet long, and $79.90 at www.thetentstore.com. The tent, designed for camping, weighs less than 10 pounds and its pyramidlike structure, Mr. McDonough said, ''is inherently stable.'' Bright, interlocking rubber mats printed with numbers and letters protect Colette if she falls. You could say she is a happy camper.

description: WHITE--Marjorie Powers. 79, of NYC, at Heron Island, ME, died August 8th, 2004. Married to Willard D. White Jr., mother of Shawn, Stephen, Catherine and Nicholas White, and grandmother of Zoe Frederick and Nicholas Jr., Katie and Patrick White. She was the daughter of Frank T. Powers Sr. and Mary D. Powers of Glen Cove, NY. She was an enthusiastic alumna of Sarah Lawrence College. Later she attended the Art Students League of NY and the Academy of Fine Arts in Florence, Italy. Though a life long artist and writer, she was shy about publishing. She was a great admirer of light-moon, stars, Christmas and sunsets. Travel, the subject matter of many of her poems, prints and photographs, found its seeds in her early association with the Experiment in International Living. She said she would get another cat in a minute, go to Mexico in a minute, but she did not want to go to Australia unless Willard did--then she would go in a minute. Her love of books and libraries was voluminous. Memorial donations may be made to NY Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, Room 73, NY, NY 10018. There will be no services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, J. IRWIN
description: MILLER -- J. Irwin. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art note with sorrow the passing of J. Irwin Miller, a businessman, philanthropist, and advocate for exceptional design. Irwin began his relationship with the Modern in 1960, when David Rockefeller introduced him, and his wife Xenia, to the Museum's then curator, Dorothy Miller. Miss Miller suggested some galleries to visit where the couple was introduced to and began collecting works by Wassily Kandinsky, Mark Rothko, Sam Francis, and Milton Resnick. Ten years later, Irwin was elected to MoMA's Board of Trustees and served for five years, after which he became a Life Trustee. Of course, Irwin's greatest legacy is the very town in which he lived. Through the Cummings Engine Foundation, Irwin turned Columbus, Indiana into a living repository of modern architecture by commissioning public works from masters such as Eliel and Eero Saarinen, I.M. Pei, and Richard Meier. He embodied corporate responsibility as one of the first executives to believe that corporations should engage in the communties where their businesses were located. In doing so, Irwin forever changed the face of a city. He will never be forgotten, but he will be sorely missed. We extend our sympathies to the entire family. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Patricia Phelps de Cisneros, Chairman, Trustee Committee on Architecture and Design Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, N.Y.

title: The New Hanging Chads
description: One of the scandals of the last presidential election was the large number of voters who were denied the right to vote because of foul-ups in the election system, like errors in the voting rolls or problems in directing voters to their correct polling places. As a result, Congress required that this year, voters be allowed to fill out provisional ballots if their eligibility is in question, and that the validity of those ballots be determined later on. It was a crucial reform, but in many places the ballots aren't working out the way they are supposed to because of poor procedures and overly technical regulations. If this year's election is close, there are likely to be furious battles over how these rules were applied. While there is still time, state and local officials should fix the provisional-voting problems.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Retail Sales Surge
description: Retail sales in Brazil rose in June for the seventh consecutive month, gaining 12.8 percent from the year-earlier period, the government's statistics agency said. It was the biggest monthly gain in retail sales since 2001. Furniture and household appliance sales led the surge for the fourth consecutive month, soaring 36.3 percent, while clothing and shoe sales climbed 14.15 percent. For a second consecutive month, sales rose in 26 of Brazil's 27 states. Retail sales are up 10.9 percent this year, suggesting that the country's economic rebound is being driven by an increase in domestic demand as well as a booming export sector. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Petroleum Taxes Cut
description: India cut taxes on petroleum products to curb the effect of high energy prices on growth and on inflation, the finance ministry said. The customs duty on gasoline and diesel fuel was cut to 15 percent from 20 percent and the excise tax on the products was cut to 23 percent from 26 percent, the ministry said. India's wholesale price index rose to 7.6 percent in July, a three-and-a-half-year high. Oil is the country's biggest import. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: More Hospitals Took Children's Glands
description: The biopharmaceutical company Novo Nordisk confirmed that in the 1980's it received 2,500 pituitary glands from 32 hospitals around Ireland that had removed the glands from the bodies of dead children without parental consent. The practice of removing children's glands ended in the 1980's and was previously thought to have been limited to Dublin. The glands were used to make human growth hormone, which is now created synthetically, and hospitals received just a few dollars for each gland. A parents' organization has criticized a three-year High Court investigation into the scandal for spending $18 million without any results and has accused government authorities of allowing organ removals on a larger scale. ''Children who died from cardiac problems had virtually every organ in their body removed,'' said Fionnuala O'Reilly, chairwoman of the parents' group. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Volkswagen Plant Strike
description: Almost 10,000 workers walked off the job at the Volkswagen plant in Puebla in a pay dispute. The plant, about 80 miles southeast of Mexico City, exports the new Beetle to 80 countries and is Volkswagen's only North American factory. The company and union leadership had agreed to a 4.5 percent pay raise and an additional $100 a year in food coupons for each worker but the union's rank and file voted against the agreement. Last year, the union agreed to accept a four-day workweek with the fifth day at 30 percent pay to avoid 1,800 layoffs. ''But now the workers are feeling it and we want to recuperate our salaries,'' said Miguel ngel Galn, a union spokesman. A strike in 2001 shut down production for 18 days. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: ARBITRON REACHES DEAL TO PROVIDE RATINGS TO INFINITY
description: Arbitron Inc., which compiles television and radio ratings, said it had agreed to supply quarterly radio ratings to the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation unit of Viacom Inc., setting off a 10 percent gain in Arbitron's share price. Arbitron said on Tuesday that it would supply 185 Infinity stations with audience ratings in 42 markets. Financial terms were not disclosed. Arbitron said in June that Infinity had decided not to renew its contract. With the agreement, Arbitron's 2004 earnings will rise to $1.75 to $1.79 a share, from $1.63 last year, the company said in a separate statement. Stock in Arbitron, based in New York, rose $3.35 yesterday, to $37.80 a share.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Telecom Profit
description: China Mobile (Hong Kong), the listed unit of China's biggest cellphone operator, posted a 7.8 percent increase in first-half profit on a 23 percent increase in its subscriber base. Its net profit in the six months ended June 30 rose to 18.83 billion yuan ($2.27 billion) from 17.47 billion yuan a year earlier. Revenue rose to 86.42 billion yuan from 76.66 billion yuan. The results were slightly better than analysts had forecast.

title: COST OF BENEFITS CITED AS FACTOR IN SLUMP IN JOBS
description: Correction Appended

title: A Museum Of Indians That Is Also For Them
description: A century ago George Gustav Heye, a New Yorker, traveled across the United States, gathering up Indian objects by the boxcar. All told, he amassed 800,000 examples of Indian art and life, which will have a new home at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of the American Indian, which opens here on Sept. 21.

title: AGSTAR OFFERS $650 MILLION FOR FARM CREDIT SERVICES
description: AgStar Financial Services made an unsolicited offer to buy the rural cooperative Farm Credit Services of America for $650 million in cash, topping a $600 million bid last month by the Rabobank Group, a Dutch bank. As a condition of the Rabobank transaction, Farm Credit Services, which makes loans in Iowa, Nebraska, South Dakota and Wyoming, would have to withdraw from the United States Farm Credit System and pay an exit fee of more than $800 million. AgStar, which is also a member of Farm Credit System, said its offer would let Farm Credit Services stay in the borrower-owned network.

title: Sports of The Times; A Step Back To the Essence Of Competing
description: SHUT off the cameras, close down the venues, turn out the lights.

title: Israel Court Orders Government to Reply to Hague Ruling
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 19  The Israeli Supreme Court today ordered the government to produce a statement in the next 30 days assessing the ramifications of a nonbinding ruling of the International Court of Justice in The Hague that declares the Israeli security barrier around the West Bank to be illegal.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Ouch! Insiders Feel an Unexpected Pinch
description: Investors' hesitance about Google's offering cost some very important people -- the insiders -- millions of dollars. Google's top executives wound up taking out only a third as much as they had hoped when the company priced its offering last night. And the venture capitalists, who had nurtured Google and had expected to take out more money than anyone else, wound up not selling any shares at all.

title: Hiding in Ads Is Campaign For a Book On Politics
description: For the past week, enigmatic ''Retro vs. Metro'' advertisements have created a buzz among newspaper and Internet readers.

title: Hiding Places In Plain Sight
description: THEY may be called blanket chests, but for the space-starved homeowner, these perennials of American design can be used to store anything. They swallow up out-of-season clothes and bedding and many do double duty as benches at the end of a bed or in a hallway. Some versions are soft and stack on closet shelves or can be squashed into an armoire.

title: Restoring Antique Artistry in Reed and Cane
description: IT was 7:20 one morning last March when a wayward car careered off Route 6A here, landing smack in a window of Leslie Curtis Antiques & Design. The side wall was, Ms. Curtis recalled, ''smashed to smithereens.'' If the window and door were easy to replace, what sat behind them was not. It was a small, square wedding cake of a wicker table, decked with curlicues, bird cages, flowers and braids. The late-1890's confection, made by the Heywood-Wakefield Company, bore a price tag of $3,800 -- until the impact left its oak top in three pieces and many of its whimsical details wrecked.

title: A Cruel Fate in Jerusalem: Will Mahdi, 6, Walk Again?
description: Mahdi Abu Snaineh, 6 years old, lies nearly immobile on a hospital bed on sheets covered with toy trains. He cannot move his legs or his left arm. A breathing tube snakes into his pert nose. His lungs are full of fluid. He has shrapnel close to his spinal cord and his aorta.

title: Benicia Journal; Referee at the Crossroads Of Humans and Wildlife
description: The uneasy truce between human and wild looms large in California. And lately there has been plenty of breaking news from the trenches: A mountain lion shot dead in Palo Alto. ''Pig Crossing'' warning signs springing up on Highway 1 near Carmel after collisions involving feral pigs and cars. Wild turkeys overrunning Sonoma County and sabotaging the morning commute on Main Street in Moraga.

title: Zambrano and the Mets Pray It All Works Out
description: The visiting clubhouse was just about empty late Tuesday night when Victor Zambrano slid two strands of white beads off his neck and studied the crosses attached to them.

title: A Reflective View at Ground Zero, With Images From Your Sponsors
description: HAVING mournfully contemplated the place where 2,749 people perished on Sept. 11, 2001, you may be ready to plan your next ski vacation.

title: S.E.C. Orders Mutual Funds To Cease Incentive Pay
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday ordered mutual funds to stop paying higher commissions to brokers who promote the companies' funds. The agency also required portfolio managers to reveal investments in funds they supervise.

title: Played in Court, Tapes Show Judge Coaching Lawyer And Taking Cash
description: Surveillance tapes made last year in a Brooklyn matrimonial judge's office and played publicly by prosecutors for the first time yesterday show the judge, Gerald P. Garson, offering a lawyer detailed instructions on how to argue a case before him. He also assures the lawyer that if he follows them, ''The worst possible scenario is a win.''

title: Toppled Power Lines Everywhere Are Posing A Herculean Task to Get the Lights Back On
description: ''Life goes a lot better in Florida with electricity,'' Gov. Jeb Bush said on Saturday, a day after Hurricane Charley struck, as he toured downtown Punta Gorda, where decapitated utility poles left electric cables at an altitude of four feet, making it difficult to cross U.S. 41.

title: Ownership Of Gazprom Questioned; Shares Fall
description: A Russian lawmaker has demanded an investigation into whether foreigners illegally bought Gazprom shares that only Russians may own, sending the stock down 13 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RACHELSON, CHARLES COOKY
description: RACHELSON--Charles Cooky of New York City on August 17, 2004. Founder and owner of Cooky's Steak Pubs, Inc. Beloved husband of Sonia. Devoted father of Joy, Judi, and Jani. Cherished grandfather of Jackie, Matthew, Alex, Jay, Luke and Sean. Proud father-in-law of Leonard and David. Funeral services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Thursday, August 19 at 11:30AM.

title: Shares of Google Jump as It Debuts on Nasdaq
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18  Bringing to a close the most anticipated stock offering since the bursting of the dot-com bubble in 2000, Google made its debut on Wall Street today as shares in the Internet search engine company were up nearly 20 percent at the close of market, $100.34 a share.

description: For the first time in decades, foreign affairs and national security issues have emerged in the American presidential campaign as greater concerns among voters than economic matters, according to a new survey.

title: Judge Orders U.S. to Release Data on Detainees It Holds Overseas
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has ordered the government to release information on the treatment of detainees held at military bases or other facilities overseas, including official policies and records requested months ago by the American Civil Liberties Union under the Freedom of Information Act.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Carteret: Apartment Building To Be Wheelchair-Accessible
description: A developer accused of failing to design and build features for the handicapped in one of its apartment complexes will make the complex more accessible to people using wheelchairs under the terms of an agreement announced by the Justice Department. Under settlement of a suit filed in April, Carteret Terrace, a development company from Woodbridge that built the eight-building Meriden Square Apartments, will establish a $45,000 fund to compensate those affected. The architect, Feinberg & Associates of Gibbsboro, has agreed to pay $5,000 in compensation, according to Justice officials.

title: Ad Spending Rises For Year's First Half
description: Advertising spending figures for the first half of 2004 indicated that the stop-and-start recovery seemed to be continuing.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about students from the Mount Sinai School of Medicine who toured East Harlem for lessons in local culture, diet and health misspelled the names of two of the foods some of the students sampled and described one of them incorrectly. The fried codfish fritter is a bacalaito, not a baccelaito; the fritter filled with meat is an alcapurria, not an acapurriea, and it is typically made with plantains and yucca or taro root, not corn meal.

title: An All-in-One Device With Printing for Two
description: It used to be that when summer ended and students headed back to class, they needed nothing much more than a few books, a three-ring binder and some sharpened No.2 pencils. But these days, back-to-school shopping includes ever more high-tech tools.

title: New York's Lobbying Law Is Ruled Unconstitutional
description: A state court ruled on Wednesday that parts of New York's lobbying law are unconstitutional because they allow the state to fine lobbyists without giving them proper hearings.

description: ARKIN--Albert J. 04/17/1909 - 08/19/1985. Dad -Thank you for all your hard work. Wish you had had more fun. With love, Joan

title: Bomb Is Defused Near a Villa Where Berlusconi Met With Blair
description: The police defused a bomb early Wednesday morning in Porto Rotondo, Sardinia, the town where hours earlier Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi had entertained the British prime minister, Tony Blair, and his wife, Cherie.

description: The rest of the world has contributed so little to the fight against AIDS that the United States cannot make its full contribution this year, President Bush's global AIDS coordinator said yesterday.

title: At Last, Stone Basins That Won't Sink the Budget
description: Tired of plain-Jane bathroom and kitchen sinks? Until now, stone sinks have usually come with high prices -- Artistic Tile's marble farmhouse sink, uncarved, is $2,750; Ann Sacks's white onyx 16-inch-diameter sink is $1,600. At Ex:Inc., known for Italian ceramic tile and stone flooring, there are good deals on stone sinks from Turkey, India and Israel in marble, limestone, travertine and sandstone. A 16 1/2-inch carved sandstone sink for a bathroom (above) is $600. A basin in polished marble, as below, starts at $300. A rectangular sandstone farmhouse kitchen sink, 32 inches by 22 inches by 12 inches deep, with carving is $1,900. Uncarved it is $1,500. Ex:Inc. is at 155 East 56th Street; www.exinc.org or (212) 758-2593. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Interactive World Cup To Be Announced
description: Microsoft, Electronic Arts and FIFA, the worldwide governing body of soccer, are expected to announce today the FIFA Interactive World Cup at the Leipzig Games Convention in Germany. The three-month worldwide contest, which will be held from October until December, will involve a soccer video game tournament using Electronic Arts' FIFA Football 2005 played on Microsoft's Xbox console and Xbox Live online service. The finals of the tournament will be played in Zurich in December in conjunction with the announcement of the world soccer player of the year. Electronic Arts has been successful with its FIFA-branded line of soccer games for Microsoft, Nintendo and Sony platforms, but this is the first year the company had made its games available for the Xbox Live. Jack Bell (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Concern At Detention Of 39 Gay Men
description: French gay rights groups have joined Human Rights Watch and the United Nations AIDS agency in expressing concern over the detention of 39 homosexual men since Aug. 9. The groups called for the immediate release of the men, who were arrested in Katmandu after a Nepalese lawyer asked the Supreme Court to close the Blue Diamond Society, a Nepalese gay rights group, saying it wanted to ''to legalize the homosexual activities.'' David Rohde (NYT)

title: Sharon Rebuffed by Party, as Arafat Admits Making Mistakes
description: The leaders of Israel and the Palestinians faced deep dissension in their constituencies on Wednesday, with Yasir Arafat making a rare admission of personal error to those seeking change, and Ariel Sharon suffering a rebuff from his own party.

title: 2 Big Carriers At O'Hare To Cut Flights
description: The nation's two largest airlines, American and United, announced on Wednesday that they would cut flights at O'Hare International Airport to ease congestion that has been delaying flights from coast to coast.

title: The Sports Report
description: TENNIS -- ''I'm just not hitting the ball like I used to,'' said Jon Gretz of Holland. ''I think I'm going to temporarily up my dosage.'' When asked about his surprise defeat by an unrated Swede, he said: ''Doig responds well to steroids and for that he should be commended. But he also showed himself a gentleman when he thanked his supplier, the unsung hero in all this. That was true sportsmanship, which is almost forgotten in today's 'anything to win' atmosphere.''

title: Bobby Fischer's Fiance Is Fine With Being a Pawn
description: TOKYO Aug. 19  In a high-stakes chess game with Japanese immigration authorities, Miyoko Watai, the freshly minted fiancee of Bobby Fischer, acknowledged today that the imprisoned American chess master might be using her as a "pawn."

title: In the Classroom, Web Logs Are the New Bulletin Boards
description: LAST spring, when Marisa L. Dudiak's second-grade class in Frederick County, Md., returned from a field trip to a Native American farm, all the students wanted to do was talk about what they saw. But instead of leading a discussion about the trip, Mrs. Dudiak had the students sign on to their classroom Web log.

description: BUTLER--Margaret Kiley, 92, of Whiting, NJ, died Tuesday, August 17 at the Keswick Pines Lifecare in Whiting. She was born in Peabody, MA and resided in Brooklyn, NY and Waldwick, NJ, before moving to Whiting six years ago. She was a registered nurse. Mrs. Butler was the beloved wife of the late Dr. Joseph I. Butler, and loving mother and mother-in-law of Dr. David and Mary Ann Butler of Norwood, NJ; Brian Butler of California; Bobby and Betty Butler of Breezy Point, NY; Virginia and Raymond Gehan of Barnegat, NJ, and the late Joseph ''Jay'' Butler and Carol Butler; and the late Margaret Butler. Cherished grandmother of 15 grandchildren and 9 great-grandchildren. Dear sister of David T. Kiley of Blacklick, Ohio. Relatives and friends may call from 2PM to 4PM and 7PM to 9PM on Thursday at the Joseph G. Duffy Funeral Home, at 255 9th St, Bklyn, with a Funeral Mass Friday at 9:45 AM at Saint Saviour Church, Eighth Ave, Bklyn

title: Spotting Signposts to Higher Education
description: ON the last day of sixth grade, as my eldest daughter prepared to graduate to the unknown world of middle school, her teacher gave a final assignment: list on a sheet of paper both your short-and long-term goals in life.

title: Grard Souzay, 85, a Baritone Revered for Art Song Repertory
description: Grard Souzay, the French baritone who was one of the 20th century's finest interpreters of art songs, died on Tuesday at his home in Cap d'Antibes, France. He was 85.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about plans by Advanced Micro Devices, the semiconductor maker, to ship chips based on an advanced production method, the 90-nanometer manufacturing process, referred incorrectly to problems that a rival, Intel, is having with the process. While Intel is indeed delaying a projection television chip, the delay is unrelated to the new process.

title: Selling Houston Warts and All, Especially Warts
description: The heat. The humidity. The hurricanes. The flying cockroaches. The refineries. The flooding. The list of factors that make this city challenging, particularly in the steamy month of August, goes on, many Houstonians acknowledge.

title: Curtiss to Acquire Synergy
description: The Curtiss-Wright Corporation, a maker of electronic controls and sensors for aircraft, agreed to buy Synergy Microsystems Inc. for $49 million to build its position in military and commercial markets.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Aug. 10 about running techniques misstated the achievements of one runner, Brook Thomas. Mr. Thomas was an all-American while running for Stanford University in cross country, and competed in the Olympic marathon trial in 1972, but dropped out before the finish. He did not come in fourth.

title: Opposition Rejects Audit Plan in Venezuela Recall Vote Dispute
description: After demanding an audit of voting results upon failing to oust President Hugo Chvez in a recall referendum, representatives of Venezuela's opposition movement said Wednesday that they would refuse to take part in or recognize the review, asserting that the audit would fail to detect the deception that they insist took place.

title: Antiwar Group Asks Court To Allow Central Park Protest
description: The group planning what could become the largest demonstration marking the Republican National Convention took the city to court yesterday in its quest to rally in Central Park the day before the convention begins.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about resurgent neo-Nazism in France referred imprecisely to the timing of the release of 14 Alsatians convicted in 1953 of participating in a massacre at Oradour, France, in 1944. Thirteen received amnesty almost immediately but one was not released from prison until 1959. The article also misstated at one point the surname of an artist from the Alsatian village of Hipsheim who was interviewed about a recent rally of neo-Nazis there. He is Luis Branco, not ''Mr. Lucas.''

description: Federal and city officials said yesterday they had arrested scores of immigrants in New York City, who were facing possible deportation to their home countries because of their convictions in sex crimes.

title: Past Arrests Could Play a Role In Prosecution of Protesters
description: Something unusual happened in State Supreme Court in Manhattan in April, when more than a dozen antiwar protesters who had been convicted of disorderly conduct were to be sentenced.

title: Corrections

McGreevey of New Jersey, who have supported him in the wake of his announcement that he is gay, transposed the maiden name and married name of the founder of the Straight Spouse Network, a group that counsels heterosexual spouses of homosexuals. She is Amity Pierce Buxton, not Buxton Pierce.

title: Post-Hurricane Duty? It Could Be Worse, A Veteran of Iraq Says
description: Sgt. Darren Cockerham, the son of a geologist, can pinpoint one tiny difference between Florida and Iraq: On Florida's beaches, the grains of sand are square. In the baked Iraqi desert, they are round.

title: Firewall Protection Without the Conflicts
description: Q. I understand that Microsoft's Service Pack 2 for Windows XP, a new update, includes improved firewall protection. I currently use Norton Personal Firewall; will any incompatibility result when both firewalls are installed, and is one better than the other?

title: Unable to Acquire Dampier, Knicks Settle for Baker
description: Isiah Thomas tried, but neither trade possibilities nor the midlevel salary exception nor the allure of New York City could put Erick Dampier in a Knicks uniform. So with Dampier on the verge of finding a new place to play, heading from the Golden State Warriors to the Dallas Mavericks yesterday, Thomas, the Knicks' president, settled on his backup plan for a backup center, re-signing Vin Baker.

title: Classes Of Last Resort
description: The United States Olympic basketball team's gold medal hopes would be significantly diminished if it were forced to shoot at a rim that was 11 feet high rather than 10 feet like its competition's. The gold might well end up in Lithuania -- but would this mean that the winning team from Vilnius was better on the court than the Americans? Of course not. Rather, it would establish that in an unfair competitive environment, people and institutions with real advantages will normally win.

title: A 'War President' Reinforces His Military Positions
description: Nearly three years after the Sept. 11 attacks transformed him into what he calls a ''war president,'' and 76 days before an election that will probably turn in large part on national security issues, George W. Bush is still trying to burnish his credentials as commander in chief.

title: In Climax to a Tumultuous 4-Day Debate, Iraq Chooses an Assembly
description: After four marathon days of back-room bargaining and strident debate, a political conference here selected a national assembly on Wednesday, putting Iraq on the road to becoming a constitutional democracy in a jumbled process that never included a formal vote.

title: Accounts
description: Shell Oil Co., Houston, part of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, has begun a review for the creative duties on the Quaker State account, which have been handled since 1999 by Tucker Hampel Stefanides & Partners, New York. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $25 million. Tucker Hampel will take part, along with Doner, Southfield, Mich.; the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group; and the Detroit office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group. A decision in the review, managed by Roth Associates, New York, is expected in September.

title: US Airways Chairman Steps Up Pressure for Cuts
description: The chairman of US Airways, David G. Bronner, said yesterday that its employees must agree to a third round of wage and benefit cuts worth $800 million in the next 30 days or the airline could be liquidated.

title: Despite Setback, Sharon to Proceed With Withdrawal
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 19 — The Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, said today that he would press ahead with his plan to pull soldiers and settlers out of the Gaza Strip despite the repudiation of his own party in nonbinding votes late last night.

title: Republican Now Opposes War in Iraq
description: Representative Doug Bereuter of Nebraska, a respected Republican voice on intelligence issues who is retiring from Congress, is telling his constituents that he now considers the war in Iraq a mistake despite his earlier support for the invasion.

title: Promotion Rate For 3rd Graders Looks Stable
description: After months of uproar over Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's pledge to stop the social promotion of third graders, city officials said yesterday that they expected fewer than 5,000 children to have to repeat the grade -- about the same as were held back last year.

title: Awe (and Maybe Acolytes) From Bold Architecture
description: When Alessia Urso, an architecture student, came to celebrate Sunday Mass at the spectacular new sanctuary in this pilgrimage town in southern Italy, she made sure that she brought her camcorder.

title: Late Goal Rescues U.S. in World Cup Qualifier
description: The capital seemed abuzz Wednesday with expectation of unprecedented victory. Customs agents, hotel workers, taxi drivers, even the Anglican minister who gave the pregame invocation believed that Jamaica would finally defeat the United States in a soccer match.

title: Twist the Screen, and a Notebook Has Something to Grow On
description: Tablet computers, which used to be expensive heavy slabs with bad handwriting-recognition software and a clumsy stylus-driven user interface, have slimmed down lately in size and price. Averatec's new C3500 tablet computer, which converts from a tablet to a standard laptop with a twist of the screen that reveals a keyboard underneath, weighs in at five and a half pounds and a list price of $1,350, making it one of the less expensive tablets available.

title: The 3 R's and Beyond, With a Software Boost
description: FOR educational software, these are not times of plenty.

title: Yankees Glimpse October, and It's Not Pretty
description: Once the erratic Mike Mussina trudged through a shoddy fourth inning Wednesday night, Tanyon Sturtze stopped warming up and returned to his seat in the Yankees' bullpen in right field. Sturtze sat down for only a few seconds before jumping up as if someone had set his cap on fire and feverishly began throwing again.

title: Gymnastics Draws Viewers
description: With women's gymnastics as the core of its Summer Olympics programming on Tuesday, NBC Universal Sports generated an 18.3 rating, up 18 percent from the same night in Sydney four years ago. An audience of 71 million total viewers watched the four-hour broadcast, up from 64 million in Sydney.

title: Corzine Says He Won't Push McGreevey Out of Office
description: United States Senator Jon S. Corzine made his first public statement on Wednesday about Gov. James E. McGreevey's impending resignation, saying that he accepted Mr. McGreevey's decision to remain in office until Nov. 15 and would not push for a special election this fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAMESEK, MORTON

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WACHSBERGER, SYLVIA

To her parents, Liz Neumark, Chaim Wachsberger, as well as to her siblings, our dear students, Sam, Kaitlin, and Nell, our hearts go out to you. Sylvia was full of life and spirit and we shall always remember her that way. She was loved by all who had the good fortune to have known her. To Liz, our devoted board member, and dear Chaim, we are all here for you as you have been for us. May you and your entire extended family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Alisa Doctoroff, President Board of Trustees Roanna Shorofsky Head of School The Abraham Joshua Heschel School

title: Globe-Trotting Englishwomen Who Helped Map the World

The company recorded 15 billion Hong Kong dollars in gains from selling stakes in companies including its Chinese venture with the Procter & Gamble Company. Its wireless unit lost 12.2 billion Hong Kong dollars but it expanded its subscriber base to 3.2 million customers from 1.7 million three months earlier. Hutchison, based in Hong Kong, is controlled by the Asian billionaire Li Ka-shing.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Church Needs Scaffold Permit
description: A day after the city's Buildings Department mistakenly stopped limited demolition work at a deteriorating Harlem church, the city acknowledged yesterday that contractors actually had permission to remove a cross and several spires. The problem, the department said yesterday, was that scaffolding had been erected without a permit. Joseph Zwilling, the spokesman for the Archdiocese of New York, said an approval notice posted on the department's Web site had led contractors to believe they had a scaffold permit and could begin the already-approved rooftop work at the church, St. Thomas the Apostle, on West 118th Street just off St. Nicholas Avenue. He said that the archdiocese expected to acquire a scaffold permit today and would apply soon for a permit to demolish the church. The archdiocese received two other citations yesterday: one for failing to provide architectural plans to an inspector and the other for a sidewalk shed that extended onto a separate property. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRESLAUER, BERNARD H.
description: BRESLAUER -- Bernard H., bibliophile, died in New York City on Saturday, August 14, 2004 at age 86 of congestive heart failure. Only son of Martin and Grete Breslauer of Berlin, he joined his father's firm of antiquarian booksellers in 1935, fleeing the Nazis in 1937 to settle in London, where after voluntary military service during the war he became the leading binding expert in the book trade. He advised and represented at auction the greatest private collectors and many institutional libraries in Europe and America. In 1977, he moved to New York to his apartment overlooking the Metropolitan Museum which became the inevitable port-of-call of visiting European bibliophiles. In 1978, he established a worldrecord price for a printed book by purchasing the Gutenberg Bible on behalf of the State Library of Wuerttemberg. He was the author of several authoritative monographs and a long series of scholarly and well-written catalogues. In 1997, the Free University of Berlin conferred on him an Honorary Doctorate of Letters for his contributions to bibliophily and bibliographical scholarship. Dr. Breslauer formed unmatched private collections of medieval manuscripts, illuminations and, most originally, of historical bibliography in finely bound association copies. He was also a discriminating patron of contemporary artistic bookbinders. In 1996, he was made an Honorary Fellow of the Pierpont Morgan Library, a rare distinction. In 1998, the London quarterly journal, The Book Collector, devoted a special issue to mark Dr. Breslauer's 80th birthday. He will be greatly missed in the world of rare books. Dr. Breslauer leaves no family. His friends will organize a memorial reception on a date soon to be announced.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: 24/7 Real Media Acquires Decide Interactive
description: 24/7 Real Media Inc., which provides Internet advertising for Lycos Web sites and the News Corporation's Fox News, has acquired Decide Interactive, a closely held Australian company, for $26 million in cash and stock. 24/7 Real Media paid $15 million in cash and 4.5 million shares of stock valued at about $11 million. The company might pay as much as $7.5 million more to former Decide shareholders if certain financial-performance goals are met. Decide Interactive's technology helps businesses direct customers to their Web sites. The acquisition will give 24/7 an entry into Australia, which is expected to have 4.6 million Internet subscribers and online advertising spending of $140 million this year, the company said yesterday. The acquisition is expected to generate $3 million in fourth-quarter revenue for 24/7 Real Media. Shares of 24/7 Real Media fell 19 cents, to $2.50.

The announcement is likely to be made today. Magna, based in Aurora, Ontario, makes auto parts and is subcontracted to assemble vehicles. Frank Stronach, Magna's founder and chairman, has been serving as interim president since January, when his daughter, Belinda Stronach, resigned as president and chief executive to make what became an unsuccessful run for leader of the Conservative Party. Mr. Hogan, 53, has spent three decades at G.M. in a variety of roles. In the late 1990's, as chief of small-car operations, he clashed with union leaders over a plan to streamline assembly processes. title: Technology Briefing | Software: Sony Cuts Playstation 2 Price In Europe
description: The Sony Corporation cut the price of its PlayStation 2 machine by a quarter in Europe, after reductions by its rival Microsoft before the Christmas season. A PlayStation 2 now sells for 104.99 ($192) in Britain and 149 euros ($184) in countries using the common European currency, Tokyo-based Sony said yesterday on its Web site. Sony reduced United States prices in May. The reduction is the latest step in the price war between PlayStation 2 and Xbox in the $8 billion console industry. Microsoft said yesterday that it would cut the Xbox's price to 149.99 euros in Europe, starting at the end of the month. PlayStation was introduced in 1994. In three years, it became the world's top game machine, beating those of Nintendo and Sega Enterprises Inc., now Sega. The first PlayStation models, still on the market, have sold more than 100 million units. The successor, PlayStation 2, has sold more than 70 million, including 24 million outside of Japan and North America, according to Sony. Xbox, introduced in November 2001, trails with 15.5 million units sold worldwide so far.

Hundreds of thousands of pilgrims came to Lourdes for the pope's visit, according to the diocese, but they ignored collection boxes. Collection receipts tallied $247,000, while the overall budget for the papal visit was nearly $1.5 million. ''The system didn't work,'' Bishop Perrier told reporters at a news conference in Paris this week. According to the news agency ANSA, he said the pilgrims, instead of lining up slowly so that donations could be asked of them, rushed past collection boxes ''to get a good spot.'' description: COLE--Irwin Jack. On August 6, 2004 following a brave battle with cancer. Never losing his positive outlook, he passed with courage and dignity surrounded by his friends and family. Irwin was born August 2, 1927 and recently celebrated his 77th birthday with his family. He is survived by his wife Amy of Poughkeepsie, NY; his children Loren of Brattleboro, VT, Michael of Los Gatos, CA and Suzanne of Anchorage, AK; his grandchildren Rebecca, Jacob, Benjamin, Elijah, Daniel, Elizabeth and Madeline; stepchildren John, Kathryn and Jennifer; step-grandchildren Daniel, Nicholas and Jessica; and sister Maxine Alter of Tarrytown, NY. Irwin graduated from Syracuse University and the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania. His career highlights include attending the Executive Training Program at Macy's and then working as a Senior Executive at Montgomery Ward before assuming the role of President of the Amtico Division of American Biltrite. Thereafter, Irwin started his own company I.J. Cole and Associates which he actively ran until his passing. During his career, he also served as an Adjunct Professor of Business at the University of New Haven in New Haven, CT. In addition to his professional experience, Irwin was an active member of the Wednesday Ten and the Aspen Institute of Humanistic Studies. A beacon of optimism and encouragement for his family and friends, he will be greatly missed but never forgotten. Donations in his memory may be sent to the Pancreatic Cancer Research Laboratory, C/O Dr. Robert Fine, Columbia University Medical Center, 650 West 168th Street, Room 20-05, NY, NY 10032 or The American Red Cross, 103 Hooker Avenue, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601.

title: Large and Small Footprints on a Trail
description: MY 12-year-old niece has almost reached the other side of the stream when she skids on a slick rock and plunges in up to her shins. I try to grab her and my right foot also slips into the cold water. Behind us are the others in our little band -- my husband and our 7- and 11-year-old children -- who have yet to make the crossing, one of several on this relatively level but unusually wet trail in the Big Indian/Beaver Kill Wilderness Area in the Catskills. Though we've all had experience day hiking and stone-hopping, this is the first time we're trying both while carrying packs stuffed with overnight gear. And we're obviously still getting used to the fact that we can't move quite so nimbly with 5 to 20 extra pounds strapped to our backs.

title: 36 Hours | Galena, Ill.
description: WHEN Ulysses S. Grant went to Galena in 1860 to be a clerk in his father's leather store, he was at the lowest point in his life -- a West Point graduate out of the Army and working far below his potential -- and the town was at a high. A few years later their positions reversed. While Grant soared as a war hero and two-term president, Galena, a Mississippi River boomtown that had 15,000 people at a time when Chicago claimed only 1,200, went into decline as steamboating gave way to railroads, its lead mines played out and its tributary to the river began to silt in. Galena today has just 3,500 residents, but, after another reversal of fortune beginning in the 1960's, it draws 1.3 million visitors a year. They come for festivals, for easy kayaking along the gently flowing Galena River, above, and the Grant history, but above all for the well-preserved 19th-century beauty of the town itself. The tourists crowding the shops, restaurants and bed-and-breakfasts that now occupy many of the old buildings come from far and wide, but most are from that one-time swamp village called Chicago. MARTHA JANE PINDER

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Chatter Over The Head Of State
description: Was the white bandanna that Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi donned during Prime Minister Tony Blair's stay at his villa on Sardinia earlier this week hiding evidence of a hair transplant, Italian newspapers gossiped? Did the man alleged to have had a midwinter facelift fill out his follicles in midsummer? After days of speculation and bemused debate over the pirate look of the usually staid Mr. Berlusconi, 67, it appears that he may have. On Thursday evening, Mr. Berlusconi went for a stroll through the town of Porto Rotondo without the bandanna, and the ANSA news agency reported that his scalp was marked with ''regular, small crusts.'' For his part, the prime minister reportedly joked to a young man who had complimented him on the bandanna that ''having a little more hair is better.'' Elisabetta Povoledo

title: National Briefing | Politics: Publisher Settled Harassment Charge
description: Deal W. Hudson, publisher of the conservative Roman Catholic magazine Crisis and until this week a top adviser to the Bush campaign, paid $30,000 to settle accusations of sexual misconduct brought by an 18-year-old student when he was her professor at Fordham University in 1994, according to an article on the Web site of The National Catholic Reporter and a person involved in a university investigation. In papers filed with Fordham at the time and quoted in the paper, the student said that after she became drunk with Mr. Hudson and a group of students at a Greenwich Village bar, he took her to his office, where at his suggestion they exchanged sexual favors. She accused him of sexual harassment, and the university revoked his tenure. On Wednesday, Mr. Hudson resigned as a Bush adviser in anticipation of the article. Yesterday, Crisis said in a statement that Mr. Hudson ''deeply regrets'' the incident at Fordham but remained bound by a confidentiality agreement. David D. Kirkpatrick (NYT)

title: CHEVRONTEXACO ORDERED TO PAY $41 MILLION IN LAWSUIT

A state court jury in Cascade County, Mont., awarded $16.1 million in compensatory damages and $25 million in punitive damages, said Keith Marr, a lawyer in Great Falls, Mont. ''There is no health risk to the people of the town of Sunburst associated with the contamination under the refinery,'' a ChevronTexaco spokesman, Michael Barrett, said in a statement. title: Technology Briefing | Software: Salesforce.com Posts Big Profit Rise
description: Salesforce.com Inc., which sells Internet-based customer-management software, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit was more than ninefold the profit in last year's quarter. The company raised its forecast for the year. Net income rose to $1.17 million, or a penny a share, from $122,000 a year ago, the San Francisco-based company said in its first financial report since going public in June. Sales in the quarter that ended July 31 rose 88 percent to $40.6 million. Salesforce.com said it would earn 2 to 4 cents a share this year, on sales of $165 million to $170 million. That was up from the $160 million to $165 million that the chief financial officer, Steven Cakebread, told investors to expect at a meeting in New York last month. The company said then it expected net income this year to range from break-even to 3 cents a share. Its shares fell 39 cents, to $11.78, in after-hours trading. They rose 22 cents, to $12.17, in regular trading.

Independently produced and self-distributed by Joe Camp, who made the first Benji film back in 1974, the film, which opens today nationwide, is an old-fashioned boy-and-his-dog story, in which the dog is played not by a swarm of manipulated pixels but by an actual flesh-and-fur canine.

title: The Essence of Wit And as Cool as Jazz
description: Now it is prized by collectors and loved by connoisseurs, but not so long ago Art Deco was so tiresomely ubiquitous that nobody wanted it. Applied to everything from ashtrays to skyscrapers, it appeared everywhere from Australia and India to London, New York City and small Midwestern towns. It defined the look of modernity for almost 30 years and then, just before World War II, plummeted out of fashion into the dustbin of design history. There it languished until the late 1960's, when it was revived by a new generation bored by the stringencies of Modernism and delighted by Art Deco's witty elegance, polymorphous complexity and kitschy excesses.

title: Study Weighs Terror Threat to Kensico Dam
description: Westchester County officials, who for weeks have said that they plan to reopen a road atop the Kensico Dam here in early September, are now weighing a study that examined what could happen if terrorists set off a bomb at the dam.

title: The Bat Awakens, Stretches, Yawns

''Dracula, the Musical,'' which sets the familiar tale of old snaggletooth to the familiar music of Frank Wildhorn, creaked open last night at the Belasco Theater with all the animation, suspense and sex appeal of a Victorian waxworks in a seaside amusement park.

title: Slab of Building Facade Falls, Injuring 2 People in Times Square
description: A 100-pound marble slab near the top of the Times Square building famed for the New Year's Eve ball suddenly came loose yesterday morning and fell 20 stories, shattering as it hit billboard supports and raining white marble chunks the size of fists onto the street below. A man and a woman waiting to cross the street were slightly injured.
