title: The City Life; The Snooze
description: In a civilized city, clean public restrooms would be easy to find. New York is still working on that modest goal. Someday, to be a truly civilized city, we'll also have to make it easy to find a good place to take a nap. The chairs in Bryant Park were clearly designed to prevent sleeping. A nap on the grass in Central Park depends too much on the weather. And to sleep on a bench suggests that you're not only tired, but possibly homeless.

title: Flip-Flop Leaves Peirsol With the Gold
description: The self-appointed technique critic in swimming came in for some criticism of his own on Thursday night in the shark tank that is the Olympic pool. Despite being disqualified shortly after his final, the world's best backstroker, Aaron Peirsol of the United States, was eventually reinstated as the winner of the 200-meter race that he has dominated the last four years.

title: How Seurat Worked Up To Sunday
description: GEORGES SEURAT was from outer space. One day in the mid-19th century, he was beamed, fully formed, down to Paris with a few cryptically perfect paintings and some of the most beautiful drawings you'll ever see. Later, age 31 in human years, he was beamed back up to wherever he had come from, leaving behind a few letters, a new kind of art and a big, spacey picture called ''La Grand Jatte.''

title: Campaign Tactic: Blame Foreigners and Ignore the Trade Deficit
description: BLAME the foreigners. That is a time-tested political tactic in America, and this year is no exception.

title: When a Lesson Taught Turns Into a Lesson Learned
description: In ''Mean Creek,'' the first feature written and directed by Jacob Aaron Estes, a group of kids in a small town in Oregon decide to take revenge on a bully. The scenario is somewhat reminiscent of Larry Clark's ''Bully,'' a horrific and exploitative tale of lawless youth. The contrast between the two films is worth noting, since Mr. Estes, in the best Sundance tradition, is careful not to let his fascination with errant young people drift into exploitation. Where ''Bully'' was prurient and cynical, ''Mean Creek'' is earnest almost to a fault, exploring the moral difficulties of its characters with heartfelt -- and at times heartsick -- empathy.

title: An Idea Lost in the Rubble
description: A year ago yesterday, I was visiting the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad with my good friend, Arthur Helton, a human rights lawyer, to investigate the human costs of the war and its aftermath. We were sitting with Sergio Vieira de Mello, the United Nations special representative in Iraq, and his staff in Sergio's comfortable office. All of a sudden a huge bomb exploded beneath us, collapsing the ceiling upon us and catapulting us down two floors. I have learned that I was conscious after the bombing, that I spoke to a rescue worker and that both my legs were amputated while I was trapped upside down in the rubble but I scarcely remember this. My first clear memory is of waking up a month later at a hospital in Oxford, England. Everyone else who had been in the room was killed.

title: After a Life Spent Behind Bars, Out Walks a Free Man
description: Robert Carroll Coney was in prison when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated. He was in prison when the Beatles came to America, when men walked on the moon, when the war raged in Vietnam, when Communism fell, and when the Internet and cellphones were invented.

title: Mastering the Art of Julia Child
description: A few days before Julia Child died, we sat together in her compact, fragrant garden in Montecito, Calif., talking about her life. She was about to turn 92. Although she was thin and pale, she seemed stronger and more acute that day than she had been in weeks. She had always loved to work, and, as usual, she corrected my French accent and added little soupons of information to the book we were writing together, a series of reminiscences from the years 1948 to 1954, when she and her husband Paul, my great-uncle, lived in France. Julia sometimes had difficulty remembering a conversation from the day before, but she could recall events from 50 years ago with surprising clarity.

title: Finding Satisfaction At the Top
description: IN rock climbing, the belay rope is your umbilical cord. If you lose your balance, pull loose rock or just freeze in utter terror midway up, you have to trust that your partner on the ground holding the other end of the rope (and your life) in his hands, will check your fall. On belay, trust is what allows you to hang from three fingers grasping a hair-wide crack of rock while your feet flail about, searching for the slightest purchase. Conquering your natural fear of falling requires calling up stores of faith you never knew existed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NGO, DR. IGNACIA U.
description: NGO--Dr. Ignacia U., 64, passed away on August 18, 2004 four days after a massive stroke. She was an extraordinary, vivacious, and beautiful person, beloved and respected by her relatives, friends, colleagues, and patients. ''Iggy'' grew up in Manila and Xiamen, attended the University of the East, and trained as an anesthesiologist at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. She was an attending anesthesiologist at Roosevelt Hospital for 28 years, earning the respect, confidence, and admiration of all of her colleagues. She was the center and supporter of her very extensive family, caring for her brothers and sisters, her many nieces and nephews, and her parents. Her sense of obligation to them was the guiding spirit of her life. She enjoyed art, music, drama, travel, food, cooking, and meeting with her many friends. She is survived by her parents, Edward and Siong Ngo, ten siblings and their spouses, many nieces, nephews, grandnieces, grandnephews, and her companion, Oscar B. Garfein, MD. The world is both less beautiful and good for her passing. Funeral services will be held in San Francisco. A memorial service will be held in October. Her friends and colleagues are invited to the home she shared with Dr. Garfein on August 23rd and 24th, 6-9 PM. Memorial contributions may be made to the Department of Anesthesiology, St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Center, 1000 10th Ave., New York, NY 10019.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, J. IRWIN
description: MILLER -- J. Irwin. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art note with sorrow the passing of J. Irwin Miller, a businessman, philanthropist, and advocate for exceptional design. Irwin began his relationship with the Modern in 1960, when David Rockefeller introduced him, and his wife Xenia, to the Museum's then curator, Dorothy Miller. Miss Miller suggested some galleries to visit where the couple was introduced to and began collecting works by Wassily Kandinsky, Mark Rothko, Sam Francis, and Milton Resnick. Ten years later, Irwin was elected to MoMA's Board of Trustees and served for five years, after which he became a Life Trustee. Of course, Irwin's greatest legacy is the very town in which he lived. Through the Cummings Engine Foundation, Irwin turned Columbus, Indiana into a living repository of modern architecture by commissioning public works from masters such as Eliel and Eero Saarinen, I.M. Pei, and Richard Meier. He embodied corporate responsibility as one of the first executives to believe that corporations should engage in the communties where their businesses were located. In doing so, Irwin forever changed the face of a city. He will never be forgotten, but he will be sorely missed. We extend our sympathies to the entire family. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Patricia Phelps de Cisneros, Chairman, Trustee Committee on Architecture and Design Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, N.Y.

description: Canadian wholesale sales rose 0.6 percent, to 37.8 billion Canadian dollars ($29.1 billion) in June, led by cars and trucks. That pushed the second-quarter increase in sales to 5.1 percent, the largest jump in a decade. The government agency Statistics Canada revised May's figure to 37.6 billion Canadian dollars, a 0.7 percent increase from April. The Bank of Canada's governor, David Dodge, has said he is counting on Canadian consumers to power growth through 2005. Mr. Dodge said in his July policy review that consumers would account for half of Canadian growth in 2004 and 2005. Sales at motor vehicle wholesalers rose 4.2 percent, to a record 8 billion Canadian dollars, spurred by exports, Statistics Canada said. Excluding auto sales, wholesale sales fell 0.4 percent. Sales of building materials rose 1.3 percent, while the farm, personal and household, and food and beverages categories showed decreases.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Neo-Nazi Rally Allowed
description: Citing the right of freedom of assembly, a Bavarian appeals court ruled that thousands of neo-Nazis from across Europe will be allowed to march today near the tomb of Rudolf Hess, Hitler's deputy. The authorities in the Bavarian town of Wunsiedel had banned the march, fearing it could turn into a riot. Last year, nearly 3,000 far-right sympathizers gathered near the town's cemetery to mark the anniversary of Hess's death. Hess, sentenced to life in prison at the Nuremberg trials, committed suicide in Spandau Prison in Berlin in 1987 and is revered as a martyr by neo-Nazis. Victor Homola (NYT)

Exposure of its more subtle aspects requires the skill of an artist, who can explore the realms of the half-conscious, where the indefinable and the inexpressible reside.

title: Sending Up the Downtown Life

title: TEKELEC TO BUY STELEUS GROUP FOR $56 MILLION
description: Tekelec, which makes telecommunications equipment, agreed to buy the closely held Steleus Group for $56 million, its second acquisition this year. The price includes $29 million in cash and $27 million in stock, Tekelec said. The purchase will cut Tekelec's fourth-quarter earnings by 1 cent to 2 cents a share, but add 1 cent to 2 cents to earnings in 2005. Tekelec, based in Calabasas, Calif., said the deal would add switches, which are devices that transmit phone calls between segments of a network, for service providers. Steleus is based in Westford, Mass.

title: VIACOM MIGHT CONSIDER ACQUISITION OF MIDWAY GAMES
description: Viacom Inc. might consider buying Midway Games Inc., the money-losing maker of video games. Midway is controlled by Viacom's chief executive, Sumner M. Redstone. Viacom named three independent directors to evaluate transactions like a purchase or licensing agreements with Midway, Mr. Redstone said in a regulatory filing. Mr. Redstone owns 74 percent of Midway. Viacom is interested in moving into the electronic games business through an acquisition, according to the filing. Mr. Redstone said in April that he was buying Midway shares as a personal investment and did not plan to sell them. In June, he hired an adviser to study whether to take Midway private.

title: A Camp On The Rebound
description: The most successful institution I've ever been involved with closed down last year, and is now being resurrected. It's the teen summer camp section of the Episcopal Camp and Conference Center in Ivoryton, Conn. It takes mostly New York area kids out of the familiar context of their lives and sticks them in tents in the forest, where they have to cook two meals a day over an open fire and socialize with people nothing like themselves.

title: Mies Villa, Jostled by History, Is in a Race Against Time
description: One of the monuments of Modernist architecture is falling apart, again. Tugendhat Villa, the house that Ludwig Mies van der Rohe built for Grete and Fritz Tugendhat on a hill in Brno, Czechoslovakia, in 1930, is famous for its open, flowing plan, its retractable window wall and its plush modern materials. It is hard to estimate its historic value. But ''in spite of its monumentality, it's a race against time for this building,'' John Stubbs, the vice president for field programs at the World Monuments Fund, said at a symposium last month about Tugendhat at the Center for Architecture in New York.

title: Endangering Community Development
description: The Bush administration, which has already hobbled programs that provide housing subsidies for the poor, is undermining the Community Reinvestment Act, the most successful community revitalization program in the nation's history. The act requires banks to lend, invest and provide banking services to poor communities. So far, it has made more than $1.5 trillion available, much of it to developers and nonprofit groups that build affordable housing for the elderly and disabled people, as well as to medical clinics and other projects that would never get built if they were left to the private sector.

As The Times reported earlier this week, the confrontation began when a newly arrived Marine Expeditionary Unit in Najaf started skirmishing with Moktada al-Sadr's Shiite militia without its officers first clearing that decision with top American commanders in Baghdad or with Iraqi political leaders.

title: What the Devil Is Going On Here?
description: Spinning heads, cascades of pea soup and your mother's Army boots are nowhere to be found in ''Exorcist: The Beginning,'' but lovers of the ridiculous may be delighted to know that the specter of little Linda Blair a-twitch and a-tremble is not entirely forgotten. A prequel to ''The Exorcist,'' William Friedkin's 1973 shocker in which Ms. Blair played a child hijacked by Beelzebub, this new film comes gussied up with some fine talent and its very own bag of cheap tricks. But when push comes to demonic shove, hell apparently hath no fury like a woman in green pancake makeup just as surely as some producers have no shame.

title: Corrections

The article also referred incorrectly to the interview, which was shown in two parts. While it was seen in the ''60 Minutes'' time slot, it was a CBS News special, not a ''60 Minutes'' program. A telephone message from a reader on May 18 pointed out the error about the payment. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: 9/11 Panel to Wrap Up Its 20-Month Inquiry
description: The independent federal commission that investigated the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks is scheduled to shut its doors on Saturday, ending a 20-month investigation that rewrote the history of the attacks and that has pushed President Bush and Congress this summer to weigh an overhaul of the nation's intelligence agencies.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Court Finds For Church In Abuse Suit
description: Mormon church officials are not responsible for notifying their members if a known sexual predator is in their congregation, the State Court of Appeals has ruled. The court upheld a lower court's dismissal of a lawsuit by a mother and son who had sued the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints because they said they were each sexually abused by the same man as children. According to the ruling, which was issued on Thursday, the church received several complaints from members from 1966 to 2002 that the man, George Tilson, was sexually abusing children. Mr. Tilson was a ''high priest'' in the church, but not a member of the clergy. The appeals court noted that the reported abuse had not occurred at the church and was not related to church activities. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Orchestra Asserts A Sound Of Its Own
description: It has been a longstanding complaint in the classical music world that as recordings and jet travel have shrunk the globe, an international sound has been fostered that has filtered out regional differences in timbre and interpretation. This is not entirely true, of course. A listener need hear only the Vienna Philharmonic, or any number of Eastern European orchestras to hear sonic qualities unlike those common in the United States, or for that matter, England or France. And every now and then an orchestra comes along with a sound that is surprising and fresh.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Economic Growth
description: The South Korean economy grew at an annualized rate of 5.5 percent in the second quarter, slightly faster than the 5.3 percent in the first quarter, the Bank of Korea said. The growth in the country's gross domestic product was broadly in line with market expectations. Exports drove expansion, rising 27 percent, year on year, fostering growth in capital spending of 5.7 percent. Analysts said a slowdown in exports is expected because of faltering growth in Japan and the United States, leaving Korea increasingly dependent upon China, where demand has been strong. Domestic demand growth was 2.2 percent, reversing a decline in the previous quarter. The bank warned that an expected recovery in consumer demand in the second half could be jeopardized by record high oil prices. Andrew Salmon (NYT)

title: H.G. Davis Jr. 80, Winner Of Pulitzer for Editorials
description: Horance Gibbs Davis Jr., a Pulitzer Prize-winning editorial writer who became an influential journalism educator at the University of Florida, died here on Monday. He was 80.

title: JUDGE DENIES PFIZER A RESTRAINING ORDER AGAINST IVAX
description: Pfizer Inc. failed to get a restraining order to block Ivax from selling a copy of Neurontin, a seizure medicine. Judge John Lifland of the United States District Court in New Jersey denied an emergency request by Pfizer. A Pfizer spokesman, Bryant Haskins, said, ''We will obviously continue any legal options that we have.'' Ivax, which is based in Miami, began selling a tablet form of gabapentin, the main ingredient of Neurontin, on Wednesday. Judge Lifland said he would hold hearings within a few weeks to deal with the broader issue of whether Ivax and other drug makers that want to sell generic Neurontin would infringe Pfizer's patent. Neurontin generated $2.7 billion in sales for Pfizer last year.

description: A crisis in Los Angeles County's emergency health care system became more acute this week with the announcement that the oldest hospital in the San Fernando Valley would close by Dec. 31, officials said here Friday.

description: When it became clear that the elders in this isolated Eskimo village on St. Lawrence Island in the Bering Sea approved of the marriage, Clifford Apatiki's relatives did what was required of them: They bought him his bride.

title: QUIGLEY TO BUY MANUFACTURER OF ITS COLD REMEDY
description: The Quigley Corporation, moving to keep the process for making its Cold-Eeze lozenges a secret, said yesterday it had agreed to acquire the lozenges' manufacturer, Joel Inc., for $5.1 million. Joel, which operates factories in Lebanon, Pa., and Elizabethtown, Pa., has made Cold-Eeze for Quigley since the product's introduction in 1995. Quigley, which had revenue of $41.5 million last year, says its zinc gluconate glycine lozenges and tablets reduce the length and severity of the common cold. Under the agreement, Quigley will pay $4.1 million in cash and $1 million worth of shares. Quigley, based in Doylestown, Pa., will consider whether to continue making several other Joel products, including a line of organic hard candies sold under the College Farm brand.

title: Letter from Australia : Sydney's Olympic sites beginning to pay off
description: SYDNEY  Four years after Sydney's Summer Olympics, the landmark stadium carries the name of Telstra, Australia's largest telecommunications company. Instead of golden rings, vendors now hawk green flags emblazoned with yellow wallabies and the slogan, "I wanna be a Wallabee!"

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Same-Sex Marriage
description: A member of the Cherokee nation challenged the marriage license issued to a lesbian couple who are tribal members. The women, Dawn McKinley and Kathy Reynolds, were married at Tulsa in May. Todd Hembree, who contested the license, argues that same-sex marriages violate tribal law. A judge in tribal court declined to dismiss the complaint and scheduled a hearing for Dec. 17. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Citigroup To Sell Nikko Stake
description: Citigroup Inc. will sell 117.4 million shares in the Nikko Cordial Corporation, the Japanese brokerage firm, valued at 56.6 billion yen ($518 million), the companies said yesterday. The price for the shares, a 6 percent stake, will be set some time from Aug. 31 to Sept. 3, they said in the statement sent to the Tokyo Stock Exchange. Citigroup said in June that it would sell a 9 percent stake in Nikko. Officials at both companies said the sale would strengthen the management of Nikko.

title: Across New York, a Death Penalty Stuck in Limbo
description: In Albany, a 27-year-old former convict who shot a police officer to death in December is no longer facing the death penalty prosecutors had been seeking for months. He was sentenced on Wednesday to life in prison after pleading guilty with the understanding that his execution was no longer possible. New York's highest court had seemingly suspended capital punishment in June, finding a central provision of the state's death penalty law unconstitutional.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: First Witness In Trial Of Yukos Chief
description: After weeks of procedural maneuvers and numbing tedium, the trial of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former chairman of Yukos Oil, had its first witness. The prosecutor called the former director of the Apatit fertilizer plant, the privatization of which in 1994 is at the center of the criminal charges against Mr. Khodorkovsky and his partner, Platon Lebedev. In eight hours of questioning, the former director, Anatoly Pozdnyakov, did not appear to bolster the government's case, according to news reports from the courthouse in Moscow. He said the purchase of Apatit by Mr. Khodorkovsky's investor group had in fact improved conditions at the plant, paying back wages and taxes, while increasing production. The prosecutor objected, questioning disparities in pretrial testimony, before the trial was adjourned until Monday. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: No Snowmobiles
description: When it comes to snowmobiling in Yellowstone National Park, the Bush administration seems to have a hard time understanding what science has to tell it. So here's the bottom line: no snowmobiles. They're bad for wildlife, bad for rangers, bad for visitors, bad for the air and bad for the very idea of what Yellowstone stands for. That was the National Park Service's conclusion after careful study during the Clinton administration, and it was backed up by further study even after George Bush took office. But now, given a deadlock in the courts, the National Park Service is proposing new rules that will allow up to 720 snowmobiles a day into the park for three years. That is just slightly fewer than the current average of 765 snowmobiles a day.

title: Questions for Harold Evans

My money's on him. He's witty, accomplished and seems to be a true gentleman. He's slim and trim and looks years younger than 76. I did like Solomon's comment about the Clinton biography that Evans has been asked to write. (''Haven't we read enough about Clinton?'') Evans's reply was more than witty. (''I'll put the book off. Forget that I mentioned it.'') That settles the debate once and for all. He is indeed Sir Harold.

title: Are You My Mother?

Interestingly, the theme eerily parallels the plight of the protagonist's mother in Albert Camus's ''Stranger,'' who, right before her death, finds love at her old-age home. This sort of relationship is what both mothers yearn for. ''I want a husband, not a son,'' Skloot's mother states, and why not? There cannot be an age cap on finding love, and certainly not on happiness.

title: Read the Book, Darling
description: EVELYN WAUGH'S satiric novel ''Vile Bodies'' was published in 1930, but it's set in a sort of nonfuturistic future. There has been ''no mechanical or scientific advance,'' Waugh wrote in an author's note describing the book, but ''existing social tendencies have become more marked.'' Partygoing, for one. ''What a lot of parties,'' one of the characters complains in the book's most famous passage. ''Almost naked parties in St. John's Wood, parties in flats and studios and houses and ships and hotels and night clubs, in windmills and swimming baths . . . parties at Oxford where one drank brown sherry and smoked Turkish cigarettes, dull dances in London and comic dances in Scotland and disgusting dances in Paris.''

title: Uganda Raises Fees To View Primates
description: Travelers to Uganda will now pay more to follow and observe endangered mountain gorillas and chimpanzees in their natural habitats. Effective Aug. 1, permits to track endangered mountain gorillas cost $360 a day for foreign visitors to Bwindi Impenetrable National Park and Mgahinga Gorilla National Park. The gorilla-tracking permit had been $275 at Bwindi and $220 at Mgahinga. Foreigners pay the fees in dollars.

title: Did Antidepressants Depress Japan?
description: If you had lived in Japan for the last five years, you would know by now that your kokoro is at risk of coming down with a cold. Your kokoro is not part of your respiratory system. It is not a member of your family. Its treatment lies well beyond the bailiwick of your average ear, nose and throat doctor. Your kokoro is your soul, and the notion that it can catch cold (kokoro no kaze) was introduced to Japan by the pharmaceutical industry to explain mild depression to a country that almost never discussed it.

title: At Taxpayers' Expense
description: Talk about a cushy job. New York's legislators are paid $79,500 a year for a position that allows them to clock in every workday morning and then, if they want, go to the gym. Their votes are recorded automatically. Then comes the bonus of $9,000 or more a year for being a ''leader.'' That bonus is not for actual leading; it's for following the real bosses in Albany -- Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker; Joseph Bruno, the Senate majority leader; and Gov. George Pataki. You can get these bonuses even if, like State Senator Ada Louise Smith or former Senator Guy Velella, you are in a state of disgrace. Ms. Smith, a Democrat, got her leadership money even though she was demoted after run-ins with her staff and the Capitol police. After pleading guilty to a bribery-related charge, Mr. Velella, a Republican, is now serving a year at Rikers Island. Yet he got this year's bonus as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEARLE, WILLIAM L.
description: SEARLE--William L., a respected and influential businessman and philanthropist whose family owned and operated the G.D. Searle Pharmaceutical Company until 1985, has died of complications from lung cancer at Lake Forest Hospital on August 19. Bill Searle was 76. Mr. Searle made his permanent home in Elko, Nevada where he owned Maggie Creek Ranch. He was an avid sportsman and actively involved in support of numerous environmental and educational organizations. ''I am the luckiest man I know. I can spend what time and talent is given me to try to make the world around me a little better place,'' Mr. Searle once said. Mr. Searle served on the boards of the Field Museum and Chicago Symphony Orchestra as well as the ShikarSafari Club International Foundation, the U.S. Sportsmen's Alliance, the Boone and Crockett Club, and the Western Folklife Center, Elko, Nevada. He was also the founding supporter of The Island School, an environmental and educational institution in South Eleuthera, Bahamas. He was a member of The Grand Island Lodge in Bath, Illinois. A University of Michigan graduate, Bill Searle was the manager of the 1951 Rose Bowl team. He was also a graduate of the Advanced Management Program of Harvard University. He served in the Army Chemical Corps during the Korean War. His wife, Sally Burnett Searle; his daughters Marion S. Searle, Elizabeth B. Searle, and Louise S. Klarr; his brother D.C. Searle; his sister Suzanne Searle Dixon; ten grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews survive Mr. Searle. Services are scheduled for 4:00 P.M. Tuesday, August 24 at Church of the Holy Spirit, Lake Forest, IL. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to U. S. Sportsmen's Alliance, 801 Kingsmill Parkway, Columbus, OH 43229 or The Nature Conservancy in Illinois, Emiquon Project, 8 South Michigan Avenue, Suite 900, Chicago, IL 60603. A visit from his minister prompted Mr. Searle, while still a young boy, to ponder the question, ''Why am I here on earth?'' In later years, he told an interviewer, ''I'm still working on it. But part, or maybe most, of the answer is 'not just getting by, but making a difference.'''

title: The Making of an X Box Warrior
description: It was only a virtual Baghdad, baking under a virtual sun. As in real life, though, troops were dodging gunfire. I was at the Institute for Creative Technologies in Marina Del Rey, Calif., playing a new X box video game called Full Spectrum Warrior. Leading eight men in an Army squad on a patrol of the war-torn city, I got a taste, however approximate, of why Iraq is such a hard place to be a soldier these days. My job, as squad leader, was to order my soldiers where to go and what to do. First, I sent half of my men into an alleyway, where they immediately came under fire from insurgents hiding nearby. Scrambling for safety, I ordered us to duck into a building, pausing to marvel at the detail of the architecture. I then led us back out onto the street, directing my team to crouch behind a car while we tried to locate the snipers. This was a bad idea. Despite what you see in action movies and other video games, cars do not provide good cover from bullets. The snipers cut loose, and my troops crumpled to the ground. It was surprisingly distressing. In barely three minutes, I had led every single one of my soldiers to his death.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IF amnesia didn't exist (and it barely does, scientists say), the movies would have invented it, just for the melodrama. But in the life-affirming Finnish comedy THE MAN WITHOUT A PAST (2002), amnesia is about the purity of knowing nothing, a route to the ultimate starting-a-new-life story, a fable about the human capacity for change. Markku Peltola plays a man who, arriving in Helsinki, is beaten and robbed and wakes up with no idea who he is. Poor people are kind to him, especially a plain, lonely Salvation Army worker (Kati Outinen) who tells him, ''It's all about mercy.'' But as soon as he has housing, a girlfriend and a dog, he's arrested for ''refusing'' to identify himself after witnessing a bank robbery. Aki Kaurismaki wrote and directed -- Monday at 7 a.m. on Cinemax.

description: ROSS--Dr. Jean D. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Kearny and Fair Haven, NJ died August 17th, 2004 of natural causes. He was 95. Born in a house on Kearny Ave, he was the youngest son of a former Kearny Town Clerk, William B. Ross. He went through the Kearny school system and was recently inducted into the Kearny High School Athletic Hall of Fame for winning the NJ State quarter mile track championship two years in a row. He graduated from the University of Maryland School of Dentistry, Magna Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa. He served in the US Navy in WWII as a Lieutenant Commander at St. Mary's Pre Flight School outside of Hayward, California. He returned to Kearny after the war and practiced dentistry until 1978 when he and his wife moved to Boca Raton. He is survived by his wife Grace, his daughter Lynn, his son William and his grandson Lawrence Molloy.

title: Editorial Observer; Walden at 150: What Would Thoreau Think of the 24-Hour News Cycle?
description: In his time at Walden Pond, Henry David Thoreau periodically returned to Concord, Mass., and when he did, the village seemed to him like a ''great news room.'' After days alone, he found himself surrounded by gossip on all sides, from the idle talk of his neighbors to the frivolous reports in the newspapers. Thoreau was not immune to the appeal of gossip, which he saw as ''really as refreshing in its way as the rustle of leaves and the peeping of frogs.'' But he worried that society was being dulled by its fascination with trivial events. ''Hardly a man takes a half-hour's nap after dinner,'' Thoreau lamented, ''but when he wakes he holds up his head and asks, 'What's the news?'''

These were books populated by snivelers and goody-two-shoes, the most saintly of whom were sure to die in some tediously drawn-out scene. When the characters weren't dying or performing acts of charity or thawing the hearts of mean old gentlemen, they mostly just hung around the house, thinking about how they felt about their relatives.

title: Vistas Bleak and Wondrous

When it opened 20 years later, thanks to a Depression public works program, The Banff Crag and Canyon crowed, ''20 Switzerlands in one.'' Without debating the relative merits of the Alps and the Canadian Rockies, 93 North, better known as the Icefields Parkway, is undeniably a ''wondertrail.'' Stretching from Lake Louise to Jasper, its 143-mile length affords constantly changing views of more than 600 glaciers, six icefields and a cornucopia of mountains.

title: A VIOLIN INVESTIGATION

Axelrod, who was indicted in April on federal charges of tax evasion, has placed the value of the collection at $48.9 million. But outside appraisers recently questioned the authenticity of at least four violins and a cello, some of which have been represented as the work of Stradivari. A lawyer for Mr. Axelrod, who fled the country in April, said he maintained his innocence. A federal grand jury in Trenton is also reviewing the transaction. Jeremy Pearce

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAMM, HEDY
description: KAMM--Hedy. Died Friday, August 20. Born in Vienna in 1907, she fled Austria and hid in France during WWII while her husband Henry fought the Nazis with the French Foreign Legion. She helped her parents escape from Austria before she and her husband came to the U.S. in 1941. She had a successful career as a dress designer until she retired at the age of 90. She was a devoted wife, mother and grandmother. She is predeceased by her husband and is survived by her daughter Renee, son-in-law Neal, and two grandchildren, Daniel and Teddy. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREDERICKS, J. WAYNE
description: FREDERICKS -- J. Wayne. Died of a stroke on August 18, in Bronxville, NY at the age of 87. He graduated with highest honors in Engineering from Purdue University in 1938 and worked at the Kellogg Company of Battle Creek, Michigan. During World War II he served as a B-17 bomber pilot, leading one of the first American crews sent to Britain. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross, and French and British decorations. He also served on the strategic bombing surveys of Germany and Japan. After the war he returned to Kellogg's as Assistant Manager of the Foreign Division. Fredericks came to New York in 1956 to work for the Ford Foundation. His association there was interrupted by a request to come to Washington with the Kennedy administration. He served from 1961-1967 in the Department of State as Deputy Assistant Secretary for African Affairs, earning the Department's Distinguished Honor Award as well as decorations from the governments of Ivory Coast and Ethiopia. On his return to the Ford Foundation, he headed its program on the Middle East and Africa until 1974 when the Ford Motor Company appointed him Executive Director of its International Govermental Affairs Office. After his retirement from Ford, Fredericks served as Counselor in Residence at the Institute for International Education and at the Carnegie Corporation. He also was a member of the Ford Foundation Study Group on Africa. He was a former trustee of the Overseas Development Council, the Near East Foundation and Foreign Policy Association. He was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and of the Century Association. He is survived by his wife, Anne, his daughter, Maria, his son, William and two grandchildren. Memorial service on October 1 at 2:30 PM, at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Nelson Mandela Children's Fund USA Inc., Suite 1200, One Central Plaza, 11300 Rockville Pike, Rockville, MD 20852.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TITUS, JOSEPH SYLVANUS
description: TITUS -- Joseph Sylvanus. Physicist of Sudbury, MA. A retired sensor systems engineer, died August 18, 2004 after a series of adverse events. He was 74. Mr. Titus was born in East Haven, CT and raised in Branford, CT. He served in the U.S. Army Air Force from 1947-1951. He graduated from Georgetown University and became a memer of the Physics Honor Society. He settled in Sudbury in 1970. Mr. Titus (Joe) was a major contributor to our nation's defense through inventions in space systems. He was a leader and an innovator, publishing many technical papers and holding many patents, and was a nationally recognized expert in cryogenic infrared optical sensors. Joe was a founder of the New England Research Center (NERC) and Sensor Systems Group (SSG, Inc.). Sensor systems engineering is an interdisciplinary skill - spanning optics, electronics, communications, and computing. Few practitioners of this art have ever achieved the level of performance, even briefly, that Joe was able to sustain throughout his career. A generous and compassionate man, Joe was often referred to as ''the smartest guy I've ever known.'' His many interests included cooking, fishing, boating, reading, tennis, and gardening. He was an avid skier, spending most winters at his second home in Steamboat Springs, CO, where his goal was to ski at least 100 days every year. Husband of Norma Jean (Mulder) Titus, he also leaves behind his five children: Robert W., Elizabeth A., Amy J., James M. and Daniel J. He was very proud of his three grandchildren: Lydia and Dylan Gallagher and Josephine Rawlings. He is also survived by his brother Eugene Titus of Branford, CT.

title: The Apprentices
description: IT'S a good thing Lance Rubin declined the beer with his dinner, because dessert involved power tools. From 7 to 11 (according to the schedule posted daily on the call board) he had ''Carps'' duty at the Williamstown Theater Festival's scenery shop. That particular evening, he wound up cutting wood into long strips of molding for the elaborate set of ''Design for Living,'' which would play for two weeks at the Adams Memorial Theater, starring Marisa Tomei, Campbell Scott and Steven Weber. It was not the worst assignment Mr. Rubin might have drawn. As an apprentice at the festival -- one of 70 -- he would be given, over the course of his 10 weeks there, a little taste of everything. Sometimes even that was too much; the job called ''Super'' meant picking cigarette butts and other garbage from the brilliant green lawn in front of the theater. Other jobs were hit or miss. ''Run Crew'' might mean operating a spotlight for the new musical ''R Shomon'' at the festival's smaller stage, the Nikos; or dressing its star, Audra McDonald; or mopping the deck or setting the props or filling actors' glasses with too much ice and getting upbraided for it. The best assignment was ''Lines,'' which meant helping one of the Equity actors (perhaps Ms. Tomei?) memorize her part. The most exhausting was ''Changeover,'' which happened every other Sunday evening, when one show came down and the next loaded in, requiring heavy physical labor straight through to morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KNAUTH, BEHRI PRATT
description: KNAUTH--Behri Pratt, 82, of Stonington, CT died peacefully at Fairview Manor on August 19, 2004. She was born in New York City, November 10, 1921, the daughter of Richard Pratt and Marjorie Marsh. She was graduated from Julia Richmond High School in 1939, where she excelled in the arts. She went on to study art at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts and the Art Students League. After working as First Piece Inspector at Sperry Gyroscope in 1943, she began a career in magazine design with Seventeen, Junior Bazaar, Engineering News Record and Life Magazine. It was there that she met her husband Percy. In the coming years she kept busy doing freelance work while raising a family in NYC. In 1966 the family moved to Paris where Percy served as Foreign Editor for Time-Life. It was during this time that she learned French cuisine and studied under Simone Beck. In 1970 they moved to Stonington, CT where she continued to explore her passion for cooking, teaching and for a time, running the Club 145 in Stonington. In 1975 she joined the staff at Mystic Seaport Museum and returned to publication design, retiring in 1980. Throughout her life she shared her passion of the arts and music with all around her. She was predeceased by her husband Percy, in 1995, and her brother Timothy Ashe. She is survived by her sons Timothy Pratt Knauth of Stonington, Geoffrey Stanton Knauth of Williamsport, PA and her daughter Elisabeth Anne Knauth of Mystic, CT, four stepsons, Peter Gries Knauth of Kilmarnik, VA, Phillip Whitman Knauth of Hong Kong, Allan Roediger Knauth of Munster, Germany and Steven Alexander Knauth of Ivoryton, CT, her brother Thane Ashe and sister Maedra Kellam. She had three grandchildren, Mary Wright of Mystic, CT and Alexander and William Knauth of Williamsport, PA. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations in her memory may be made to the VNA of Southeastern Connecticut, 403 North Frontage Road, Waterford, CT 06385-4349. For information: Mystic Funeral Home, Route 1, Mystic.

description: VENABLE RAPP--Virginia. Widow of William Jourdan Rapp, playwright ''Harlem'' 1929. August 12, 2004 at home, Lynchburg, VA. Born Devil's Lake, ND, June 8, 1907; graduated magna cum laude Rockford College; awarded fellowship (Philosophy) Cornell; chose Broadway. Starred in ''Fiesta'', two plays with Mrs. Fiske, ''Pursuit of Happiness'', and many roles on radio. With husband and C.D. Morris formed production company for the new entertainment medium. Some 35 daily and weekly programs came out of their shop, including ''Rinso Show'', ''Lux Theatre of the Air'', and ''The Shadow''. In addition, she read thousands of manuscripts in support of her husband's position as Editor-inChief of ''True Story Magazine'', which shared circulation honors with ''Life''. After her husband's sudden death in 1942, Mrs. Rapp was named to the Editorial Board of Macfadden Pub. and served on Education Committee of the Magazine Publishers Association. She wrote hundreds of articles for various women's magazines and lectured at over 50 colleges and schools of journalism on article writing and audience analysis. She is survived by her daughter Mrs. Bernard W. Hostrop of Warrenton, VA; her son Dr. William Venable Rapp of Scarborough, NY; two granddaughters: Stacy Rapp, Christina Rapp Prescott; three grandsons: Frederick and Richard Hostrop, Jordan Rapp; and four beloved great-grandchildren.

title: The State of the George W. Bush Joke
description: IN December 1992, just weeks before departing office, President George Herbert Walker Bush invited Dana Carvey to the White House. Mr. Carvey had spent the previous four years impersonating Mr. Bush on ''Saturday Night Live'' as a patrician wimp, and turning Bushisms like ''it's ba-a-ad'' and ''wouldn't be pru-dent at this juncture'' into national punch lines. But as Mr. Carvey performed from behind a podium in the East Room, the president, according to press accounts, laughed and looked happier than he had in weeks. It wasn't hard to see why: the humor was gentle and apolitical, making light of minor personal foibles. Speaking with reporters afterward, Mr. Bush recalled a conversation with the comedian: ''He said, 'I hope I've never crossed the line.' And I knew exactly what he meant. And as far as I'm concerned he never has.''

title: Vanessa Carlton Squared

(Find both at www.vanessacarlton.com.) Five short piano notes and then the verse starts, as Ms. Carlton floats down from falsetto to mourn the end of a beautiful, scary summer. She sings of ''strange new friends'' and ''pretty-eyed boys'' and then, ''My first time, hard to explain/ Rush of blood, oh, and a little bit of pain.'' The video, directed by Sophie Muller (who has also made great videos for Bjork and No Doubt), is just as ambivalent. Two Vanessa Carltons perform in the same room; one plays piano and sings while the other works on a ballet-inspired -- and, occasionally, computer-enhanced -- dance routine. The pianist (envious? contemptuous? confused? anxious?) gazes at the dancer, but the dancer never gazes back, although she does crawl on top of the piano to sing the last verse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HODGES, REV. GRAHAM RUSHING
description: HODGES -- Rev. Graham Rushing, 88, died peacefully on Friday, July 9, 2004 surrounded by his family at Francis House, a home for the terminally ill in Syracuse, NY. A 1937 graduate of the University of Mississippi, Rev. Hodges earned a bachelor of divinity degree from Yale University in 1940. He was a parish minister for many years for the United Church of Christ in northern and central NY and spent 23 years as pastor of Emmanuel Congregational Church in Watertown, NY. In 1971 he was elected moderator of the NY Conference of the United Church of Christ. He was active on the local and state levels with the American Heart Association and served as chairman of the board for the statewide NYS Heart Affiliate. He was a founder of the statewide NYS Coalition for Family Planning and of Planned Parenthood of Northern NY. He wrote several books of children's sermons published by Abingdon Press as well as many magazine articles and letters to the editor. He was an unwavering advocate for social justice and a caring parish minister as well as a devoted husband and father. His wife, Elsie Russell Hodges, whom he married in 1941, died in June 2000. He is survived by his children, Mary Buckley of Liverpool, NY, Graham Hodges of Hamilton, NY, Judith Rippeteau of Washington, DC and Janet Casler of Humble, TX; six grandchildren, Caroline, Maison and Eva Rippeteau, Rosemary and Andrew Casler and Elizabeth Buckley and two sisters, Jessie Anna Puryear of Senatobia, MS and Lucille Bennett of Austin, TX. Donations may be made to Francis House, 108 Michaels Ave, Syracuse, NY 13208 or to the charity of the donor's choice.

The results, gathered by the American Federation of Teachers, raised a red flag for charter schools, which are set to grow tremendously under a federal law that proposes them as one remedy for schools with persistently low test scores. description: A driver was killed early Saturday after losing control of his car on a wet road and driving into a gasoline pump off the Merritt Parkway, the state police said yesterday. The driver, Richard L. Cascella Jr., 32, of Norwalk, hit the pump just before 4 a.m. at the gas station near the New Canaan rest area, between Exits 37 and 38, troopers said. His Mercedes-Benz split in half and burst into flames, they said. The two workers who were inside the rest stop were not injured, the authorities said. title: Editorial Observer; The Silence of an Old Soldier and the Literary Education of Some Young Ones
description: On a summer evening almost 20 years ago, I sat at the kitchen table in an Iowa farmhouse with my uncle Elmore Jack. We'd spent the day baling and stacking hay -- hot, dusty, humid work -- and the evening had cooled off hardly at all. Elmore Jack had spread some photographs across the table, pictures he'd taken just after the end of World War II, as the occupation of Japan was beginning. We talked about the war visible in the photos -- military stockpiles in tunnels, a bomb-ridden landscape -- but we also talked about the war he hadn't photographed, a far more private war fought on islands across the Pacific. Above all, I remember the words ''listening post.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REMMER, PATRICIA CADY
description: REMMER -- Patricia Cady. Passed away peacefully, surrounded by her family, on August 19, 2004. Pat was an incredible woman devoted to her family and friends. Known for her charm, enthusiasm and positive outlook, she exuded warmth to everyone who met her. Supportive and caring, independent and strong, Pat was somebody that you could always count on. Whether bird hunting with her husband Gene, playing bridge with her friend Al, skiing with her children, or camping in Tanzania with her grandchildren, Pat was always a great sport. She was born in South Bend, Indiana, on February 4, 1924, to Marcella and George Donahue. Educated on full scholarships to St. Agnes School in Albany and Barnard College in New York, she married Gene Remmer in 1945. An Old Greenwich resident for over forty years, Pat was tremendously active in community organizations as New York City Outward Bound Director, Columbia College Advisory Board Member, Barnard College Board Vice-Chairwoman, Chair of the Remmer Family Foundation and Trustee of Girls, Inc. of Jacksonville. After Gene's death in 1988 Pat served as Chair of EHR Investments. Pat is survived by her four children, their spouses and ten grandchildren, as well as her dear friend, Albert Lewis. Memorial services will be held at First Congregational Church, Old Greenwich, Connecticut, on Saturday, August 28, at 3 pm. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the Patricia Cady Remmer Scholarship at Barnard College or the Vicars Landing Scholarship Fund. For more information contact Quinn-Shalz, A Family Funeral Home & Cremation Centre, Jacksonville Beach, FL; 904-249-1100.

title: RECONSTRUCTING A WHITE HOUSE LIBRARY
description: A century and a half after the volumes in the first White House library were sold and scattered around the country, two groups are working to reconstruct the collection and get a glimpse into reading trends of the mid-19th century. The library, founded in 1850 by Millard Fillmore, the 13th president, and his wife, Abigail, a schoolteacher and librarian, had some 270 books and 260 periodicals, including standard texts like a Bible, an atlas and a Webster's dictionary, along with George Catlin's ''North American Indian Portfolio'' and George Bancroft's ''History of the United States From the Discovery of the Continent.'' Other volumes included the Federalist Papers and a collection of law books. The National First Ladies' Library and the Bibliographical Society of America want to compile a complete catalog of the library that will include a history and an annotated list of its contents, reconstructed from surviving invoices, correspondence and memoranda, said Pat Krider, the executive director of the first ladies' library. But the group's final goal, Ms. Krider said, is to find as many of the 19th-century imprints in the library as possible -- exact editions or very close -- and display them in its library in Canton, Ohio. JOHN FILES

title: Roadblock at Yucca Mountain
description: A federal appeals court decision has thrown a gigantic roadblock in the way of efforts to create an underground burial site for nuclear wastes at Yucca Mountain in Nevada. A three-judge panel in the District of Columbia ruled last month that regulators could not simply require the repository to contain the wastes for 10,000 years, the standard set by the Environmental Protection Agency, but must instead ensure that Yucca could function acceptably for hundreds of thousands of years. That standard is so outlandishly stringent it may not be achievable. Unless Congress steps in to change the ground rules, the court ruling could significantly delay or even derail efforts to move ahead with an underground repository that will be vitally needed in coming decades.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Woman Ejected From Car, Then Fatally Struck
description: A woman ejected from a sport utility vehicle on the Belt Parkway in South Ozone Park on Saturday night was struck and killed by a second vehicle whose driver, after stopping to check her pulse, drove off, the police said. The driver of the S.U.V., identified as Keith Haigbea, 38, of 166th Place in Jamaica, was charged with second-degree manslaughter, said a spokesman for the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. The authorities said that Mr. Haigbea had been drinking and that additional charges were possible pending the results of a blood alcohol test. Mr. Haigbea lost control of the vehicle around 10:35 p.m. in the eastbound lanes of the parkway near Exit 20 and the vehicle flipped over, a law enforcement official said. The woman, identified as Tammy Cromer, 32, of Brooklyn, was ejected onto the westbound lanes, where she was struck by a red Mercury Cougar, the police said. The driver of the Cougar stopped long enough to check Ms. Cromer's pulse before fleeing, the police said. Ms. Cromer, whom the authorities said was Mr. Haigbea's girlfriend, was pronounced dead at the scene. Her two daughters, ages 9 and 12, who were in the back seat, were treated for minor injuries. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Attacking 'Tire Mountains'
description: Work is to begin this fall on a plan to get rid of about 30 million used tires stockpiled in 95 places around New York State, environmental officials said yesterday. The first tire mountains to be tackled will be Pinnacle Tire in West Monroe, Oswego County, and Mohawk Tire in Waterford, Saratoga County. Each contains at least eight million tires collected by failed recycling businesses. Initial funding for the new recycling projects will come from a $2.50 fee collected on tires sold since 2003. Old tires are considered an environmental threat because they harbor mosquitoes and can emit hazardous smoke if they burn. About one million will become fill for construction of an overpass on Interstate 87 in Clinton County. Other priority sites are Hornburg Tire in Sinclairville, Chautauqua County; New York Tire in Smithtown, Suffolk County; and Cycletech in Hudson, Columbia County. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

description: The Silicon Valley company Opsware Inc. plans to announce today that Electronic Data Systems has signed a $50 million agreement to license its software for automating corporate data centers. The pact follows an earlier $52 million commitment that Electronic Data, a large computer services company, made to use Opsware's software in 2002. The new agreement runs through March 2008, with an option for five additional years that could bring Opsware another $95 million. The announcement comes at a time when large software deals are scarce. Marc Andreessen, Opsware's chairman, says his company is benefiting from the shift among corporate customers to products employing Web technology standards, including the Java programming language and browser-based applications. The deal also provides a lift to Opsware, started in 1999 by Mr. Andreessen, a co-founder of the browser pioneer Netscape, and a team of former Netscape senior managers and engineers. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAMEN, DR. SAUL
description: KAMEN--Dr. Saul, 88 died of a stroke on August 23, 2004. Beloved father of Dr. Paul Kamen, Dr. Leonard Kamen and Jon Kamen. Beloved brother of Rebecca Jarmon. Beloved grandfather of Sasha, Ashley, Zoe, Max, Jacob, Lisa and Zack. Beloved father-in-law of Nancy, Sandra, Sandy and Angela. He was bereft from the recent losses of his beloved wife Helen and his beloved son Michael, the noted composer. His deep commitment to human values led him to devote his professional career to pioneering the advancement of dental care for patients with special needs. After receiving a BA from NYU, he attended the University of Pennsylvania School of Dental Medicine, graduating in 1940. For 30 years he served as Chief of Pediatric Dentistry at the Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center. There, he designed and conducted a continuing education program in the Dental Management of Developmentally Disabled Persons, most of them children. This course trained thousands of dental professional throughout the world in this specialized area of dental care. He later focused his interest on older persons with special needs, serving from 1971-1987 as Chief of Dental Service at the Parker Geriatric Institute. This was the first approved geriatric dental training program in the US. He was one of the early organizers of the American Society for Geriatric Dentistry and the Federation of Special Care Organizations in Dentistry. He was Professor of Dental Health at SUNY Stony Brook, and held numerous other faculty appointments, including the Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery, St. Barnabas Hospital, the Bronx VA Medical Center and Goldwater Hospital. Through his teaching and prolific writings, he inspired thousands of dental professionals throughout the world to devote themselves to caring for patients with special needs. His legacy will be the vastly improved quality of life for many thousands of people throughout the world, demonstrated by their smiles. To his friends he was a perpetual source of warmth and great humor. To his family he was warm, loving, and generous; unstinting in his devotion. He will be sorely missed. Services Wednesday 10 am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Mr. Bloomberg said each mentor will advise 17 or more new teachers. Recent studies have found that public-school teachers who quit within three years often cite a lack of professional support. title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T To Sell CallVantage Through Best Buy
description: AT&T will sell its CallVantage Internet-based phone service through the Best Buy Company's 628 stores across the United States by early October. AT&T, which plans to expand CallVantage to other retailers, is running a sales trial of the service at some Target stores in California, said Gary Morgenstern, a spokesman for AT&T, which is based in Bedminster, N.J. The agreement with Best Buy, based in Richfield, Minn., is part of AT&T's strategy to expand its Web-based phone service as it retreats from offering conventional consumer calling. In taking the step, AT&T follows Vonage Holdings, a closely held company that sells its Web-calling plans at Best Buy, RadioShack and Circuit City Stores. CallVantage, introduced in March, uses conventional telephones to send calls over the Internet as packets of data, similar to e-mail. Customers must have a high-speed Internet connection to use the service. Terms of the contract with Best Buy were not being disclosed, Mr. Morgenstern said.

Mr. Padilla, 50, was executive vice president for merchandising at the Marshall Field's chain of Target. Target sold Marshall Field's in July. Mr. Padilla, who will join Sears on Sept. 15, will report to the chief executive, Alan J. Lacy, and will be responsible for marketing all Sears products and brands, including Kenmore and Lands' End. Sales at Sears stores open at least a year have fallen for all but 2 of the last 14 quarters, and second-quarter profit fell 83 percent. While senior vice president in charge of clothing merchandising for Target stores from 1994 to 2001, he introduced the Mossimo and Cherokee clothing lines, a Sears spokesman, Chris Brathwaite, said.

title: NEW YORKER GETS BLUEGRASS HONOR
description: Bill Vernon, a native New Yorker who quit Wall Street to become one of bluegrass music's leading broadcasters and historians, has been elected to the Bluegrass Music Hall of Honor, joining stars like Bill Monroe, the Stanley Brothers and the Carter Family, the International Bluegrass Music Association announced late last week in Nashville. Mr. Vernon, who died in Virginia in 1996, heard Lester Flatt and Curly Seckler's song ''We Can't Be Darlings Anymore'' when he was 14, and told friends that he knew right then that bluegrass would be his calling. His family, however, urged him to follow his father into corporate tax work, and Mr. Vernon worked on Wall Street for 12 years. He moonlighted as a disc jockey on WBAI in New York, and left the city in 1970 for full-time radio jobs in Delaware and Virginia. ''If you asked Bill a question about old-time music, he always gave you the right answer,'' said Sonny Osborne of the Osborne Brothers. ''I miss him a whole lot.'' PHIL SWEETLAND

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHATTUCK, MARTHA MERRILL
description: SHATTUCK--Martha Merrill. Died peacefully at her home in Guilford, CT on August 21. She is survived by the family that she was devoted to and who love her and miss her: James, her husband of 63 years; her three sons, Bradlee, Alden and Jonathan; her daughter-in-law, Marianne; her five grandchildren, Johan, Kyle, Trevor, Brendan and Avery; her granddaughters-in-law, Trisha and Emily; and her great-grandchildren, Xavier, Johan and Elise. Apart from the satisfaction she found in caring for her family and friends, Martha found peace and guidance in her faith as well as great happiness in charity, activity, travel and learning. She was born Martha Merrill, the only child of Guy and Alice Merrill, in Cambridge, MA on March 29th, 1920. She graduated from Tufts (Jackson) College in 1941 and married James H. Shattuck of Neenah, WI that same year. Two years later, in 1943, Martha began a lifelong avocation of contributing her time and energy to a total of 23 philanthropic, educational and other organizations starting with the Prisoner of War Committee of the American Red Cross in Appleton, WI (Chairman) and ending with her membership on the Board of Friends of Grove Street Cemetery in 2001. It's not possible to list them all but a sample of the roles she played would include Chairman of the New Haven Unit of Recording for the Blind; member and Chairwoman (1980-83) of the Board of Trustees of Quinnipiac College; founding member of the Board of Directors of the Friends of the New Haven Library; Director of the First Constitution Financial Corporation; member of the Board of Directors of the Dorothy Whitfield Historical Society in Guilford, CT; and member of the Board of Trustees of Yale-New Haven Hospital. In 2003, Quinnipiac College awarded Martha an honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters. In lieu of flowers, please send a contribution in her name for the use of the Oncology Department of Yale-New Haven Hospital. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, September 1, at 1 PM at the First Congregational Church, Broad and Church Streets, Guilford, CT.

title: Stealing Beauty
description: In a line-up of the world's great art museums, the Museum of the Missing would rank near the top. This imaginary museum, whose collection would consist entirely of stolen paintings and drawings, would sprawl as endlessly as the Louvre. Its treasures would include 551 Picassos, 43 Van Goghs, 174 Rembrandts and 209 Renoirs. Vermeer would be there, and Caravaggio and Van Eyck and Czanne. On Sunday, the museum made two new acquisitions, Edvard Munch's ''Madonna'' and ''The Scream,'' which were taken from the Munch Museum in Oslo.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: RCN Plans To Exit Bankruptcy
description: The RCN Corporation, a provider of cable television, phone and Internet service, filed a plan yesterday to exit bankruptcy that will exchange $1.2 billion in unsecured debt for all of the equity in the company by the end of the year. The company, based in Princeton, N.J., will give unsecured creditors, mostly bondholders, equity worth $620 million to $820 million, according to the plan filed in Federal Bankruptcy Court in New York. That would give them 52 cents to 68 cents on the dollar for their holdings. The plan was approved by RCN's unsecured creditors. Unsecured bondholders typically receive 30 cents to 60 cents on the dollar on average, said Edward Altman, a professor of finance at the Stern School of Business at New York University. RCN filed for bankruptcy protection in May after failing to lure enough customers to pay debts amassed while expanding its networks. The company will fully repay its banks, including J.P. Morgan Chase, $432.5 million. All current stock in the company will be canceled. Shareholders will receive warrants to purchase up to 2 percent of the common stock in the company, according to court filings.

title: Not as Good as Gold
description: We were among those thrilled at the astonishing come-from-behind heroics of the American gymnast Paul Hamm in the men's gymnastics all-around competition at the Olympic Games last week. Mr. Hamm, who had been favored to win a gold medal, looked as if he had blown it when he stumbled and fell off the mat in the vaulting event, dropping him to 12th place. But in the final two events, the parallel bars and the high bar, he earned stunning marks that, when coupled with faltering performances by some leading competitors, propelled him to the head of the pack. It was an inspiring story of an athlete who had triumphed over seemingly impossible odds. The only trouble was, it now turns out that he didn't really deserve the gold.

title: Fighting the Sources of Asthma
description: Parents of children with asthma often try to rid their homes of the things that can set off wheezing or coughing spells: furry pets, dust mites, secondhand smoke and plant pollen. But their well-intentioned efforts are often a waste of time.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Retail Sales Rise
description: Retail sales rose 0.2 percent, to 28.7 billion Canadian dollars ($22.1 billion) in June, the second-weakest performance this year, Statistics Canada reported yesterday. Sales by auto retailers rose 1.5 percent, while sales of all other products fell for the first time since December, dropping 0.5 percent. Furniture, home furnishing and electronics stores sold 1.7 percent less in June, and sales of clothes and accessories fell 1.0 percent. Cool summer months probably hindered purchases of wares other than cars, the agency said. For the second quarter, retailers increased sales 1.3 percent, slower than the 2.3 percent gain in the first three months.

title: Finest, Bravest, Greediest?
description: With the Republican National Convention about to come to town, leaders of the city's police and firefighter unions are taking advantage of the national attention focused on New York to make their case to the public. In TV ads, on billboards and at sidewalk rallies, the unions' message is the same: because the city does not pay its cops and firefighters an adequate wage, New York cannot attract or retain skilled uniformed workers.

title: CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER RESIGNS AT STEEL DYNAMICS
description: Steel Dynamics Inc., which produces steel from recycled metal, said its chief financial officer, Tracy Shellabarger, resigned to pursue other business interests and to spend more time with his children. Theresa Wagler, the company's assistant secretary and chief accounting officer, was named acting chief financial officer, Steel Dynamics said in a regulatory filing. Mr. Shellabarger will assist in the transition while the company seeks a replacement. His decision to leave was unrelated to any financial issues, the filing said. The company's second-quarter profit surged as it raised prices to take advantage of growing demand. Steel Dynamics is based in Fort Wayne, Ind.

title: NOVARTIS WINS U.S. APPROVAL FOR NEW USE OF ZELNORM
description: Novartis, the Swiss drug maker, won Food and Drug Administration approval to sell Zelnorm, its irritable-bowel medicine, as a treatment for chronic constipation in people younger than 65. Regulators approved the new use after two trials showed that taking the drug twice a day reduced symptoms of chronic constipation, a Novartis spokeswoman, Carrie Callahan, said. The United States is the 11th country to approve Zelnorm for chronic constipation. The drug has been sold in the United States since 2002 as a treatment for women with short-term irritable-bowel syndrome.

title: Tweaking the Math to Make Happier Medical Marriages
description: Earlier this month, a federal district court dismissed an antitrust challenge to the Residency Match, the program that assigns medical students to residency positions. The plaintiffs say they will continue their legal efforts, but whatever the outcome, the case has already captured the attention of mathematical economists, who are wrestling with a question at the heart of it: By making it difficult for students to negotiate the terms of employment, does the match program enable hospitals to underpay residents?

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Airline's Bankruptcy Plan Approved
description: Air Canada, the country's largest carrier, won court clearance yesterday to leave bankruptcy on Sept. 30 with a plan that will give bondholders most of the equity and reduce labor costs by 1.1 billion Canadian dollars ($847.4 million) a year. Judge James Farley of Ontario Superior Court, who has overseen the case since Air Canada sought bankruptcy protection on April 1, 2003, approved the plan at a hearing in Toronto. The airline will have 2.87 billion Canadian dollars of long-term debt when it emerges, down from 4.3 billion dollars. Under the plan, creditors, including a General Electric unit and Deutsche Bank, will have most of the equity.

title: MEMO PAD
description: SOUTHWEST SHIFTS ITS SCHEDULES -- Southwest Airlines said it would cut 88 daily flights from its fall schedule to concentrate more of its planes on highly competitive markets like Philadelphia, the US Airways bastion where Southwest began service May 9. The schedule changes will trim flight frequencies in small and medium-size cities like Albuquerque; Kansas City, Mo.; New Orleans; Little Rock, Ark.; and Austin, El Paso and Lubbock, Tex. But big hub airports like Los Angeles International, Houston Intercontinental and Dallas-Fort Worth International will also lose a small number of daily flights, said Ed Stewart, a Southwest spokesman. ''Philadelphia is certainly one of the places where we are growing faster than any of our other city openings in recent history,'' he said. Other city-pair routes on which Southwest will add flights include: Hobby Airport at Houston and Orlando, Fla.; Houston Hobby and Los Angeles; Baltimore and Nashville; Chicago Midway and Tampa, Fla.; Las Vegas and Tucson, Ariz.; and St. Louis and Oklahoma City. Joe Brancatelli, the publisher of the business-travel Web site JoeSentMe.com, said Southwest's move made sense. ''It's what smart airlines do,'' he said. ''Only in the airline industry is inventory management considered a radical proposition.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Group Claims Jewish Arson Attack
description: French investigators are looking into a statement on an Islamist Web site that claimed responsibility for an arson attack on Sunday on a Jewish center in Paris, though they are skeptical that the claims are true. The statement, purporting to be from a previously unknown group called Jamaat Ansar al-Jihad, said its members set fire to the center ''in retaliation for the racist acts carried out by the Jews in France against Islam and Muslims, and acts of defiling Muslims' cemeteries.'' description: Pfizer Inc. said the Food and Drug Administration approved Geodon, an anti-psychotic medicine, for treating bipolar disorder. In a study, Geodon eased manic symptoms and sustained the improvements for three weeks without causing weight gains, a side effect of some bipolar medicines. Pfizer, which is based in New York, is counting on additional uses for medicines like Geodon to increase sales as the company loses patent protections over the next few years for some of its best-selling drugs. Geodon had 2003 sales of $353 million. Pfizer's 2003 sales were $45.2 billion. Geodon was approved in 2001 in the United States to treat schizophrenia.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Wider African Role In Darfur Rejected
description: At the start of peace talks in Nigeria aimed at ending the conflict in the western Sudan region of Darfur, Sudan rejected an expanded role for African Union troops. The Nigerian president, Olusegun Obasanjo, the chairman of the African Union, suggested at the outset of the talks that African soldiers could play a role in disarming the government-backed militias that have run rampant in Darfur. But Mazjoub al-Khalifa, Sudan's agriculture minister and its top negotiator, rejected the idea. The government is negotiating with two rebel groups. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Congressman Illegally Shared Wiretap Tape, Judge Rules

While designed to provide a short-term boost to Israel's embattled prime minister, Ariel Sharon, this cynical change in administration policy will have important long-term costs. It will further demoralize Israeli and Palestinian moderates, frustrate Washington's closest European and Middle Eastern allies, and undermine the American-backed road map peace plan, which, though a long shot, is the only current peaceful political alternative.

title: Downtown, a Trailblazer Matures
description: BY most rights, 71 Clinton Fresh Food should be a negligible restaurant ? a faded memory, a postscript. So much has changed since it opened on the Lower East Side nearly five years ago and ascended fleetly into the culinary firmament. Back then, it had a different master, a different menu and a much different mojo. It was a lonely beacon in a frumpy neighborhood, a colony of hip on an unconquered continent. title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Study Finds Depression In Caregivers

The depression symptoms can stem from stress, guilt, lack of control over care and the knowledge that a loved one's health is declining, said Dr. Richard Schulz, the lead researcher on the study and a professor at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine. Researchers interviewed 1,222 people who cared for Alzheimer's patients, 180 of whom placed a patient in a care facility during the 18-month study.

description: Scott Peterson denied to his mistress, Amber Frey, involvement in the disappearance of his pregnant wife, Laci, and did nothing to dissuade her from going to the police, Ms. Frey acknowledged during the defense lawyer's cross-examination in Mr. Peterson's murder trial. The lawyer, Mark Geragos, replayed recordings of Mr. Peterson repeatedly telling Ms. Frey, ''I had nothing to do with it.'' Mr. Geragos tried to cast doubt on Ms. Frey's credibility, asking her about her cooperation with the police, who fed Ms. Frey questions and talking points in their effort to secure incriminating statements from Mr. Peterson. During one call played in court, Ms. Frey asks, ''I can assume she's possibly missing because you love me?'' Mr. Peterson, who never professed his love, replied that his wife was missing because ''someone abducted her.'' Carolyn Marshall (NYT)

The benefits fund receives more than $120 million a year from the city and helps pay for prescription, optical and dental services for the union's 121,000 members. title: Berlin Brouhaha
description: A leading German art historian has accused the New York-based curators of the ''MoMA in Berlin'' exhibition of cultural colonialism. The show, with more than 200 20th-century masterworks from the Museum of Modern Art, is on view through Sept. 19. Writing in the national daily Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, the historian, Werner Spies, a former director of the National Museum of Modern Art at the Pompidou Center in Paris, said the exhibition minimized the impact of European artists on new American painting in an ''outrageous way'' that ''seems to be downright colonialist.'' He argued that the failure to include European artists like Matisse, Max Ernst, Dubuffet and Giacometti in the part of the exhibition that focuses on the last 50 years of 20th-century art suggests that ''the Americans who chose the selections are engaging in cultural politics.'' His accusations were rebuffed by Peter Raue, the president of the Friends of National Gallery, who helped take the exhibition to Berlin. He said: ''It is completely exaggerated to talk about American colonialism in this context. Every visitor can easily figure out by himself that this is an American exhibition.'' KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

title: Crazy Horse Writ Large And Dream To Match
description: There are no authenticated photographs of Chief Crazy Horse, the enigmatic and ill-fated Sioux warrior who routed Lt. Col. George Armstrong Custer at the Battle of Little Bighorn only to die, in 1877, at the hands of an American soldier outside a Nebraska jail. Yet his visage is the first thing visible when one turns off of Highway 16/385 onto the Avenue of the Chiefs here, where it rises out of Thunderhead Mountain like an American sphinx. Only partly finished, this sculpture is already promoted as the world's tallest.

title: The Short Story Shakes Itself Out of Academe
description: Almost no one makes a living from writing short stories anymore. The story has to a large extent been severed from its traditional roots -- from popular, large-circulation magazines, that is -- and it has been transplanted into the greenhouses of the academy. Collections of stories occasionally sell more than modestly, especially if they're by new authors, like the recent or fairly recent books by Nathan Englander, Nell Freudenberger, Z.Z. Packer, and Maile Meloy. On the other hand John Updike's ''Early Stories: 1953-1975,'' which came out last year, a monumental collection by one of the form's great masters, earned glowing reviews and never cracked the New York Times best-seller list. Except for books by Louis L'Amour and Stephen King, the last short story collections to spend time on that list were Adam Haslett's ''You Are Not a Stranger Here,'' a Today show book club pick, and Lorrie Moore's ''Birds of America,'' published in1999, which may have been lofted there on the strength of a single piece, the knockout, heartbreaking ''People Like That Are the Only People Here,'' about a children's cancer ward. --

title: CASCADES PURCHASES REMAINING HALF OF DOPACO
description: Cascades Inc., a Canadian maker of paper packaging, bought the half of the closely held Dopaco Inc. that it did not own for $90 million to $100 million to add plants in Asia. Cascades paid $63 million yesterday and agreed to make another payment in May 2005, based on a financial formula it would not disclose. Dopaco, based in Exton, Pa., makes drink cups, food trays and other packaging for fast-food chains. Cascades, based in Kingsey Falls, Quebec, bought 20 percent of Dopaco in May 1997, then increased its ownership in stages to 50 percent in October 2003, said a company spokesman, Marc Jasmin. Dopaco buys boxboard from Cascades to make folding cartons to hold fast food, said Robert Hall, vice president for legal affairs at Cascades.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Stuck At Heathrow
description: Thousands of British Airways passengers were stranded at Heathrow Airport in London after more than 50 flights were canceled because of a staff shortage caused by recruitment delays and workers taking sick leave. The disruption began Monday when British Airways canceled three flights to the United States because of what it called technical problems with aircraft. Many other short-haul flights to and from British and European destinations were canceled because of the staff shortages. August is the airline's busiest month, with an estimated 100,000 passengers a day on its flights to and from Heathrow. Mike Street, a British Airways spokesman, said he was ''extremely sorry'' about the delays. Alan Cowell (NYT)
