title: Metro Briefing | New York: Officer Charged With Threatening Boy
description: A city police officer was charged yesterday with taking a 14-year-old boy to his home in Brownsville, Brooklyn, on Monday and threatening the boy with a gun, the police said last night. The officer, Clive Peters, who has been an officer for two years and who is assigned to the 105th Precinct in Queens, was suspended and charged with endangering the welfare of a child, unlawful imprisonment, menacing and official misconduct. The police said the boy, whose identity was not disclosed, escaped from Officer Peters, and the boy's parents then reported the incident to the police. Police officials said Officer Peters was not on duty on Monday, or when he was arrested yesterday. They said motives remained unclear in the case. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Prison For Indians In Tree Farm Burning

Two of those found guilty have gone into hiding rather than accept the verdict, which has been criticized by human rights groups. More than a dozen other Mapuche leaders are awaiting trial on similar charges. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Bank Workers On Strike
description: An estimated one million employees of India's government-owned banks went on strike Tuesday as part of a countrywide protest demanding higher pay. Trading volume in the foreign exchange market was thin. Volume also fell in the bond market. Nine unions representing bank workers rejected the government's offer of a 9.5 percent raise, demanding twice that much. Government-owned banks are the lifeline in small towns where private banks have still not entered in a big way. Meanwhile, a strike by truckers entered its fourth day yesterday. Truckers are demanding that the government scrap a service tax proposed for freight-booking agents. Saritha Rai (NYT)

Out in the Saronic Gulf, a Greek naval ship bobbed on the water, its satellite dish spinning like an all-seeing eyeball.

title: Quest for Gold Ends Badly For the U.S.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Seeking To Force Care For TB
description: Seattle's health department has asked King County Superior Court to permit the involuntary detention of a person with tuberculosis to compel that person to treat the illness properly. Matias Valenzuela, spokesman for the health department for Seattle and King County, said the court records were under seal, and he could not say whether the order was granted. He did say the patient was working with the health department on a treatment plan. About 155 cases were diagnosed last year, mainly among immigrants and homeless people, Mr. Valenzuela said. Eli Sanders (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANK, LEOPOLD ''MANY''
description: FRANK--Leopold ''Many'', 78. Beloved husband, father, grandfather. Hiker, farmer, mechanic. Loved plants, animals and honest labor. Remembered for being kind, generous, decent, practical, devoted to family. Survived by sons David (Catherine) and Jeffrey (Kristin) and grandchildren Emma, Asher and Elias. Funeral 1PM today, New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Oil Prices Fall for 3rd Day as Fears Ease
description: Oil prices fell for a third day on Tuesday, retreating from the record highs of near $50 a barrel set last week, as exports from Iraq resumed and traders worried less about supply shortages.

description: Some days, running for president amounts to being America's tourist in chief. Except that the snapshots are carefully staged for maximum effect and, instead of being stored in an old scrapbook, sent to newspapers and television stations around the world ( one ran on the front page of today's New York Times).

title: ANADARKO AGREES TO SELL SOME ASSETS IN CANADA
description: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, a producer of oil and natural gas, agreed to sell some Canadian properties to the Advantage Energy Income Fund for $142 million under a plan to shed assets and cut debt. The 35 oil and gas fields included in the sale have proven reserves equivalent to 9.9 million barrels of oil, net of royalties, Anadarko said in a statement. Anadarko, based near Houston, said net production from the fields was equivalent to 4,500 barrels of oil a day. Advantage, which is based in Calgary, Alberta, said the transaction, expected to close by Sept. 30, would help increase its monthly payments to investors by 8.7 percent, to 25 Canadian cents (19 cents) a unit.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Hollinger Director Quits
description: An independent director of Hollinger Inc., Conrad M. Black's holding company, has quit the board citing an excessive workload. The director, Richard Rohmer, left, an author of 23 books, a lawyer and a retired Canadian general who is 80 years old, joined Hollinger's board seven months ago at the height of a controversy over its management, conflicts of interest and oversight. ''I reached this decision as a result of the significant and persistent workload associated with my service on the board, which I did not anticipate when I joined the board,'' Mr. Rohmer said in a statement issued by Hollinger. Hollinger Inc. controls 68 percent of the voting shares of Hollinger International, whose holdings include The Chicago Sun-Times and The Jerusalem Post. Hollinger International has started a $1.25 billion legal action against Lord Black and Hollinger Inc. In separate legal actions, Hollinger Inc. is trying to recover management fees it says it is owed by Hollinger International. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Cupcakes at 15 M.P.H.
description: Having a picnic in Riverside Park? Don't worry about packing dessert. Elaine Cohen, above, is tooling around the park in a little electric wagon on Saturdays and Sundays, selling chocolate, vanilla, carrot and coffeecake cupcakes ($2 each) made by the Cupcake Caboose (www.cupcakecaboose.com), her catering company. Ms. Cohen, who says she is on a mission to improve the food served in public places, also sells iced coffee, iced mint tea and bottled water.

title: Coach Is Still Deciding if Jones Should Run
description: Marion Jones has kept a low public profile in the days leading to her first appearance of these Games on the long-jump runway on Wednesday.

title: Roll, Roll the Dough In a No-Stick Way
description: I love my old-fashioned wooden rolling pins. My favorite is a slender French tapered one without ball bearings. I love the feel of pin on pastry and using the strength of my forearms to expand the circle of tender dough. Nonetheless, I may become a convert to a new rolling pin, the Silpin, a hefty ball-bearing model wrapped in nonstick silicone. I tried it for pte brise, biscuits and somewhat sticky cream cheese dough, all with excellent results: smooth, even, nonstick rolling. I prefer the cushiony model with plastic handles, around $40, to the heavier, more expensive one with shiny zinc alloy handles, around $50. The rolling pins, made in China for Harold Import in Lakewood, N.J., are sold at Art of Cooking, Zabar's and Sur la Table.

title: Freed U.S. Journalist Found Solace in Philosophy During 'Moments of Terror'
description: Not many men have returned safely from the forbidding domain where Micah Garen spent 10 harrowing days this month, as a captive of Islamic militants who took him hostage in the southern city of Nasiriya and threatened to execute him unless American troops withdrew from Najaf.

title: Profit Rises Sharply for Bank of Montreal
description: The Bank of Montreal, Canada's fifth-largest bank, said yesterday that third-quarter profit rose 30 percent, helped by lower provisions for bad loans and higher fees from its consumer banking in Canada and in the United States.

title: Keeping Cool in New York
description: Less than a week before the Republican convention, New York City is in an uncomfortable situation. Flocks of demonstrators are due to arrive this weekend and it still is not clear where they are going to protest. The largest group, United for Peace and Justice, was still in court yesterday trying to win access to Central Park for a Sunday rally. The city was insisting on the West Side Highway. Nothing is resolved, including matters as basic as how protesters who might number in the hundreds of thousands will get drinking water on an August afternoon.

title: Grill Mastery From Japan
description: WE may think of ourselves as a grilling nation, but there is no place on earth where grilling -- and its flip side, broiling -- is as popular as in Japan. Every commercial street in its big cities has at least one shop offering skewered grilled food, with the morsels including whole cloves of garlic, tiny fish, mochi (a rice paste not unlike a very substantial marshmallow) or poultry or meat.

title: Junk E-Mail And Fraud Are Focus Of Crackdown
description: Federal and state law enforcement agencies have quietly arrested or charged dozens of people with crimes related to junk e-mail, identity theft and other online scams in recent weeks, according to several people involved in the actions.

description: Elisabeth Kubler-Ross, the psychiatrist whose pioneering work in counseling terminally ill patients helped to revolutionize the care of the dying, enabling people all over the world to die more peacefully and with greater dignity, died Tuesday at her home in Scottsdale, Ariz. She was 78.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Report Adds Fuel To Welfare Debate
description: Welfare rolls did not rise during the recession of 2001 to 2003, in part because the city stepped up the rejection rate for those seeking aid to 27 percent from 18 percent, according to a report from the Independent Budget Office released yesterday. The report adds fuel to an old debate about the 1995 reform of the city's cash assistance program. Critics have argued that the city is inappropriately blocking individuals seeking aid. But Pat Smith, the first deputy commissioner of the Human Resources Administration, said there were legitimate reasons for the higher rejection rates, including hidden assets ferreted out by computers and better job placement rates for applicants. Leslie Kaufman (NYT)

title: Report Offers No Clear Victory For Charter School Opponents
description: Anyone who has tired of hearing more than 20 years of relentless attacks on public education, dating back to the Reagan administration report on ''A Nation At Risk,'' could be forgiven the temptation to gloat last week, when the critics were hoisted with their own petard of standardized testing.

description: The New York State comptroller's office announced yesterday that it would conduct a thorough audit of Westchester Medical Center, a regional hospital in Valhalla, N.Y., that has been struggling to pull itself out of a financial crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FUCHSBERG, ESTA
description: FUCHSBERG--Esta. Of Great Neck, NY, on August 23, 2004, of complications from ovarian cancer. Beloved wife of Seymour for 50 years. Loving mother of Jane, Paula and Gil and devoted mother-in-law of Debbie. Adoring grandmother of Ella and Julian. Cherished sister to Lou (and wife Evelyn) and the late Doris, Rose, Joe and Hank. Favorite aunt to numerous nieces and nephews. Born Esta Abramowitz on the Lower East Side, she was the youngest child of Pauline and Thomas. She was an extraordinary woman, a magnetic, fun-loving spirit who brought life, laughter and love to everyone who knew her. Stylish, witty and warm, she generously gave of herself to her family, friends, synagogue and community. She will be deeply missed. Services on Thursday, August 26, at 11:30 A.M. at Riverside/Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. To honor her memory, donations may be made to the Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation, 5 Channel Drive, Port Washington, NY 11050.

title: Shortlist Prize's Long List
description: The Shortlist Music Prize, founded in 2001 for innovative and underground music, has announced its first step for this year's award: a ''long list'' of 73 names that next month will be winnowed down to 10 finalists. The artists who made this first cut are a diverse bunch, including Franz Ferdinand, Loretta Lynn, Dizzee Rascal, Devendra Banhart, TV on the Radio, the Killers, Ghostface Killah, the Wrens, Bebel Gilberto and Nellie McKay. The selection panel of 20 musicians, journalists and filmmakers included Norah Jones, Jim Jarmusch, Robert Smith of the Cure, Ahmir Thompson of the Roots, Jack Black and John Mayer. The $10,000 award will be presented at a concert in Los Angeles on Nov. 10. BEN SISARIO

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Motives Unclear In Three Shootings
description: The motives for three separate attacks in the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn on Monday night that left four men dead remained unclear yesterday, the police said. At 357 Legion Street in Brownsville, Brooklyn, three men were shot shortly after 11 p.m. Two of them, David Smith, 19, of Canarsie, and Alfonso Fearon, 29, of Broadway Junction, died. A third, 16, was in serious condition at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center. In Jamaica, Queens, about 7:50 p.m., a man on a bicycle shot three men standing on a corner, killing one, identified as Joe Leverette, 24, of South Jamaica. The other two were reported in stable condition at Mary Immaculate Hospital. The Bronx shooting took place about 7:10 p.m. in front of 2630 Kingsbridge Terrace. A 22-year-old man, whose name was not released, was shot several times in the chest. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Rebels Lift Blockade
description: Maoist rebels who have blockaded the capital, Katmandu, for a week said they were lifting the blockade, news agencies reported. The reports quoted a faxed statement in which the rebels said they had made the decision after considering requests from businesses, human rights advocates and citizens. But they warned that the blockade could be reimposed in a month if their demands for the release of detained Maoists and for inquiries into missing and dead comrades are not met. Before the announcement that the blockade was being lifted, Maoists enforcing it killed at least four soldiers and wounded two after ambushing an army truck on the highway between Katmandu and Tibet. The government again expressed its willingness to talk to the Maoists, but said it would not accept preconditions. The Maoists withdrew from peace talks last August. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Former Museum Official Pleads To Theft
description: A former museum conservator, charged with stealing more than 100 artifacts from the Nassau County Museum, pleaded guilty yesterday to a felony charge of possessing stolen property, the Nassau district attorney, Denis Dillon, said. Under the plea agreement, Richard Kappeler must pay $249,158 in restitution to the county, the state and Christie's auction house. He faces a sentence of one and a half to four and a half years. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Cognos Offers To Buy Frango For $52 Million
description: Cognos Inc., the largest Canadian software maker, has offered to buy Frango of Sweden for 390.8 million kronor ($52 million) to expand in corporate performance management software. Frango shares surged as much as 62 percent. Cognos said yesterday that it offered 85 kronor for each Frango Class B share. Cognos, based in Ottawa, also offered 93.5 kronor for Frango Class A shares, which are not publicly traded. The offer for the Class B shares is a premium of 63 percent over Frango's closing price on Monday. Cognos's chief executive, Robert G. Ashe, who took over in June, wants to use the company's $420 million in cash to make takeovers and broaden the product range, which is needed to attract bigger companies and achieve a goal of reaching $1 billion in sales. Microsoft said last month it might develop business intelligence software, challenging companies like Cognos and Business Objects. Shares of Cognos fell 17 cents, to $32.40.

title: If Life Gives You Ugly Berries, Make Sorbet
description: This rainy summer has not been kind to the berries that Franca Tantillo, below, sells in the Union Square Greenmarket on Wednesdays and Fridays: they taste just fine but are not as pretty as usual. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSTON, ALISTAIR
description: JOHNSTON -- Alistair. Of Riverside, CT, and Rancho Santa Fe, CA, died suddenly at his home in California on August 19. He was born in Glasgow, Scotland on June 7, 1937 and, after service in the Highland Light Infantry, began a career in Reinsurance at Lloyds of London. He moved to the U.S. in 1961 to work for General Reinsurance where he became a vice president as well as president of Herbert Clough, a General Re subsidiary until he retired in 1997. An avid golfer, fly fisherman, and bicyclist as well as wine enthusiast, he also served on the Board of Directors of the nonprofit agency FIRST and as secretary of a family foundation. He was a devoted father and thrilled to be the grandfather of six. Sadly, he was predeceased by a son, Cameron in March. He is survived by two other children, Andrew and Rosemary; his wife of twenty-one years, Penelope; his sister, Elspeth Clark; two step daughters, Sheila Dietz and Katherine Penna; and his former wife, Melissa MacKenzie. A memorial service will be held September 10, at 4 p.m. at The Recital Hall, The Performing Arts Center, Purchase College, 735 Anderson Hill Rd., Purchase, NY. Contributions may be made in his memory to The Alliance of Information and Referral Systems 211, 11240 Waples Mill Rd., Suite 200, Fairfax, VA 22030 or to Partnership For After School Education, 120 Bway, NY, NY 10271.

That approach, which NASA experts deem increasingly credible, could help Mr. O'Keefe escape the box he got into by canceling a planned servicing mission by astronauts in the wake of the Columbia accident.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DELACORTE, ALBERT
description: DELACORTE -- Albert. The Board of Trustees, the faculty, students and staff of Teachers College, Columbia University are deeply saddened by the passing of Albert Delacorte, who was a friend of the College and of education. Mr. Delacorte, an alumnus of Teachers College, was dedicated to working with underserved young people through education-spending many years as a teacher, himself, and providing financial support for initiatives in the arts, the City and the schools. His generous support of the Peace Corps Fellows Program at Teachers College continues to make a tremendous difference in the lives of the Fellows teaching in New York City schools and in the lives of the children they teach. Many hundreds of people have benefited from Mr. Delacorte's generosity without ever having known his name. His enthusiasm, devotion and vision toward improving urban education serve as an inspiration to us all. Arthur Levine, President, Teachers College, Columbia University

Back then, it had a different master, a different menu and a much different mojo. It was a lonely beacon in a frumpy neighborhood, a colony of hip on an unconquered continent. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Jurors Hear Tapes In Bribe Case
description: Prosecutors played some 40 taped telephone conversations yesterday that they contend prove that an electronics salesman, a lawyer and two court employees were attempting to steer a divorce case to Justice Gerald P. Garson of State Supreme Court. The defendants in the Brooklyn case -- Paul Sarnell, a clerk for Justice Garson, and Louis Salerno, a court officer -- are charged with receiving bribes and participating in the conspiracy to steer the cases of Paul Siminovsky, a lawyer, to Justice Garson. Prosecutors say the judge received cash and gifts from Mr. Siminovsky as payment for ruling in his clients' favor. In the tapes from February and March 2003 heard yesterday, Mr. Sarnell, who was then retired, talks with the electronics salesman, Nissim Elmann, about how to get Mr. Siminovsky's case assigned to Judge Garson. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

description: Toronto-Dominion Bank is in advanced negotiations to buy control of Banknorth, based in Portland, Me., in a deal worth more than $3 billion, executives close to the talks said yesterday. The deal would give Toronto-Dominion, which has $300 billion in assets, a foothold in the New England consumer market. Banknorth, with about $30 billion in assets, has more than 350 branches in northern New England and upstate New York. In June, Banknorth announced that it would acquire the parent company of the Boston Federal Savings Bank in a cash and stock deal worth $195 million. The executives cautioned that any deal between Toronto-Dominion and Banknorth was not yet final and could still be abandoned. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Samsung Says L.C.D. Prices Need To Fall 20%
description: The Samsung Electronics Company, the world's largest maker of liquid crystal displays, said yesterday that L.C.D. prices need to fall 20 percent in the third quarter for demand to pick up in the final three months of the year. ''Prices, particularly for L.C.D. televisions, are too high for the average person,'' said Lee Sang Wan, president for the flat-screen display business of the company, based in Suwon, South Korea. ''The second-half outlook for the market looks soft.'' Demand will probably pick up in the fourth quarter, led by monitors, said Mr. Lee, who spoke to reporters at the International Meeting on Information Display in Daegu, south of Seoul. His comments underscored concern that producers might have overestimated consumers' willingness to replace glass tube screen televisions with slimmer L.C.D. versions at a premium. On Monday, the market researcher DisplaySearch cut its global L.C.D. sales outlook for 2004 by 13 percent, to $36 billion, citing rising inventories that are cutting the prices of flat televisions and computer monitors. The industry had 2003 sales of $24 billion. Shares of the world's five largest L.C.D. makers have fallen 13 percent to 31 percent in the last three months, amid concern that growth in demand will not live up to expectations. DisplaySearch said a 17-inch monitor that sold for $459 to consumers in the second quarter could fall as low as $299 to $349 by this holiday season in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITE, MARJORIE (NEE TAGGART), M.D.
description: WHITE--Marjorie (nee Taggart), M.D. Psychologist and psychoanalyst, died in New York Hosptial on August 17, 2004 at the age of 88. She had suffered from Alzheimer's disease for many years. Dr. White was born in Upstate New York and attended the University of Rochester, where she earned her undergraduate and graduate degrees. A pioneer in the selfpsychology movement, she enthusiastically mentored many psychologists. A lifelong member of the American Psychological Association, Dr. White was a prolific author of books and professional journal articles. Dr. White had been pre-deceased by her husband, Llewelyn ''John'' White, who had been an editor of Newsweek magazine. A memorial service was held on Monday, August 23, 2004. Contributions for research may be sent to the Alzheimer's Association, 180 North LaSalle St., Chicago, IL. 60601.

title: KERR-MCGEE RAISES FORECAST FOR OIL PRODUCTION
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation has raised its forecast for oil output in the third quarter because a field in the Gulf of Mexico is exceeding expectations. The company expects oil production to average 156,000 to 170,000 barrels a day, beating an earlier forecast of 142,000 to 155,000, a spokeswoman, Debbie Schramm, said. Higher oil production at the Gulf of Mexico field, called Nansen, will delay gas output there, Kerr-McGee said. The company, based in Oklahoma City, pared its third-quarter projection for daily gas production to a range of 1.06 billion to 1.14 billion cubic feet a day from a previous forecast of 1.16 billion to 1.24 billion.

Fire officials also said that they had initiated termination proceedings against Christian Waugh, 33, one of the first two suspended firefighters, because he refused to cooperate with the Department of Investigation. title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trade Surplus Widens
description: Brazil's current account surplus widened in July for the 14th consecutive month, bolstered by surging exports, the central bank said yesterday. The country posted a surplus of $1.81 billion last month, up from a surplus of $740 million in the period a year ago. That brought the account, a country's widest measure of foreign transactions, to a surplus of $8.99 billion in the last 12 months, equal to 1.69 percent of gross domestic product. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Plane Maker's Profit Falls
description: The airplane maker Bombardier said second-quarter profit declined 66 percent as its aircraft unit had a loss because of lower deliveries and the higher costs of sales incentives. Net income in the quarter, which ended July 31, dropped to $23 million, or 1 cent a share, from $68 million, or 4 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 1.5 percent, to $3.88 billion, Bombardier said. The company, which is based in Montreal, had lower profit margins in its airplane and train units in the quarter. The aircraft unit had a pretax loss of $12 million, in contrast to a profit of $19 million a year ago, while profit from train equipment fell 39 percent, to $46 million, because of higher costs on some contracts.

Sliding doors are made of plexiglass and wood. Solid beech furnishings include beds, a table and stools, and there is a kitchen island and a shower similar to one by Boffi. Sadly, Malibu Barbie will not fit. The house, distributed by Ameico, is $585; for store locations, (888) 350-8765.

title: War in Iraq, Viewed Through the Blurred Lens of Rural America
description: It's called shooting fish in a barrel. Asked to express their opinions about the war in Iraq, the mostly unidentified subjects of this documentary polemic, ''This Ain't No Heartland,'' are only too happy to make fools of themselves. Their fundamental ignorance of the facts, compounded by their disinterest in knowing more, doesn't prevent them from expressing strong opinions and conveying misinformation in bad grammar.

title: Like That Nicholson Movie, Only a Lot Darker
description: 'The Last Detail'

title: Judge Bars Big Rally in Park, But Protest March Is Still Set
description: A state judge ruled yesterday that organizers of the largest protest planned during the week of the Republican National Convention may not hold a rally in Central Park on Sunday, throwing into doubt what thousands of people will do after marching to the Midtown convention site.

title: Give Your Name to the Police? Advice to Protesters Differs
description: Some civil liberties groups are advising protesters at the Republican National Convention to refuse to identify themselves to police officers, despite a recent Supreme Court ruling that the police have a right to obtain such information from people suspected of breaking the law.

title: Computer People Reopen Art History Dispute
description: Some art historians may have considered the matter closed. But a fresh clash has surfaced over the painter David Hockney's three-year-old theory that early Renaissance painters used cameralike devices to paint with perfect perspective.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on July 15 about an official British report that criticized the country's prewar intelligence on Iraq misstated one finding of a parallel report released the previous week by the United States Senate Intelligence Committee. Like the British report, the Senate report traced several sources that appeared to substantiate claims that Iraq had sought to buy uranium from Niger; the Senate report did not find that the claims were based on a single set of forged documents. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Calendar
description: Textile Talk

title: A Reign of Words
description: WHEN Gore Vidal isn't writing, he is presiding. Among the pride of lions, literary and otherwise, who have called on him in his Italian salon are Erica Jong and her husband, Kenneth Burrows, a lawyer.

title: APOLLO GROUP SEES IMPROVED FIRST-QUARTER PROFIT
description: The Apollo Group, the operator of the largest for-profit education company in the United States, said first-quarter profit, excluding some costs, would be 56 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter ending Nov. 30 will be $529 million to $532 million, up from $411.8 million a year earlier. Campus enrollment will be 12 percent to 13 percent more than a year earlier, the company said. In the first quarter a year ago, Apollo had net income of $84.3 million, or 44 cents a share. Apollo, based in Phoenix, disclosed its outlook after the close of market trading. In the after-hours market, its stock rose more than 6 percent.

title: For a Brando Retreat, Maybe Birds, Perhaps Hotels
description: When Marlon Brando died last month, his assets included the Polynesian atoll of Tetiaroa (left), 26 miles north of Tahiti, which he purchased in 1966 after ''Mutiny on the Bounty'' was filmed there. It is valued at about $12 million, nearly double that if developed. The French Polynesian Assembly is said to be pondering a proposal to turn the atoll into a bird sanctuary, saving it from developers who have filed permits to build luxury hotels.

title: Settlements and the Road Map
description: To the Editor:

title: Hiding the Truth in a Cloud of Black Ink
description: In September, Congress will reconvene with a common goal at the top of its collective to-do list: reform our intelligence services in order to better protect the country from terrorist threats. Republicans and Democrats bring the best of intentions to their national security responsibilities. But too often, Congress and the American people lack the best information -- in the form of declassified intelligence and national security materials -- to ensure that the job is done right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOY, SISTER MARIE CLEMENTINE
description: FOY--Sister Marie Clementine, beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, Convent of Mary the Queen, died Wednesday, August 25, 2004. Loving sister of Sr. Rita Foy R.C., Eileen McLean & Francis X. Foy. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark Street, Yonkers, NY on Friday 1-8 p.m. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:30 a.m. at the convent. Interment to follow at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Ave., Bronx, NY 10471.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEUBARDT, SELIG B., M.D.
description: NEUBARDT--Selig B., M.D., on August 24, 2004. Survived by his loving wife Saundra and adoring children Andrew (Jane), Seth and Amanda (Seth Miller) and darling grandchildren. In his role as physician, author, husband, father, grandfather and friend, he reflected the finest qualities of the human spirit. He was loved and admired by all who were fortunate to know him and will never be forgotten. Funeral at Kol Ami Synagogue, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains, 10 AM today. In lieu of flowers, donations to Planned Parenthood Hudson Peconic 914-467-7300

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Visits Libya For Migrant Talks
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi arrived in Libya for a meeting with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi that was to focus on ways to keep illegal immigrants from using Libya as a launching point for Italian shores. Only Wednesday, a boat believed to have left from Libya carried 275 illegal migrants to the Sicilian island of Lampedusa. Mr. Berlusconi said he would ask for increased vigilance of Libya's coast and the creation of holding centers there for illegal immigrants. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Monday about the Olympic women's marathon -- in which Paula Radcliffe of Britain dropped out with less than four miles to go -- misstated the earlier year in which she set the world record, 2 hours 15 minutes 25 seconds. It was 2003, not 2000.

title: Stolen Art Can Reappear in Unexpected Ways
description: If they are recovered at all, stolen art masterpieces like ''The Scream'' and ''Madonna,'' the two Edvard Munch paintings torn from the walls of an Oslo museum on Sunday, can come to light at unexpected times and in unexpected places.

title: War-Crimes Case at Guantnamo Base Thrown Into Confusion
description: GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, Aug. 26  A 36-year-old Yemeni on trial here for conspiracy to commit terrorism threw the military commission proceedings into confusion today when he said that he was a member of Al Qaeda and that if he were not allowed to represent himself he would boycott the trial and, if forced to attend, would sit silently in the courtroom.

title: Who's Knocking at the Door? Check Your E-Mail First
description: THE Internet is renowned for its ability to create communities of people with common interests, no matter where in the world they are. But a new Web site aims to build a community among users who are not so far-flung.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Art From Junk (Mail)

title: A Great Big Family With One Busy Member
description: 'Decoding the Tablecloth'

title: A Woman in Search Of a Closet Whisperer
description: IF life were fair, we would all have closets like that of Candy Spelling, the wife of the television producer Aaron Spelling. Built in the couple's mansion in the Holmby Hills section of Los Angeles, her enormous dressing chambers are equipped with motorized racks like the ones dry cleaners use, which instantly summon sables and Valentinos to her side.

title: Hockey Dude Knows His Badminton (No, Really)
description: Among the most unusual things said on American sports television in my lifetime was this, from Bill Clement, during the Olympics: ''New feathers.'' He also said, ''Bird change request by Gao Ling,'' as well as: ''Once the feathers get frayed, it affects the flight of the bird, and it becomes a game of chance. You have no idea how the bird will react.''

title: U.S. Issues Its First Plan for Responding to a Flu Pandemic
description: Galvanized by the SARS epidemic and the spread of avian flu, the Bush administration yesterday issued the first national plan for how the country should prepare for and respond to a pandemic of influenza, should it strike the United States.

title: When Pacer Leaves, Riders Hit the Finish Line
description: As far as an Olympic moment goes, Nikoglok Xenephon may have experienced the oddest. He drives the Derny, a moped designed and built specifically to pace cyclists in the men's Keirin competition.

title: Hank Borowy, 88, Top Pitcher With Yankees and Cubs in 40's
description: Hank Borowy, a right-handed pitcher who helped the Yankees capture pennants in 1942 and 1943, then starred for the last Chicago Cubs team to reach the World Series, died Monday at his home in Brick, N.J. He was 88.

title: One Way to Get Online: Piggyback
description: ABOUT to begin graduate school, Radha Patel needed a high-speed Internet connection at her Brooklyn apartment. She turned first to her cable company, only to encounter weeks of technical and bureaucratic hurdles.

title: Warner To Start Against The Jets
description: When Giants Coach Tom Coughlin pulled aside Eli Manning and Kurt Warner as they came out of a meeting Wednesday morning, he told them that Warner would start against the Jets on Friday.

title: Seeing Their Way Clear to Letting the Public Take a Peek
description: MAYBE 311 works for zoning violations, too.

title: Playing Catch-Up With Sheffield
description: The now-familiar-looking 11-year-old with slits for eyes, a space between his two front teeth and the beginning of a mischievous grin announced himself to a national audience during the introductions for the 1980 Little League World Series.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Police Shoot Man And Free Hostage
description: The Toronto police fired one shot and freed a hostage by killing her armed assailant after a 40-minute standoff in front of Union Station, the city's main train station. Hundreds of horrified commuters watched the sequence of events, at the height of the morning rush hour. The man had grabbed the woman in front of the station as a policeman pursued him after he allegedly shot andwounded another women, believed to be his estranged wife, at a nearby underground food court. Heavily armed officers then surrounded the man and tried to negotiate with him before shooting him. The hostage, described as being in her 20's, was unharmed. Identities of the people involved were not immediately released. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Wounds Opened Anew As Vietnam Resurfaces
description: Many of them are bent and broken, grayer and wider. Some carry shrapnel from a step too far, an ambush replayed over and over. All carry memories. And now as the debate over service 35 years ago in a war that will not entirely fade roils the presidential campaign, Vietnam veterans wonder if they are doomed to take the arguments that divided a nation to their graves.

title: Tackling the High Cost of Health Benefits Takes Some Creativity
description: Dave Ratner, the owner of a small retail chain in western Massachusetts called Dave's Soda and Pet City, took a gamble with his firm's health insurance this year.

title: PEPSICO WINS BEVERAGE CONTRACT FROM QUIZNOS
description: PepsiCo Inc., which lost Subway Restaurants as a major fountain customer last year to Coca-Cola, has won the United States beverage and snack business of the Quiznos Corporation. The agreement, which covers 3,600 restaurants, will end the sandwich chain's 23-year relationship with Coke. Quiznos already sells snacks from Frito-Lay, a PepsiCo unit, alongside other brands. Frito-Lay is expected to make up a larger percentage of Quiznos's business under the new deal. The conversion to Pepsi soft drinks and noncarbonated drinks will start early next year.

title: To Oppose War, a Campaigner Learns Diplomacy
description: WILLIAM K. DOBBS remembers the first time he telephoned a news organization. He was about 10 years old, calling The Associated Press. ''I wanted to know how to get news quicker,'' he said. ''I asked how much it would cost to get an A.P. ticker. They said they'd look into it.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic Trial Reset For Tuesday
description: After repeated delays on doctors' orders, Slobodan Milosevic is now scheduled to begin his defense on Tuesday, the war crimes tribunal confirmed. The panel of three judges that is trying the former Yugoslav president for war crimes also said that for now it would not split the enormous indictment, which spans three wars over 10 years. The judges had asked the parties' opinions on whether carving up the indictment would speed up the process and reduce the workload for Mr. Milosevic, 62, whose faltering health has frequently brought the trial to a halt. The judges are expected to rule next week on whether they will impose a defense counsel on Mr. Milosevic, who conducts his own defense.

title: With Hurricane Charley, a Federal Agency Gets a New Chance to Prove Itself
description: Correction Appended

title: A Traditionalist Takes Off Along the Edge of Audacity
description: Diana Krall arrived at Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday evening with a lot to prove. Having methodically built a career as a formidable pop-jazz traditionalist who suggested a hybrid of Peggy Lee, Nat King Cole and Oscar Peterson, Ms. Krall seemed poised to coast for decades recording tasteful albums of standards.

title: An American Fights, and Wins, To Make His Grandfather Happy
description: From the center of the ring, Andre Dirrell heard voices screaming at his back, warning him to circle away from the boxer closing in.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: For Gore Vidal, A Last, Long Look From the Heights
description: THE forever view of the Gulf of Salerno from Gore Vidal's villa rising operatically from the bluffs mirrors the expansive panorama that Tiberius once savored from his clifftop palace on the island of Capri. Facing nearly the same view, each man lived life at the edge of a precipice of his own choosing. ''We have a lot in common,'' said Mr. Vidal, his mordant wit already primed as he faced a morning's portion of granola earlier this month.

title: Days of Protests, Vigils and Street Theater (Thongs, Too)
description: They promise to carry a thousand coffins in tribute to fallen soldiers, ''ring out'' the Republicans with chiming bells, bare their anti-Bush thong underwear, don masks to pay tribute to the poor and forgotten, chant, drum, sing and of course, march, march and march, with and without police permission.

title: Deal for Mountain West
description: College Sports Television will announce a deal with the Mountain West Conference today that will let the young network carry Division I football and basketball games for the first time. The package, which includes the rights to all the conference's other sports, became available when ESPN did not renew it yesterday.

title: Canadians Confirm Talks On Bank Deal
description: The Toronto-Dominion Bank confirmed on Wednesday that it was negotiating to buy all or part of the Banknorth Group, which has branches in five New England states and upstate New York.

title: For Graphic Artists, Back to the Barricades
description: ''MAKE nice,'' urge the banners flying near Madison Square Garden, where some 5,000 Republican delegates will meet next week. But those who venture farther may encounter a different message, in the form of graphically brazen, un-nice-making posters protesting Republican administration policies.

description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, MARSHALL
description: KLEIN--Marshall, on August 24, 2004, at the age of 86. Beloved husband of the late Hanna. Loving father of Robert and his wife Carol, and Susan and her husband Russell. Adoring grandfather of Loren and Michael Klein, and Hanna. Dear brother of Samuel. Cherished companion of Florence Neidich. Mr. Klein was a principal of Crown Products of Yonkers, NY. Funeral service Thursday, August 26, 2004, 1 PM from ''Westchester Reform Temple'', 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY.

title: Some Abu Ghraib Abuses Are Traced to Afghanistan
description: Some of the aggressive tactics used by American military interrogators at Abu Ghraib prison now appear to have had their origins in shadowy corners of the campaign against terrorism, following interrogation techniques developed by Special Operations forces and the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Law Banning Type of Abortion Is Unconstitutional, Judge Says
description: Afederal judge in New York ruled today that a federal law that banned a form of abortion is unconstitutional because it does not include an exception for cases where the procedure might be necessary to protect a woman's health. The law, the Partial Birth Abortion Ban Act, enacted in November, makes it a crime for doctors to perform any "overt act" to "kill the partially delivered living fetus."

title: Against Undefeated Spain, U.S. Hopes Good Is Good Enough
description: Allen Iverson answers his telephone with caution.

description: ''I thought Vietnam was over a few years ago, but apparently not.''

Rearden Jr. Dear grandmother of John B. III, Jennifer H., Sandra C., Thomas O. Farnham and Brian N. Farnham. Reposing Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9PM at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave, Bronx. Service Thursday 11AM at Riverdale Presbyterian Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Hernndez Delivers, But Yanks' Relief Slips
description: The pieces had fallen into place for the Yankees. Orlando Hernndez, who had been good enough to make the Yankees unbeaten in the previous eight games he started, had staked the team to a one-run lead. Paul Quantrill had done his part with a scoreless inning, and it was left to Tom Gordon to get through the eighth inning.

description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New Rules For Gas And Electricity
description: State regulators said yesterday that new rules governing the retail energy market in New York, in which companies buy gas and electricity in bulk and resell it to individual consumers, would increase competition and provide customers with clearer options for getting their power. By requiring companies to elaborate on how they determine their prices, the new policy makes it easier for competitors to compare pricing plans, the Public Service Commission said. The new policy will also allow groups of customers, like those in apartment buildings or large commercial buildings, to win savings by signing aggregate contracts. The new policy will also expand the commission's efforts to publicize competing price plans. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POLK, HERBERT P.
description: POLK--Herbert P. July 8, 1918-August 25, 2004. Beloved husband of the late Irene Josephson. Loving father of Buddy and his wife Debby, Jim and his wife Laney, Jon and his wife Nancy. Proud and cherished grandfather of Richard, Jenna, Alex and Emily. Loving uncle to Francine. Graduate of Cornell University and Cornell Law School. Partner in Parr, Doherty, Polk & Sargent and Whitman & Ransom where he had a highly distinguished career as a property insurance litigator. Herb worked hard and played hard and he will leave a void in the hearts of all who knew him. Services today 9:45am at Riverside Nassau North Chapels.

title: Oil Price Off As Data Show Steady Supply Of Gasoline
description: Crude oil prices fell yesterday for the fourth consecutive session, influenced by an Energy Department report that the nation's supply of gasoline was unchanged last week.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Court Calls Lesbian Parent 'Legally A Stranger'
description: The state's highest court has ruled that a woman who consented to having a child with her former lesbian partner and helped her choose a sperm donor at a fertility clinic in 1999 is not required to pay child support to the mother. In a 4-to-3 ruling that upholds a lower court decision, Associate Justice Judith A. Cowin wrote that because the woman, ''B.L.'' in court records, did not ''become a de facto parent by virtue of a long-term relationship with the child'' or adopt him, she is ''legally a stranger to the child.'' Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Wright, Hitting Third, Can't Do It All for Mets
description: The Mets wanted to ease David Wright into the major league life, alleviate the pressure on his 21-year-old shoulders, ensure that a player fresh from the minor leagues would not have to carry the burden for an entire organization.

title: ABUSES AT PRISON TIED TO OFFICERS IN INTELLIGENCE
description: A high-level Army investigation has found that military intelligence soldiers played a major role in directing and carrying out the abuses of Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison. The report undercut earlier contentions by military officials and the Bush administration that a handful of renegade military police guards were largely to blame.

title: Sports of The Times; I.O.C. Ignores Snub, But Israel Stands Tall
description: HE was the brown-eyed windsurfer with a gentle waviness to his thick hair, perched last night atop a medal stand, struggling to keep his tin voice on key as he sang a national anthem called ''The Hope.''

description: MY children complain that since they became tennis orphans, the inside of our refrigerator has started to resemble a bachelor's.

title: When Married Couples Play, Murder May Be in the Cards
description: ''How to Murder Your Wife,'' the hilarious 1965 Jack Lemmon movie, offered guidance on how to do the deed and get away with it. The other side of the coin, in real life, was the Bennett murder in 1929. Myrtle Bennett shot her husband dead because he had the temerity to criticize her bidding. She was acquitted by an impressionable jury, collected a large insurance payment but had trouble thereafter finding bridge partners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERKOWITZ, WILLIAM
description: BERKOWITZ--William, died August 22, 2004. My close friend for more than 50 years, Bill will always be in my thoughts. I will treasure the good times we had together. Love to his wife, Dale, and the entire Berkowitz family. Fred and the Lansky Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEARLMAN, ALEXANDER W., M.D.
description: PEARLMAN--Alexander W., M.D. Died August 24, 2004 in Jamaica Estates, NY at age 90. Beloved husband of the late Sarah Birstein Pearlman; loving father of Beth Smith, Deborah Pearlman and Ellyn Shander; father-in-law of the late Lewis Lofsky Smith; cherished grandfather of Ethan and Rachel Smith and Eytan Shander. His life was dedicated to medicine, family and the arts. We will remember and miss him.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Consultant's Shares Rise
description: Shares in India's largest software services outsourcing company, Tata Consultancy Services, rose more than 16 percent on their first day of trading. Tata's shares closed at 987.50 rupees ($21.31), up from the offering price of 850 rupees. Tata raised $1.17 billion through the public offering, India's largest by a privately owned company. Tata's market valuation comes to slightly more than $10 billion. India's $12.5 billion outsourcing industry, led by Tata, Wipro and Infosys Technologies, has boomed in recent years, growing more than 30 percent annually. Tata Consultancy is part of the Tata group, a giant Indian industrial conglomerate. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Europe Opens Another Inquiry Involving Microsoft
description: The European Commission has opened an investigation into the planned acquisition of ContentGuard Holdings by Microsoft and Time Warner, a commission spokeswoman said Wednesday. ContentGuard specializes in software that protects digital material from counterfeiting.

description: Correction Appended

description: CARO--Eva. Dearest mother, you are in my heart forever. All my love, Frances

title: CONSOL ENERGY EXPECTS LOSS IN THIRD QUARTER
description: Consol Energy Inc., a coal producer, said it would have a net loss of 30 to 40 cents a share in the third quarter because of lower production and higher costs. The company, based in Pittsburgh, forecast last month that it would earn 5 cents to 10 cents a share. In the third quarter of 2003, Consol had a loss of $5.9 million, or 7 cents. Equipment problems at mines and labor shortages in eastern Kentucky contributed to the production drop, the company said.

description: FITZGERALD--John A. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John A. Fitzgerald, associated with The Times from January 1980, until retiring in May 2002.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts last Thursday about the film ''Shortbus,'' a comedy in which actors have sex on camera, misidentified the project that its director, John Cameron Mitchell, said had scandalized his mother. (The misidentification also occurred on Saturday in a correction in this space.) The project was ''Shortbus'' -- not ''Hedwig and the Angry Inch,'' a drag hit of which he was the creator and star.

title: A Digital Divide
description: Everyone covets a piece of Apple Computer's iPod. And for good reason. It essentially defines what consumers want in a digital music player: capacity, style, seamless integration with personal computers and, through them, access to an enormous musical database. The iPod itself has been wildly successful with consumers, and that translates into profits. The iTunes Music Store has been no less successful in its way, though it has been slower to make money. Apple's business strategy is to maintain control over both the music and its digital player.

title: PILOTS CONSIDERING OFFER FROM US AIRWAYS
description: Leaders of the pilots union at US Airways began meeting yesterday in Arlington, Va., to consider the struggling airline's latest contract offer. The meeting was expected to end Friday. The company is asking for wage and benefit cuts of $295 million a year from the pilots, who are proposing smaller reductions. US Airways wants a total of $800 million in concessions from its unions by Sept. 15 to avoid a second bankruptcy protection filing. The wage and benefit cuts would be the third by union members in two years. On Sunday, negotiators for the union broke off talks with the airline, which asked that its proposal be given to union leaders. The union leaders can endorse the plan and send it to the rank and file for a vote; send it for a vote without an endorsement; reject it; or ask negotiators to resume talks. Micheline Maynard (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: She's Oh So Wonderful and Proud of It
description: 'The Life and Times of Wonder Woman'

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Mediacom-Sprint Phone Deal
description: The cable television provider Mediacom Communications and Sprint plan to jointly offer telephone service in 23 states, the companies said yesterday. Mediacom, based in Middletown, N.Y., will begin offering local and long-distance calling next year as part of a package that includes Internet access and cable TV, John G. Pascarelli, executive vice president for operations at Mediacom, said in an interview. Sprint will make the phone-call connections. Sprint, based in Overland Park, Kan., may offer its customers cable TV in Mediacom's region and Mediacom may market Sprint's mobile-phone service, Mike Smith, director of business development in Sprint's cable division, said in an interview. The Wall Street Journal reported the agreement earlier. Shares of Mediacom rose 5 cents to $6.53. Sprint rose 15 cents to $19.35.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about an independent panel's report on the Abu Ghraib prison abuses misstated the initial of a former defense secretary who headed the panel. He is James R. Schlesinger, not James M.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Wireless Share Offer
description: Telefnica Mviles of Spain and Portugal Telecom, the joint owners of Vivo, Brazil's largest mobile phone company, offered 1.52 billion reais ($515 million) to raise their stake in four wireless units in Brazil. The two companies made the offer through Brasilcel, the holding company that controls Vivo, which already has about 44 percent of Brazil's growing wireless market. In the Brazilian market, Vivo is competing against Amrica Mvil of Mexico and Telecom Italia Mobile of Italy. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: British Farmer Killed
description: A British farmer was shot to death on Tuesday night in Kenya's Rift Valley, but the police said they were treating the killing as a robbery without any apparent connection to a land dispute between Masai tribesmen and ranchers of European descent. The killing of John Christian Palmer Martin, at his home in Naivasha, was the first of a European farmer since Charles Stonewigg, an elderly Scotsman, was slashed to death in January at his farm near Gilgil, the police said. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: United States Men Keep Gold Medal Hopes Alive
description: ATHENS, Aug. 26  Stephon Marbury was backpedaling when the ball bounded toward Rodolfo Fernandez, bringing a spasm of hope to an arena singing Spanish songs. Marbury crouched low, so low that Fernandez could not see him waiting to pounce on his pass, stealing Spain's last fourth-quarter hope with the hands that had carried the United States past every doubt.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Wins Equipment Contract
description: Nortel Networks won a $300 million contract from the cellphone provider T-Mobile USA yesterday to provide network equipment that will permit T-Mobile to expand service in Chicago, Dallas, Denver, Detroit, Milwaukee, New York and Phoenix. The equipment includes base station controllers and switches. T-Mobile, a unit of Deutsche Telekom based in Bellevue, Wash., has aggressively solicited customers by cutting prices and expanding its coverage. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY BOUGHT STAKE IN SERVICEMASTER
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. disclosed yesterday that it had bought 3.73 million shares of the Servicemaster Company, a stake that regulators said Berkshire could no longer keep confidential. Berkshire owned 3.05 million shares at the end of 2003, and bought 680,600 more shares in the six months through June 30, revised filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission showed. Berkshire, based in Omaha, argued that the stocks it buys or sells should be kept secret because copycat investing would increase its trading costs. Servicemaster shares rose 3.7 percent, to $12.47, in the 12 minutes after the disclosure yesterday. Servicemaster, based in Downers Grove, Ill., owns and franchises lawn-care and pest-control centers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANKLIN, PHYLLIS
description: FRANKLIN--Phyllis. The Modern Language Association mourns the loss of Phyllis Franklin, who died on 20 August 2004 in Coral Gables, Florida. A scholar and teacher of American literature and women's studies, she served with great distinction as executive director of the MLA from 1985 until her retirement in 2002. She wrote on issues affecting the humanities and higher education, edited the journal ''Profession,'' and coedited ''Preparing a Nation's Teachers: Models for English and Foreign Language Programs.'' She initiated survey projects that provided statistical information about the curriculum and trends within the field, advocated for federal funding for the humanities, and collaborated with other organizations to enhance public understanding of the humanities. Memorial contributions may be made to the Phyllis Franklin Award for Public Advocacy of the Humanities, Modern Language Assocation, 26 Broadway, 3rd floor, New York, NY 10003-1789.

The measure would modify the rules of the next medallion auction, in October, and create a separate auction for the purchase of 27 wheelchair medallions. Currently, only 3 out of 12,487 yellow cabs are wheelchair accessible. In an effort to attract more bidders, a lower minimum price would be set for those medallions. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer Accused Of Propositioning Boy
description: A New York City police officer was arrested yesterday on charges that he forced a 13-year-old boy into his car and ordered him at gunpoint to strip, the Brooklyn district attorney's office said. Officer Clive Peters, an officer since two years ago assigned to the 105th Precinct in Queens Village, was off duty and in civilian clothes, according to the complaint, when he approached the boy in Brooklyn Heights at 5 p.m. on Monday, showed his badge, ordered the boy into his personal car and attempted to frisk him at gunpoint. After the officer tried to get the boy to remove his clothes, the youth said he wanted to leave. The officer agreed to drive him back but propositioned him. Officer Peters was released on his own recognizance and has been suspended pending a departmental investigation. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ADC Telecom Narrows Loss
description: ADC Telecommunications, which makes networking equipment and related software, said yesterday that its third-quarter net loss narrowed to $14.3 million after an acquisition increased sales. The net loss for the quarter that ended July 31 was 2 cents a share, compared with $15.1 million, or 2 cents a share, a year earlier, said ADC, based in Eden Prairie, Minn. Sales rose 55 percent, to $235.2 million. The $294 million acquisition in May of the Krone Group, which makes fiber optic and copper cable and network devices, increased revenue. ADC is also selling units that are unrelated to its networking business, like the Singl.eView billing software unit. Sales in this quarter should rise to $250 million to $260 million, with profit, excluding certain costs, of 1 cent to 2 cents a share, the company said. Excluding some costs, ADC said, the company broke even on a per-share basis in the third quarter, matching the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Analysts expected sales of $234.9 million. Shares of ADC rose 3 cents, to $2.25.

title: Marab Journal; Brazil's Problem in a Nutshell: Bolivia Grows Nuts Best
description: Throughout the 20th century, most of the Brazil nuts consumed around the world came from the jungle surrounding this bustling river market town in the eastern Amazon. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Gains Server Market Share
description: I.B.M., the No.1 maker of computer servers, increased its lead in global server sales in the second quarter, while No.2 Hewlett-Packard lost market share, the research firm Gartner said yesterday. Sales of servers -- computers that run other computers -- rose 7.7 percent worldwide in the second quarter, to $11.5 billion. I.B.M.'s share rose to 30.7 percent from 29.8 percent a year earlier, while Hewlett-Packard's share fell to 27.3 percent from 28.2 percent, Gartner said. No.3 Sun Microsystems, based in Santa Clara, Calif., dropped to a 13 percent share from 13.7 percent, and No.4 Dell rose to 9.8 percent from 8.8 percent. Dell, based in Round Rock, Tex., had the biggest gain from a year earlier, as sales rose 20 percent, to $1.13 billion, Gartner said.

title: A Poet Worthy of Protest
description: When I heard that protesters were going to demonstrate at Czeslaw Milosz's funeral tomorrow at the Mariacki Church in Krakow, it was easy for me to imagine the great poet's laugh. The protesters do not think he was Catholic enough, or Polish enough. He raised such antagonisms all his life. As a kind of byproduct of being a great writer, devoted to ultimate things -- call him an Eschatological Humanist -- he drove authoritarians crazy. In the 1970's, Czeslaw knew that the Soviet authorities in Poland were beginning to rehabilitate his reputation when an official reference work alluded to him -- unmistakably, though not by name -- as one of several poets in his generation who were of no particular significance.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Activist Defies Ban On Housing Protesters
description: A leader of a Mott Haven community center said yesterday that he would defy a court order forbidding him to house political demonstrators during the Republican National Convention. Last week, Justice Patricia Williams of State Supreme Court ordered Rafael Bueno, left, to bar visitors from staying in a five-story building whose ownership is in dispute. Mr. Bueno's lawyer, Harry Kresky, said yesterday that he was opposing the transfer of title by the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development to a residential developer last April on grounds that area zoning does not allow residential development. About 20 demonstrators from out of town began sleeping in the building after Mr. Bueno announced recently that they were welcome. Colin Moynihan (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Icon To Be Returned To Russia
description: A 12-by-10-inch Russian icon, the Mother of God of Kazan, plated in gold, bedecked in precious jewels and embroiled in a dispute between the Roman Catholic and Russian Orthodox churches that has impeded Pope John Paul II from visiting Russia, is to be returned to Russia today on a military plane. The Vatican hopes that Russia will appreciate the return of the icon -- actually an 18th-century copy of an image that first appeared 200 years earlier in Kazan -- as a gesture of unity and reconciliation, and that it will help pave the way for a visit by the Slavic pope. John Paul has long desired to go to the country that he is often credited with helping to free from Communism, and to mend the centuries-old schism between the Orthodox and Catholic faiths. The icon disappeared from Russia sometime after the Bolshevik Revolution. It was bought by a Catholic group in the 1970's and later given to the pope. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: The Narcissist And His Lover
description: Remove self-love from love, wrote the 18th-century French aphorist and revolutionary Chamfort, and not much would be left. Remove self-love and self-serving outrage from the already notorious ''The Brown Bunny,'' a minor scandal of a movie that opens today in New York and Los Angeles, and not much would be left, either. Which isn't to say that this artful road movie from the director, narcissist nonpareil and most excellent huckster Vincent Gallo should be avoided, especially if you like your art-house exercises tarted up with some good old-fashioned, hotel-room smut.

The film, subtitled ''The Story of the Crew of Patrol Craft Fast 94,'' charmingly pretends to be a study of the six-man team that patrolled the Mekong Delta in early 1969 on the 94, treating the team's leader, the young John Kerry, as just one of the guys.

title: GILEAD SAYS ITS AIDS TREATMENT IS BETTER THAN GLAXO'S
description: Gilead Sciences Inc. said early results from a study show that a combination of its AIDS drugs suppressed H.I.V. more effectively than a GlaxoSmithKline treatment. Researchers compared the effectiveness of Gilead's Viread and Emtriva medicines with Glaxo's Combivir after 24 weeks of a 48-week study. About 88 percent of patients getting the Gilead medicines had blood levels of H.I.V. below the target, compared with 80 percent of people on Combivir, Gilead said. A Glaxo spokeswoman, Mary Faye Dark, said it was too early in the study to draw conclusions. ''It's interesting to see what's happened at 24 weeks,'' she said in a telephone interview. ''Until you get to 48 weeks, you can't do too much with it.''

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: TiVo 2nd-Quarter Loss Widens
description: TiVo Inc., a maker of digital video recorders that can pause and replay live television, said yesterday that its second-quarter loss had widened to $10.8 million as it spent more on marketing and research and development. The net loss in the period that ended July 31 was 13 cents a share, compared with a loss of $4.39 million, or 7 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue rose 49 percent, to $39.8 million, from $26.7 million. TiVo, based in Alviso, Calif., is spending more on marketing and developing new features for its recorders to increase sales through electronics stores. TiVo shares rose as much as 46 cents, to $5.26, in extended trading. In regular trading, they rose 18 cents, to $4.80.

title: PEPSICO MAKES SHIFT AT TOP OF QUAKER FOODS UNIT
description: PepsiCo Inc., the world's second-largest soft-drink maker behind Coca-Cola, promoted Mary Dillon to president of its Quaker Foods division after the retirement of Polly Kawalek, a 25-year veteran. Ms. Dillon, 43, previously Quaker Foods' vice president for marketing, assumes her duties immediately, PepsiCo said. Ms. Kawalek, 49, is retiring to spend more time on personal interests, PepsiCo said. The unit was acquired in 2001 as part of PepsiCo's $14.5 billion acquisition of the Quaker Oats Company, which also included Gatorade sports drinks. PepsiCo, based in Purchase, N.Y., received $1.47 billion in revenue from Quaker Foods last year.

title: BLACKROCK TO BUY STATE STREET RESEARCH
description: BlackRock Inc., the bond fund manager, agreed to buy State Street Research and Management from MetLife Inc. for $375 million to broaden its stock and real estate investments. MetLife will receive $325 million in cash and $50 million worth of stock, BlackRock and MetLife, both based in New York, said. The price may increase by as much as 25 percent if the transaction meets certain unspecified conditions, they said. BlackRock is trying to reduce its dependence on bonds by attracting more equity and hedge fund investors. About half of State Street Research's $52 billion of managed assets is in stocks and real estate. MetLife is leaving the money management business. The combination of BlackRock and State Street would manage about $366 billion of assets. The purchase also will expand BlackRock's brokerage network.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Soldiers' Convictions Reinstated
description: The Supreme Court's Military Board overturned the acquittal of four members of a Russian special forces unit who had been charged with murder in the death of six Chechen civilians in 2002. The decision sets the stage for a new trial. Last April, a jury found that the four men had been following orders, and that although the orders might have been criminal, it could not be determined who had given them. The acquittals prompted an outcry among Chechens and human rights activists. Presidential elections are to be held in Chechnya on Sunday, and some observers linked the decision to overturn the acquittal to Moscow's efforts to pacify voters in Chechnya. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Kennedy Nephew Is Sued

They also say that they are being denied meaningful participation in the review process for the $1.4 billion project, since they do not have adequate information about changes in air and water pollution, traffic congestion and noise, among other things, that would affect the neighborhood. title: 36 Hours | Bar Harbor, Me.
description: FORMERLY named Eden, Bar Harbor may well be the perfect New England tourist town. There are the requisite T-shirt emporiums and fudge shops and multiple quality homemade-ice cream joints. There are the tasteful and schlocky art galleries and free chamber music concerts on Friday nights. The architecture consists mainly of ''cottages'' built in the early 20th century by titans of pre-income-tax industry, but they are not about Newportesque excess as much as bygone elegance. Meanwhile, the honky-tonk water slides, go-karts and minigolf are just far enough away, in nearby Trenton, to make them accessible but invisible. Above all else, though, Bar Harbor is special because a few of those early visitors donated their land and pulled the strings to get 40 percent of the incomparably dramatic and beautiful Mount Desert Island, on which Bar Harbor sits, designated as Acadia National Park. Bike, hike, amble, kayak, rock-climb, horseback ride, lobster tour, whatever -- it's a day tripper's paradise, at least until the leaf peeping ends around the second week of October. PAUL SCHNEIDER

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Lyndhurst: Xanadu Plan Moves Ahead
description: The New Jersey Meadowlands Commission yesterday approved -- with reservations -- the plan to build the $1.3 billion Meadowlands Xanadu family entertainment and sports complex, sending it on for a series of detailed lease and permit negotiations with state environmental and transportation agencies. At meetings earlier this year, the commission's hearing officers voiced reservations that echoed criticism of opponents and made 14 recommendations, including requiring stiffer environmental safety measures, more mitigation of expected traffic problems and a host of additional payments by the developer to localities and the state. The commission's chairwoman, Susan Bass Levin, above, said that the project would bring economic development, job creation, increased tax revenues and ''smart growth,'' criteria that influenced the commission's decision to move forward. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Oil Contract To End
description: Indonesia's state-owned oil and gas company, Pertamina, has decided not to extend a contract with Exxon Mobil to develop one of the country's largest oil fields when the contract expires in 2010. Exxon Mobil bought the contract, to manage the Cepu field in central Java, on Pertamina's behalf in 1999 only to discover in 2001 that it held much more oil than previously believed. Pertamina then said that if it did not get more of the revenue, it would not renew the contract. The companies have been at loggerheads since over how to divide the proceeds. A Pertamina official told a parliamentary commission this week that Pertamina would develop Cepu alone. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: BUSH DISMISSES IDEA THAT KERRY LIED ON VIETNAM
description: President Bush said on Thursday that he did not believe Senator John Kerry lied about his war record, but he declined to condemn the television commercial paid for by a veterans group alleging that Mr. Kerry came by his war medals dishonestly.

title: Mountain West and CSTV Agree on $82 Million Deal
description: The five-year-old Mountain West Conference announced yesterday that it had sold seven years of television and media rights, starting in 2006, to College Sports Television, an 18-month-old network, for $82 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: US Airways' Pilots Union to Resume Talks With Airline
description: US Airways' pilots union said tonight that it would resume talks with the struggling airline, which is urging its unions to grant $800 million in cuts to save it from another bankruptcy filing.

title: Report Is Likely to Prompt Criminal Charges
description: The Defense Department report on the abuses at Abu Ghraib prison, issued Wednesday, will almost certainly give rise to criminal charges or disciplinary action against many of the more than 50 people found responsible. But the report's most immediate impact will probably be in the handful of pending cases against low-level military police personnel.

title: Chirac Takes a Practical Approach to U.S.-Franco Partnership
description: PARIS, Aug. 27 — Clearly the American election is on the mind of the president of France.

description: The Justice Department announced Thursday that more than 150 people had been arrested, charged or convicted in the last three months in a wide-ranging sweep of criminal activity on the Internet.

description: BITROS--Mara (McGrath). It has been five painful years since your tragic accident. We miss your sweetness, kindness and beauty, and think of you always. Your loving husband Jim, brother Dennis, and all your family and friend

title: Calling All Scooters? Officers Will Patrol With a Putt-Putt-Putt
description: The New York City Police Department is preparing to mobilize a new tool to prevent chaos during the Republican National Convention -- a fleet of sleek, stylish Italian scooters. The police have purchased 300 scooters made by Piaggio, the company that created the Vespa, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday.

title: U.S. Economy Grew at Slower Pace Than Expected
description: The United States economy grew more slowly in the second quarter than previously stated, as it struggled under an increasing trade deficit and a slowdown in consumer spending, the Commerce Department said in a report today.

title: For the President, Special Setup Is Planned at Convention
description: Moving to bring a special intimacy to the carefully scripted atmosphere of a political convention, President Bush will give his acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention next week from a small circular stage in a sea of thousands of delegates and other guests.

title: A Nazi Prison Camp Became A Symbol of Olympic Spirit
description: It was shown late in NBC's prime-time Olympics broadcast on Wednesday night, shortly after 11:30 p.m.: the network's riveting mini-documentary about the Polish prisoners of the Nazis who staged their own Summer Games in 1944.

description: While a conservative politician from Texas takes center stage in Manhattan next week, some of the most radical political art of the 20th century will heat up the wide-open gallery spaces of the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, in a big, sharp, unconventional show called ''Inverted Utopias: Avant-Garde Art in Latin America.''

title: Mutual Fund and Top Officer Fined Over Valuation of Securities
description: Garrett Van Wagoner, who oversaw some of America's top-performing mutual funds in the late 1990's, and his firm agreed yesterday to pay $800,000 to settle accusations by regulators that they had misstated the value of ''illiquid securities'' in their funds.

title: Cruising, Slowly, Back in Time
description: FOR this year's Woodward Dream Cruise, cars started arriving nearly a week early, a '59 lowered Chevy from Youngstown, Ohio, and a Bel Air from Spring Hill, N.Y., among them. Maybe their drivers were unable to hold out any longer against the lure of an event that promises to bring back the days when nothing more than a cheap radio, a borrowed car and a slow tour down a suburban street could deliver teenage nirvana.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Electronic Data To Sell Unit To GTCR
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the world's second-largest seller of computer services, will sell a wireless services business to the private equity firm GTCR Golder Rauner for $57 million. The business, Interoperator Services North America, is based in Maynard, Mass., GTCR said yesterday. Interoperator sells services for voice and data companies, including settlement of wireless roaming transactions.

title: For Separated Twins, All Signs Are Positive, With Boys Being Boys
description: Arlene Aguirre feels a lot like a new mother these days.

title: Sports of The Times; N.B.A. Millionaires Decide To Play a Little Street Ball
description: ISIAH THOMAS woke up early in New York yesterday morning to watch the United States men's basketball team play unbeaten Spain in the opening round of Olympic medal play. Thomas, the Knicks' president, felt a sense of urgency, almost as if he were playing. In some ways he was.

title: Journalist From Italy Killed in Iraq By Captors
description: The Arab news channel Al Jazeera reported early Friday that it had received a videotape from a group calling itself the Islamic Army in Iraq showing the killing of an Italian journalist, Enzo Baldoni, who disappeared last week while traveling to Najaf. Italy's Ansa news agency quoted Italian officials in Iraq as confirming the Al Jazeera report.

description: The Russian government said Thursday that it would hold an auction Sept. 29 to sell its 7.59 percent stake in Lukoil, the giant oil company, at a starting price of $1.93 billion.

description: The Toronto-Dominion Bank cautiously entered the United States consumer banking market on Thursday with a $3.8 billion deal to acquire 51 percent of the Banknorth Group of Maine.

description: The walls began closing in on Josef Sudek (1896-1976) almost from the beginning of his photographic career. At least that's how it appears from ''Josef Sudek: Poet With a Camera,'' an exhibition at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, organized by Anne Havinga, to celebrate the museum's acquisition of 78 Sudek works from Sonja Bullaty and her husband, Angelo Lomeo. (She was a concentration camp survivor who was Sudek's assistant for a brief time after World War II, then his friend for life.)
