title: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Truths in the Court of a King Who Would Be Emperor
description: In ''Hero,'' an ambitious period epic about the birth of the first Chinese empire, warriors fly through the air like birds of prey, their swords cutting through enemies and lovers alike. Set during the third century B.C., the story of an assassination plot against a powerful king unfolds with such dazzling bursts of color and blurs of furious action it might be easy to miss the nationalistic message tucked amid the visual enchantments. Roll over, Chairman Mao, and tell the comrades the news: the history of the empire now comes wrapped in kaleidoscopic kung fu cool.

title: Warm and Fuzzy Olympians
description: The best moments in the Olympics have little to do with which large and powerful country can accumulate the most medals (the United States was well ahead of China and Russia at last count) or even which highly talented athletes can turn in superhuman performances. The real drama comes in those heart-tugging moments when some improbable underdog triumphs against all expectations, or some unheralded competitor grabs a medal, any medal, and electrifies a smaller nation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Mohammed Arif, an Indian soldier wrongly accused of desertion five years ago after being imprisoned in Pakistan during the conflict over the disputed territory of Kashmir, misstated the action taken by his wife, Guriya, before he was released in a prisoner exchange this year. While she remarried on the assumption that he would never return, she did not formally divorce him first.

title: Arby's Names Finalists For Creative Project
description: Arby's, the sandwich shop chain owned by the Triarc Companies, has named four finalists in a review for the creative part of its national branding assignment, with spending estimated at $15 million.

description: The best player on the top-ranked team in college football will not be eligible to play this season.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Aug. 4 about evidence that Islamic groups are training fighters in Pakistan and sending them into Afghanistan misstated the nature of a 1998 American air strike on a militant training camp in Afghanistan. It was carried out with cruise missiles fired from ships in the Arabian Sea, not bombs dropped by American planes.

title: DreamWorks Officer Quits
description: DreamWorks SKG, the studio that created the ''Shrek'' films, said yesterday that Helene Hahn would step down as chief operating officer. Ms. Hahn, who will serve as a consultant for a year, will continue in her role until a successor is named, DreamWorks said.

title: Swoopes's Sly Shot Puts U.S. Women Into Basketball Final
description: ATHENS, Aug. 27  The United States women's basketball team was watching its margin of dominance dwindle to a single basket in a suddenly tense Olympic semifinal game this afternoon, but Sheryl Swoopes remained unfazed. She stood in her team's huddle during a timeout, listening to the play designed to get her the ball with just over four minutes to go.

title: U.S. Court in New York Rejects Partial-Birth Abortion Ban
description: A federal judge in New York ruled yesterday that a federal law banning a rarely used method of abortion was unconstitutional because it did not exempt cases where the procedure might be necessary to protect a woman's health.

title: The German Question: If Workers Get Less, Will More Get Work?
description: AMONG the major industrialized economies, Germany is the un-United States. Americans spend with abandon, while Germans save. America runs a huge and growing trade deficit, while Germany's exports rise along with its trade surplus. American housing prices have risen sharply, while German prices have stagnated.

title: With Two Men Out, McGreevey Steps Up to the Plate and Saves the Day
description: When Gov. James. E. McGreevey announced on Aug. 12 that he was gay and that he planned to resign in November, many thought he showed a thoughtful side in discussing his sexual orientation. On Thursday, he showed that he has a sense of humor about it, too, saving the jobs of two men who had been dismissed for having fun at his expense.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Grows
description: Japan's trade surplus grew for the 13th consecutive month in July, fueled by rising exports to China and other Asian trading partners. The July surplus increased 44.2 percent from a year earlier to 1.14 trillion yen, or $10.3 billion. Exports rose 14.3 percent, to 5.31 trillion yen, and imports gained 8.2 percent, to 4.17 trillion yen. Japan's trade surplus with other countries in Asia surged 63 percent, to 751 billion yen. The surplus with the United States widened by 12.6 percent, to 640 billion yen. The overall trade surplus was larger than expected, as exports to Asia remained strong despite predictions that their growth would begin to slow. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: New York Awaits Republicans With Reluctance and Unease

title: In Kobe Bryant Case, Issues of Power, Not of Race
description: As recently as a generation ago, the fact that Kobe Bryant is black and the woman who has accused him of rape is white would probably have been enough to reawaken at least a few of the ghosts that rattle around America's racial attic. Many men have been lynched on the basis of lesser accusations.

title: Miscellany
description: Kupper Parker Communications, St. Louis, plans to acquire EPS Communications, Charleston, Mass., in a deal that is expected to close by early 2006. Terms were not disclosed.

title: No Bumper Sticker Defines The Fey Oregonian Voter
description: Jerry Witham's presidential votes over the last 20 years might seem rather erratic.

title: BIG BELGIAN DRUG MAKER TO CLOSE BOSTON RESEARCH UNIT
description: UCB, Belgium's biggest drug maker, said yesterday that it would close its research unit in Boston as it reorganizes its research and development activities after the purchase of the Celltech Group. UCB, which is based in Brussels, agreed to buy Celltech, the British biotechnology company, for 1.53 billion ($2.74 billion) earlier this year, giving UCB an experimental arthritis drug with potential sales of as much as $1 billion. UCB's pharmaceutical unit has research facilities in Belgium and Britain.

title: Regional Income Steady; City Housing Costs Rise
description: New York City's poverty rate and median income held steady last year, while housing continued to take an ever larger chunk of New Yorkers' paychecks, according to an annual survey released yesterday by the Census Bureau.

title: Flight Recorders Little Aid in Russia Crash
description: The flight recorders of two Russian airliners that crashed nearly simultaneously on Tuesday night were damaged and could provide little help in determining the cause of the twin disasters, which killed at least 89 people, senior Russian officials said Thursday.

title: A Track Victory for Torre
description: Joe Torre is a part owner of Sugar Punch, a 3-year-old bay filly who held off Beautiful America by a neck on Thursday at Saratoga Race Course to win the first running of the Union Avenue Stakes for fillies and mares bred in New York. It was Sugar Punch's first stakes appearance and fourth consecutive victory since she ran second in her first start.

title: An encore for Robuchon
Party Labels Take Beating on Road to the State Senate
description: For years, former State Senator Guy J. Velella was the only Republican elected official in the Bronx, a distinction that helped make him a political powerhouse there and in Albany, where his party controls the Senate. But Mr. Velella resigned his seat earlier this year and was subsequently sentenced to a year in jail for conspiring to take bribes from people seeking to do business with the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPARBER, NORMAN H.
description: SPARBER--Norman H. The partners and staff of Brauner Baron Rosenzweig & Klein, LLP mourn the loss of our dear friend and retired partner Norman H. Sparber, who served for more than 50 years as a partner and of counsel to our firm. He addressed legal problems with intelligence and diligence and earned the respect of his colleagues and clients. Even after his formal retirement, he remained actively engaged in the activities of the firm and the needs of his clients. We will miss his wise counsel and acerbic wit, and extend our deepest condolences to his children Merryl and Roy, his daughter-in-law Susan, his grandchildren and great grandchildren.

title: A Serial Killer Who Stalks Other Serial Killers Is Loose
description: Finally, a serial-killer movie so preposterous, so garnished with accidental laugh lines and absent essential narrative logic it may actually put a permanent kibosh on this tediously overworked crime subgenre. Here's hoping, at any rate. Directed with self-conscious hothouse flair by E. Elias Merhige, from a puzzler of a screenplay credited to Zak Penn and Billy Ray, ''Suspect Zero,'' which opens nationwide today, involves a serial killer who's doing away with other serial killers and the disgraced F.B.I. agent who refuses to let this meta-murder madness go unpunished. Think ''Seven'' minus the talent.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Changes Centrino Chip Set
description: The Intel Corporation announced yesterday wireless enhancements to its Centrino chip set for notebook computers that it hoped would address persistent concerns that wireless networks are less secure and overly complex. The module, which supports three Wi-Fi standards, includes new security features for users in large companies. Among other new features, the chip set has software technology from Cisco Systems and its Linksys division that makes it easier to configure a Wi-Fi network. Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said the chip set enhancements will be available in notebook computers beginning in September. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: MERCK OF GERMANY TO BUY PFIZER GENERIC DRUG UNIT
description: Merck KGaA, the German drug maker, said yesterday that it would buy most of Pfizer's Stockholm-based NM Pharma generic drug operation for 53.8 million euros ($65 million) to become the top seller of generics in Scandinavia. NM Pharma had sales of 39.1 million euros last year, Merck said. Merck, based in Darmstadt, Germany, will combine the unit with its existing Scandinavian business under the name Merck NM. Merck, which is unrelated to the drug maker Merck & Company of the United States, is seeking to become one of the top three generic drug companies. Pfizer is based in New York.

title: A Mystery About a Mistress in North Korea
description: South Korean government officials are struggling to confirm persistent reports from North Korea of the recent death of its leader Kim Jong Il's favorite mistress, a former dancer who was elevated in the Communist state's pantheon to the status of ''respected mother.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Maspeth: Man Found Slain In Burning Truck
description: A Maspeth man was found shot to death inside the burning cab of a tractor-trailer early yesterday morning, the police said. Firefighters found the man, identified as Joseph Giarraputo, 41, of 59-59 61st Street, as they were putting out the fire at 58th Street and 58th Avenue, at 1:20 a.m. Mr. Giarraputo had been shot twice in the chest and once in the head. No arrests were made and the motive in the shooting was unknown.

title: Abu Ghraib, the Next Step
description: For months, John Warner, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, has been gamely resisting pressure from Republican leaders to call off his hearings on the Abu Ghraib prison disaster -- the only real sign of life on Capitol Hill on this important issue. Mr. Warner was patiently awaiting the outcome of a set of Pentagon investigations, including one by the Army and one by a civilian panel set up by Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld. Both issued reports this week, and it's clear that Mr. Warner still has work to do.

title: Health Plans Cover Fewer While Costs Keep Rising
description: Rising costs for health coverage and a continuing fall-off in the number of workers in employer-sponsored health plans are among the reasons that a greater number of people did not have health insurance last year, experts say.

title: Warming to Global Warming
description: After three years of belittling or suppressing science, the Bush administration appears willing to concede that humans and their industrial activity have been largely responsible for the recent warming of the earth's atmosphere. This tardy acceptance of what mainstream scientists have been saying for years does not mean that the administration is prepared to deal seriously with the problem -- by, for instance, supporting mandatory caps on emissions of carbon dioxide. But at least nobody is trying to hide the evidence.

title: Rumsfeld Mischaracterizes Findings of 2 Studies on U.S. Abuse at Iraqi Interrogations

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Budget Surplus
description: Brazil posted a primary budget surplus of 6.61 billion reais ($2.24 billion) in July, up from 4.32 billion reais a year earlier, the central bank said. So far this year the government has run up a primary surplus, which excludes interest payments on debt, of 52.8 billion reais, putting it on track to meet fiscal targets in a $14 billion loan deal with the International Monetary Fund. Under the loan agreement, Brazil agreed to a year-end surplus of 75.1 billion reais, or 4.25 percent of gross domestic product. The rising surplus has helped Brazil reduce its net public sector debt to 55.3 percent of its gross domestic product by the end of July, down from 56 percent a month earlier. The data reflect the fiscal performance of federal and local governments and state-run companies. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Celebrating a Fame That Burns Warm, Not Hot

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Versace Names Executive
description: The fashion house Gianni Versace named a former chief executive of Fendi, Giancarlo Di Risio, as chief executive as it tries to cut costs and increase sales. Mr. Di Risio was head of Fendi from January 2002 to October 2003. He also spent a year at IT Holding, the owner of the Gianfranco Ferre fashion house. Versace, based in Milan, posted a loss of 26.5 million euros ($32 million) last year and is working to become more competitive with its Italian rivals Gucci and Prada. The company was founded by Gianni Versace, who was killed in 1997. His sister Donatella and his brother Santo will remain co-chairmen. They own 50 percent of Versace.

title: Music Official At Warner To Step Down

title: Economic Reality Bites
description: If anyone required further evidence that President Bush's fiscal policies have not worked the way he says they have, this week's report from the Census Bureau provided it. In brief, from 2001 through 2003, poverty increased, income stagnated and the ranks of the uninsured grew, while the United States spent some $400 billion on tax cuts, which mainly benefited wealthy families. The Bush administration seemed intent on minimizing the political impact of the report, releasing the data on Thursday, instead of the usual date in late September, to get it done before the convention. But the numbers spoke for themselves. Since Mr. Bush came to power, 4.3 million people have fallen below the poverty line, set at $18,660 for a family of four in 2003, bringing the total number of people living in poverty in 2003 to 35.9 million, or 12.5 percent of the American population.

title: What's New
description: THE BIG TEN WILL BEGIN an experimental season of instant replay this year. It will not follow the N.F.L.s system, in which coaches challenge plays for review. Instead, a technical advisor in the press box will determine when to stop a game for a review. Inevitably, games will be longer, but dont expect the system to be used throughout the top levels of college football anytime soon. I dont think its imminent, said Dennis Poppe, the N.C.A.A. managing director for football and baseball. Theres a lot to still be discussed, including facilities and cost.

description: After months of legal dickering, the city's elaborate plans to steer antiwar protesters away from Central Park will be tested tomorrow by what is widely expected to be one of the city's largest political demonstrations in decades.

title: Dining With the Enemy
description: The Republicans about to convene in New York City may feel they're on unfriendly turf. After all, this is an overwhelmingly Democratic town; while it has played host to five Democratic National Conventions -- 1868, 1924, 1976, 1980 and 1992 -- this is the first time the G.O.P. has paid a visit. But the delegates need not be daunted politically -- for the last decade the city has been led by Republican mayors (Rudolph W. Giuliani and Mike Bloomberg) and the state by a three-term Republican governor (George Pataki). And I suspect they will find the dining scene equally solicitous: from the bottom of the island to its northern reaches, there are plenty of restaurants at which a delegate can expect to be fted like a king, or at least like a Vanderbilt or a Rockefeller.

title: Yo! Queens Goombahs
description: It's nice that two stand-up comics from Queens can make a movie about their neighborhood and some wacky fictional adventures. Nice, but that doesn't mean the film is worth anyone's time besides those of their families, friends, neighbors and the nice man from Connecticut who let them use his restaurant.

description: The union representing New York City's police officers has joined with opponents of a football stadium on the West Side to create a television advertisement that seeks to block the project.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: War Crimes Case
description: Federal prosecutors say that a Bosnian man who became a permanent alien in 2001 took part in a military unit that carried out the killing of thousands of Muslims in the former Yugoslavia in 1995. Officials charged the man, Marko Boskic, 40, of Peabody, Mass., with two counts of immigration document fraud. Mr. Boskic was arrested Wednesday in Peabody, where prosecutors said he had lived for four years. Officials say Mr. Boskic lied on his refugee application, claiming he had served in the Yugoslavian army only in the 1980's. Mr. Boskic faces up to 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine on each count; he could also be deported. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: The Icon the Republicans Want to Forget
description: ''I am a product of the Nixon era,'' President Bush told a small audience of journalists shortly after his inauguration. Yet when Mr. Bush accepts his party's nomination in New York next week, his listeners are not likely to hear many references to Richard Nixon, his father's political mentor and the modern-day chief executive many observers see as the president he most strongly resembles -- in his relish for partisan combat, his occasional deviations from conservative dogma, and in the irrational hatred he engenders in liberals.

title: U.S. Set Back On Treatment Of Combatant
description: A federal judge on Friday ordered the government to explain why Yaser E. Hamdi, an enemy combatant captured in Afghanistan, has remained in solitary confinement in a military brig for more than two years, even as prosecutors and defense lawyers are negotiating his imminent release.

title: Cardinal to Pray at the Convention
description: Cardinal Edward M. Egan, the Roman Catholic archbishop of New York, will deliver the closing benediction at the Republican National Convention, the archdiocese said yesterday.

title: Lessons of Najaf
description: Iraq's interim government did well to avoid a bloody fight to the finish with Moktada al-Sadr over the Imam Ali Mosque, the country's most sacred Shiite site. It could have suffered incalculable political damage even if it had won. Instead, Prime Minister Ayad Allawi accepted a face-saving compromise worked out by the country's leading Shiite cleric, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, thus ending a siege that had occupied center stage in the war in Iraq for three weeks.

title: Bush Order Extends C.I.A. Director's Reach
description: President Bush issued a new order on Friday enhancing the powers of the director of central intelligence, but the White House said that new legislation was still needed to establish the kind of strong national intelligence director recommended by the independent Sept. 11 commission.

title: Man Gets $800,000 in Arrest Settlement
description: Six days after his mistaken arrest in 1999 in the murder of an Orange, N.J., police officer, a 24-year-old East Orange resident, Terrance Everett, emerged from police custody with what he later described in a lawsuit as a footprint on his back, a chipped tooth and a bruised face.

title: About New York; Learning To Tell RANT From RAIL
description: ERIC LAURSEN, earnest anarchist, concluded yet another news conference the other day, this one in the name of the Campaign to Demilitarize the Police. He then took a seat on the steps of City Hall and patiently began to explain the distinctions among protest groups whose individual cries of outrage about the Republican National Convention tend to blend into one protracted howl.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Nazi Resort To Be Auctioned
description: A large part of the Nazi holiday resort Prora, on the Baltic island of Rgen, is set to be auctioned off next month. After Hitler came to power, he chose a four-mile stretch of Rgen's beach for what was to be the world's largest vacation complex, a string of hostels where 20,000 guests could stay. The project was abandoned because of the outbreak of World War II. The starting price for a 1.5-mile stretch of the estate, including five huge buildings, beaches and forest land, is a modest 125,000 euros ($151,000), because the German government has been trying to sell it for several years. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Pentagon Official Suspected of Giving U.S. Secrets to Israel
description: The F.B.I. is investigating a Pentagon official on suspicion of passing secrets to Israel, government officials said Friday.

title: 1929:Revolt in Palestine : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: JERUSALEM: With the Arab uprising against the Jewish colonization of Palestine spreading from town to country, the British authorities are faced with a veritable revolt, which, it is now foreseen, can only be suppressed by the use of force on a large scale. Troops are being rushed to the storm centres, but owing to the lack of communications, no sooner is one attack dealt with than another begins elsewhere. The situation is admittedly serious and today [Aug. 27] the Consuls of all nations held a meeting to urge the British authorities to take stringent measures to protect their nationals. Although no doubt is expressed that order will eventually be restored, it is admitted that this may take some time owing to the countryside character which the uprising has taken. Several more warships carrying troops and airplanes are reported to have arrived at Jaffa, and today two British battalions and several contingents of armed sailors and marines were dispatched in haste to the storm centres. Airplanes are also reconnoitering and landing troops wherever urgently needed.

title: Corrections

Although he abdicated in 1911, he did not leave until 1924.

description: Underpinning the 9/11 commission's call to reform the nation's intelligence services is the parallel warning that Congress must reform itself. The commission called on Congress to junk its 17-committee jungle of jurisdictional fiefs, which have failed miserably in their responsibility of oversight.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bank's Profit Slips
description: Canada's largest bank, the Royal Bank of Canada, said lower earnings in the United States and higher expenses led to a 1 percent decline in third-quarter profit, the first decline in three years. Net income for the period, which ended July 31, fell to 768 million Canadian dollars ($584 million), from 776 million Canadian dollars, a year earlier, the bank said. Revenue rose 2 percent, to 4.4 billion Canadian dollars. Profit from Royal Bank's United States operations fell by about a third from the quarter a year ago.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Coup Case For Thatcher's Son
description: Equatorial Guinea's legal counsel was quoted as saying that his government would seek to extradite Mark Thatcher, the son of Margaret Thatcher, the former British prime minister. Mr. Thatcher was arrested Wednesday in South Africa, and he is accused of aiding a failed plot to overthrow Equatorial Guinea's government. South African officials said they had yet to receive a formal request for Mr. Thatcher's extradition. An acquaintance of his, Simon Mann, a British military expert, has also been accused in the case. On Friday, Mr. Mann was convicted in Zimbabwe on charges of illegal arms dealing. Michael Wines (NYT)

Biapharm controls Laboratoire Medix, which makes a line of wound-treatment emulsions under the Biafine brand. Its United States subsidiary is Medix Pharmaceuticals Americas Inc., based in Largo, Fla. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Johnson & Johnson Consumer France said the deal was expected to close by the end of September, subject to regulatory approvals. Johnson's French unit, a marketer of skin care brands like RoC and Neutrogena, has 542 employees. Johnson & Johnson is based in New Brunswick, N.J.

From Southampton, N.Y., to Rumson, N.J., to Newport, R.I., they may wear polo shirts and chino shorts during the day, but at sunset it is navy blazers, light trousers, seersucker or linen suits, and the occasional very colorful jacket. And in some instances, two-tone shoes. Young men in the city are tweaking this establishment look, pairing frayed chinos with impeccable linen jackets, white shirts and ties.

title: The Season of My Life

Walking slowly down the shady side of the street in the heat of an afternoon, I'll suddenly recall the city of my youth, the trees, the heat, the smell. Or watching kids getting ice cream bars from the vaporous freezer in the little country store where I shop in Vermont, I'll remember a ritual country summer Sunday treat of long ago -- home-made ice cream, and my grandfather making it after church, slowly turning the crank on the wooden ice-cream maker with one hand, while in the other he held the Bible he was reading from.

She is survived by her daughter, Deborah Goodman, two nieces, two nephews, and several cousins, grandnieces, and grandnephews. She will be missed by her family and many close friends. title: How Different is New York City?

Since then, a host of models has used the runway for takeoff into the pop stratosphere. Carla Bruni had a platinum-selling CD on the French charts, and new stars like Anouck Lepre and Karen Elson have been in the recording studio. But we're living for the new self-titled CD by Karen Mulder, the Dutch supermodel who in 2001 went through a well-publicized breakdown and spent time in a sanitarium after alleging that she had been raped by her model bookers, family members and Prince Albert (claims she later retracted). Mulder confronts her demons and on the track ''Divine Justice'' goes as far as to say, ''You can call me crazy.'' Can do. HORACIO SILVA

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HERSHCOPF, BERTE RUTH
description: HERSHCOPF -- Berte Ruth. Sweetheart, you are in our thoughts and memory each and every day. We miss your beauty, competence and incredible wit. Love Jack and the family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELMAN, CHARLES, MD.
description: KELMAN--Charles, MD. The creative spark of the inventor, ophthalmologist, entertainer, friend & loving family man touched the lives of many. He will be affectionately remembered at a tribute on Monday, September 13, 2004 at 11:30AM at the St. James Theater, 44 Street (Broadway and 8th Ave), NYC. Friends, colleagues and patients welcome to attend. Inquiries: Diane 212-736-9696.

title: Who's Buried in Grant's Tomb?
description: Correction Appended

title: Menendez's Blooper In Attacking McGreevey
description: Representative Robert Menendez, the articulate and accomplished national politician, is in good shape.

title: SUMMER 2004 GAMES -- TRACK AND FIELD: WOMEN'S 4x100 RELAY; For Jones, a Turbulent Year Comes to a Jarring Finish
description: Marion Jones, lunging out of breath with the baton and failing to catch Lauryn Williams for a handoff in the women's 4x100-meter relay, produced a jarring image of her diminished role at the Athens Games.

title: Arm Candy
description: The must-have accessory for every status-conscious woman comes with some strings attached. A love story.

title: Karen Cook, Holger Mueller
description: Karen Cook and Dr. Holger Michael Mueller were married yesterday in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. The Rev. Louis J. Mazza, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Immaculate Conception Church.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Bush administration's ties to Wall Street misstated the former occupation of John W. Snow, the Treasury secretary. He was chief executive of the CSX Corporation, the railroad company, not a steel executive.

title: Prick Up Your Ears
description: In Los Angeles they're referred to as the mannequins -- those ageless thespians whose misadventures with Botox have left their faces temporarily stripped of expression. And despite Hollywood's insatiable demand for fresh features and unfurrowed brows, they have triggered a Botox backlash, with a number of directors finally speaking out. ''I love Sergio Leone crop shots,'' declares Allen Hughes, who with his brother, Albert, directed ''American Pimp.'' ''But sometimes you can't shoot as close as you want because it starts to looks fake.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GAINES, LAWRENCE
description: GAINES--Lawrence. Beloved husband of Harriet. Devoted father of Stephen and Jonathan. Father-in-law of Teri and Lisa. Cherished grandfather of Katie, Rebecca, Nicole and Jacob. Services Sunday 1 PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: City to Republicans: See This. Telling the Delegates Where to Go
description: CONVENTIONEERS, already booked into dozens of events, have been inundated with official advice about what to visit in New York. Corey Kilgannon of The New York Times asked some prominent New Yorkers where they would take delegates to see the real New York.

title: It Takes a Village Planner
description: Ever find yourself driven to distraction because you're busy redesigning the British Airways lounge at O'Hare? Losing a night's sleep because you wouldn't have put quite so much curve in the tail lights of the new Mercedes S-Class? Standing around the luggage carousel cursing all the ugly-looking bags and scripting a bill that would ban all wheels and superfluous buckles? For most of my life, I've been a fierce competitor in the high-stakes game of mental decorating. With no fixed rules, time limits or lurid uniforms, I've been an industrial designer on the train to work, a chef at lunch, an architect in the afternoon and a network programmer on the sofa. Recently I've been flip-flopping between shopkeeper and urban developer. On the road to engineering a new nation state, I thought it would be best to start with something more manageable, like the perfect urban village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOLLANDER, SOPHIE
description: HOLLANDER--Sophie. In her 91st year. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Arthur. Loving mother of Ellen and Marvin Perlman, Charles and Ronni. Dear sister of Goldie Boden. Adoring Nana of Leslie, Andrew & Jennifer, and Adam. Doting great grandmother of Mitchell Arthur. We love her, treasure her and will miss her forever. Services were previously held. For further information call 800-446-0406.

title: Oh, What to Do About the Big Flab on Campus?
description: AS a parent who this weekend is dropping his older daughter off at college for the first time, let me say that I am appalled by the condition of the young men on our campuses. They are both intellectually and physically unworthy, a far cry from the noble young scholar-athletes that Socrates -- or was it Joe Paterno? -- had in mind when he devised the modern system of higher education. Or so I have read.

title: No Control: Once a Pitched Ball Is Hit, Luck and Defense Come Into Play
description: If you know the name Voros McCracken, you may not have been surprised by Barry Zito's struggles this year. Just two years removed from a Cy Young award, Zito has an earned run average hovering around 4.50, and a strange concept known as DIPS deserves much of the blame.

title: Carl Lewis Blasts Coaches For American Relay Losses
description: A day after watching the United States women be disqualified in the 4x100-meter relay, and hours after watching the men finish second in their 4x100 relay, the three-time Olympian Carl Lewis criticized the coaches and the leadership of USA Track and Field.

title: Black Is the New Black
description: When, in 1963, Lois K. Alexander-Lane proposed the historic role of blacks in New York City retailing as the topic for her N.Y.U. master's thesis, her professors responded that there was no such thing. A phenomenally strong-willed black woman who has been, at various times, a published writer, designer, world traveler and boutique owner, Alexander-Lane was not about to let that stand. Her answer, the Black Fashion Museum, is now in its 25th year, and to celebrate, it is returning to Harlem, from Washington, D.C. On display at the Riverside Church from October 21 through October 28 will be a 125-year-old opera cape stitched by the former slave Louvenia Price, as well as works by more recognized designers, like Patrick Kelly, Willi Smith and Stephen Burrows. You didn't know that the Alabama-born Ann Lowe designed Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy's wedding dress? Well, neither did those N.Y.U. professors.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 15 about designer toys from Hong Kong and elsewhere misstated the relationship between the cost of manufacturing them and their retail price, $100 or more. The cost of making them is a small fraction of the sales price.

title: 'African-American' Becomes a Term for Debate
description: For a moment, the Ethiopian-born activist seemed to melt into the crowd, blending into the sea of black professors, health experts and community leaders considering how to educate blacks about the dangers of prostate cancer. But when he piped up to suggest focusing some attention on African immigrants, the dividing lines were promptly and pointedly drawn.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Political Points column last Sunday about entertainers who are to appear at exclusive parties during the Republican National Convention in New York cited one erroneously. Although the country singer Faith Hill was listed on a preliminary schedule, she never agreed to perform and will not do so, her publicist said.

title: Sharon's Wars
description: 'Where Is Ariel Sharon Leading Israel?'' Who knows? But as an old Zionist, I believe I know what his ultimate goal is. Growing up in Germany in the 1920's, I joined Kadima, a Zionist youth organization. Our goal, and the ultimate goal of every Zionist (including, no doubt, Ariel Sharon), has always been ''Eretz Israel.'' This meant all of what was known as Palestine. What we Zionists did not foresee was the tenacity of the Palestinians to hold on to their land and not be subjugated.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: N.F.L.

title: Transcending Politics, A Whale Necktie
description: DEMOCRATS and Republicans may clash over who did what when they put on military uniforms. They may disagree about where on their shirts to wear religion. But they are all but united in their taste in neckties.

title: Housing for Artists? How About Bicycle Repairmen?
description: I LIKE artists as much as the next guy, but when I read that a Jersey City developer was converting a warehouse into an apartment building that would reserve six units for low-and moderate-income artists, I could feel my blood boil. According to news reports, Jersey City is already home to 1,600 artists, so it's not like six more Andy Warhol clones is going to make that much of a difference. Moreover, Jersey City is right across the river from New York, home to tens of thousands of artists, so the idea of designating special housing for even more painters and sculptors, whatever their economic condition, seems like a waste of precious resources.

title: Bush Jokes; The Apprentices; Classical Critics
description: BUSH JOKES

title: Dressage Code
description: Even before the wonder horse Smarty Jones captured the hearts of racing fans around the world, we fashion folk always knew that this was going to be the year of the horse.

title: A Model of Zen In an Elephant-Crossing Zone
description: Correction Appended

title: Seoul Mates
description: It's the hot new label from Korea (honest), and not since the 1980's -- when Rei Kawakubo and Yohji Yamamoto unleashed the minimalist Japanese wave that transformed American fashion -- have two designers from across the Pacific made such a splash. The eccentric husband-and-wife team behind Y & Kei dabbles in monkish minimalism, but ultimately surrenders to feminine, form-fitting pieces with color and frills. In 2003, the couple won the prestigious Rising Star award for best new designer from Fashion Group International. Months later came their SoHo boutique, where stars like Halle Berry, Kate Hudson and Britney Spears began snapping up everything from the velvet jackets to the hand-embroidered camisoles to tweed Hepburnesque trousers. But it is Kate Moss, not Kate Hepburn, whom they cite as their muse, obsessed with her uptown-downtown look, her ''risky'' style and the way she looks in jeans.

title: What Belongs on Page 1?
description: In ''What Belongs on the Front Page of The New York Times'' (Aug. 22), you say that ''Times editors have taken pains'' to see that analysis, or Q-head articles, ''do not express opinion.'' That is fundamentally impossible.

title: Here, Kitty, Kitty
description: Louis Vuitton's cheery Murakami bags and the Lucy Liu segment of ''Kill Bill'' were just the tip of the tsunami. With its sexy, futuristic silhouettes and Pop Art palette, the wide-eyed universe of Japanese animation, or anime, is a natural source of inspiration for fashion. As early as 1997, the photographer Nick Knight and the designer Alexander McQueen transformed Bjork into a gorgeous humanoid geisha for the cover of ''Homogenic.'' And now for fall, anime looks are leaping from the screen.

title: In New York, Try and Find A Genuine New York Bagel
description: BEWARE the billowy bagel. It bears no resemblance to its small, gnarly forebears. The traditional bagel was as tough as New Yorkers imagine themselves to be. It was a workout: the carb count of a handmade bagel was net zero once the chewing was done.

description: This

title: Lori Koenig, Alexander Cone
description: Lori Diane Koenig and Alexander Brian Cone are to be married today in Manchester, Vt. The Rev. R. Craig Bustrin, an Episcopal priest, is to officiate at the Hildene, a house museum where Abraham Lincoln's son Robert Todd Lincoln once lived.

title: The Nation; Swift Boats and the Lessons of Dukakis
description: THIS is not the first time Senator John Kerry's advisers have heard the guns of August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PLUMMER, PAUL CALVIN, JR.
description: PLUMMER--Paul Calvin, Jr., died of cancer on August 15, after a courageous struggle. A life-long New Yorker, he graduated from Music and Art High School in 1948 and served in the U.S. Army in the Korean War, 1951-1952. In the 1960s he worked at the War Resisters League and Village Gate and was a convening presence at The Poetry Project at St. Mark's Church and Umbra. Paul appeared in Jonathan Miller's 1964 production of Robert Lowell's ''The Old Glory.'' He worked at CBS Publications and Columbia University's Senate and was president of the Commercial Chess League of New York and active in the Banker's Athletic League Chess Team, which will establish an annual tournament in his name. His partner of 30 years, Corinne Coleman; sister, Jacquiline Hewitt-Duval; daughters Noel and Kerry, granddaughter Sidney, son Kevin; nieces; and many friends will miss his elegance and dignity, quicksilver intelligence and wry humor.

title: Seoul Mates
description: It's the hot new label from Korea (honest), and not since the 1980's -- when Rei Kawakubo and Yohji Yamamoto unleashed the minimalist Japanese wave that transformed American fashion -- have two designers from across the Pacific made such a splash. The eccentric husband-and-wife team behind Y & Kei dabbles in monkish minimalism, but ultimately surrenders to feminine, form-fitting pieces with color and frills. In 2003, the couple won the prestigious Rising Star award for best new designer from Fashion Group International. Months later came their SoHo boutique, where stars like Halle Berry, Kate Hudson and Britney Spears began snapping up everything from the velvet jackets to the hand-embroidered camisoles to tweed Hepburnesque trousers. But it is Kate Moss, not Kate Hepburn, whom they cite as their muse, obsessed with her uptown-downtown look, her ''risky'' style and the way she looks in jeans.

title: Swede Spot
description: To the uninitiated, Sweden is to style as Germany is to humor. But as anyone with finely tuned radar will tell you, the land that gave us Roxette and Lars Nilsson is now on the international fashion map. Stockholm, the Swedish capital, even has a thriving new shopping district, which is named, much to the embarrassment of the locals, SoFo, as in ''south of Folkungagatan.'' Located in the formerly working-class district of Sodermalm, SoFo serves up a smorgasbord of indie fashion stores selling everything from ascetic avant-garde to hard-edged streetwear. And in case you find the street signs as impenetrable as the Swedish chef on ''The Muppets,'' we asked Salka Hallstrom Bornold -- an editor at the cool-as-Borg Stockholm-based fashion magazine Bon -- to provide us with this handy guide. Shop till you drop -- or, as they say in Sweden, Shoppa loss!

title: Rhythms And Algorithms
description: ''It's not country dancing,'' Melanie Axel-Lute, who books bands for them, says of the twice-monthly sessions of contra dancing held at Ogden Memorial Church in Chatham. ''That's something people get wrong all the time.'' But it sure looks like square dancing. As a 50-ish crowd forms lines to swing and switch partners over bouncy fiddle and accordion beats, a caller issues classic square dance commands. ''Do-si-do!'' will ring out, or ''allemande!'' Differences, it is safe to say, are subtle, yet this Saturday-night town tradition is now in its 15th year. ''This is something traditional,'' Ms. Axel-Lute said. ''It descended from stately English country dances of the 1700's. George Washington was an avid dancer, and we still do some of the dances he did.''

title: Seeing Another Opportunity to Make Boston Play Second Fiddle
description: New York's convention planners have made little effort to conceal their hope that this week's Republican National Convention will convince the world that New York is Boston's superior when it comes to playing host to a major event, just as it is in baseball, finance, the arts and, well, everything that counts.

title: A Second Act, Paintbrush in Hand, for Gary Burghoff
description: WHEN Gary Burghoff -- the future actor, artist and wildlife advocate -- was five, he liberated a few geese from a neighboring farm in Bristol. ''I had a hell of a time,'' said Mr. Burghoff, best known for his Emmy-winning role as Radar O'Reilly on the old ''M*A*S*H'' television show.

title: Two Views on the Politics of Succession
description: With Governor McGreevey's resignation date all but fixed for Nov. 15, New Jersey is bracing for its second crisis of succession in less than four years.

title: Make Way for The Big Duck
description: IT'S time to move Long Island's classic roadside icon, the Big Duck, to this region's newest entryway for hundreds of thousands of visitors -- MacArthur Airport in Bohemia.

title: Lee Speckenbach, Chris Franzek
description: Lee Rock Speckenbach and James Christopher Franzek were married yesterday at Holy Cross Church in Rumson, N.J. The Rev. Stephen F. Duffy, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Wrapping Up the Athens Games
description: ATHENS, Aug. 29  The last heart-pounding race of the Summer Games ended today in a white marble arena in the heart of Athens, bringing the modern Olympics full circle, back to the precise spot where they were revived 108 years ago.

title: Bjork Grabs The World By the Throat
description: NEVER underestimate the inspired perversity of artists. Consider a central paradox of 21st-century pop: at a time when musicians can instantly summon an infinitude of sounds, easily tune them into any melodic contour and digitally layer as many tracks as they want, austerity rules instead.

title: Is It a Bird? Or a Plane? No, It's Just a Reality Show
description: A stunt for a new ESPN game show that had contestants hanging from a blimp 500 feet over Long Island Sound in the Stratford area last Monday may have surprised or confused some onlookers.

title: On Buses, Courtesy Goes a Long Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Car's Here, On Track 2
description: SOMETHING must be said right away about riding the subway in Los Angeles: It may not take you where you want to go. In an area of such sprawl, its 73.1-mile route system seems meager -- you can forget Venice Beach or the Santa Monica Pier -- and regular commuters complain of faraway stations with inconvenient bus connections, not to mention frequent slowdowns.

title: Correction
description: Ashort article in the Travel Advisory column on Aug. 15, about plans to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the liberation of Paris, misspelled the name of the city's mayor. He is Bertrand Delanoe, not Delano.

title: Sweet, Heritage, Teddy
description: Sweet / (sw $; et) / adj. / having the taste of sugar or a substance resembling sugar; surfer-speak for something that's, like, totally awesome; a word that has demurely entered the style lexicon as a more considered nod than the all-purpose ''fabulous.'' Although the fashion world can be as sweet as sour milk, this season, labels like Marc Jacobs, Libertine and Moschino captured the charming sweet-bird-of-youth culture. Bow blouses, lace and $2,000 cashmere sweaters with cartoon figures can -- if not paired correctly -- be so sweet as to induce cavities.

title: The Rising Appeal (and Falling Cost) of Term Insurance
description: WHEN it comes to life's priorities, protecting one's family falls in the priceless category. And because of increased competition, the actual price for term life insurance has dropped by half in a decade. For $40 or so a month -- about the cost of a cup of coffee a day -- a healthy 40-year-old male can buy a policy that will pay $500,000 if he dies within 20 years.

title: Nails, Massage or Eyebrow Job, In the Privacy of Your Hotel Room
description: THE standards of grooming are very high in New York, and not surprisingly, salons and spas here offer services you will not easily find anywhere else. From a Thai massage that involves yoga and warm herbal compresses to meticulous eyebrow shaping and manicures, there are special treatments to help you look fresh and camera-ready.

title: 10 Reasons You'll Know You're Not in Kansas Anymore
description: FIRST-TIME visitors and those of you who haven't been back since the city was ''cleaned up'' may have gotten the wrong impression. If you believe the conventional wisdom, Times Square has become a tame Mall of America, and national chain store theme parks rule the streets and avenues -- indeed the very heart and soul -- of what was once a one-of-a-kind metropolis. Some of you may wonder if all the homogenization has left anything that makes New York the idiosyncratic, difficult, challenging and charming city it once was.

title: Posterior Modern
description: This woman is walking down the street ahead of me, ordinary looking, but as she passes, every male head swivels. I can almost see dotted lines streaming from popping eyes to bobbing cheeks. And then I think, Of course, buttocks are the new breasts. Every culture and every time has its template for the ideal female form. Here in the United States, after more than 50 years of breast fixation, the bottom has come into its own. Jennifer Lopez's generous seat may be driving the trend, or it may just embody, so to speak, the current ideal. It doesn't take a degree in anthropology to tie the new silhouette to the ascendance of African-American and Hispanic influence in entertainment (e.g., that hip-hop classic ''Baby Got Back'').

title: DataBank; Markets Extend Gains as Oil Prices Start to Cool
description: Stocks rose last week as the price of oil dropped almost 8 percent, to $43.18 a barrel, and a peace agreement was arranged in the Shiite holy city of Najaf in Iraq.

title: Greenport Seeks to Raise Transfer Tax Exemption
description: Trustees of the Village of Greenport are asking the State Legislature to alter a voter-approved land preservation program financed by a 2 percent transfer tax on real estate.

title: A Platform for Immigrants
description: Political parties generally like to get through the business of adopting their campaign platforms without too much fuss. But on the eve of their convention, President Bush and his loyal followers had to deal with undercurrents of unhappiness from conservatives about the issue of immigration reform.

title: Museumus Peconicus, an Evolving Species
description: AN amateur paleontologist, Tim Serabian, stood in front of a hulking, lifelike statue of a platecarpus at the new Dinosaur Walk museum in Riverhead, telling an impromptu tour group that the aquatic reptile lived during the time of the dinosaurs but wasn't a dinosaur.

title: Corrections

title: Beach Closings Rise In New Rule's Wake
description: BEACH closings in Nassau and Suffolk are rising as the two counties step up water monitoring and impose a new state standard to protect swimmers from bacteria that can make them sick.

title: Lana Zak and Seth Andrew
description: LANA ZAK wanted her wedding to Seth Andrew to have a water theme, reflecting his love of sailing, a late-night thunderstorm that sealed their fate and what the bride called their ''ocean of love.''

title: Father's Eye Guides Ward to Boxing's Gold, the First Since '96
description: ATHENS, Aug. 29  Every day for the last two years, Andre Ward has listened for his father's voice urging him through miles of roadwork and different opponents in the ring.

title: Secrets From the Badlands
description: MIDWESTERN killing sprees seldom resemble one another except in their ability to lend a certain melancholia to wide-open spaces, peeling paint and yellow porch lights that can be seen from great distances. Nonetheless, in 1990, a 15-year-old girl in Brooklyn named Liza Ward conceived the idea that ''In Cold Blood'' was written about her grandparents. She believed this to be so because the only thing she knew about her grandparents, C. Lauer and Clara Ward, was that they had lived in a Midwestern city and had been murdered by a cold-blooded killer.

title: Where the World Trade Center Fell, an Aura Still Stands
description: THE difficulty of visiting ground zero is more than emotional and spiritual, though it is certainly that. After all, this is where 2,749 people died on Sept. 11, 2001.

description: AT most corporations, new rules to ensure that a majority of directors are independent and serving shareholders' interests are finally in effect. But just how assiduously are they being followed?

title: Bush Landslide (In Theory)!
description: Econometrics, essentially the convergence of economics and statistics, attempts to objectively analyze complex events through empirical research. It is a widely accepted discipline in business, government and academia.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Republican Party's shifting status in Westchester misstated the tenure of Representative Nita Lowey, a Democrat from the county. She has served eight terms in Congress, not four.

title: 'An Alchemy of Mind'
description: Like tiny islands on the horizon, they can vanish in rough seas. Even in calm weather, their coral gradually erodes, pickled by salt and heat. Yet they form the shoals of a life. Some offer safe lagoons and murmuring trees. Others crawl with pirates and reptiles. Together, they connect a self with the mainland and society. Plot their trail and a mercurial past becomes visible.

title: How Do You Spell Regret? One Man's Take on It
description: SOMETIMES, a single moment can eviscerate a politician's image, forever dwelling in voters' memories and late-night comedians' repertories.

title: GOING OUT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIENER, SIDNEY
description: WIENER--Sidney, on August 27th, 2004. Beloved husband of Shirley. Loving father of Helen Beth Friedlander, Alan Wiener, Bunny Schorr and Kenneth. Adored grandfather of Robert, Deborah, Justin, Jeremy, David, Deborah Anne, Brian, Amy and Kevin. Former National President of Bnai Zion. May his memory be for a blessing. Services today, 12 noon, at ''BoulevardRiverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Katharine Lawrence, Matthew Sawatzky
description: Katharine Peabody Lawrence, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David T. Lawrence of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married yesterday to Matthew Robert Sawatzky, the son of Marylou Foley of Braintree, Mass., and Walter K. Sawatzky of Hanson, Mass. The Rev. Michael Corrigan performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Our Saviour in Brookline, Mass.

title: The Street Of No Return
description: Unified commercial strips are a hallmark of New York. There is the diamond district on West 47th Street and Restaurant Row on West 46th Street, and down on the Bowery, a series of storefronts offer all manner of lighting supplies. It stands to reason that it makes economic sense to dedicate a strip to that most final of purchases, the funeral.

title: Reprising the Spice Girls
description: FOR as long as either Lindsay Nyman or Brittney Segal can remember, each has warmed to the glare of stage lights and longed to become a star. Now, at the ripe old age of 14, both girls are well on their way to finding the fame they have craved.

title: Lisa Bell, Michael King
description: Lisa Rene Bell was married yesterday to Michael Joseph King at St. Paul African Methodist Episcopal Church in Lexington, Ky. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth W. Cummings Sr., a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Monterey
description: The Monterey Peninsula is one of those uncommon places of tourism plenty. Like a painter's palette, it is suited for travelers prone to dabbling in a bit of this and a bit of that -- whether it be jazz, whale-watching or auto-racing.

description: Mitch Jones has hit 37 home runs this season, and after each of them, he has put his head down and run the bases.

title: Lt. Governor Is Not A Solution
description: LET'S not throw the baby out with the bathwater. Reactions to the McGreevey incidents in New Jersey have included suggestions involving the reduction of the powers of the governor and the establishment of a lieutenant governor by amendment to the state Constitution. Let's take a closer look.

title: Welcome to Julie's World
description: 1. The first thing you notice about Julie Gilhart is her enthusiasm. And right now she is enthusing in her tawny Texan twang about one of her ultimate style heroes, Cristbal Balenciaga. ''He was pure, unadulterated genius,'' she says. For fall, Balenciaga's current designer, Nicolas Ghesquire, took six haute-couture designs from the archives and tweaked them a bit. ''What could be better than owning Nicolas's version of Balenciaga haute couture?'' she asks. ''This dress'' -- for $2,400 -- ''is really what's happening now in terms of volume. It looks right this second.''

title: Andrea Salzman, Lee Hutter
description: Andrea Jessica Salzman, the daughter of Sonia and David E. Salzman of Beverly Hills, Calif., is to be married today to Lee Benjamin Hutter, the son of Marcia Markowitz of Brightwaters, N.Y., and Julian Hutter of New York. Rabbi Gershon Johnson is to officiate at the Rosenthal vineyard in Malibu, Calif.

description: Union Says Employee Misused $200,000

title: Snapshots: Album or Cerebrum
description: FOR as long as I've been a traveler, I've been a shutterbug. Happily clicking my way through my trips and then assembling photo journals is a fond travel ritual, a way of encountering places along the route and later noting details I may have missed. My shelves overflow with photo scrapbooks of my travels, but I also cherish another resource of recollection. I call them mental snapshots.

title: Decarcerate?
description: Nine years ago, my cousin was kidnapped, bound, repeatedly sodomized and finally bludgeoned to death with a baseball bat. Some may see ideas about abolishing incarceration as benevolent. I see them as an appalling disregard for the feelings of victims' families.

title: Buyers Shrug Off Terror Alert To Snap Up Wall St. Condos
description: AUGUST began with a terror alert and quickly segued into pre-convention jitters. None of that seems to have dampened sales at a new condominium conversion across the street from the New York Stock Exchange.

title: What They Swam This Summer
description: Students at Holmdel High School may soon be writing essays on what they did over summer vacation, but chances are they won't top their business education teacher, Michelle Davidson. title: BackTalk; Reforming the B.C.S. Gains Momentum

The coalition had three goals: support the academic reform movements by the National Collegiate Athletic Association; identify ways to bring fiscal sanity to intercollegiate athletics; and eliminate the financial, branding and competitive disparities created by the Bowl Championship Series. As a new season begins, it seems an appropriate time to look back at the changes of the past year.

title: PHOTO-OP
An Artist Shaped in Queens
description: Inconspicuously tucked amid warehouses and commercial garages in Long Island City, along the western slice of Queens on the river, stands the last great piece of art created by the Japanese-American artist Isamu Noguchi. For the prolific sculptor, designer and essayist, who worked for decades in the borough, no other creation could have been as personal. It is his museum, which he conceived, stocked and installed himself in 1985, three years before he died. Starkly built, with concrete walls and floors and wood-beamed ceilings, it is an understated monument which, after a much-needed renovation, the museum has reopened in time for the centenary of Noguchi's birth.

Barrie, the author of ''Peter Pan,'' and the studio, Miramax, was hoping for a more marketable name to star opposite him, like Gwyneth Paltrow, perhaps, or Nicole Kidman. The film, directed by Marc Forster, weaves together a tragic family story and the creation of Barrie's greatest artistic triumph. Out in theaters in October, ''Neverland'' is eloquently sentimental, a movie that beautifully depicts the link between art and life, where influences overlap and inspire.

They catch and throw flip-wristed, and for no reason at all dash to a rickety wooden bleacher set up on the beach. Arranging themselves for a still shot, arms and legs flutter, won't be tamed. Amusing pets, all pretty. Some have ribbons round their bobbed hair. Some wear brimless hats molded close to the head, a flirty curl or two escaping. Their bathing suits, belted or sashed, are striped, a few checkered in harlequin patterns. Silly girls laughing, smiling to beat the band. title: Kitsch Of The Day
description: If you need a break from the fast lane, the Vermont Country Store catalog offers the chance to settle into a nostalgic time warp. And while nostalgia doesn't come cheap, it's a hoot poring over the oldies-but-goodies: Fuller Brush mops, girdles and muumuus, and green-goddess salad dressing. Opened in 1946 by Vrest Orton, the store, in Weston, Vt. (population: 630), is still family owned, by Lyman Orton and his sons. It's the kind of place where Diane Keaton sold her homemade applesauce in ''Baby Boom.'' But this is postmodern interactive retail; the Ortons take requests and hunt down yesterday's conveniences, like Brown Bread in a Can. ''Our weirdest request?'' Cabot Orton says. ''A woman wrote in asking if we sold muzzles for children.'' They don't, but they do sell Tangee lipstick ($13), which changes color according to mood. All four Ortons use the store's pants stretchers: put them in a pair of wet trousers, and when they dry, no ironing's required; better yet, perfect creases appear. Lollipop underwear, anyone? Go to www.vermontcountrystore.com. S.S. FAIR

That idea is at the heart of Mira Nair's sumptuous, witty new version of ''Vanity Fair'' (opening Wednesday) with Reese Witherspoon as Becky Sharp, one of literature's great survivors, social climbers and perpetual self-inventors. After all these years, Becky carries with her the aura of her many spiritual daughters: Scarlett O'Hara, Madonna, even Elle Wood, Ms. Witherspoon's smart dumb-blonde character from the ''Legally Blonde'' comedies. And while ''Vanity Fair'' remains essentially true to the setting of William Makepeace Thackeray's 1848 novel, it also offers a Becky Sharp for today, a 19th-century heroine who appeals to contemporary attitudes about class, ambition and women fending for themselves.

Era had a bit of money in the bank -- she was the vice president of sales, West Coast -- and she figured that she could always sell her new Mercedes C320 if her savings ran out. She wanted to learn how to make leather bags by hand, but finding an artigiano, an old-school artisan to whom she could apprentice herself, might not be that easy. And even if there were any artigiani still around, and she were lucky enough to find one who would take her on, she had a lot to learn before starting her own business, and learning takes time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WANG, NIAN, TZU, N.T.
description: WANG--Nian-Tzu, N.T., of Larchmont, NY, died of cancer, on August 26, 2004. Loving husband of Mabel U, devoted father of June, Kay (Leighton Chen), Cynthia (Daniel Sedlis), Geraldine, and Newton, and proud grandfather of Christine, Stephanie and Lucy. In his autobiography, ''My Nine Lives'', NT wrote of his lives as number one son, traditional scholar, foreign student, public servant, instructor, international servant, advisor, academician, and immigrant. NT was born in Shanghai on July 25, 1917. Initially trained to be a Confucian scholar, he received a classical education at home, where he was tutored in Chinese poetry, painting, the Classics and other literati skills. Math, science, and languages were introduced later by his father, Pai Yuan (PY) Wang, a sophisticated banker when he decided to school his four sons in Western ways when they were teenagers. In 1937, NT went abroad to study at the London School of Economics and Germany. He transferred to Columbia where he graduated Phi Beta Kappa with honors in economics in 1941, and went on to receive an M.A. and PhD in economics from Harvard. NT will be remembered throughout the international community for his dedicated efforts in advising businesses and governments around the world on ecomonic development. He made many contributions to his homeland of China, the U.S., his home since 1939, and to countless countries which he helped through his work at the U.N. Economic and Social Council. After retiring from a 28 year career at the United Nations, as the Director of the Centre on Transnational Corporations, he returned to Columbia Univ. to teach at the School of Business and the School of International and Public Affairs. He thoroughly enjoyed his time with his students, organizing seminars, creating training programs for Chinese academic and business leaders, and working tirelessly as the Director of the China-International Business Project. In his final days, he was polishing his keynote speech as part of Columbia University's 250th anniversary celebration. He was an honorary professor of ten universities, a fellow of the International Academy of Management, and a recipient of many awards, including the New York Governor's Award for Outstanding Asian American. In addition to his many professional achievements, his passions included dancing with his life partner of 62 years, Mabel, and playing tennis. NT exhausted his daughter Kay playing two and a half hours of tennis after celebrating his 87th birthday just one month ago. Throughout his life, he took time to compose classical Chinese poems, which his family will compile as the tenth chapter in his life, 'The Poet'. A memorial service will be announced later. Contributions may be made to Community Funds Inc. for the N.T. and Mabel Wang Charitable Fund, which will continue the mission of the China-International Business Project he established at Columbia University, c/o Community Funds Inc., 2 Park Avenue, NY, NY 10016

title: Hollywood High; Jersey Girls
description: When it comes to fashion, Los Angeles -- especially the closely watched state of glamour that is commonly referred to as Hollywood -- has two speeds: skin-revealing casual or red carpet. There are notable exceptions, like any member of the Coppola planet and female executives who don suits for the office, but a frighteningly large number of women in L.A. seems to favor a day uniform of belly-baring velour sweats or extreme low-rise jeans. There is no age limit to this look: girls from 6 to, yes, 60 are donning pastel workout clothes and exposing their thongs when they bend over in their jeans. The look is all too often accessorized with DayGlo flip-flops and, lest anyone doubt the wealth of the casual dresser, a ridiculously enormous Birkin bag from Herms that screams money. Even when this ensemble looks, technically, good -- as when the body is tanned and toned and the sports bra is filled to bursting -- I always think anything else would look better. How about a pencil-thin skirt to show off your curves? Or a fitted sundress? But no: if it's L.A., it must be sloppy. If dressing reflects the mental state of the culture, Angelenos have barely woken up. They're still children in their play clothes.

title: Fellini's No-Good Role Models
description: THERE was a time when it seemed as if half the good movies made in America had been inspired, or at least enabled, by a single Federico Fellini film: not ''La Strada'' (1954) or ''La Dolce Vita'' (1960) or ''81/2'' (1963), but the beautiful, lesser-known ''I Vitelloni'' (1953, issued last week on DVD), which he wrote and directed just before he started down that ''Felliniesque'' road on which he could not safely be followed. ''I Vitelloni,'' not even released in this country until after ''La Strada'' had made Fellini an art-house celebrity, nonetheless managed, by the beginning of the 70's, to work its way deep into the consciousness of several of the best young American filmmakers. You can hear this movie's voice whispering in the ear of Peter Bogdanovich in ''The Last Picture Show'' (1971), of George Lucas in ''American Graffiti'' (1973), of Martin Scorsese in ''Mean Streets'' (1973), of Philip Kaufman in ''The Wanderers'' (1979), of Barry Levinson in ''Diner'' (1982).

title: Guided By Voices Into Retirement
description: GUIDED BY VOICES -- Occasionally I go through a funk in which I'm sick of all my records. I was in one recently until I heard some news that slapped me in the face. Guided by Voices is calling it quits after more than two decades. Since then I've been pulling out all my Guided by Voices albums. I once spent a month studying Doug Gillard's guitar parts before playing a show in a Guided by Voices tribute band. Figuring out the guitar solo for ''I Am a Tree'' made me feel more confident about using guitar solos in my music. And the album ''Bee Thousand'' blew me away from the first spin. I couldn't believe how many undeniable hooks they were cramming into a minute-and-a half tune. Robert Pollard is the most naturally charismatic frontman I have ever seen. Now through the end of the year, the band will be traveling across the country on its ''Electrifying Conclusion'' tour.

Obama, the Democratic candidate for Illinois's open Senate seat, strode into the national spotlight last month with his keynote speech at the Democratic National Convention. With a chance to become the Senate's only African-American member, Obama, a Harvard-educated civil rights lawyer, has been called ''the new Tiger Woods of American politics.'' Obama's memoir, reissued with a new preface, traces his unusual family history. His father, a black Kenyan, and his mother, a white American from Kansas, met and married in Hawaii (his father returned to Kenya when Obama was still young). Paul Watkins, writing in the Book Review in 1995, said Obama's memoir ''persuasively describes the phenomenon of belonging to two different worlds, and thus belonging to neither.''

title: Abolish the Electoral College
description: When Republican delegates nominate their presidential candidate this week, they will be doing it in a city where residents who support George Bush have, for all practical purposes, already been disenfranchised. Barring a tsunami of a sweep, heavily Democratic New York will send its electoral votes to John Kerry and both parties have already written New York off as a surefire blue state. The Electoral College makes Republicans in New York, and Democrats in Utah, superfluous. It also makes members of the majority party in those states feel less than crucial. It's hard to tell New York City children that every vote is equally important -- it's winner take all here, and whether Senator Kerry beats the president by one New York vote or one million, he will still walk away with all 31 of the state's electoral votes.

Ray and his partner Bill were very successful on the crafts circuit. Bill, with Ray's assistance, was a very talented artisan in wood carving. Ray was a very active organizing volunteer from the beginning of the Gay Men's Health Crisis. At GMHC Ray founded and facilitated the first and longest running support group for care-partners of people living with AIDS. He was a member and supporter of SAGE (Senior Action in a Gay Environment), both in New York City. Surviving are his best freinds, Mary Healy and Herb Pitchford, and many devoted friends, clients and associates. He was predeceased by his companion, William J. Schneck in 1991. title: Neiman Markdown
description: All modesty aside, I am the greatest shopper in the world. Maybe two or three other women out there come close, but enough about them. This is not misplaced arrogance or pathetic self-aggrandizing; it's simply a matter of fact. Whereas others shop in a desperate delirium akin to sugar shock, or soldier on with humorless determination as if the species depended on their ability to come up with the perfect, white spread-collar shirt, I focus in on the goods at hand. Steadily gazing, infinitely serene, alert to the unexpected, I strike only when the look, fit and price are unassailably right. Samurai shopping, when practiced with due diligence and a light touch, becomes instinctual and swift, thoughtless in true Zen fashion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERKOWITZ, WILLIAM
description: BERKOWITZ--William. Age 62, died peacefully in his sleep at his home in Sarasota, FL, on Sunday, August 22, 2004, after a long battle with cancer. Mr. Berkowitz, as President of one of the nation's first and largest retail Money Market Mutual Funds, Dreyfus Liquid Assets, helped to transform the way Americans save. As he told ''Forbes'' in 1980, ''...the savings public is becoming more sophisticated. It will not stand for this 5% rate on passbooks (savings accounts).'' He fought against the regulation of the money market industry and welcomed competition from banks by testifying in favor of lifting Regulation Q--which prevented banks from paying prevailing high interest rates on savings accounts. In 1964 a twenty-three year old William ''Bill'' Berkowitz came to work at The Dreyfus Corporation, the New York based investment management firm. By 1974 Bill Berkowitz had become an officer of The Dreyfus Corporation, and soon thereafter he created and became President of Dreyfus Liquid Assets, one of the first retail oriented Money Market Mutual Funds. Dreyfus' money market services and assets grew to a top industry position under his leadership. By 1981 most of Dreyfus' $12.4 billion of assets under management was in short-term money in over 300,000 accounts. Bill became President of the Reich & Tang, L.P. Mutual Funds Group and Executive Vice President and Director of Reich & Tang L.P. in 1982. The Mutual Funds Group grew rapidly under his leadership until 1994 when Reich & Tang, L.P. merged with the asset management division of the New England Companies, creating one of the largest investment management companies in the world. He was also a VicePresident and Board member of various third party mutual funds like Gabelli Asset Growth, Equitable Life's money market mutual funds and Speers, Benzak, Solomon and Farrell Funds. He was born September 20, 1941, in Bronx, NY. Before receiving his Bachelor of Science in Finance from New York University in 1963, he attended Syracuse University and graduated from Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan in 1959. He lived in Middletown, NJ, and commuted to New York City for 16 years before moving to Sarasota, FL, in 1982. He retired from Reich and Tang, L.P. in 1994. Through the William and Dale S. Berkowitz Family Foundation and through invididual efforts, Bill supported the Flanzer Jewish Community Center of Sarasota, FL, and its Maccabi Games. He also supported the Florida Studio Theatre and the Sarasota YMCA Foundation. Bill was an avid art collector and a patron of a number of local Sarasota artists. Survivors include his beloved wife of 41 years, Dale S.; a daughter and son in law, Dana B. and John Snyder of Columbia, MD; sons and daughters in law David L. and Patti C. of Middletown, NJ, Barry J. and Chrissy of Potomac, MD, and Jeffrey A. and Susan of Sarasota; a sister Harriet Fortgang of Atlanta; and six grandchildren, Matthew, Dylan, Daniel, Bryce, Anna and Alexandra. Services and entombment were held on August 25, 2004, at the Palms Funeral Home and Memorial Park, 170 Honore Ave, Sarasota, FL 34232. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice of Southwest Florida, 5955 Rand Blvd, Sarasota, FL 34228.

title: Girls Behaving Manly
description: For a fashion photographer, Helmut Newton certainly spent a lot of time avoiding clothes. When his Teutonic beauties weren't hauling fresh-cut timber while clad only in black ankle boots, they were wearing saddles and sheer stockings. But when Newton did put his models in something they might actually wear out of the house, it was often pants. Undoubtedly Newton wasn't thinking of comfort or practicality when he composed his famous image of an Yves Saint Laurent pantsuit in a dim Parisian street, and it would come as a complete surprise if his bedtime reading included ''The Feminine Mystique.'' He put women in pants because they looked sexy, and he didn't require any sacred Weltanschauung. Sex is power. But sometimes sex is just sex.

title: The Lion in Late, Late Autumn

Mills says that Paterno can still drop to the floor and perform 20 push-ups and that the coach often takes part in drills with his linemen that result in a bloody nose. ''Nobody tries to hit him,'' Mills says. ''But accidents happen. It's funny to see a man his age running around like a kid.'' Paterno isn't trying to be funny. ''I'm young physically, so I can horse around in practice,'' he says.

That was before he took the reins at Carlota Joakina, the secondary line produced by his mother, the Brazilian avant-garde designer Glria Coelho. Pedro and I are tucked away in his parents' airy, Modernist den in S-o Paulo (his father is the Brazilian fashion star Reinaldo Loureno), and as we watch the procession -- a yellow suspender dress with a sheer tulle front; a cheerful, sky-blue pencil mini; a loose top made of periwinkle plastic -- it's clear that Pedro is right. There's more than a touch of the jejune to these happily rough-hewn clothes. To the audience, as well, if the three grade-school kids fighting to stay awake in the front row are any indication. But perhaps it's to be expected. At the time of the show, staged in his parents' living room, Pedro was 9. Now he's 14.

title: Decarcerate?

My late husband was a white-collar, first-time offender. He received two years in a federal penitentiary. But it's not only the inmate who serves time; the family does as well. My family had a father and grandfather taken away while facing financial devastation, humiliation and stress. Alternatives for incarceration are the answer. A hefty fine, community service and educational programs would promote betterment for the offender, the family and the community.

title: A METER IS RUNNING
description: The federal government should help pay for New Jersey's increased costs of maintaining security during the Republican National Convention, State Attorney General Peter C. Harvey said last week. New York City is receiving $50 million in federal funds to provide security during the convention. But New Jersey officials say that terrorism threats, and the costs they bring, do not end at the Hudson River. ''The sad truth is that New Jersey did not get a dime,'' Mr. Harvey said. He said he did not know how much overtime would be needed to conduct extra security sweeps and searches of bridges, tunnels and roads leading into New York, but he plans to keep a record of expenses to give to the federal government.

title: Charis Menschel, Ryan Drant
description: Charis Bettie Menschel, a daughter of Ronay and Richard Menschel of New York and Nantucket, Mass., was married last evening to Ryan David Drant, the son of Sandra Drant of Cypress, Calif., and the late Richard Drant. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated at the bride's family's home on Nantucket.

description: A POLITICAL convention prompts thought about what it means to be an American, and so do a number of current museum exhibitions in New York.

description: ON the last day of July, one day before the public learned that the Prudential building here was a possible terrorist target and that New Jersey's security could be jeopardized just as much as New York's or Washington's, a law enforcement agency began scrambling officers and getting ready for what seemed to be an imminent threat.
