description: St. Martin de Porres School in Uniondale, a Roman Catholic school that is about $200,000 in debt, will reopen next month under the auspices of the Marianists on Long Island, also known as the Society of Mary.

title: In Cleveland's Suburbs, New Luxury vs. Old
description: BUILT nearly 100 years ago as one of the country's first planned communities, this is still in many ways an ideal community. Old-growth trees shade stately English Tudor, Country French and Georgian homes. Lush green lawns gently slope toward winding residential streets. Well-maintained rapid transit lines whisk people to downtown Cleveland in less than 20 minutes. The public school system serves an economically and racially diverse student body while remaining one of the best in Ohio. Exclusive private schools, lured by the area's founders with free land, are still in operation today.

title: A Respectful Quarterback Draws Respect for Missouri
description: The fate of Missouri's moribund football program changed one winter day four years ago, in the corner office of Mount Calvary Pentecostal Church in Youngstown, Ohio.

description: IN the wake of the corporate governance scandals of the last several years, chief executives must make changes to rebuild their stature as leaders, says Andrea Redmond, co-leader of the C.E.O. and board services practice at Russell Reynolds Associates, an executive recruitment firm. Following are excerpts from a conversation with Ms. Redmond, who is also a co-author of a new book, ''Business Evolves, Leadership Endures'' (Easton Studio Press):

title: Torchbearers: 4 Nights of Cabaret
description: IT was a long weekend of torch singers and Cole Porter-like wit. Full nights ripe with music redolent of smoky adult sophistication and risqu necklines. The old late-night standards of London, Paris and New York, all right here in the Hamptons.

title: For One Texan, Gotham Hasn't Felt Like Home
description: DURING the Democratic National Convention last month, it seemed that John Kerry could not spend enough time in a city he calls home. He sneaked in off the campaign trail for a Red Sox game. He was cheered by Bostonians on street corners. And when it came time for bed, home was not just another hotel room: it was a town house within walking distance of the FleetCenter.

title: Laura Branigan, Pop Singer Famous for 'Gloria,' Dies at 47
description: Laura Branigan, a singer whose high-volume vocals in the disco-style song ''Gloria'' propelled her into pop stardom, died in her sleep Thursday night at her home in East Quogue, N.Y. She was 47.

title: SUMMER 2004 GAMES -- TRACK AND FIELD: MEN'S 4x100-METER RELAY; An American Relay Effort Again Gets Out of Hand
description: No one had run faster than the United States' 100-meter sprinters -- at least without a baton. But put the stick in an unpracticed American's hand on the track in these Olympics, and it transforms talent into tumult.

description: Skiers can get cheaper unlimited access to the slopes with early-bird discounts at many ski resorts.

title: A Declining Budget For Westchester Magnet
description: The loss of a $ 650,000 grant from the United States Department of Education means that the Westchester Magnet Academy, an alternative-type high school that serves 175 students from the Greenburgh Central 7, Harrison and Irvington school districts, will start the school year with a 25 percent decline in its operating budget, leading to cost-cutting measures in programming and staffing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEHON, RUTH
description: LEHON--Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Hyman Lehon. Loving mother of Phyllis Richman and father-in-law of Paul Richman. Devoted grandmother of Jason Richman.

description: Leonard C. Boyle, the state's newly appointed commissioner of the state's Department of Public Safety, considers staffing the specialized units of the state police a priority, according to a department official.

title: Format Helps Top Teams Stay on Top
description: Ten teams spend more than $1 billion every season to compete in Formula One, but only one has won the championship in half a decade. If that sounds mad, the rest of what is going on in Formula One may explain why.

title: Shaking 'The Big Apple' Out of History's Convoluted Tree
description: By day, Barry Popik is a New York administrative law judge who handles things like parking violations. By night, he is an amateur etymologist who has traced the origina of thousands of words and phrases.

title: KIDDIE CAFTAN
description: When trends hit the runway, why should grown-ups get all the glamour? Hot on the hem of the recent caftan craze, Charlie Bradley, a British cafe owner turned fashion designer, has introduced a line of lavishly embroidered linen and brushed cotton caftans and djellabas for the jungle-gym set. Ms. Bradley, 41, went to Marrakesh last October and was so inspired by the intricate work of local seamstresses that she began a new business. Her Charlie-brand clothes -- embroidered by hand -- are available in London at Nursery Window (011 44 20 7581 3358), and can be made to order. Prices range from $90 for a minicaftan to $260 for the adult variety. ''People see the children's clothes and ask, 'Oh, can you make that in a larger size?' so I had to branch out a bit,'' Bradley said. For custom orders, write to charlie@charlottebradley.co.uk. MITCHELL OWENS

title: Death Takes a Holiday
description: ALTHOUGH I haven't yet made a trip abroad because of something I read in a detective story, I can't say I haven't been tempted. Mysteries set in faraway places make me want to toss some clothes in a bag and take off at dawn for:

title: France's Chief Purveyor Of Paranoia
description: PARANOIA is both cause and subject of many deeply satisfying cinematic styles: lucid and elegant, (Hitchcock); stylized and explosive, (Scorsese); absurdly debonair (Fellini); florid and witty (Woody Allen); austere and frostbitten (Bergman); murderous and spiked with quotations from Japanese comic books (Tarantino). But movies were not the first medium to offer paranoid enactments as entertainment. And no writer has provided as many scenarios for suspense films -- a genre that arguably provides the purest expression of excruciating paranoia -- than the great master of unease, Georges Simenon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CURY, SARA B.
description: CURY--Sara B. Of Quogue, NY on August 22, 2004. Beloved wife of Buddy, devoted mother of Thomas, dear sister of MaryLynn Cheely. Funeral services were held on Thursday, August 26, 2004.

title: Imagining Arts With Politics
description: Republican delegates can expect a response from the left this week. But how many are expecting those responses to come from a 15-foot long red megaphone -- the Freedom of Expression National Monument -- in Foley Square? Or from a man reading Homer's ''Odyssey,'' complete, while riding the Staten Island Ferry?

title: Behind VW's Wheel, With Brick Walls Ahead
description: THE most famous thing that Bernd Pischetsrieder has ever done with a car, he readily acknowledges, is to crash it. In 1995, Mr. Pischetsrieder, then the chairman of BMW, took his company's McLaren F1 -- an exotic $1 million sports car -- home for the weekend. Driving on a serpentine road in the Bavarian countryside with two passengers, he lost control of the car, which rolled over several times and came to rest in a field. His companions had only minor injuries, but the McLaren was wrecked.

title: Marchers Denounce Bush as They Pass G.O.P. Convention Hall
description: On bicycles, on foot, and some with their children in tow, hundreds of thousands of people moved through areas of Manhattan today in rallies or mass demonstrations, carrying messages against war and the Bush administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NORMAN, JANE P.
description: NORMAN--Jane P., died August 26, age 90. Innovative art educator for New York public schools. Consultant to the Metropolitan Museum of Art for thirty years. Unabashed New Yorker, lover of its parks, museums and people. Beloved wife of the late Theodore Norman. Treasured mother of Alice and Lucy, grandmother of Tanya, Greg, Ezra, Josh, Gideon and Sam, great-grandmother of Evelyn and Isaac, mother-inlaw of Richard Mandel and William Friedman, grandmother-in-law of Alyson and Amanda. Memorial service Friday, September 10 at 2:00 pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, at 91st Street. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to Planned Parenthood of New York, 26 Bleecker Street, NY, NY 10012.

title: What Women Want to Watch
description: WHEN Mark Graff, a longtime veteran of adult entertainment, founded Playgirl TV in 2003, he wasn't necessarily interested in liberating women to enjoy the pleasures of erotic entertainment; he was more interested in exploiting them, as an underserved market.

title: Black Is the New Black
description: When, in 1963, Lois K. Alexander-Lane proposed the historic role of blacks in New York City retailing as the topic for her N.Y.U. master's thesis, her professors responded that there was no such thing. A phenomenally strong-willed black woman who has been, at various times, a published writer, designer, world traveler and boutique owner, Alexander-Lane was not about to let that stand. Her answer, the Black Fashion Museum, is now in its 25th year, and to celebrate, it is returning to Harlem, from Washington, D.C. On display at the Riverside Church from October 21 through October 28 will be a 125-year-old opera cape stitched by the former slave Louvenia Price, as well as works by more recognized designers, like Patrick Kelly, Willi Smith and Stephen Burrows. You didn't know that the Alabama-born Ann Lowe designed Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy's wedding dress? Well, neither did those N.Y.U. professors.

title: It Takes Tons of Food to Feed a Village
description: If ever there were an Olympic culinary triumph, it would be pleasing the palates of the 16,500 calorie-gorging athletes from 202 nations and their 5,000 or so support staff who make up the customer base of what is perhaps the largest restaurant on earth: the 6,000-seat Olympic Village cafeteria in Athens.

title: Janis Holzapfel, David Auster
description: Janis Jessica Holzapfel and David Lionel Auster are to be married today in Rome, N.Y. The Rev. Charles B. Hanna Jr., a Lutheran minister, is to officiate at the Teugega Country Club. Rabbi William H. Kraus is also to take part in the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: The Food column on Aug. 15, about cooking with fruits and vegetables from Northern California, misspelled the surname of a Bay Area chef. He is Charles Phan, not Pham.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet: Horse Attitudes

title: Going To Extremes
description: There's a whiff of '68 in the air. At least 200,000 demonstrators are expected to converge on the Republican National Convention at Madison Square Garden in New York -- the largest such crowd since the Yippies gamboled in Chicago's Lincoln Park back in the days of the People's Revolution. My son, Alex, who is not quite 14, is begging us to let him join the protests; he had a peace flag hanging out his bedroom window for much of this past year, and he believes that no denunciation of the Bush Administration can be too extreme. And judging by the popularity of ''Fahrenheit 9/11,'' and by the fighting-mad spirit of Howard Dean's candidacy, a sizable body of Americans feel the same way. It has become increasingly common to hear the war in Iraq described as a political miscalculation and a moral catastrophe on the order of Vietnam.

title: EDITOR'S NOTE
description: The Times has changed. Sixty years after the first Fashions of The Times, welcome to T, a magazine dedicated to style, and a nearly monthly companion to the Sunday magazine.

title: Out of Antwerp
description: This past spring, an American designer came to visit Dries Van Noten at his home outside Antwerp, an occasion that Van Noten saw no reason to publicize. Although his name is synonymous with Belgian fashion, Van Noten has never made appreciable use of his celebrity. It is almost a foreign thing to him, as psychologically uncomfortable as wearing a hat you have no head for, and after spending an afternoon walking around Antwerp with him, I even wondered if he himself were an invention. Almost nobody we passed seemed to recognize the Belgian star.

title: Fashion Victims
description: In the 1978 film ''Eyes of Laura Mars,'' Faye Dunaway plays a fashion photographer with visions of murder. Because she's utterly fabulous, not to mention able to shoot on location in five-inch heels, her homicidal hallucinations are impeccably styled, just like the fashion shoots over which she presides. While the Los Angeles-based photographer Melanie Pullen -- whose ''High Fashion Crime Scenes'' opens at Chelsea's Ace Gallery this October -- isn't channeling a model killer, the similarities between the two are close enough to warrant comparison.

title: Susan Lindauer's Mission To Baghdad
description: On the morning of March 11, 2004, Susan Lindauer woke to find five F.B.I. agents at her front door. After reading her her rights, the agents took Lindauer from her home in Takoma Park, Md., to the F.B.I. field office in Baltimore, where she was charged with having acted as an unregistered agent of Saddam Hussein's Iraqi government and otherwise having elevated the interests of a foreign country above her allegiance to the United States. ''The only visible sign of stress is that I'm chain-smoking,'' she said when I met with her recently. Forty-one and free on bail, she wore a red cotton shirt, shapeless khaki pants and battered white leather sneakers. With her casual manner, she could pass for an ordinary resident of Takoma Park, where ''War Is Not the Answer'' signs are available free at the local co-op.

title: CAMPAIGN AGAINST SLAVERY
description: State officials announced a campaign last week to raise awareness of a growing problem of human trafficking in New Jersey, joining the Catholic Archdiocese of Newark and other groups. The campaign against this modern from of slavery is to include television ads, a state task force and a toll-free phone line. United States Attorney Christopher Christie said federal officials were investigating several reports of trafficking rings in New Jersey, in addition to more than 100 nationwide, that supply mostly women for forced labor and the sex industry. Jeremy Pearce

title: No Headline
A White-Tablecloth Trattoria Next Door
description: THE village of Chappaqua seems never to have enough parking spaces or informal eating spots to meet a growing demand. Grappolo Locanda's name suggests a neighborhood trattoria, but the dcor, menu and high prices suggest the place has ambitions to be more than a local joint.

title: Champlain on Two Wheels
description: THE others are still struggling into their padded bike shorts and snapping on garish blue surgical gloves to keep the rain off their wool ones. I, however, race out and mount my Trek 24-speed hybrid bicycle and pedal as fast as I can through the cold, cloudy dampness of the Vermont morning. I am petrified that I will be the last one home.

title: Purl Harbor
description: Perhaps it's a longing for comfort at a time when we're surrounded by technology, or maybe we're turning into our grandmothers. Whatever the reason, handmade knits are all the yarn. On the runway, Junya Watanabe (bottom left) showed crocheted capes that cocoon the wearer in exaggerated textures and colors. Knitwear also showed up at Vronique Branquinho, Prada (bottom right) and Louis Vuitton, among others.

title: Corrections
description: The caption of the Aug. 22 Photo-Op misstated the occasion for a church event and its location. The event was not celebrating the feast of the Immaculate Conception. The bazaar was held at the Immaculate Conception Church in Sleepy Hollow, not North Tarrytown.

title: American Defeats Iraqi to Advance
description: ATHENS, Aug. 28 (Agence France-Presse) - The American Steven Lopez proved unpopular at the Olympic tae kwon do competition Saturday as the Olympic and world champion overpowered Raid Rasheed of Iraq in their opening match.

description: Originals by a Faux-Art Master

title: Fortress New York
description: SOLDIERS and police brigades patrol the island, placing bridges and train stations under machine-gun surveillance. Coast Guard vessels scour the harbor for enemy craft, while rumors of intruders with hard-to-pronounce names sweep through the city. Haunted by a recent act of sabotage, the largest ever on America soil, New Yorkers live in a state of high alert.

title: 2 Charged With Plotting To Bomb Train Station
description: Two New York City men were charged yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn with conspiring to set off a bomb in the subway station at Herald Square, law enforcement officials said.

title: A New U.S. Hope Rewards Faith
description: When the final horn sounded on his gold-medal wrestling match Saturday, Cael Sanderson ran out of ideas. He lifted his arms in the air, but otherwise looked stunned. It took his two coaches -- first Bobby Douglas, then Kevin Jackson -- storming onto the mat to lift him into the air, twice, to start a proper celebration.

title: Pump Empty and Platform Gone, His Little War Is Lost
description: Around 8:30 Monday morning, Inderjeet Parmar ran out of gas. He sold the last 1,000 gallons at his Getty station on Van Dam Street in Long Island City, Queens, and soon after, a city marshal arrived with an eviction notice and asked him to stand on the sidewalk as technicians checked his tanks for signs of sabotage.

title: Sharon's Wars
description: James Bennet (Aug. 15) suggests that Ariel Sharon is blind to the ''rising anti-Israeli-ism in what he sees as anti-Semitism.'' What is anti-Israeli-ism? Was there ever a parallel anti-Britishism? Anti-Italianism? Do people opposing Chinese policies define themselves as anti-Chinese? Doesn't this phenomenon of opposing the expression of Jewish self-determination require further examination, owing to its singularity?

title: Convention Delegates Put Aside Fears
description: FRANK RIESS started leaving ominous articles out for his wife weeks before the Republican National Convention. Norma Riess, a delegate from Redding who was scheduled to leave today for the convention on a bus carrying many of Connecticut's 29 other Republican representatives, said her husband made it obvious that he didn't want her to be in New York during the convention. He had been in Manhattan on Sept. 11, 2001, and he worried that the convention would become a terrorist target.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Big Deal column on Aug. 15 about the sale of a penthouse once occupied by the violinist Isaac Stern misstated a family relationship of Nikki Scheuer, the broker at Douglas Elliman who represented the seller. She is a former sister-in-law of Walter Scheuer, who owned the apartment Mr. Stern rented. She is divorced from Mr. Scheuer's brother Steven.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 15 about designer toys from Hong Kong and elsewhere misstated the relationship between the cost of manufacturing them and their retail price, $100 or more. The cost of making them is a small fraction of the sales price.

title: Gerri Gussin, Brett Lawrence
description: Gerri Brooke Gussin and Robert Cutting Lawrence IV were married last evening at 1811 House, an inn, in Manchester Village, Vt. Rabbi Lev Baesh officiated.

title: Yes, Follow Up. But How?
description: You suggest that newspapers ask readers what they want to know more about.

title: What's New
description: THE BIG TEN WILL BEGIN an experimental season of instant replay this year. It will not follow the N.F.L.'s system, in which coaches challenge plays for review. Instead, a technical advisor in the press box will determine when to stop a game for a review. Inevitably, games will be longer, but don't expect the system to be used throughout the top levels of college football anytime soon. ''I don't think it's imminent,'' said Dennis Poppe, the N.C.A.A. managing director for football and baseball. ''There's a lot to still be discussed, including facilities and cost.''

title: Stratford Journal; An Encore Effort to Bring Shakespeare Back to Stratford
description: Long before Indian-sponsored casinos became the biggest reason people traveled to Connecticut, the state's biggest draws were Mystic Seaport and Shakespeare, as performed here.

title: Russians Find Explosives On 2nd Plane
description: Investigators found traces of explosives on the second of two passenger airliners that crashed simultaneously in Russia, security officials announced Saturday, confirming that they consider the twin air disasters to be terrorist acts.

title: The Consensus Thief
description: O.K., before the art stuff, a little bow to Diana Vreeland -- she of the Kabuki rouging, knowing beak and shellac-black hair, who insisted that the soles of her shoes gleam -- because I think about her, well, frequently, especially when perusing culture magazines at a newsstand. D.V. led rather than followed, and I'm so tired (aren't you?) of opening the pages of glossies and seeing articles on what's already happening -- synergistic tie-ins -- rather than on what should be going on. Ego ideal, my dream D.V. reigns, sibyl of the untimely, the unlikely: she doesn't tow party lines. Can't you hear her, chic in a Mainbocher suit, channeling heavenly edicts? ''Why don't you donate all your John Currins to the local Braille institute? The blind need something to look at when they're not busy reading.''

title: Who Can Claim to Know A City of 8 Million?
description: AGAIN to a secret city place: the easternmost, uppermost deck of Pier 17 at the South Street Seaport in Lower Manhattan, a sanctuary in the midst of tourists, where lounge chairs bolted to the floorboards all but demand that you pause for a while and consider.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GINGOLD, JEFFREY
description: GINGOLD--Jeffrey. 2/19/48--8/31/87. In our hearts always. We love you, Mom, Arlene and Bonnie

title: Acuff Finds Her Path To a Medal Blocked
description: Lying in Amy Acuff's path to the high-jump bar was an exhausted and jubilant English sprinter. Britain had just upset the United States in the men's 4x100-meter relay on Saturday. Twenty yards past the British sprinter, the bar for Acuff was set at 6 feet 7 1/2 inches, and the clock was ticking: she had one last chance to clear the height and only 20 seconds to do so.

title: Open-Space Bond Issues Will Go to the Voters
description: The Suffolk County Legislature voted unanimously last week to place a $75 million bond referendum on the November ballot, despite resistance from environmental groups that opposed a last-minute change favored by developers.

title: Riding the Rails
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''No-Rush California'' (Aug. 15), I enjoyed re-living, through John Tierney's eyes, my own journey from San Jose to Los Angeles on the Coast Starlight. But I had an additional high point.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPARBER, NORMAN H.
description: SPARBER--Norman H. The partners and staff of Brauner Baron Rosenzweig & Klein, LLP mourn the loss of our dear friend and retired partner Norman H. Sparber, who served for more than 50 years as a partner and of counsel to our firm. He addressed legal problems with intelligence and diligence and earned the respect of his colleagues and clients. Even after his formal retirement, he remained actively engaged in the activities of the firm and the needs of his clients. We will miss his wise counsel and acerbic wit, and extend our deepest condolences to his children Merryl and Roy, his daughter-in-law Susan, his grandchildren and great grandchildren.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENT, PETER WOODRUFF
description: MENT--Peter Woodruff, 29, beloved son of David and Nancy, brother of Andrew and Nicole, died August 25, 2004, in an automobile accident in Costa Rica. Photographer, musician, surfer and friend--our joy and treasure. Memorial gathering Tuesday, August 31st, 2PM, The Cathedral of Saint John the Divine, 111 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Preseason Picks
description: PETE THAMEL and FRED BIERMAN predict the college football season for 2004. Oklahoma and U.S.C. will win their conferences and finish in the top two in the Bowl Championship Series. Oklahoma will prevail in the Orange Bowl.

title: Trousers With a Sense of Suspense
description: IT'S not often that a turn at go-go dancing helps pave the way to fame; usually it's a step on the road to ruin. But the infectiously brazen show Jake Shears puts on as the lead singer of Scissor Sisters puts quite the dent in that wisdom.

title: Newton's Lore
description: A topless blond dominatrix stares invitingly into a mirror, her nipples obscured by a strategically placed scarf. She's a study in the complex theater of the female persona, the softness of her wet perm offset by the strictness of her white jodhpurs and the riding whip she holds behind her back. That the creator of the seminude image was Helmut Newton, the divinely decadent German photographer who died at 83 in January, should surprise exactly no one. He was, after all, also known as the King of Kink and the Grandfather of Porn. The only real shock is that the woman in the photo is not one of Newton's favorite models, like the glamazon Brigitte Nielsen, but the bland bombshell Olivia Newton-John.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: August 29, 2004
description: Weeks

title: Chain Gang
description: Madonna may have pared her accessories down to a single cabala bracelet, but jewelry designers this fall are finding inspiration from her first fashion epiphany, when she wrapped herself in rosaries and rubber bracelets. Jewelers are tying all sorts of stuff on to the standard chain necklace: religious talismans, vintage mink, shoelaces, buttons, feathers, even kitchen utensils (trend alert: see the hair at the John Galliano fall runway show).

title: Witch Doctorate: One Man's Journey
description: JOHN DEMOS first rappelled into the murk and drama of witchcraft and witch-hunting more than 40 years ago, when he was a graduate student in history at the University of California, Berkeley.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 1 about moderately priced houses with water views misstated the reason that the shape of a waterfront site, Mariner's Pointe, in City Island, was changed by Loewen Development. The company removed landfill under order from the Department of Environmental Conservation because it said the fill had been illegally placed by a former owner -- not because of complaints by neighbors over the blocking of their views.

title: Conference Oulook
description: SOUTHEASTERN

title: The Un-Rosie
description: ON Sept. 6, Ellen DeGeneres will start the second season of ''The Ellen DeGeneres Show.'' The syndicated daytime talk show, which appears five times a week, has been an unexpected hit. After the demise of both her two sitcoms (''Ellen'' and ''The Ellen Show'') and her relationship with the actress Anne Heche, Ms. DeGeneres found her career in decline. But the new show has won critics' affection and the 2004 Daytime Emmy Award for outstanding talk show. Having publicly come out in 1997, Ms. DeGeneres has been sorting out what her sexual identity has to do with her comedy. The answer, as she told Virginia Heffernan in an interview excerpted here, is everything. And nothing. And she wasn't flirting with Jessica Simpson, for the record.

title: Pomp and Circumstancet
description: Tall hair is innately elegant. If you dispute this, go to ''Dangerous Liaisons,'' the exhibition in the Wrightsman Galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and look at the 18th-century tableau of a man on a stepladder who is dressing his lady's coif. A lofty do lengthens the forehead, stretches the neck and encourages a queenly posture. What gives big hair a bad rap is when the hoi polloi imitates it -- alas, elegant is fleeting, and cheap endures.

title: Primary Endorsements; In the Bronx and Westchester
description: Most political experts are predicting that New York's primary on Sept. 14 will be a very small affair. All the action is local, and a few very big decisions could be made by very few voters. Therefore, everyone who shows up at the polls could make a real difference , especially in races like the one in State Senate District 34 to replace former State Senator Guy J. Velella.

Doillon, the towering 21-year-old daughter of the British-born actress Jane Birkin and the French director Jacques Doillon, lives what she calls a ''light'' life. ''People make you believe that you have to reflect yourself in your possessions,'' she says over cigarettes and a glass of mineral water at Caf de Flore in Paris. ''I know that tomorrow, if my house is burning, I have to take my kid and my dog, and that's it.'' And she finds it ''funny'' that she has lately become an international style icon with her crazy mix of flea-market frocks, designer gifts and well-worn cowboy boots. ''I would like to be an icon of thinking,'' she says.

title: Editorial Observer; Peak Performance in Athletics: Is That All We Can Expect?

Will they soon find it difficult or impossible to run or swim faster, jump higher or throw farther than their predecessors? A glance at the world record tables in swimming and in track and field, the central events of the quadrennial Olympics, yields a mixed answer. It looks as if the world's best swimmers are still surging ahead while the top track and field competitors are already stuck in the Dark Ages, unable to match records set years or even decades ago. One plausible explanation for the falloff is that many past records may have been artificially inflated by performance-enhancing drugs. The current slowdown may simply reflect the stringent crackdown on doping, surely a worthwhile price to pay for cleaning up sport.

title: Eye Pod
description: The stock of retro eyewear at Fabulous Fanny's is so vast that even after the Japanese buyers swoop in and leave with $3,000 worth of frames (to be resold at a profit), there is plenty left for average Joe Four Eyes. After more than 15 years in the wholesale eyewear business, Ken Finneran and Stan Blackmer, the owners of Fanny's, have amassed an absurd number of dead-stock, never-been-worn frames, from 18th-century spectacles to oversize 80's sunglasses. Besides the 4,000 pairs on display in their East Village shop, 335 East Ninth Street, 30,000 more are packed in a New Jersey warehouse. In the store, the glasses are organized in drawers: fancy readers; metal frames; tortoise rhinestone; blue cat's-eyes. Pricier items, like the very first designer glasses (gold Christian Dior frames, from around 1950), are in the window. Prices generally range from $35 to $135, but can run as high as an eye-popping $3,000. Finneran says he's always amazed by what's suddenly deemed cool again. Recently, a young woman in stiletto boots tried on rhinestone-encrusted green plastic frames that Finneran called ''very Elton John.'' ''Yeah,'' she said. ''They're for when I need to bling.'' title: Still Shimmering After All These Years

Oh, sure, I thought -- I had all the New York moves even though I had spent the previous 35 years in suburbia. After all, I was born in Brooklyn, played street games, loved and lost the Dodgers, took the A train to C.C.N.Y., and was lucky enough to have married up -- a girl from Queens!

title: It's Not New Jobs. It's All The Jobs.
description: NOW that the work force is growing again, President Bush and Senator John Kerry have been arguing about the quality of the newly created jobs -- whether a majority are toward the higher or lower end of the wage scale. That is the wrong debate. The real issue is not how well the new jobs pay, but whether the incomes of workers in general are rising or falling. On the second score, there is not much to debate. The incomes of most workers, adjusted for inflation, are sinking.

But now, as many executives of the newly expanded NBC Universal see it, Ms. Pauley has moved beyond the status of V.I.P. -- all the way to V.I.A. Today she is looked upon as a very important asset.

title: School Achievement Reports Often Exclude the Disabled
description: The first time Tyler Brenneise, a 10-year-old who is autistic and mildly retarded, took the same state achievement tests as California's nondisabled children, his mother, Allison, anxiously awaited the results, along with the state report card on his special education school, the Del Sol Academy, in San Diego. But when the California Department of Education issued its annual report on school performance several months later, Del Sol Academy was nowhere to be found. Ms. Brenneise wrote state officials asking why. ''They wrote back,'' she said, ''that the school doesn't exist.''

title: Vast Anti-Bush Rally Greets Republicans in New York
description: A roaring two-mile river of demonstrators surged through the canyons of Manhattan yesterday in the city's largest political protest in decades, a raucous but peaceful spectacle that pilloried George W. Bush and demanded regime change in Washington.

title: With Restraint and New Tactics, March Is Kept Orderly
description: Plainclothes police officers on stylish Italian motorscooters herded bicycle-riding demonstrators into thick orange nets stretched across intersections. Airborne spy cameras on blimps and helicopters monitored the crowd. Digital video cameras were used to tape arrest scenes and collect evidence for later use in court. A military-inspired sound device was ready to disperse crowds with shouted orders or painful blasts of noise.

title: Show Me the Convention
description: As a Democratic commissioner on the Federal Communications Commission, I may not agree with many positions taken by speakers this week at the Republican National Convention. Even so, I believe our broadcast media owe us more coverage of an event that remains an important component of the presidential campaign. Yet tonight, if people around the country tune in to the commercial broadcast TV networks, most will not see any live convention coverage. That's not right.

title: The Enemy of Your Enemy Is Your Friend?
description: The Georgia delegation to the Republican National Convention is getting ready to embrace Senator Zell Miller when Mr. Miller, a fellow Georgian, though a Democrat, delivers the keynote address at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night. And among the delegates will be a man Mr. Miller actively campaigned against two years ago.

Not the authorities on the subject, but the gal in pink-on-pink. She was a media magnet and that was useful to see -- a reminder that whatever else characterizes this Republican convention week in New York, it will be show biz.

It's quite a challenging way to practice law.''

title: Corrections

Roosevelt signed an executive order permitting restrictions on people in the United States who were born in Japan, Germany or Italy. (Ms. Scottoline's grandparents were from Italy.) It was February 1942, not December. The article also misstated the timing of Ms. Scottoline's father's military service in Italy as a member of the United States Army Air Forces. He was there after the Allies invaded Sicily in 1943, not when F.B.I. agents raided her grandparents' home in 1942.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELSEY, JOHN FORSYTH, JR.
description: KELSEY--John Forsyth, Jr. 80, formerly of Short Hills, on August 27, 2004, at Green Hill Memorial Home. Beloved husband of the late Elsie Luddecke, father of John F. III and his wife Pamela and Bruce C., and grandfather of Katherine Kelsey Pisano and John F. IV. Mr. Kelsey was the retired Executive VicePresident for Bender & Company. Previously, he held executive positions with Marsh & McLennan and W.R. Grace. As a First Lieutenant, Kelsey served in the United States Army and flew 35 combat missions as a B-17 Bombardier. He received the Air Medal with five clusters and a Purple Heart. Mr. Kelsey was active in a wide variety of organizations, but his special love was golf. He was a former president of the Metropolitan Golf Association, the Montclair Golf Club, on the Board of Pine Valley Golf Club, the NJSGA and USSGA. In New York City, he was a founding Board member of the John Street Club, and active in the Union League Club, the Madison Square Garden Club and The Pilgrims. Relatives and friends are invited to a memorial service in Grace Presbyterian Church in Montclair on Tuesday, August 31, at 11 am. For further information, please visit: bradleyfuneralhomes. com

description: SHIRE--Maurice. 84, of Mt. Vernon. Beloved husband of 54 years, father, brother, grandfather, uncle, father-inlaw, cousin and friend. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Boat Seized In Harbor
description: The police confiscated a 45-foot pleasure boat in New York Harbor and arrested its owner about 2 a.m. yesterday after finding three weapons, including a machine gun, on board, the authorities said. Coast Guard officers initially stopped the boat, the My Way, in the harbor near Governors Island, because it was cruising without navigation lights, the authorities said. Under questioning, the owner and captain, Frank Mele, 52, of Weehawken, N.J., admitted having a 12-gauge shotgun, a .30-caliber rifle and an AK-47 on board, the authorities said, adding that they do not believe that the guns were part of any plot. The boat was escorted to a New York Police Department pier in Brooklyn, where its 22 passengers disembarked. The police said the captain had a license to carry the guns in Florida, but not New York. Mr. Mele was charged with criminal possession of a weapon. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Singapore's Moment
description: Singapore is rich, but hardly ever envied. Outsiders have long viewed the gleaming city-state that attained its independence in 1965 as a tidy but soulless place, the nanny state that famously banned chewing gum. The good news is that the new prime minister, Lee Hsien Loong, son of the longtime ruler Lee Kwan Yew, seems to realize that Singapore needs to loosen up. At his swearing-in ceremony earlier this month, he said what not long ago would have sounded like heresy in a nation where the bottom line is the bottom line: ''Prosperity is not our only goal, nor is economic growth an end in itself.''

Mr. Fenton, who lived on 118th Street, was pronounced dead at North General Hospital, and Mr. Young was in stable condition at St. Luke's Hospital yesterday. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WANG, NIAN, TZU, N.T.
description: WANG--Nian-Tzu, N.T., of Larchmont, NY, died of cancer, on August 26, 2004. Loving husband of Mabel U, devoted father of June, Kay (Leighton Chen), Cynthia (Daniel Sedlis), Geraldine, and Newton, and proud grandfather of Christine, Stephanie and Lucy. In his autobiography, ''My Nine Lives'', NT wrote of his lives as number one son, traditional scholar, foreign student, public servant, instructor, international servant, advisor, academician, and immigrant. NT was born in Shanghai on July 25, 1917. Initially trained to be a Confucian scholar, he received a classical education at home, where he was tutored in Chinese poetry, painting, the Classics and other literati skills. Math, science, and languages were introduced later by his father, Pai Yuan (PY) Wang, a sophisticated banker when he decided to school his four sons in Western ways when they were teenagers. In 1937, NT went abroad to study at the London School of Economics and Germany. He transferred to Columbia where he graduated Phi Beta Kappa with honors in economics in 1941, and went on to receive an M.A. and PhD in economics from Harvard. NT will be remembered throughout the international community for his dedicated efforts in advising businesses and governments around the world on ecomonic development. He made many contributions to his homeland of China, the U.S., his home since 1939, and to countless countries which he helped through his work at the U.N. Economic and Social Council. After retiring from a 28 year career at the United Nations, as the Director of the Centre on Transnational Corporations, he returned to Columbia Univ. to teach at the School of Business and the School of International and Public Affairs. He thoroughly enjoyed his time with his students, organizing seminars, creating training programs for Chinese academic and business leaders, and working tirelessly as the Director of the China-International Business Project. In his final days, he was polishing his keynote speech as part of Columbia University's 250th anniversary celebration. He was an honorary professor of ten universities, a fellow of the International Academy of Management, and a recipient of many awards, including the New York Governor's Award for Outstanding Asian American. In addition to his many professional achievements, his passions included dancing with his life partner of 62 years, Mabel, and playing tennis. NT exhausted his daughter Kay playing two and a half hours of tennis after celebrating his 87th birthday just one month ago. Throughout his life, he took time to compose classical Chinese poems, which his family will compile as the tenth chapter in his life, 'The Poet'. A memorial service will be announced later. Contributions may be made to Community Funds Inc. for the N.T. and Mabel Wang Charitable Fund, which will continue the mission of the China-International Business Project he established at Columbia University, c/o Community Funds Inc., 2 Park Avenue, NY, NY 10016

title: For Now, Unwired Means Unlisted. That May Change.

Mr. Wilson, 25, who grew up in Southern California and now lives in the state capital of Sacramento, has been trying to make contact with childhood chums. He figures that the ones he has not tracked down must have cellphones, but he has no idea where to look up their numbers.

description: With crowds of summer revelers looking on, a small helicopter crashed into Long Island Sound just off a Suffolk County beach last night, killing the two people aboard, a flight instructor and his student, the police said.

title: Its Color Aside, This Car Is Red
description: BROOKLYN would be an unlikely setting for a test-drive of the latest sports car from Porsche, but the borough's Russian-speaking enclaves are ideal for a jaunt in a car that has emigrated from the Soviet state. Parking a Zaporozhets outside a Brighton Beach bakery with Cyrillic signs in the window can earn the driver a reception nearly as enthusiastic as the welcome given Yuri Gagarin in Red Square.

title: Kremlin's Choice Wins in Chechnya Election

At the time I was the attorney general of Massachusetts and opposed the rise of Goldwater conservatism, aligning myself with many national party leaders. I supported Gov. Nelson Rockefeller of New York for the nomination and, after he withdrew from the race, Gov. William Scranton of Pennsylvania.

title: LNR PROPERTY TO BE SOLD FOR $3.8 BILLION IN CASH AND DEBT
description: The LNR Property Corporation, the real estate development company spun off from the Lennar Corporation, agreed yesterday to be bought by Riley Property Holdings, a new company backed by the investment group Cerberus Capital Management, for $3.8 billion in cash and assumed debt. Riley offered $63.10 a share for LNR, 6.8 percent more than Friday's close. LNR's chairman, Stuart Miller, whose family controls 77 percent of the votes, accepted the offer. LNR finances, manages and develops commercial real estate.

title: UNITED AIRLINES WILL RECALL 375 LAID-OFF FLIGHT ATTENDANTS
description: United Airlines is recalling 375 flight attendants to increase that work force about 2 percent as it adds more international flights and keeps its aircraft flying for more hours. The carrier, a unit of the UAL Corporation, told employees yesterday that 171 attendants would be called back on Oct. 18 and 200 would be asked to return Nov. 22. The attendants had accepted voluntary layoffs when the company reduced its staff after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, because of lower demand. The returning attendants are in addition to 380 who were recalled in April and about 800 who will come back this year under a plan the carrier adopted in 2003, United's Association of Flight Attendants said.

title: The Courage Factor
description: John McCain, Rudy Giuliani and Arnold Schwarzenegger are the big stars of the first two days of the Republican convention, but they didn't get their prime-time slots because they're moderates. If the Republican Party had wanted to play up the moderate angle, they'd have put together the same sort of multihued and gender-balanced schmaltzfest they did in 2000. McCain, Giuliani and Schwarzenegger are speaking because they are brave.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Truckers' Strike Ends
description: Indian truck drivers called off their week-old countrywide strike on Saturday after reaching an agreement with the government. Nearly three million trucks were off Indian roads after the biggest union called a strike protesting a 10 percent service tax that was imposed on freight agents by the government in its recent budget. A finance ministry spokeswoman told reporters in New Delhi that the government had reached an agreement with the truckers' union to form a committee that would look into all their demands. If the strike had continued any longer, the already high inflation rate in the country was expected to increase still further. The truck drivers' union had threatened that its strike would go on for three months. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A textual excerpt yesterday from the Republican Party platform, consisting of its statement on same-sex marriage, with highlighting to show language added at the behest of conservatives, omitted the marking from one passage that should have carried it. Conservatives also added: ''President Bush said, 'We will not stand for judges who undermine democracy by legislating from the bench and try to remake America by court order.' The Republican House of Representatives has responded to this challenge by passing H.R. 3313, a bill to withdraw jurisdiction from the federal courts over the Defense of Marriage Act. We urge Congress to use its Article III power to enact this into law, so that activist federal judges cannot force 49 other states to approve and recognize Massachusetts' attempt to redefine marriage.''

title: MEMO PAD
description: AIRLINE FOOD -- Two years after free meals became largely a memory (good or bad) in the coach cabins of many domestic flights, American Airlines is considering joining competitors that started selling meals to passengers after eliminating free meals during the post-9/11 slump in business. American said it would begin testing in-flight food sales in September on selected flights, including some between Dallas and New York and New York and Phoenix. Meals will cost $5 to $7. If the tests are successful and American expands the service throughout its domestic schedule, the airline, the world's largest, will join most major airlines and a handful of low-cost carriers in selling food in coach on some or all flights. (In business and first class, free meals are still the norm.) Among the major carriers, only Continental still serves free meals in coach on most domestic flights.

title: S.E.C. TO REVIEW AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER MERGER
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it would review its June 2000 decision to approve the American Electric Power Company's $10 billion acquisition of the Central and South West Corporation. The commission will hold a hearing on whether the utilities' networks, which are separated by 100 miles, meet a requirement that they are interconnected and operate in a single region. The American Public Power Association and the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association, a trade group for electric co-ops, challenged the merger. A federal appeals court told the commission in 2002 to review its approval.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Defense Rests In Air India Bomb Trial
description: Lawyers representing two men on trial for the 1985 bombing of Air India Flight 182, which exploded over the North Atlantic, killing 329 people, rested their case. Neither of the men, Ripudaman Singh Malik and Ajaib Singh Bagri, testified. The prosecution rested in May. The trial, which began in April 2003, is adjourned until closing arguments, later this year. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Female Bomber Kills 9 in Moscow, Officials Say
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 31  A female bomber detonated an explosion outside a subway station in Moscow this evening, killing herself and at least 9 others and wounding 37, officials said. The bombing came exactly a week after terrorist bombs destroyed two passenger airliners over Russia.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Trade Surplus Grows
description: Canada's second-quarter current account surplus rose to 10.4 billion Canadian dollars($7.9 billion), up from 8.8 billion Canadian dollars in the first quarter and its second-highest recorded level. Statistics Canada, a government agency, said increases in merchandise exports more than offset outflows in the financial and capital accounts. The second-quarter trade surplus for goods reached 20 billion dollars, up from 3.6 billion dollars during the previous three-month period. The services trade deficit shrank slightly, to 2.9 billion dollars. Increased spending by foreign tourists, who shunned Canada during last year's SARS outbreak, helped stabilize the services segment. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Front Row
description: The soothing espresso-tone lounge area at the heart of the new Sean John store on Fifth Avenue was conceived to resemble a living room -- the slickly appointed centerpiece of a fashion emporium built around a series of shops-within-a-shop, each the size of a generous walk-in closet. As described by Sean Combs, Sean John's founder and president, the store ''feels like a home area, rather than just a place to shop.''

title: NEWMONT MINING WILL BUY A STAKE IN GABRIEL RESOURCES
description: Newmont Mining, the world's largest gold producer, agreed yesterday to buy a 19 percent stake in Gabriel Resources for 24.8 million Canadian dollars ($18.8 million), setting off a 52 percent gain in Gabriel's share price. Gabriel, which is building a gold mine in Romania, rose 67 cents a share, to 1.97 Canadian dollars, on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Newmont, based in Denver, is betting that Gabriel will complete development of the Rosia Montana mine in Romania, which Gabriel says holds 10.6 million ounces of gold. The project has been delayed because Gabriel has not been able to persuade all the people in a village near the deposit to move. Newmont's Canadian subsidiary agreed to buy 15 million units of Gabriel for 1.65 Canadian dollars each.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELSEY, JOHN FORSYTH, JR.
description: KELSEY--John Forsyth, Jr. 80, formerly of Short Hills, on August 27, 2004, at Green Hill Memorial Home. Beloved husband of the late Elsie Luddecke, father of John F. III and his wife Pamela and Bruce C., and grandfather of Katherine Kelsey Pisano and John F. IV. Mr. Kelsey was the retired Executive VicePresident for Bender & Company. Previously, he held executive positions with Marsh & McLennan and W.R. Grace. As a First Lieutenant, Kelsey served in the United States Army and flew 35 combat missions as a B-17 Bombardier. He received the Air Medal with five clusters and a Purple Heart. Mr. Kelsey was active in a wide variety of organizations, but his special love was golf. He was a former president of the Metropolitan Golf Association, the Montclair Golf Club, on the Board of Pine Valley Golf Club, the NJSGA and USSGA. In New York City, he was a founding Board member of the John Street Club, and active in the Union League Club, the Madison Square Garden Club and The Pilgrims. Relatives and friends are invited to a memorial service in Grace Presbyterian Church in Montclair on Tuesday, August 31, at 11 am. For further information, please visit: bradleyfuneralhomes. com

title: The Pentagon's Troubling Role
description: Barely two months before the presidential vote, Missouri's secretary of state has suddenly announced that he will allow military voters from his state -- one of the most pivotal in the election -- to e-mail ballots from combat zones to the Defense Department. E-mail is far too insecure to be used for voting. Missouri and North Dakota, which announced a similar rule yesterday, should rescind these orders right away. Missouri's action also sheds light on the Defense Department's role in administering federal elections, a troubling situation that needs far more scrutiny.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Circuit City To Stop Selling T-Mobile Phones
description: Circuit City Stores said yesterday that it would stop selling T-Mobile USA mobile phones and give the business solely to Verizon Wireless, its other current mobile phone partner, which will open in-store sales counters. Verizon Wireless, the nation's largest mobile phone company by subscribers, will supply employees for sales areas in more than 570 stores, said Circuit City, the second-largest electronics chain in the country. Verizon Communications owns 55 percent of Verizon Wireless; the Vodafone Group owns 45 percent. Circuit City hopes that concentrating on a single provider will bolster store traffic and sales of higher-priced items like digital televisions and DVD players. Circuit City will be able to move workers to other parts of the store while shedding the cost of having mobile phones in inventory and earning a commission on each sale, a spokesman, Bill Cimino, said. Circuit City will end T-Mobile sales on Sept. 7, a T-Mobile spokesman, Richard Brudvik-Linder, said. T-Mobile, a unit of Deutsche Telekom, is the fifth-largest American mobile phone provider by customers. Shares of Circuit City fell 24 cents, to $13.01.

title: Check Writing in the Luxury Suites
description: New York is the place to be this week for the newest generation of shadow political fund-raisers. Their targets are the wealthiest conventiongoers, and their goal is unregulated campaign donations, known as soft money. Congress banned soft money directly to politicians when it passed the McCain-Feingold campaign finance reform bill in 2002. But thanks to the lethargic Federal Elections Commission, the million-dollar gifts from special friends and special interests have found a new outlet -- in organizations that ludicrously present themselves as ''independent'' of the presidential campaign, and so beyond tight donor limitations.

They are serious,'' a spokesman, Armin Kloss, said, confirming a report in Monday's Financial Times Deutschland, in which the chief executive, Thomas Fischer, disclosed the talks. Mr. Kloss said the bank was talking with several possible buyers but declined to identify them. WestLB is selling the stake, which amounts to 31 percent of TUI, to return to profitability after two years of losses. Mr. Fischer has said the bank will not sell the shares at a loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIMBALL, WILLIAM MALTBY
description: KIMBALL--William Maltby. Died peacefully in his sleep on Wednesday, August 25 at the age of 81. He was born in Atlanta, GA, on September 19, 1922, and grew up in Buffalo, NY. He graduated from Colgate University and then served in the U.S. Army Infantry in combat in Europe during WWII. He received a law degree from Harvard Law School in 1948 and was a practicing trial lawyer in New York City until the time of his death. He is survived by his former wife and lifelong friend, Dorothy F. Kimball, his three loving children and their spouses, Pamela Kimball Kenney and her husband David, William Fisher Kimball and his wife Alexandra and Susannah Kimball Rosato and her husband Ernest Jr. He is also survived by his eight beloved grandchildren, Sarah, Alice, Ernest III, Sophie, William, Colin, Lachlan and Aengus. His sister, Jean Hutchinson of Williamsville, NY, also survives him. The burial in Cutchogue, NY, on Tuesday, August 31 will be private. A memorial will be held at a later date in New York City. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Peconic Land Trust, Box 1776, Southampton, NY 11969

title: Olympic Disasters Are No-Shows
description: Hats off to Greece for running a Summer Olympics that defied all the dire predictions. The facilities were completed on time, no terrorists showed up to wreak havoc, the anticipated traffic jams failed to materialize, and the main glitches, such as judging disputes in several sports, were hardly the fault of the host country. Greece showed that a small country could indeed play host to this massive quadrennial extravaganza. The achievement raises anew the question of whether Greece, where the Games originated, should be made the permanent site of the Summer Olympics, thus ending the road show that moves the Olympics to whatever city submits the most compelling bid for the next go-round.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Bank Rules Tightened
description: After warning that the country may be in the midst of a real estate bubble, Thailand's central bank has tightened rules on how much cash commercial banks must set aside against delinquent loans. Under the new rules, banks will have to set aside funds even on loans covered by collateral, with the proportion rising the longer the borrower fails to make payments. The central bank last month ordered the government-controlled Krung Thai bank to classify about $1 billion in loans as nonperforming, even though the loans were still being serviced, and it criticized the bank for lending to dubious property projects. All he is left with is asking them to try harder and to find a way to play better.

title: MYLAN DROPS SUIT AGAINST F.D.A. OVER URINARY TRACT DRUG
description: Mylan Inc., a maker of generic drugs, dropped a lawsuit against the Food and Drug Administration yesterday, but said it might file a new claim in its effort to block a low-cost version of Macrobid, a Procter & Gamble treatment for urinary tract infections. Mylan's lawsuit challenged the agency's approval for Watson Pharmaceuticals to sell a generic version of the drug under an agreement with Procter &Gamble. Procter &Gamble, based in Cincinnati, supplies the drugs for Watson to sell; the two share the profits. Mylan, based in Canonsburg, Pa., received approval in March from the Food and Drug Administration to sell a generic version of the drug. Under federal law, the first generic-drug company to successfully challenge a brand-drug company's patent is granted a six-month period to be the only seller of a generic version.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Lawyers Interview Potential Kobe Bryant Jurors

title: ATA HOLDINGS MAY LOSE ITS LISTING ON NASDAQ MARKET
description: The ATA Holdings Corporation, an airline company in danger of defaulting on its debt, said yesterday that its stock would stop trading on the Nasdaq stock market in November if its market value did not regain minimum levels. Nasdaq told the company in an Aug. 25 letter that the company ''has not maintained a minimum market value'' and that the stock would lose its listing unless that changed, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company has until Nov. 23 to increase the value of its publicly held shares to $15 million for more than 10 consecutive trading days to avoid losing its listing, the filing said. ATA's stock fell 5 cents yesterday, to $2.09 a share, giving the company a market value of $7.4 million excluding shares held by George Mikelsons, the chief executive.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Gaza Evacuation Plan Sped Up
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon told his cabinet that he intended to speed up disengagement from Gaza, dismantling 21 settlements all at once, instead of in four stages. The cabinet objected, saying it preferred to vote on each stage, prompting Mr. Sharon to joke that he would do it ''Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.'' The cabinet's view is unlikely to matter, as Mr. Sharon is working to change the cabinet's makeup. In discussions with the World Bank, Israel said it would demolish the settlements except for one, which would become a hospital. The other blocs would be made available for high-rise apartments for Palestinians in refugee housing. Steven Erlanger (NYT)

title: Twin Bus Bombings in Israel Kill at Least 15 and Wound Dozens

title: Scholar, Matchmaker and Convention Presence
description: THE day the rebbetzin hitched on to the Republican National Convention, she had to shelve the Hungarian book tour and fly home to deal with new challenges, like teleprompters. The rebbetzin, Esther Jungreis, who goes by the Yiddish title traditionally bestowed on the wives of rabbis, is the author of two books that fall into the ''Chicken Soup for the Soul'' genre and the spiritual leader of a large but indefinable following here and overseas. Three decades ago, she founded Hineni, a group that promotes Judaism by offering religious education in settings where single Jews mingle.

title: Technology Briefing | Nanotechnology: 2 Companies To Invest In Research Center
description: Advanced Micro Devices and Infineon Technologies plan to invest 170 million euros ($204 million) over the next five years in a center for nanotechnology research to be based in Dresden, Germany. The companies signed a memorandum of understanding at a news conference in Dresden yesterday. The state of Saxony and the federal education ministry will contribute 80 million euros. Advanced Micro, the world's second-largest maker of personal computer processors, and Infineon, Europe's No.2 chip maker, are working with the Fraunhofer Gesellschaft research institute. Advanced Micro's chief executive, Hector Ruiz, attended yesterday's event along with Hans-Jrg Bullinger, president of the Fraunhofer Gesellschaft, an umbrella organization for scientific research institutes in Germany. Nanotechnology uses single atoms or molecule-size building blocks to create electronic devices. Advanced Micro has so far invested $2.5 billion in a chip factory in Dresden.

title: Corrections
description: Atextual excerpt yesterday from the Republican Party platform, consisting of its statement on same-sex marriage, with highlighting to show language added at the behest of conservatives, omitted the marking from one passage that should have carried it. Conservatives also added: " President Bush said, 'We will not stand for judges who undermine democracy by legislating from the bench and try to remake America by court order.' The Republican House of Representatives has responded to this challenge by passing H.R. 3313, a bill to withdraw jurisdiction from the federal courts over the Defense of Marriage Act. We urge Congress to use its Article III power to enact this into law, so that activist federal judges cannot force 49 other states to approve and recognize Massachusetts' attempt to redefine marriage."

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: U.N.'S Deadline Expires
description: A deadline for Sudan to meet United Nations demands that it disarm and prosecute marauding government-backed militia fighters in the Darfur region ran out, and officials said that Jan Pronk, the special envoy to Sudan, was returning to New York and would report his findings on the Khartoum government's compliance to the Security Council on Thursday. Reports from aid workers and African Union monitors have made it clear that the government has not reined in the militias, which are held responsible for the deaths of 30,000 Darfur villagers and the displacement of more than a million others. A July 30 Security Council resolution promised punitive measures in the absence of major improvement in 30 days, but United Nations diplomats do not believe the votes are there for imminent sanctions. Warren Hoge (NYT)

description: L-3 Communications Holdings, a supplier of intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance systems, announced yesterday that it had won purchase agreements totaling $201 million for a ''major intelligence community client.'' The awards were won by L-3 Government Services, an L-3 unit based in Chantilly, Va. Since the blanket purchase agreements began in February 2003, it has won 10 contracts. The intelligence client's name is not being disclosed, nor is the exact nature of the services provided, said an L-3 spokeswoman, Martha Newman. She said the agreement had options for four more years and the services involved engineering and support.

title: The Nicotine Patch Didn't Work? You May Not Have Used It Enough
description: Smokers who try to give up cigarettes can double their chances of success by using patches, gum, lozenges, inhalers or nasal sprays containing nicotine. Yet 3 in 4 people who use these products do not end up quitting, in part because they use them too little or for too short a time.

But the state attorney general and staff members at the center, the Connecticut Juvenile Training School, said they were skeptical of how long the changes would last at the school, which has been caught up in the state's corruption scandal.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Acer's 2nd-Quarter Net Income Fell
description: Acer Inc., Taiwan's third-largest computer company by market value, had lower second-quarter net income, which analysts said was hurt by smaller gains from sales of shares in affiliates in other companies. Net income fell to 1 billion Taiwan dollars ($29 million) from 1.4 billion dollars a year earlier. The earnings, derived by subtracting first-quarter figures from the first-half results released yesterday, were worse than analysts forecast. The median estimate of five analysts polled by Bloomberg predicted net income of 1.3 billion Taiwan dollars. The company, in an e-mailed statement, did not explain the decline in net income. Acer has been selling shares it holds in other companies like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing and affiliates like AU Optronics to help lift profit. Acer said profit from operations related to its computer business rose to 709 million Taiwan dollars.

title: Money and Power Cross Paths, And a Good Time Is Had by All
description: A powerful Washington law firm's decision to honor one of its former partners on the first evening of the Republican convention last night might barely rate a second glance in this party-happy convention town. After all, the convention delegates and their guests will be celebrated and pampered all week at lavish events sponsored by corporations and business leaders.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Head Of Family Agency Resigns
description: The secretary of the state's Department of Children and Families, Jerry Regier, resigned as a result of scandal over accusations that he and two top aides took favors from contractors. Mr. Regier said perceptions about the department's effectiveness had made it difficult for him to continue. Mr. Regier, 59, did not specify when his resignation would become effective. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: New Intel Process Creates Faster Circuits
description: Intel said yesterday that it had built a test chip with a new process that creates faster circuits by packing 10 million transistors into a space the size of the tip of a ballpoint pen. Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., has made the first working memory chip that uses so-called 65-nanometer technology to shrink the circuits inside chips, an Intel researcher, Mark Bohr, said on a conference call. The method lets Intel pack twice the number of transistors into the same space. Chip makers including Intel and I.B.M. are racing to design production methods that let them cram more transistors into chips, resulting in more powerful devices that cost less to make. By being the first to use circuits measuring 65 nanometers, Intel is as much as 12 months ahead of competitors, said a Gartner Inc. analyst, Martin Reynolds.
